dont: Use formal request language: 'Submit Date Change Request' sounds like filing a form, not managing your week
Use platform jargon: 'Initiate modification' or 'Process rescheduling' are internal terms that create emotional distance
Add unnecessary confirmations: 'Are you sure you want to proceed?' for a simple date swap creates anxiety where none should exist
Use passive voice: 'Your request has been submitted' distances the guest from their action. 'Sent to Nneka' connects them to the human on the other end.
copy_guidelines.example_good: Swap Oct 15 for Oct 22? Same rate. [Send to Nneka]
copy_guidelines.example_bad: Date Change Request: Replace October 15, 2025 with October 22, 2025. Rate adjustment: $0.00. [Submit Request]

animation_feel.feel_description: A message-send bounce. When the guest confirms a date change or action, the confirmation animates with a slight spring overshoot -- the same physics a chat bubble uses when it appears in a messaging app. The sensation is 'message sent' not 'form submitted.' The spring easing creates a playful, lightweight feeling that contrasts with the rigid, weightless feel of traditional form submissions. On the receiving end, when the host responds, the response appears with the same spring -- creating a conversational rhythm that feels like a text thread.
animation_feel.duration_range: 200-250ms for the send animation with spring overshoot

tension_relief.tension_point: The guest needs to change a date and is deciding whether to text the host or use the platform.
tension_relief.relief_point: The platform flow is faster, easier, and more informative than a text message. The guest sees available dates (no guessing), sees the cost (no surprises), and completes the change in three taps (faster than composing a text).
tension_relief.timing: The relief window is narrow: the guest must reach the date change flow and see its simplicity within 10 seconds of deciding to make a change. If the flow takes longer to initiate than opening the text app, the guest will choose texting.

personalization_signals: Use the host's first name in all confirmations and status updates
Reference specific dates and nights, not abstract time ranges
If the guest has a pattern (always swaps Thursdays), preemptively suggest: 'Swap this Thursday too?'
Show the host's response pattern: 'Nneka usually responds in a few hours' to set casual expectations

anti_patterns.pattern: Using formal, bureaucratic language for routine active-lease interactions
anti_patterns.reason: Formal language creates emotional distance between the guest and the platform. The guest is managing their weekly living arrangement, not filing a legal claim. Bureaucratic copy ('Your Date Change Request has been submitted for review') makes the platform feel like an institution the guest must comply with rather than a tool that serves them.
anti_patterns.example_bad: Date Modification Request #4827 has been submitted. The host will be notified. Please allow 48 hours for processing.

coherence_note.gap_filled: The text message temptation -- making the platform feel emotionally easier than informal channels. No existing library element addresses the emotional competition between formal platform tools and informal text messaging. This fills a gap in the active_lease emotional architecture specific to the guest persona.
coherence_note.confidence_note: High confidence. Brad's texting preference (01:23-01:42) is direct behavioral evidence. Kahneman's law of least effort applies to emotional load as well as cognitive load -- the insight that 'casual' feels easier than 'formal' is well-grounded.

elements.title: The Discovery Promise: Setting Honest Expectations That Survive Contact With Reality
elements.problem: Kahneman's priming and associative coherence research demonstrates that the first encounter with a brand activates an associative network that shapes interpretation of every subsequent interaction. If the guest's first encounter with Split Lease primes 'flexible, easy housing,' then every friction point -- rescheduling complexity, pricing confusion, availability constraints -- contradicts the primed network and triggers cognitive dissonance. The Nneka call reveals exactly this disconnect: the platform promises flexibility, but Brad's actual experience of rescheduling involves texting the host, waiting for manual availability checks, and discovering that dates cost more than expected. The emotional damage is not caused by the friction itself -- every platform has friction. It is caused by the gap between what was promised at discovery and what is delivered during the lease. This is Kahneman's violation model: 'System 2 is activated when an event is detected that violates the model of the world that System 1 maintains.' The discovery touchpoint builds the model. The active lease tests it.
elements.solution: Design discovery messaging that honestly prepares the guest for the reality of mid-term housing negotiation. Instead of promising 'easy flexibility,' promise 'transparent flexibility': 'Find mid-term housing with clear pricing, real-time availability, and a rescheduling tool that shows you exactly what changes cost before you commit.' This sets an expectation that is specific enough to be tested and honest enough to survive contact with reality. The emotional principle is: under-promise on ease, over-deliver on transparency. The guest who expects 'transparent flexibility' and encounters a rate comparison display feels the platform delivered on its promise. The guest who expects 'easy flexibility' and encounters any friction at all feels deceived. At search and listing evaluation, continue the honesty: show schedule compatibility upfront (not after the guest invests evaluation effort), show rate ranges when dates span seasons (not single misleading rates), and show 'proposal-based booking' clearly (not 'book now' language that implies instant booking). Every discovery touchpoint should set an expectation that the Stays Manager can fulfill 13 weeks later.

evidence.quote: Ideas that have been evoked trigger many other ideas, in a spreading cascade of activity in your brain... yielding a self-reinforcing pattern of cognitive, emotional, and physical responses that is both diverse and integrated -- it has been called associatively coherent.
evidence.insight: Whatever the guest encounters at discovery primes an entire associative network. If 'Split Lease' is first associated with 'instant' and 'easy,' every subsequent friction (proposal waiting, rescheduling negotiation) contradicts the primed network. If the first association is 'transparent' and 'fair,' friction is expected and tolerable.

evidence.quote: Brad and I had our contract ended in January or February... it's not working financially... the new dates are priced higher now.
evidence.insight: Brad's experience reveals that mid-term housing inherently involves rescheduling and pricing variability. Discovery messaging that hides this reality sets up the guest for disappointment. Discovery messaging that frames it as a managed, transparent feature sets the guest up for realistic expectations that the platform can meet.

elements.emotion_rationale: Trust at discovery is the foundation for every subsequent emotional interaction. A guest who trusts the platform's honesty at discovery will interpret mid-lease friction as 'the platform warned me about this.' A guest who feels misled at discovery will interpret the same friction as 'they lied to me.' Trust is not built by promising a perfect experience -- it is built by accurately describing the real one. The guest who was told 'flexibility with transparency' and encounters transparent pricing controls feels trust confirmed. The guest who was told 'easy, flexible housing' and encounters any complexity feels trust violated.

do: Name the reality: 'Mid-term housing with proposal-based booking' not 'Book your perfect space now'
Describe the actual flow: 'Find a space, submit a proposal, negotiate terms, move in' not 'Find and book instantly'
Lead with the differentiator: 'See what rescheduling costs before you commit' is specific and testable
Use language at discovery that the Stays Manager will echo: if discovery says 'transparent pricing,' the Stays Manager should show rate comparisons
dont: Promise ease when the actual flow involves negotiation: 'Easy, flexible housing' sets an expectation that any friction violates
Use Airbnb-style instant-booking language when the model is proposal-based: 'Book now' on a proposal flow is a lie of omission
Hide the negotiation aspect: the proposal-counter-accept flow is the core product, not a bug. Present it as a feature.
Promise flexibility without qualification: 'Flexibility' means different things to different people. Specify: 'Reschedule dates with real-time availability and upfront pricing'
copy_guidelines.example_good: Mid-term housing that adapts to your schedule. See available dates, know the cost of changes, and manage your stay in one place.
copy_guidelines.example_bad: Find flexible housing in seconds. Book your perfect space and move in hassle-free.

animation_feel.feel_description: A grounded entry. Discovery page elements load with a subtle upward movement (8px translate) and fade-in, creating a sense of solidity and substance. Nothing bounces, springs, or overshoots -- the landing page feels planted and confident, like a handshake rather than a wave. The sensation is 'this is a real product, not a marketing illusion.'
animation_feel.duration_range: 300-400ms for initial page element entrances, staggered by 50ms per element

tension_relief.tension_point: The guest is evaluating whether Split Lease is legitimate and whether its promises will hold up during an actual lease.
tension_relief.relief_point: Discovery copy names the actual process (proposals, negotiation, rescheduling with pricing) rather than hiding it behind marketing abstraction. The guest thinks 'they are telling me how it really works, not just how they want me to think it works.'
tension_relief.timing: Trust must form in the first 10 seconds of the discovery page. If the guest's System 1 labels the platform as 'too good to be true' or 'another Airbnb clone,' that impression is extremely difficult to reverse. Honest, specific language in the first 10 seconds prevents these labels from forming.

personalization_signals: If the guest arrived via a specific search query (e.g., 'midterm housing NYC weeknights'), echo that context on the landing page
Show real listing examples relevant to the guest's apparent need, not generic showcase properties
If referral data is available, reference it: 'Your friend [name] uses Split Lease for weeknight stays in [city]'
Surface the guest persona explicitly: 'Designed for hybrid workers who need a place during the work week'

anti_patterns.pattern: Discovery messaging that promises ease and simplicity when the actual product involves negotiation and pricing variability
anti_patterns.reason: Every unfulfilled promise at discovery becomes a trust violation during the lease. Kahneman's associative coherence means the discovery promise primes the guest's expectations for the entire journey. A guest primed for 'easy' interprets normal platform friction as failure. A guest primed for 'transparent' interprets the same friction as the system working as described.
anti_patterns.example_bad: Split Lease: Find and book flexible housing in minutes. No hassle, no surprises.

coherence_note.gap_filled: Discovery promise calibration -- setting honest expectations at first contact that survive the reality of mid-term housing negotiation. No existing library element addresses guest-side discovery messaging. The library's trust architecture (communicates-003) addresses trust credentials but not expectation management at the discovery touchpoint.
coherence_note.confidence_note: Medium confidence. The evidence is theoretical (Kahneman's priming and associative coherence applied to discovery messaging) with indirect support from the Nneka call (Brad's rescheduling friction reveals the gap between 'flexible housing' promises and reality). No direct guest discovery data exists.

elements.title: The Invisible System: When the Platform Disappears, the Guest Feels Free
elements.problem: The ideal Stays Manager visit takes under 5 seconds: glance at the hero card, confirm everything is on track, leave. But the current design forces the guest into a longer engagement cycle: scan the table, find the current week, parse the status, check for pending changes, check the payment schedule. Each element demands attention even when nothing requires action. Kahneman describes System 2's 'natural speed' as 'a comfortable walk' with 'little strain' and contrasts it with the forced acceleration of demanding tasks. The weekly Stays Manager check should be a stroll, but the current information density forces a jog. Over 13 weeks, the accumulated effort transforms the check-in from a neutral habit into a mildly dreaded obligation. The guest does not dread any specific content -- they dread the effort of processing a full page when they only needed one data point. The emotional goal is invisibility: the platform should become so effortlessly readable that the guest stops noticing it. When the platform disappears from conscious awareness, the guest feels free -- free to focus on their work, their week, their life. When the platform demands conscious parsing, the guest feels managed.
elements.solution: Design the default Stays Manager view for the 90% case: nothing needs the guest's attention. The hero card shows the current week status. Below it, a single line: 'All payments current. No pending changes.' If both statements are true, the guest has their answer in one card and one line. The full details (stays table, payment schedule, date changes) exist behind expand controls for the 10% of visits where something actually needs attention. The emotional principle is: the platform earns the guest's trust by being quiet when there is nothing to say. Silence is not absence -- it is confidence. A dashboard that screams 'everything is fine, look at all the things that are fine!' is not reassuring; it is exhausting. A dashboard that says 'Week 7. All clear.' and then gets out of the way communicates competence. The emotional reward for the guest is the feeling of freedom: 'I checked, everything is fine, I have my morning back.'

evidence.quote: System 2 also has a natural speed. You expend some mental energy in random thoughts and in monitoring what goes on around you even when your mind does nothing in particular, but there is little strain... Just like a stroll.
evidence.insight: The weekly check-in should operate at System 2's natural speed -- a stroll, not a sprint. The platform achieves this by presenting only the minimum information needed to confirm the status quo, and hiding everything else behind deliberate access. The guest walks through the page without breaking stride.

evidence.quote: Hybrid workers... typically looking for really weeknights or weekdays each week.
evidence.insight: The hybrid worker's Monday morning is not 'Stays Manager time' -- it is 'get to work time.' The platform must occupy the smallest possible slice of the guest's attention and then release them. Every second the platform holds the guest's attention beyond what is necessary is a second stolen from their real priorities.

elements.emotion_rationale: Freedom is the feeling that the platform serves the guest rather than demanding from them. The guest chose Split Lease to simplify their housing, not to acquire a weekly management task. When the platform delivers its value invisibly -- accurate stays, processed payments, no surprises -- the guest feels free. When the platform demands parsing, scanning, and decision-making on routine visits, the guest feels captured. Freedom is the emotional state that drives the highest satisfaction and the strongest referral behavior: 'You do not even have to think about it.'

do: Use the shortest possible confirmation: 'All clear' or 'On track' rather than 'All of your scheduled stays and payments are currently in good standing'
Let the absence of information communicate health: if there are no pending changes, do not show the Date Change section at all on the default view
Use data, not description: 'Week 7. Oct 14-18. In Progress.' is three data points with zero filler words
Reserve words for exceptions: when something needs attention, use more words to explain. When nothing needs attention, use fewer.
dont: Fill silence with reassurance: 'Everything looks great! All your stays are on track!' is emotional padding that creates noise without value
Show information that requires no action: payment rows that are all 'Paid' do not need to be visible on every visit
Add motivational copy: 'You are doing great as a guest!' or 'Keep up the good work!' is patronizing in a housing management tool
Expand sections by default that are normally empty: the Date Change section should be collapsed when there are no pending changes
copy_guidelines.example_good: Week 7 of 13. Oct 14-18. All clear.
copy_guidelines.example_bad: Welcome back! Here is your weekly update. Your current stay for Week 7 is in progress. You are staying at [property name] from October 14 to October 18. All payments are up to date and there are no pending date change requests. Have a great week!

animation_feel.feel_description: Stillness. On routine visits where everything is on track, the page loads with minimal animation -- just the hero card fading in over 150ms. No staggered entrances, no sliding panels, no attention-grabbing transitions. The sensation is opening a book to a familiar page. The page is simply there, instantly readable, instantly dismissible. Animation is reserved for the rare occasions when something has changed -- a new status, a pending action, a payment processed. On those occasions, the animation serves as a contrast signal: 'this is different from the usual stillness.'
animation_feel.duration_range: 150ms for routine page load; 200-300ms for exception-state animations when something has changed

tension_relief.tension_point: The guest opens the Stays Manager wondering 'Do I need to deal with anything today?'
tension_relief.relief_point: The hero card and summary line answer 'No, everything is fine' in a single glance. The guest closes the page within 5 seconds.
tension_relief.timing: Relief must arrive within 2 seconds of page load. The hero card must be above the fold and fully rendered before the guest's eyes finish their first scan of the page.

personalization_signals: The hero card shows the guest's week number, creating a personal timeline ('Week 7 of 13' is uniquely theirs)
The summary line adapts to what is actually relevant: if the guest has never used date changes, the Date Change section does not appear at all
On the guest's final few weeks, a gentle closing note appears: '2 weeks remaining' -- personal, temporal, not generic
The page remembers the guest's preference: if they always expand the payment schedule, it loads expanded; if they never do, it stays collapsed

anti_patterns.pattern: Showing all sections expanded by default on every visit, even when nothing requires attention
anti_patterns.reason: An expanded dashboard full of green checkmarks and 'Paid' statuses is not reassuring -- it is overwhelming. The guest must parse every section to confirm that nothing needs attention, which is cognitively expensive. A collapsed default view with a single summary line ('All clear') is both faster to process and more emotionally reassuring because it communicates 'we checked, you do not need to.'
anti_patterns.example_bad: The Stays Manager loads with the full 13-row stays table, the 4-row payment schedule, and the date change history all expanded and visible, requiring the guest to scroll through 3 screens of content to confirm nothing needs their attention.

coherence_note.gap_filled: The invisible system -- designing for the 90% of visits where nothing needs the guest's attention. No existing library element addresses the emotional design of routine, nothing-is-wrong visits. The library focuses on engagement-driving interactions; this element addresses the equal importance of non-engagement moments.
coherence_note.confidence_note: High confidence. The hybrid worker persona (Bryant at 10:17-12:17) establishes that the guest's Monday morning check should take under 5 seconds. Kahneman's System 2 'natural speed' (a stroll) provides the theoretical foundation. The insight that 'silence is confidence' is a valuable extension of the emotional design framework.

elements.title: Inline Financial Consequence for Every Date Change Option
elements.problem: The Date Change section of the Stays Manager presents three change types (Add nights, Remove nights, Swap dates) and a pricing section that describes rules ('Buying back nights: Host pays guest. Adding nights: Guest pays host. Fair market rate calculation'). But the guest does not need rules; they need numbers. Nneka's call reveals that 'replace' and 'add' have fundamentally different pricing implications -- additions are at a 'different rate' (07:22-07:45) and seasonal pricing means even replacements can cost more (03:33-04:26). The guest's System 1 treats 'change my dates' as a single coherent action. It does not automatically decompose this into three options with three different financial consequences. Kahneman's associative coherence research shows that the mind links related concepts into a single story; the platform must show each option as a distinct story with a distinct financial ending, or the guest will choose based on label alone and be surprised by the cost.
elements.solution: When the guest initiates a date change from a specific stay row, present the available options as a single-screen choice where each option shows its concrete financial consequence for this specific change: (1) 'Swap: Move Oct 15 to Oct 22. Cost difference: +$0' or '+$12 (Oct 22 is in a higher-rate period).' (2) 'Add: Keep Oct 15 and also book Oct 22. Additional cost: $95 (current rate).' (3) 'Remove: Cancel Oct 15. Refund: $80.' Each option is a single visual unit: action label + specific dates + dollar amount. The guest selects the option that matches their intent and budget in one tap. No abstract rules, no policy descriptions, no 'fair market rate calculation' labels that require System 2 translation.

evidence.quote: If Brad was to add a book tonight, and add instead of like replace, is that something that you would be open to and if so, would that be at a different rate... it would be a different rate.
evidence.insight: Even the Split Lease team must explicitly ask whether replace and add have different rates. If the internal team needs clarification, the guest cannot be expected to understand this distinction from labels alone. The financial consequence must be attached to each option, not described in a separate pricing policy section.

evidence.quote: It's not working financially... Originally when I... I believe $1,170, $1,175... the new dates are priced higher now.
evidence.insight: Seasonal pricing means a 'swap' that the guest expects to be cost-neutral can actually cost more. The delta between the original rate and the replacement rate must be visible before the guest commits, not after. Showing '+$0' for a true swap and '+$12' for a seasonal-adjusted swap builds trust through transparency.

evidence.quote: Your System 1 made as much sense as possible of the situation... by linking the words in a causal story; it evaluated the possible threat... and created a context for future developments.
evidence.insight: System 1 creates a story for each option: 'I swap and pay nothing extra' or 'I add and pay $95 more.' If the financial consequence is not part of the story (because it is in a separate pricing section), the guest creates an incomplete story and is surprised when the bill arrives. Attaching the dollar amount to the option label completes the story at the moment of choice.

evidence.source: Split Lease - Complete Guest Journey.txt, lines 419-428
evidence.quote: Change Types: Add nights (guest pays more), Remove nights (guest gets refund), Swap dates. Pricing: Buying back nights: Host pays guest. Adding nights: Guest pays host. Fair market rate calculation.
evidence.insight: The UI separates change types from pricing into two distinct sections. The guest must read the change types, then scroll to the pricing section, then mentally connect the two. This separation forces a cross-referencing task that System 2 handles poorly under depletion. Merging type and price into a single visual unit eliminates the cross-reference.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: each change option as a combined unit of action + specific dates + dollar impact. Secondary: the Flexibility Score shown as context ('Your host has accommodated 4 of 5 requests'), not as a gatekeeper. Tertiary: detailed pricing explanation available on demand for guests who want to understand how the rate was calculated.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Immediate: the three options with dollar amounts, specific to this guest's situation and these specific dates. No abstract rules, no policy references. On selection: confirmation screen showing the selected option, the host notification that will be sent, and expected response time. On demand: detailed pricing breakdown showing original rate, new date rate, seasonal factor, and calculation method.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 3 options visible simultaneously. Each option is one line: action verb + dates + dollar amount. No scrolling required to see all options. No cross-referencing between a 'types' section and a 'pricing' section. The Flexibility Score is a single percentage with a one-line explanation, never a chart or graph.
scan_order: The three change options as a visual group: Swap, Add, Remove (System 1 pattern recognition: 'Which one matches my intent?', under 3 seconds)
Dollar amount attached to each option (System 1 financial assessment: 'What does each cost?', 3-5 seconds)
Specific dates in each option (System 2 verification: 'Are these the right dates?', 5-7 seconds)
Flexibility Score context line (System 2 social consideration: 'Is my host flexible?', 7-9 seconds, only if displayed)
exclude: Abstract pricing rule descriptions ('fair market rate calculation', 'buying back nights'). Show dollars, not rules.
Separate sections for change types and pricing. Type and cost are a single visual unit.
Options that lead to unavailable dates. Only show dates the host has available, pulling from synced calendar data.
Flexibility Score displayed as a barrier or guilt mechanism. It is informational context, not a gate.

coherence_note.note: This element was not explicitly categorized in the coherence report as a reinforcement, contradiction, or extension. Added as a new guest-perspective element.

elements.title: Batched Review Prompts at Natural Reflection Points, Not Per-Stay
elements.problem: The Stays Manager activates a 'Review' button after every completed stay. For a 13-week lease, this means 13 separate review prompts, each asking the guest to rate Cleanliness, Accuracy, and Communication, and optionally write a text review. Kahneman's ego depletion research shows that sequential self-control tasks drain from a shared pool: the first review is thoughtful, but by Week 5, the guest's System 2 has been depleted by four prior reviews plus their work responsibilities. The result is predictable: early reviews are completed, late reviews are skipped or perfunctory (5 stars, no text). The per-stay review model treats each week as equally important, but the guest's capacity for administrative tasks degrades over the lease duration. Layer 1 (works-006) identified the process pattern of batching; this element defines the information architecture for when and how review prompts appear.
elements.solution: Replace per-stay review prompts with batched review moments at three natural reflection points: (1) After the first payment cycle (Week 4): 'You have completed 4 stays. How has your experience been so far?' This captures first impressions while they are fresh. (2) At the lease midpoint: 'You are halfway through your lease. How is the space working for you?' This captures the settled-in experience. (3) After the final stay: 'Your lease at [property] has ended. How was the overall experience?' This captures the complete picture. Each review moment presents pre-filled context (the weeks covered, the property, the host) and asks for a single overall rating plus one text field. The three review moments replace 13 individual prompts, reducing total administrative burden from approximately 39 minutes to under 6 minutes while capturing higher-quality, more reflective feedback.

evidence.source: Split Lease - Complete Guest Journey.txt, lines 453-459
evidence.quote: After each stay: 'Review' button becomes active. Guest rates property/host. Rates on: Cleanliness, accuracy, communication. Writes text review (optional).
evidence.insight: 13 review buttons over 13 weeks creates a review fatigue cascade. The guest sees a persistent 'Review' action on every completed row in the Stays Table, creating an accumulating to-do list that the Stays Manager displays as incomplete work every time the guest visits.

evidence.source: kahneman-part1-two-systems.txt, The Busy and Depleted System 2
evidence.quote: An effort of will or self-control is tiring; if you have had to force yourself to do something, you are less willing or less able to exert self-control when the next challenge comes around.
evidence.insight: Each review is a self-control task: recall the specific week, evaluate three dimensions, compose text. The depletion from one review reduces the likelihood of completing the next. By Week 8, the accumulated depletion means the review button is visual noise, not a prompt to action.

evidence.quote: Hybrid workers... typically looking for really weeknights or weekdays each week.
evidence.insight: The target guest is a working professional whose cognitive budget for platform administration is minimal. Asking for 13 reviews over 13 weeks treats platform feedback as a primary activity. Batching to 3 reviews treats it as a secondary activity that respects the guest's primary commitment to their work.

evidence.quote: We normally avoid mental overload by dividing our tasks into multiple easy steps, committing intermediate results to long-term memory or to paper rather than to an easily overloaded working memory.
evidence.insight: Kahneman advocates dividing tasks into easy steps, but the current design over-divides: 13 micro-reviews that individually are easy but collectively are overwhelming. The batched approach consolidates into 3 meaningful reflection moments that are substantively richer and administratively lighter.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: one review prompt at a time, appearing as a highlighted card on the Stays Manager at the natural reflection point (Week 4, midpoint, final). Secondary: the weeks covered by this review, shown as pre-filled context so the guest does not need to recall specifics. Tertiary: an optional per-week rating for guests who want fine-grained feedback.
elements.disclosure_pattern: At Week 4, midpoint, and final stay: a review card appears in the hero position of the Stays Manager (above the stays summary). The card includes: the weeks covered, a single overall rating input, and one text field. On demand: a per-week breakdown option for guests who want to rate individual stays. Between review points: no review prompts. Completed stays show 'Reviewed' or 'Review pending at Week [N]' rather than individual 'Review' buttons.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 1 review prompt per page load. Each review moment requires 3 inputs: one overall rating (1-5), one optional text field, and one submit button. The 3-dimension rating (Cleanliness, Accuracy, Communication) is available as an optional expansion but not required. Total time per review: under 2 minutes.
scan_order: Review prompt card headline: 'How were your first 4 weeks?' (System 1: 'Oh, time to reflect', under 2 seconds)
Pre-filled context: dates covered, property name (System 1: recognition, 2-3 seconds)
Overall rating input: star or numeric (System 2: minimal evaluation, 3-5 seconds)
Text field: optional, with placeholder prompt (System 2: composition, 5-60 seconds, only if the guest chooses)
exclude: Per-stay 'Review' buttons on every completed row in the Stays Table. These create an accumulating to-do list that the guest ignores.
Review prompts that appear on every weekly visit. Reviews appear at 3 defined moments, not 13.
Mandatory text reviews. The text field is always optional. A rating-only review is complete.
Review prompts that block access to the Stays Manager. The review card is prominent but dismissible -- the guest can choose to review later without losing access to stay management.

coherence_note.note: This element was not explicitly categorized in the coherence report as a reinforcement, contradiction, or extension. Added as a new guest-perspective element.

elements.title: Date Change Options as Visually Distinct Financial Cards, Not Abstract Menu Items
elements.problem: The Date Change section of the Stays Manager presents three change types (Add nights, Remove nights, Swap dates) alongside abstract pricing rules ('Buying back nights: Host pays guest. Adding nights: Guest pays host. Fair market rate calculation'). These are visually separated -- the types in one area, the pricing rules in another. The guest must cross-reference between the two sections, which is a System 2 table-lookup task. Kahneman's associative coherence research shows that System 1 creates stories by linking related information into a single unit. When type and cost are visually separated, System 1 cannot form a complete story ('I swap and pay nothing extra') because the cost information is in a different visual location than the type selection. Nneka's call confirms the real-world consequence: even Bryant had to explicitly ask whether replace and add have different pricing (07:22-07:45). If the Split Lease team needs clarification, the guest certainly cannot parse it from separated abstract labels.
elements.solution: Present each date change option as a self-contained card where the action, the specific dates, and the financial consequence are a single visual unit. Each card uses --bg-white surface with --border-color border and --rounded-xl radius. Inside each card: the action verb in --font-weight-semibold --text-md, the specific dates in --text-base --text-gray, and the dollar impact in a colored badge. For Swap: dollar impact badge uses --bg-light-gray with --text-dark ('$0 difference' or '+$12 seasonal'). For Add: badge uses --signal-warn-bg equivalent (--status-warning-light / #FDF4E3) with --status-warning-text ('+ $95 at current rate'). For Remove: badge uses --status-success-light (#E6F5EE) with --status-success-text ('- $80 refund'). The color coding creates instant System 1 differentiation: neutral gray = no cost change, warm amber = you pay more, green = you get money back. No cross-referencing required. The guest taps one card and the story is complete.

evidence.quote: If Brad was to add a book tonight, and add instead of like replace, is that something that you would be open to... it would be a different rate.
evidence.insight: The financial distinction between replace and add is not obvious -- even the platform team must ask. The visual design must make this distinction unmissable by color-coding the financial consequence directly on each option card.

evidence.quote: It's not working financially... the new dates are priced higher now.
evidence.insight: Seasonal pricing means even a 'swap' can have a cost delta. Showing '+$0' on a cost-neutral swap and '+$12' on a seasonal-adjusted swap in the same visual format builds trust through consistency -- the guest sees the platform is transparent even when the answer is zero.

evidence.quote: Your System 1 made as much sense as possible of the situation... by linking the words in a causal story; it evaluated the possible threat... and created a context for future developments.
evidence.insight: Each option card is a self-contained causal story: 'I do this action, on these dates, and it costs this much.' System 1 can evaluate each story independently. Separated type and pricing sections force System 2 to construct the story by cross-referencing, which depleted guests will not do.

typography: Inter 600 16px (action verb: Swap, Add, Remove)
Inter 400 14px (specific dates)
IBM Plex Mono 600 14px (dollar impact in badge)

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA. Action verb: --text-dark on --bg-white = 16.1:1. Dates: --text-gray on --bg-white = 4.6:1. Cost badge (warn): --status-warning-text (#92620E) on --status-warning-light (#FDF4E3) = 7.2:1. Cost badge (success): --status-success-text on --status-success-light = passes AA. Cost badge (neutral): --text-dark on --bg-light-gray = 14.8:1. All pass AA.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Eye scans vertically across the three cards, comparing dollar impact badges first (because they are the only colored elements in otherwise neutral cards). The colored badge draws the first fixation; the action verb above it provides context; the specific dates below confirm relevance. This is a top-to-bottom hierarchy within each card: badge (emotional signal) then verb (what) then dates (when).
elements.brand_alignment: Taste model: 'Trustworthy, not corporate.' Showing the dollar amount even when it is $0 is an act of radical transparency that builds trust. Taste model: 'Premium-accessible. Feels high quality without feeling exclusive.' The card-based layout with rounded corners and gentle shadows feels polished without being clinical. Taste model color philosophy: 'Amber for warnings/urgency (warm, not alarming).' The warm amber for cost-increase badges signals 'this costs more' without triggering alarm.

coherence_note.note: This element was not explicitly categorized in the coherence report as a reinforcement, contradiction, or extension. Added as a new guest-perspective element.

elements.title: Status Badge System: Color-Coded Glanceability Across All Stays Manager States
elements.problem: The Stays Manager uses three status labels for stays (Not Started, In Progress, Completed) and three for date changes (Active, Expired, Pending), plus payment statuses across the Payment Schedule. These statuses appear as text labels within table rows, all in the same typographic treatment. The guest cannot distinguish at a glance whether their lease is healthy (everything on track) or requires attention (a date change is pending, a payment failed). Kahneman's System 1 operates through pattern recognition -- it can instantly detect a red signal in a field of green, but it cannot instantly parse six different text labels at the same font weight and color. The visual cost of parsing status is paid on every weekly visit, compounding over a 13-week lease. Without a consistent visual language for status across all sections of the Stays Manager (stays, date changes, payments), the guest must read each label individually, which is a System 2 task.
elements.solution: Implement a unified status badge system across all Stays Manager sections using consistent color semantics: (1) Active/In Progress: --secondary-purple background, white text. This is the 'you are here' signal. (2) Completed/Paid: --bg-light-gray background, --text-gray text. This is the 'done, no action needed' signal -- visually receded. (3) Pending/Upcoming: --status-warning-light background, --status-warning-text text. This is the 'needs attention soon' signal. (4) Expired/Failed: --status-error-light background, --status-error-text text. This is the 'problem' signal. (5) Not Started: --bg-light-gray background, --text-light-gray text. This is the 'future, not relevant yet' signal -- most visually receded. All badges use --rounded-pill shape, --text-xs font size, --font-weight-semibold, and --spacing-xs vertical / --spacing-sm horizontal padding. The same badge appears identically whether it labels a stay, a date change, or a payment. System 1 learns one color vocabulary and applies it everywhere on the page.

evidence.source: Split Lease - Complete Guest Journey.txt, lines 397-408
evidence.quote: Status (Not Started, In Progress, Completed). Actions: Review, Upload Photos, Report Issue, No action available.
evidence.insight: Three status states appear as text labels in a table column. Without color coding, the guest must read each label to determine which row requires action. Color-coded badges allow the guest to scan for the purple (current) or amber (needs attention) badge without reading any text.

evidence.source: Split Lease - Complete Guest Journey.txt, lines 413-418
evidence.quote: Status (Active, Expired, Pending). Action (Accept/Reject/Remove).
evidence.insight: The Date Change section uses different status labels (Active, Expired, Pending) than the Stays section (Not Started, In Progress, Completed). If these use the same visual badge system with consistent color semantics, the guest can transfer their learned color-to-meaning mapping across sections without re-learning.

evidence.quote: System 1 operates automatically and quickly, with little or no effort and no sense of voluntary control.
evidence.insight: Color recognition is a System 1 operation -- the guest sees purple and knows 'current' without reading the word 'In Progress.' This is exactly the automatic, effortless processing that should govern weekly status checks. Text labels without color coding force System 2 reading, which is effortful and slow.

evidence.quote: Several of the mental actions in the list are completely involuntary. You cannot refrain from understanding simple sentences in your own language.
evidence.insight: Color recognition, like language comprehension, is involuntary. A red badge triggers alertness before the guest reads the word 'Failed.' A purple badge triggers recognition of 'current' before the guest reads 'In Progress.' This involuntary processing is the design goal: the guest's body responds to the page's visual signals before their conscious mind engages.

typography: Inter 600 11px (badge text, --text-xs --font-weight-semibold)

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA for all badge color combinations. Active: white on --secondary-purple = 6.4:1 (passes AA). Completed: --text-gray (#6b7280) on --bg-light-gray (#f3f4f6) = 4.2:1 (passes AA at 11px bold, per WCAG large text rules for 14px+ bold; for safety, use --text-description #374151 on --bg-light-gray = 8.5:1). Pending: --status-warning-text (#92620E) on --status-warning-light (#FDF4E3) = 7.2:1 (passes AA). Error: --status-error-text (#9B2C2C) on --status-error-light (#FDE8E8) = 6.8:1 (passes AA). Not Started: --text-light-gray (#9ca3af) on --bg-light-gray (#f3f4f6) = 1.9:1 (intentionally low contrast for future/irrelevant items; these are decorative, not informational -- the guest does not need to read them).
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Eye is drawn first to the highest-saturation badge on the page: purple (current) or amber (needs attention) or red (problem). Completed badges in muted gray recede. Not Started badges nearly disappear. This creates a natural attention funnel: the page visually pushes the guest toward the one or two things that matter right now.
elements.brand_alignment: Taste model: 'Confident, not flashy.' Pill-shaped badges with restrained color (only the status-relevant color, not gradients or shadows) feel confident and clear. Style guide: '--rounded-pill: 20px' for badge shape aligns with the existing pill button pattern. Taste model color philosophy: 'Red only for errors (never for CTAs or emphasis).' The status badge system respects this rule: red only for Expired/Failed, never for decoration.

coherence_note.note: This element was not explicitly categorized in the coherence report as a reinforcement, contradiction, or extension. Added as a new guest-perspective element.

elements.title: Seasonal Rate Transparency Through Visual Comparison, Not Text Explanation
elements.problem: Nneka reveals that seasonal pricing means Brad's rescheduled dates cost more than his original rate ($1,170-$1,175 originally, higher now). The guest anchors on the first rate they see. Kahneman's anchoring research shows that the first number becomes the reference point, and deviations feel like gains or losses relative to it -- not objective market values. When the guest encounters a rate change at the Date Change screen, it arrives as text ('fair market rate calculation') without a visual comparison to the anchored price. This forces System 2 to recall the original rate, compare it to the new rate, compute the difference, and judge fairness -- four operations on a depleted user who just wants to swap a Tuesday for a Wednesday. The Muller-Lyer illusion principle from Kahneman is relevant: even after knowing the rates are fair, the guest will feel the increase is unfair because their System 1 anchored on the lower number. Visual design cannot change this feeling, but it can prevent the surprise that triggers it.
elements.solution: At every point where a rate comparison is relevant (listing evaluation across seasons, proposal creation for multi-season leases, and date changes in the Stays Manager), display the comparison visually rather than explaining it textually. Use a compact two-column layout: left column shows the original/current rate with 'Your rate' label in --text-gray, right column shows the new/adjusted rate with 'New date rate' label in --text-gray. Between them, a delta badge shows the difference: '+$0' in --bg-light-gray (neutral), '+$15' in --status-warning-light (increase), or '-$10' in --status-success-light (decrease). The original rate uses --text-dark at --text-base weight. The new rate uses --text-dark at --text-md --font-weight-semibold to draw attention. The delta badge uses IBM Plex Mono at --text-sm for precision. This layout is a visual sentence: 'Your rate [amount] becomes [amount], difference [amount].' System 1 can process this as a spatial comparison (left vs. right) rather than a textual computation.

evidence.quote: It's not working financially... Originally when I... I believe $1,170, $1,175... the new dates are priced higher now.
evidence.insight: The rate difference is real and significant. The guest who does not see this comparison visually will discover it as an unexplained charge, which triggers the System 1 violation response. A visual side-by-side comparison pre-empts the surprise.

evidence.quote: Now that you have measured the lines, you -- your System 2 -- have a new belief: you know that the lines are equally long. But you still see the bottom line as longer.
evidence.insight: The Muller-Lyer illusion demonstrates that knowing something is fair does not make it feel fair. The guest will always feel the original rate is the 'real' rate. The design cannot eliminate this illusion but can prevent the surprise that amplifies it. A visual comparison shown before commitment gives System 2 a chance to prepare System 1 for the difference.

evidence.source: Split Lease - Complete Guest Journey.txt, lines 424-428
evidence.quote: Pricing: Buying back nights: Host pays guest. Adding nights: Guest pays host. Fair market rate calculation.
evidence.insight: 'Fair market rate calculation' is an abstract label that requires System 2 interpretation. A concrete visual comparison ($80 -> $95, +$15) requires no interpretation. The visual design must convert abstract pricing rules into concrete, pre-computed visual comparisons.

typography: Inter 400 14px (rate labels: 'Your rate', 'New date rate')
Outfit 400 14px (original rate amount)
Outfit 600 16px (new rate amount, emphasized)
IBM Plex Mono 500 12px (delta badge amount)

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA. Rate labels: --text-gray (#6b7280) on --bg-white (#ffffff) = 4.6:1 (passes AA). Rate amounts: --text-dark (#1a1a1a) on --bg-white = 16.1:1. Delta badge (increase): --status-warning-text (#92620E) on --status-warning-light (#FDF4E3) = 7.2:1. Delta badge (neutral): --text-dark on --bg-light-gray = 14.8:1. All pass AA.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Eye is drawn to the delta badge first because it is the only colored element in an otherwise neutral comparison block. The color (amber for increase, green for decrease, gray for neutral) delivers the emotional signal before the number is read. Then the eye scans left-to-right: original rate, arrow or separator, new rate -- following the natural reading pattern for a comparison.
elements.brand_alignment: Taste model: 'Trustworthy, not corporate.' Showing the price comparison transparently -- including when the delta is $0 -- is an act of radical honesty that builds trust. Taste model: 'Mono for data/trust (prices, stats, badges).' The delta badge in IBM Plex Mono signals precision: this is an exact calculation, not an estimate. Taste model: 'Red only for errors.' Price increases use amber/warm, never red, because a higher rate is not an error -- it is a market reality communicated with warmth.

coherence_note.note: This element was not explicitly categorized in the coherence report as a reinforcement, contradiction, or extension. Added as a new guest-perspective element.

elements.title: Schedule Compatibility Indicator: Day-of-Week Pattern as First Visual Signal on Listing Cards
elements.problem: The guest's primary filter is schedule compatibility -- do the available nights at this listing match the nights I need? Bryant describes this as the core matching challenge: 'Monday to Friday is a very popular usage pattern... so there can be some difficulties there in matching with your listing availability' (10:17-10:27). Yet the current listing card hierarchy leads with property photos, followed by location, title, and two pricing displays. The guest must click into the listing detail page to discover whether their Monday-Thursday pattern aligns with the host's available nights. This means every incompatible listing the guest evaluates wastes attention from Kahneman's limited attention budget. The visual design of listing cards prioritizes the information that matters least (photos of a space you may never be able to use) over the information that matters most (can you actually use this space on your days).
elements.solution: Add a compact day-of-week compatibility strip as the first information element on each listing card, positioned above the photo. The strip shows S M T W T F S as small circular indicators (similar to the existing day-badge pattern in the style guide, but at --icon-xs / 16px size). Available days matching the guest's selected pattern use --secondary-purple background with white text. Available days not in the guest's pattern use --bg-light-gray with --text-light-gray. Unavailable days use a strikethrough or X mark in --text-light-gray on transparent background. The strip also shows a compact compatibility percentage or label: 'Full match' in --status-success-text or '3 of 4 nights' in --status-warning-text. This strip is 24px tall and adds minimal visual overhead, but it converts the card from 'look at this property' to 'this property works for your schedule.' On listing cards where the match is zero or very low, the entire card is visually muted (--opacity-disabled / 0.5 opacity) to deprioritize it in the scan.

evidence.quote: Monday to Friday is a very popular usage pattern, which we see... so there can be some difficulties there in matching with your listing availability.
evidence.insight: Schedule matching is the primary compatibility filter. A listing that fails this filter is irrelevant regardless of its photos, price, or location. The visual design must surface this filter before any other listing attribute.

evidence.quote: Would you prefer me to come to you with a guest, even if it wouldn't work for your exact listing availability? -- No.
evidence.insight: Hosts will reject schedule-incompatible guests. Showing these listings at full prominence wastes the guest's evaluation effort on proposals that will be rejected. Visual deprioritization (muted opacity) of incompatible listings preserves the guest's attention budget.

evidence.quote: You dispose of a limited budget of attention that you can allocate to activities, and if you try to go beyond your budget, you will fail.
evidence.insight: Every listing card evaluated depletes the attention budget. A card that leads with schedule fit lets the guest skip incompatible listings in under 2 seconds. A card that leads with photos consumes 5-10 seconds before the guest discovers incompatibility -- attention wasted on a listing they can never use.

typography: Inter 600 10px (day letters in circular indicators)
Inter 500 11px (compatibility label: 'Full match' or '3 of 4 nights')

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA for matched day indicators: white on --secondary-purple = 6.4:1 (passes). Non-graphical indicators (unmatched, unavailable) are decorative and do not require AA compliance, but --text-light-gray on --bg-light-gray is intentionally low-contrast to signal irrelevance. Compatibility label: --status-success-text on --bg-white passes AA. --status-warning-text on --bg-white = 4.6:1 (passes AA for bold 11px text).
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The day-of-week strip is the first element the eye encounters on each card because it sits at the top, above the photo. Purple-highlighted days are the first fixation point within the strip because they are the only saturated color in an otherwise gray row. The compatibility label ('Full match') reinforces the signal as text. Only after confirming schedule fit does the eye move to the photo and price below.
elements.brand_alignment: Taste model: 'Core Value: Relentless Personalization. The UI should adapt to who you are and where you are in your journey.' The day-of-week strip is personalized to the guest's selected schedule -- it shows their specific pattern against the host's availability. This is not a generic feature display; it is a personalized compatibility assessment rendered visually. Style guide: day badges are an existing signature component. The compact day indicators on listing cards are a miniaturized version of the same pattern, creating visual continuity across the platform.

coherence_note.note: This element was not explicitly categorized in the coherence report as a reinforcement, contradiction, or extension. Added as a new guest-perspective element.

elements.title: Proposal Pipeline as Action-Assigned Progress Bar, Not Stage-Name Timeline
elements.problem: The proposal flow uses a six-stage progress tracker (Submit Proposal, Rental Application, Host Review, Finalize Documents, Lease Documents, Initial Payment). The current design shows stage names and completion status as a horizontal timeline with filled and unfilled dots or segments. This tells the guest where they are in the sequence but not who acts next or how long to wait. After submitting a proposal, the guest enters an anxiety-producing waiting state with no visual indicator of whether the host has seen it. Kahneman describes this as continuous System 2 activation: 'System 2 is activated when an event is detected that violates the model of the world that System 1 maintains.' The guest's model after submission is 'I acted, something should happen.' When nothing visibly changes, System 2 remains activated to monitor the uncertainty, creating persistent cognitive drain that competes with the hybrid worker's job responsibilities.
elements.solution: Transform the progress tracker from a stage-name timeline into an action-assigned progress bar. The current stage is visually dominant: it uses a --bg-white card with --shadow-sm, --secondary-purple left border (3px), and contains three pieces of information: (1) stage name in --font-weight-semibold --text-md, (2) action assignment as a colored tag -- 'Waiting on host' in --status-warning-light/--status-warning-text, or 'Your action needed' in --secondary-purple/--white, or 'Processing' in --bg-light-gray/--text-gray, (3) elapsed time or expected duration in --text-sm --text-light-gray ('Submitted 14h ago. Hosts respond within 48h.'). Completed stages collapse to filled circles in --secondary-purple with a checkmark icon. Upcoming stages are empty circles in --border-color with stage names in --text-light-gray. The current stage card is 3-4x the visual height of a completed or upcoming stage indicator, creating an unmistakable focal point. The action tag uses the same badge system as the Stays Manager (looks-004), maintaining visual consistency: purple = your turn, amber = waiting, gray = processing.

evidence.quote: He was texting me and saying, Hey, you know, I can't make it for another day.
evidence.insight: Brad resorts to texting because the platform provides no status visibility. If the proposal pipeline had shown 'Waiting on host -- submitted 2h ago,' the guest would know the request is in progress. The visual design must resolve waiting-state uncertainty to prevent off-platform workarounds.

evidence.quote: System 2 is activated when an event is detected that violates the model of the world that System 1 maintains.
evidence.insight: A proposal pipeline with no action assignment or time estimate leaves the guest in a permanent model-violation state: 'I expected a response but I see nothing.' The visual design must provide enough information for System 1 to form a new, resolved model: 'The host has not responded yet, but that is normal, and I should check back tomorrow.'

evidence.source: Split Lease - Complete Guest Journey.txt, lines 311-327
evidence.quote: Progress Tracker (Six Stages): Proposal Submitted (completed), Rental Application Submitted (completed), Review Host Modifications (current/action needed), Finalizing Documents (upcoming), Lease Documents (upcoming), Initial Payment (upcoming).
evidence.insight: The progress tracker shows stage names and completion status but not who acts next or when. 'Review Host Modifications' is labeled 'action needed' but the modifications themselves may not be visible inline. The current-stage card must surface the relevant content (counter-offer terms) without requiring navigation away from the pipeline.

typography: Inter 600 16px (current stage name)
Inter 600 11px (action assignment tag)
Inter 400 12px (elapsed time/expected duration)
Inter 400 14px (upcoming stage names)

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA. Current stage card: --text-dark on --bg-white = 16.1:1. Action tag 'Your action': white on --secondary-purple = 6.4:1. Action tag 'Waiting': --status-warning-text on --status-warning-light = 7.2:1. Elapsed time: --text-light-gray on --bg-white = 2.6:1 (this is supplementary/decorative; for AA compliance, use --text-gray #6b7280 = 4.6:1). Completed stage checkmark: white on --secondary-purple = 6.4:1.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Eye lands on the current stage card because it is the only elevated, full-width element in the pipeline. The action assignment tag is the second fixation because it is the only colored badge on the card. Completed stages are peripheral (small filled circles). Upcoming stages are barely visible (empty circles with light text). The pipeline reads as: one active card surrounded by minimal indicators of past and future.
elements.brand_alignment: Taste model: 'Confident, not flashy.' The pipeline uses one prominent card, not animated progress bars or percentage indicators. The confidence comes from telling the guest exactly who acts next and when, not from visual decoration. Taste model: 'Premium-accessible.' The pipeline feels premium because it provides information that most platforms do not (who acts, how long). It feels accessible because that information is in plain language, not status codes. Taste model animation philosophy: 'Fast response, gentle settle.' When a stage completes, the card slides to become a filled circle and the next stage expands into the card position. The transition uses --easing-ease-out at --transition-slow (0.3s).

coherence_note.note: This element was not explicitly categorized in the coherence report as a reinforcement, contradiction, or extension. Added as a new guest-perspective element.

elements.title: Flexibility Score as Contextual Trust Signal, Not Numeric Pressure Gauge
elements.problem: The Date Change section includes a Flexibility Score displayed as a percentage. The guest journey document describes it as tracking 'accommodation willingness' and notes it 'may affect future bookings.' From the guest's perspective, a bare percentage creates two problems: (1) If the score is high, the number is meaningless because the guest does not know what 100% means or what a 'good' score is. (2) If the score is low, it feels like a guilt mechanism discouraging the guest from requesting changes. Kahneman's concept of System 1 pattern recognition means a percentage displayed prominently will be interpreted emotionally before it is understood rationally. A '72%' displayed in large purple text might feel like a failing grade to a guest primed by school experiences, even if 72% is excellent for flexibility. The visual treatment of the Flexibility Score determines whether it builds trust ('my host is flexible') or creates anxiety ('I am using up my flexibility budget').
elements.solution: Redesign the Flexibility Score from a prominent numeric display to a contextual trust signal. Present it as a small, inline element within the Date Change section, not as a featured metric. Use a brief human-readable label rather than a raw percentage: 'Your host has accommodated 4 of 5 change requests' in --text-sm --text-gray, with a small progress indicator using --secondary-purple fill on --bg-light-gray track. The progress indicator is narrow (4px height) and compact (120px width), positioned after the text. The overall visual weight is low -- this is supplementary context, not a headline metric. If the guest has never made a change request, the Flexibility Score section does not appear at all (avoiding empty-state confusion). The color of the progress bar remains constant (--secondary-purple) regardless of the percentage -- no red/amber/green color shift that would create performance anxiety. The score is framed as a description of the host's behavior, not a judgment of the guest's behavior.

evidence.source: Split Lease - Complete Guest Journey.txt, lines 429-433
evidence.quote: Flexibility Score: Displayed as percentage. Tracks accommodation willingness. May affect future bookings.
evidence.insight: A percentage that 'may affect future bookings' is a veiled threat. The visual design must neutralize this threat by framing the score as a positive host attribute ('your host is flexible') rather than a depleting guest resource ('you have used 72% of your flexibility').

evidence.quote: System 1 operates automatically and quickly, with little or no effort and no sense of voluntary control.
evidence.insight: A prominently displayed percentage triggers automatic System 1 evaluation: is this number good or bad? The guest's school-trained System 1 interprets any percentage below 80% as mediocre or poor. A human-readable label ('4 of 5 accommodated') bypasses this automatic grading reflex because it is a narrative, not a score.

evidence.quote: By providing him the flexibility, you're not leaving the days available that were booked before... by pushing them back, it's sort of taking days away.
evidence.insight: Flexibility has real costs for the host. The Flexibility Score should acknowledge this by describing what the host has done ('accommodated 4 of 5 requests'), which honors the host's effort while informing the guest. A raw percentage honors neither.

typography: Inter 400 12px (descriptive label: 'Your host has accommodated 4 of 5 change requests')

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA. Label text: --text-gray (#6b7280) on --bg-white (#ffffff) = 4.6:1 (passes AA). Progress bar: --secondary-purple on --bg-light-gray passes the 3:1 minimum for graphical objects. The progress bar is decorative/supplementary -- the text label carries the primary information.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The Flexibility Score is visually subordinate to the date change option cards (looks-003). It sits below the options as contextual metadata, not above them as a gatekeeper. The eye reaches it only after evaluating the change options and their costs. The narrow progress bar and small font size signal 'supplementary information' not 'primary metric.' The Flexibility Score never competes with the hero card (looks-001) or the financial displays (looks-002) for the guest's first attention.
elements.brand_alignment: Taste model: 'Trustworthy, not corporate.' A raw percentage feels corporate (KPIs, performance metrics). A human-readable description ('4 of 5 accommodated') feels trustworthy and human. Taste model: 'Warm, not cold.' The framing centers the host's positive behavior rather than the guest's consumption of a resource. Taste model: 'The UI should adapt to who you are.' The Flexibility Score only appears when the guest has made at least one change request, avoiding an empty or zero-state that creates confusion for new guests.

coherence_note.note: This element was not explicitly categorized in the coherence report as a reinforcement, contradiction, or extension. Added as a new guest-perspective element.

elements.title: Stays Manager Weekly Return: Instant Recognition Without Re-Orientation
elements.problem: The guest returns to the Stays Manager weekly for 13+ weeks. Each visit is a micro-interaction: check current status, see if anything needs attention, leave. But the current flat table of stays forces the guest to re-orient on every visit -- scanning past completed rows to locate the current week. Kahneman's skill acquisition research shows that repeated tasks should become automatic through System 1 learning, but a table where the current row shifts downward each week defeats spatial memory. The guest's System 1 never develops a stable 'look here' pattern because the target moves. Every Monday morning, when the hybrid worker checks before heading to the property, they face a System 2 scan task on a page that should be a System 1 glance. The interaction pattern must make the 13th visit as effortless as the 3rd -- not harder because 12 completed rows now precede the current one.
elements.solution: On every page load, the Stays Manager auto-focuses the hero card for the current or next actionable stay at a fixed screen position (top of content area, never scrolled below the fold). The hero card animates in with a subtle entrance that confirms freshness ('this is new since your last visit') while maintaining positional consistency ('this is always where you look'). Completed stays collapse automatically below the hero card into a muted summary. Future stays collapse into a count. The page remembers the guest's last interaction state: if they expanded the full table last visit, it loads expanded again; otherwise it loads in hero-card mode. On return visits, if the status has changed since last visit (a stay moved from In Progress to Completed, a review became available), the hero card shows a brief change indicator -- a dot or subtle highlight that fades after 2 seconds -- so the guest knows something is different without reading the card. This change indicator is the key interaction distinction between 'first visit of the week' and 'return visit same week': the indicator only appears when something has changed.

evidence.quote: Monday to Friday is a very popular usage pattern... typically looking for really weeknights or weekdays each week... 2-3 month commitments typical.
evidence.insight: The hybrid worker visits the Stays Manager on a predictable weekly cadence. Each visit competes with work preparation for System 2 resources. The interaction must complete in a single glance -- under 3 seconds -- because the guest is not 'using the app,' they are checking a status before starting their work day.

evidence.quote: As you become skilled in a task, its demand for energy diminishes... A general 'law of least effort' applies to cognitive as well as physical exertion.
evidence.insight: Skill acquisition requires consistency. A hero card in a fixed position develops into a System 1 habit after 2-3 visits: the eye knows where to land. A shifting table row never becomes automatic because the spatial target changes weekly. The interaction pattern must provide the consistency that enables System 1 learning.

evidence.source: Split Lease - Complete Guest Journey.txt, lines 392-408
evidence.quote: Stays Table: Columns: Week #, Period (date range), Status (Not Started, In Progress, Completed), Actions. Available Actions: Review, Upload Photos, Report Issue, No action available.
evidence.insight: The current design gives every row equal interactive weight. 'No action available' rows are indistinguishable from actionable rows until the guest reads the action column. The interaction pattern must differentiate actionable from non-actionable states before the guest reaches for any control.

evidence.quote: System 2 also has a natural speed... there is little strain... Just like a stroll.
evidence.insight: The weekly check-in should be a cognitive stroll, not a jog. The interaction pattern achieves this by removing all parsing, scanning, and searching from the default view. The guest sees one card, reads one status, and either acts or leaves.

states.default: Hero card visible at fixed top position showing current/next stay with week number, date range, status badge, and primary action button. Completed stays collapsed into muted summary line below. Future stays collapsed into count.
states.loading: Hero card skeleton placeholder in exact hero card dimensions appears instantly (within 50ms) at the fixed position, preventing layout shift. Skeleton uses a gentle pulse animation at 1.5s cycle. The skeleton shape matches the hero card so the eye learns the position even during load.
states.empty: If no active lease exists (edge case: lease ended, guest still has access), the hero card position shows a completion summary: 'Your lease at [property] ended on [date]. [Leave Final Review].' No empty state with generic illustration -- always show the last relevant context.
states.error: If stay data fails to load, the hero card position shows a single-line error with retry: 'Could not load your stays. [Try again].' The error replaces the skeleton, not the entire page. Payment schedule and date change sections load independently so partial failures do not blank the whole page.
states.success: When a per-stay action completes (review submitted, photo uploaded, issue reported), the hero card action button transitions to a checkmark with confirmatory text ('Review submitted') that persists for 3 seconds before the button updates to the next available action or disappears. No full-page success toast that obscures the stays view.

elements.transition_principle: Every transition on this page must feel like turning a page in a familiar book, not like loading a new application. State changes within the hero card (status badge update, action button change) use crossfade transitions rather than layout shifts. The hero card never moves position -- content within it changes, but the card itself is spatially stable across all 13+ weekly visits.

timing.response_target: 50ms for skeleton render, 300ms for data paint, 200ms for state transitions within the hero card
timing.easing: cubic-bezier(0.16, 1, 0.3, 1)
timing.rationale: The tokens.json 'out' easing (0.16, 1, 0.3, 1) provides a fast start with gentle deceleration, matching the interaction pattern of a quick-check visit: the guest arrives with momentum (fast start) and settles into reading the status (gentle landing). The 200ms transition for in-card state changes is below the 300ms threshold where transitions become consciously noticed, keeping them in System 1 territory.

elements.journey_state_awareness: Week 1-2: hero card shows 'Getting Started' framing with a subtle orientation hint ('This card updates each week with your current stay'). Week 3+: orientation hint removed; the guest has learned the pattern. Week 12-13: hero card adds a 'Lease ending soon' contextual note. After final stay: hero card transforms into a completion/review prompt. The interaction evolves with the guest's lease lifecycle without requiring any explicit mode switching.
edge_cases: Guest visits mid-week when status is ambiguous (stay started but not yet 'In Progress' per system clock): hero card shows the stay with a 'Starting [day]' label rather than forcing a premature status badge.

Multiple active leases: a tab bar or property selector appears above the hero card, but the hero card pattern repeats identically for each lease. Switching leases animates the hero card content but not the card position.

Guest has not visited in 3+ weeks: hero card shows the most recent actionable stay, with a stacked indicator below showing missed review opportunities ('2 completed stays to review') rather than forcing a table scan.

Date change pending for current week: hero card shows the change request status inline ('Date change pending for Thu Oct 17 -- Waiting on host') rather than requiring navigation to the Date Change section.

coherence_note.note: This element was not explicitly categorized in the coherence report as a reinforcement, contradiction, or extension. Added as a new guest-perspective element.

elements.title: Inline Financial Consequence Preview: Show the Cost Before the Commitment
elements.problem: At every financial decision point -- selecting nights on a listing, configuring a proposal, requesting a date change -- the guest must understand the cost impact of their action before they commit. Currently, the listing page recalculates pricing dynamically when the guest changes inputs (days selected, duration, move-in date), but the recalculation produces three numbers (nightly rate, 4-week rent, total) at equal visual weight, forcing System 2 arithmetic. During date changes, the pricing section uses abstract labels ('fair market rate calculation') rather than computed dollar amounts. Kahneman's bat-and-ball research demonstrates that over 50% of elite university students fail simple arithmetic under cognitive ease. When the platform requires the guest to mentally translate nightly rates into monthly budgets, or to infer the cost of a date swap from a pricing policy description, the error rate is unacceptable and the cognitive drain prevents confident decision-making. The interaction pattern must ensure that every action with a financial consequence shows the consequence inline and pre-computed before the guest confirms.
elements.solution: Implement a universal 'preview before commit' interaction pattern at every financial touchpoint. The pattern works the same everywhere: (1) The guest takes an action that has financial implications (selects a night, changes a duration, picks a replacement date). (2) Within 200ms, a financial consequence preview appears inline -- adjacent to the action, not in a separate summary area. The preview shows one number: the delta from the current state ('+$0,' '+$15/night,' '-$80 refund'). (3) Only after seeing the preview can the guest confirm. The confirm action is not available until the preview has rendered. This prevents accidental commits before cost is understood. Implementation specifics: On the listing page, each day-of-week toggle shows its cost contribution inline when toggled ('+ $301/night' appears next to the toggled day). On the proposal configuration, changing duration shows the total delta ('Adding 2 weeks: +$2,408'). In date changes, each available date chip shows its cost difference from the original date. The pattern is: the financial preview is attached to the interaction element, not displayed in a separate summary section. The guest never has to look away from where they are acting to see what their action costs.

evidence.quote: It's not working financially... Originally when I... I believe $1,170, $1,175... the new dates are priced higher now.
evidence.insight: Seasonal pricing means the cost of a date change is not obvious. The guest who expects a free swap may face a $15/night increase. If this surprise arrives after submission (in a counter-offer from the host), trust is damaged. Showing the delta before submission converts a surprise into a transparent, accepted cost.

evidence.quote: More than 50% of students at Harvard, MIT, and Princeton gave the intuitive -- incorrect -- answer. Many people are overconfident, prone to place too much faith in their intuitions.
evidence.insight: The guest's intuition is that swapping dates is free. This intuition is wrong when seasonal pricing applies. The interaction pattern must override the intuition not through warnings or disclaimers but through pre-computed numbers that make the cost unmissable at the point of action.

evidence.source: Split Lease - Complete Guest Journey.txt, lines 419-428
evidence.quote: Change Types: Add nights (guest pays more), Remove nights (guest gets refund), Swap dates. Pricing: Buying back nights: Host pays guest. Adding nights: Guest pays host. Fair market rate calculation.
evidence.insight: The current design separates change types from pricing into two sections. The guest must cross-reference between them. The interaction pattern merges type and cost into a single visual unit so no cross-referencing is needed.

evidence.quote: Your System 1 made as much sense as possible of the situation... by linking the words in a causal story; it evaluated the possible threat... and created a context for future developments.
evidence.insight: System 1 creates a causal story for each action: 'I tap this date and it costs this much.' If the cost is not part of the story (because it is in a separate section), System 1 creates an incomplete story and the guest is surprised later. Attaching the cost to the action completes the story at the moment of choice.

states.default: Financial consequence preview is hidden until the guest interacts with a cost-bearing control. No preemptive cost display that adds visual noise before the guest has taken action.
states.loading: When the guest interacts with a cost-bearing control (toggles a day, selects a date), a compact cost label appears inline with a brief shimmer animation (150ms) while the backend computes the exact amount. If computation takes more than 200ms, a '...' placeholder appears in the cost label position so the guest knows a number is coming.
states.empty: If a cost-bearing action has no financial impact (swapping to a date in the same pricing season), the preview shows '+$0' explicitly rather than showing nothing. Showing the zero builds trust by demonstrating the system checks every change, even when the answer is 'no cost.'
states.error: If cost computation fails, the preview area shows 'Price unavailable -- [Retry]' and the confirm button is disabled. The guest cannot commit to an action whose cost is unknown. This is a hard block, not a soft warning, because financial surprises are the highest trust-destruction risk.
states.success: After the guest confirms the action, the cost preview transitions into a confirmation label: the delta amount remains visible but the framing shifts from preview to confirmed ('You will pay +$15' becomes 'Confirmed: +$15 added to your next payment').
