This label persists for 5 seconds then fades into the updated payment summary.

elements.transition_principle: Cost previews appear with a fast fade-in (100ms) and a subtle scale-up from 95% to 100%, creating a 'pop into existence' effect that draws the eye without being disruptive. Cost amounts animate numerically (counting up or down to the final value) over 200ms when the guest changes inputs, providing a sense of continuous calculation rather than discrete jumps. The confirm button enables with a simultaneous opacity transition (from 50% to 100%) and a slight upward shift (2px), signaling readiness without being aggressive.

timing.response_target: 100ms for preview appearance after interaction, 200ms for cost amount update on input change, 200ms maximum for backend cost computation on simple changes, 500ms maximum for complex multi-variable recalculations
timing.easing: cubic-bezier(0.16, 1, 0.3, 1)
timing.rationale: The out easing provides a fast attack (the cost appears quickly, matching the urgency of financial information) with a gentle settle (the number arrives at its final value smoothly, conveying precision rather than abruptness). The 100ms appearance time ensures the cost is visible before the guest's finger moves toward a confirm button, preventing accidental commits.

elements.journey_state_awareness: On the listing page (pre-commitment): cost previews are prominent and use larger type because the guest is still evaluating. During proposal configuration: cost previews use medium type because the guest is configuring, not browsing. In the Stays Manager date change flow: cost previews are compact because the guest is making a targeted micro-decision within an established relationship. The visual weight of the cost preview decreases as the guest's commitment level increases, reflecting that financial literacy about the lease grows over time.
edge_cases: Guest rapidly toggles multiple days on the listing page: cost updates debounce with a 150ms delay so the display does not flicker. The total updates once after the guest pauses, not on every individual toggle.
Cost computation returns a $0 delta that might confuse the guest (e.g., swapping two dates in the same pricing tier): show '+$0 -- same rate period' to explain why the swap is free.

Guest is on a slow connection and cost computation takes more than 500ms: the preview shows an animated '...' for up to 2 seconds, then falls back to 'Estimated: ~$X based on similar dates' with a note that the exact amount will be confirmed on submission.

The cost delta is negative (guest removes a night and gets a refund): display in green with a minus sign ('-$80 refund') using the success color token, signaling that this is money returned, not money owed.

coherence_note.note: This element was not explicitly categorized in the coherence report as a reinforcement, contradiction, or extension. Added as a new guest-perspective element.

elements.title: Payment Schedule as Passive Confidence, Not Active Monitoring
elements.problem: The Payment Schedule table in the Guest Leases page shows individual payment rows (Scheduled Date, Actual Date, Rent Amount, Maintenance Fee, Damage Deposit, Total, Payment Status, Receipt) without cumulative context. The guest must mentally track how much they have paid versus how much remains. For a 13-week lease with monthly payments, this means 3-4 payment rows that the guest scans on each visit to verify nothing unexpected happened. Kahneman's ego depletion research shows that monitoring tasks -- even low-effort ones -- draw from the same depleted pool as the guest's work responsibilities. A payment table that requires verification on every visit is a low-grade cognitive tax that accumulates over the lease. The interaction pattern must make payment status a passive confidence signal (everything is fine, I can see it at a glance) rather than an active monitoring task (let me check each row to make sure nothing is wrong).
elements.solution: Replace active table monitoring with a passive summary bar that sits at the top of the Payment Schedule section. The summary bar shows: 'Paid: $4,380 of $11,738' with a visual progress indicator. If the next payment is upcoming, it adds: 'Next: $1,460 on Nov 26.' If a payment failed or is overdue, the summary bar changes color (amber for upcoming/warning, red for failed/overdue) and shows the issue: 'Payment of $1,460 due Nov 26 -- card declined. [Update payment method].' The detailed table exists below the summary bar for guests who want to verify individual payments, but the summary bar answers the three questions the guest actually has: (1) Am I on track? (2) What is next? (3) Is anything wrong? These three answers are visible without scrolling and without reading any table rows. The interaction pattern for the summary bar is entirely passive: it updates automatically when payments process, requires no guest interaction, and changes color only when attention is needed. On weekly visits where everything is on track, the guest glances at the green progress bar and moves on. This is the 'everything is fine' System 1 signal that prevents unnecessary System 2 engagement.

evidence.source: Split Lease - Complete Guest Journey.txt, lines 369-386
evidence.quote: Payment Schedule Table: Columns: Scheduled Date, Actual Date, Rent Amount, Maintenance Fee, Damage Deposit, Total, Payment Status, Receipt (downloadable).
evidence.insight: Six columns of financial data per row is a System 2 parsing task. The guest must read Payment Status to know if everything is fine. If the status is always 'Paid,' reading it every week is wasted effort. A green progress bar at the top communicates 'all payments current' without requiring any row-level scanning.

evidence.quote: System 2 also has a natural speed... there is little strain. You make many small decisions as you drive your car... all with little effort and no strain.
evidence.insight: The weekly payment check should have the cognitive strain of checking a fuel gauge: a glance at a bar, not a reading of a spreadsheet. The progress bar interaction pattern converts a six-column table scan into a single-element glance.

evidence.quote: Originally when I... I believe $1,170, $1,175.
evidence.insight: Both parties reference pricing in aggregate monthly terms. The payment summary bar should show aggregate paid/remaining, matching the mental model. Individual payment rows are verification data for disputes, not weekly monitoring data.

evidence.quote: You dispose of a limited budget of attention that you can allocate to activities.
evidence.insight: Every weekly table scan, even a quick one, consumes attention budget. Over 13 weeks, this is 13 table scans that serve no purpose when payments are on track. A progress bar that never changes color returns that attention budget to the guest's work and life.

states.default: Summary bar at top of Payment Schedule section showing progress (paid/total), next payment date and amount, and a calm visual indicator (green/accent progress fill). Detailed table collapsed below with an expand control. The summary bar is always visible; the table is opt-in.
states.loading: Summary bar skeleton renders with a progress bar placeholder at the correct width (based on cached data from last visit if available). The skeleton prevents layout shift and communicates 'your payment info goes here' even before data loads.
states.empty: Before the first payment (new lease, no payments processed yet): summary bar shows 'First payment: $1,460 on [date]. Auto-pay is [enabled/not set up].' with a call-to-action to set up auto-pay if not configured. No empty progress bar that looks like $0 paid.
states.error: Payment failed: summary bar background transitions to signal-warn-bg (#fef3e2) with signal-warn text. Content updates to: 'Payment of $1,460 on [date] was not processed. [Update payment method].' The summary bar becomes the most prominent element on the page, overriding even the hero card's visual hierarchy, because a payment failure is the highest-urgency state in the active lease.
states.success: When a payment processes successfully, the progress bar extends smoothly (300ms, out easing) to its new position, and a brief confirmation appears: 'Payment of $1,460 processed successfully' with a receipt download link. The confirmation fades after 5 seconds, and the summary bar returns to its calm default state.

elements.transition_principle: The payment summary bar is the calmest element on the Stays Manager page. It rarely changes. When it does change (payment processed, payment failed), the transition is deliberate and noticeable -- not because it needs to be dramatic, but because any change to a normally-calm element is inherently noticeable. Kahneman's violation model applies: System 1 notices the change precisely because the element is usually static. This means the payment summary bar can use minimal animation and still capture attention when something changes.

timing.response_target: Summary bar data loads within 300ms (cached from last visit, refreshed in background). Progress bar extension on payment: 300ms. Error state transition: 200ms. Confirmation fade: 5000ms display then 500ms fade.
timing.easing: cubic-bezier(0.16, 1, 0.3, 1)
timing.rationale: The out easing for progress bar extension creates a smooth, unhurried movement that conveys reliability -- the payment system is working steadily. The 300ms duration is slow enough to be perceived as a real update (not a glitch) but fast enough to not demand sustained attention.

elements.journey_state_awareness: First payment cycle: summary bar includes a one-time note ('Your first payment was processed on [date]. You will be charged $1,460 every 4 weeks.'). Mid-lease: summary bar shows just the progress and next payment. Final payment: summary bar highlights 'Final payment: $1,460 on [date]. This is your last scheduled payment.' Post-lease: summary bar shows 'All payments complete. Total paid: $11,738. [Download all receipts].'
edge_cases: Guest has auto-pay disabled and a payment is upcoming within 7 days: summary bar shows a gentle amber reminder ('Payment of $1,460 due in 3 days. [Pay now]') without alarm. The guest may prefer manual payment.
Payment amount changes due to a date change mid-cycle: summary bar shows the updated amount with a brief note ('Adjusted from $1,460 to $1,475 due to date change on [date]. [See details]').

Guest disputes a payment: summary bar shows 'Payment dispute in progress. [View status].' The disputed payment row in the table is highlighted but the summary bar does not turn red (disputes are not failures).

Multiple leases with different payment schedules: each lease's payment summary bar is independent, visible only when that lease's tab is selected. No combined financial view that mixes payments across properties.

coherence_note.note: This element was not explicitly categorized in the coherence report as a reinforcement, contradiction, or extension. Added as a new guest-perspective element.

elements.title: Batched Review Prompts at Natural Reflection Points, Not Per-Stay Interruptions
elements.problem: The Stays Manager activates a 'Review' button after every completed stay. Over a 13-week lease, this creates 13 review prompts that accumulate as an unfinished to-do list visible on every visit. Kahneman's ego depletion research shows that sequential self-control tasks drain from a shared pool: the first review is thoughtful, but by Week 5, the guest's System 2 has been depleted by four prior reviews plus their work responsibilities. The interaction problem is not just fatigue -- it is that the accumulating unreviewd stays create a guilt signal on every visit. The Stays Manager, which should feel like a helpful dashboard, starts to feel like a nagging task list. The guest who ignores 5 review buttons feels irresponsible; the guest who dutifully completes them feels drained. Neither outcome serves the guest or the platform. The interaction pattern must collect high-quality feedback without converting the Stays Manager into an obligation.
elements.solution: Replace per-stay review buttons with three batched review moments at natural lease milestones: after Week 4 (first payment cycle), at the lease midpoint, and after the final stay. Each review moment appears as a highlighted card in the hero position of the Stays Manager, gently displacing the weekly status card for one visit. The review card includes pre-filled context (the weeks covered, the property name, a sentence summarizing the period) and asks for a single overall rating plus one optional text field. The interaction is: see the card, tap a rating, optionally type a sentence, submit. Under 90 seconds. Between review moments, completed stays show a muted 'Reviewed' or 'Review at Week [N]' label rather than active 'Review' buttons. The key interaction principle: the review card appears once at each milestone, and if dismissed without completion, it moves to a secondary position (below the hero card) for the next 2 visits, then disappears entirely. The platform does not nag. Three thoughtful reviews at reflection points yield richer data than thirteen perfunctory star ratings.

evidence.source: Split Lease - Complete Guest Journey.txt, lines 453-459
evidence.quote: After each stay: 'Review' button becomes active. Guest rates property/host. Rates on: Cleanliness, accuracy, communication. Writes text review (optional).
evidence.insight: 13 active Review buttons over 13 weeks creates an accumulating to-do list. Each unreviewd stay is a small guilt signal. The interaction pattern must eliminate this accumulation by collecting feedback at defined intervals rather than after every single stay.

evidence.source: kahneman-part1-two-systems.txt, The Busy and Depleted System 2
evidence.quote: An effort of will or self-control is tiring; if you have had to force yourself to do something, you are less willing or less able to exert self-control when the next challenge comes around.
evidence.insight: Each review is a self-control task: recall the week, evaluate three dimensions, compose optional text. The depletion from one review reduces the likelihood and quality of the next. Batching to three review moments respects the depletion curve: the guest gives feedback when they have something meaningful to reflect on, not when the system's per-week data structure demands it.

evidence.quote: Hybrid workers... typically looking for really weeknights or weekdays each week.
evidence.insight: The target guest is a working professional. Their cognitive budget for platform administration is minimal. The interaction pattern must treat review as a secondary activity that fits into the guest's existing weekly visit pattern, not as a primary obligation that demands a separate session.

evidence.quote: We normally avoid mental overload by dividing our tasks into multiple easy steps, committing intermediate results to long-term memory or to paper rather than to an easily overloaded working memory.
evidence.insight: Kahneman advocates dividing tasks into easy steps, but the current design over-divides: 13 micro-reviews are individually easy but collectively overwhelming. The batched approach consolidates to 3 meaningful reflection moments that are richer and lighter.

states.default: Between review milestones: no review prompts visible. Completed stays show a small 'Reviewed' chip or 'Review at Week [N]' note in muted text. The Stays Manager is a clean status dashboard, not a task list.
states.loading: Review card skeleton renders in the hero position with a star rating placeholder and text field outline. The skeleton establishes that a review is being requested before the context data loads, giving the guest a moment to prepare mentally.
states.empty: If the review milestone is reached but no stays are completed (unlikely edge case): the review card does not appear. Reviews are only prompted when there is something to review. No 'You have no stays to review' empty state.
states.error: If review submission fails, the review card shows an inline error: 'Could not save your review. [Try again].' The guest's rating and text input are preserved so they do not need to re-enter. The card does not disappear on error.
states.success: On submission, the review card plays a brief thank-you animation: the star rating pulses once, a checkmark appears, and the card shrinks smoothly (300ms, out easing) to reveal the hero card beneath. A small toast appears: 'Thank you for your feedback.' No full-page celebration that feels disproportionate to a review submission.

elements.transition_principle: The review card enters from above (sliding down into hero position, 250ms, out easing) on the first visit after a milestone, displacing the weekly hero card downward. This spatial relationship communicates that the review is temporarily more important than the weekly status, but the weekly status is still present below. When the review is submitted or dismissed, it exits upward (sliding up, 200ms, out easing) and the hero card slides back up to its default position. The movement metaphor is: the review card is a brief visitor in the hero position, not a permanent resident.

timing.response_target: Review card appearance: 250ms slide-in on page load at milestone visit. Star rating tap response: immediate (<50ms). Review submission: 500ms maximum server response. Success animation: 300ms. Card exit: 200ms.
timing.easing: cubic-bezier(0.16, 1, 0.3, 1)
timing.rationale: The out easing for the review card's entrance and exit creates a smooth, non-jarring insertion into the page flow. The 250ms entrance is slow enough to be noticed (the guest should see the review card arrive) but fast enough to not feel like a loading delay. The 200ms exit is faster than the entrance because dismissal should feel swift and decisive.

elements.journey_state_awareness: Week 4 review: framed as 'first impressions' ('How were your first 4 weeks at [property]?'). Midpoint review: framed as 'settled-in assessment' ('You are halfway through. How is the space working for your routine?'). Final review: framed as 'overall experience' ('Your lease at [property] has ended. How was the experience overall?'). Each framing gives the guest a cognitive anchor for their reflection, reducing the effort of generating a response from scratch.
edge_cases: Guest dismisses the Week 4 review card: it moves to secondary position (below hero card) for 2 visits, then disappears. If still unreviewed by midpoint, the midpoint review covers Weeks 1 through midpoint instead of just the recent period.
Guest's lease is shorter than 8 weeks (no midpoint): only two review moments -- after Week 4 and after the final stay.

Guest wants to review a specific week in detail: an 'Add details for a specific week' expand option within the batched review card lets the guest drill into individual weeks. This is opt-in, never required.

Guest submits a very negative review: the review card does not immediately close. It shows a follow-up prompt: 'Would you like to report a specific issue? [Report issue]' -- connecting the review to the action system rather than leaving negative feedback as a dead end.

coherence_note.note: This element was not explicitly categorized in the coherence report as a reinforcement, contradiction, or extension. Added as a new guest-perspective element.

elements.title: The Waiting Ache: Resolving Proposal Anxiety Through Status Visibility
elements.problem: After submitting a proposal, the guest enters an emotionally vulnerable state: they have committed to wanting a place to stay, but they do not know if they will get it. Kahneman describes how System 2 is activated when 'an event is detected that violates the model of the world that System 1 maintains.' The guest's model after submission is 'I acted, something should happen.' When the platform shows no change -- no acknowledgment, no timeline, no indication that the host has seen the proposal -- System 2 stays activated in monitoring mode. This is not a one-time activation; it is a persistent, low-grade cognitive drain that competes with the guest's work responsibilities. Brad's behavior confirms this pattern: he texts Nneka directly because the platform provides no channel for resolving the uncertainty. The emotional cost of this opacity is not just anxiety -- it is helplessness. The guest cannot do anything to accelerate the process, cannot see whether progress is happening, and cannot plan their housing situation. Helplessness is the most disempowering emotion a platform can inflict, and it is entirely created by the absence of status information.
elements.solution: Replace helplessness with informed patience. At every stage of the proposal pipeline, provide three pieces of emotional infrastructure: (1) Acknowledgment: 'Your proposal was received and sent to [host name].' This validates the guest's action. (2) Timeline: 'Hosts typically respond within 48 hours. Submitted 14 hours ago.' This converts open-ended uncertainty into bounded waiting. (3) Agency: 'If you do not hear back by [date], you can send a reminder or contact support.' This gives the guest a future action to hold onto, preventing the feeling that they are entirely at the mercy of the host. The emotional principle is: the guest can tolerate waiting if they know what they are waiting for, how long it should take, and what they can do if it takes too long. Open-ended, information-free waiting is emotionally intolerable. Bounded, transparent waiting is manageable.

evidence.quote: He was texting me and saying, Hey, you know, I can't make it for another day... if I have availability.
evidence.insight: Brad texts because the platform provides no status channel. The emotional driver is not impatience -- it is the inability to tolerate uncertainty without any information. A status display that says 'waiting on host, expected response within 48 hours' would reduce the emotional urgency of the text.

evidence.quote: System 2 is activated when an event is detected that violates the model of the world that System 1 maintains.
evidence.insight: The guest's mental model after submission is 'something should happen next.' When nothing visibly happens, System 2 activates to monitor the gap. This activation is emotionally experienced as anxiety -- the cognitive strain of unresolved uncertainty. Status updates resolve the gap by confirming that the process is proceeding even when the guest cannot see it.

elements.emotion_rationale: Assurance is the opposite of helplessness. The guest who feels assured knows that the process is working, knows when to expect a result, and knows what they can do if the result does not arrive. Assurance does not require certainty of outcome -- it requires certainty of process. A guest can be assured that 'hosts typically respond within 48 hours' even though they do not know what the response will be.

do: Name the person the guest is waiting on: 'Waiting on [host name]' not 'Waiting on host response'
Provide specific time context: 'Submitted 14 hours ago' and 'Hosts typically respond within 48 hours'
Offer a future action: 'No response by Friday? You can send a reminder.'
Acknowledge the guest's emotional state implicitly: 'We will notify you the moment [host name] responds' -- the promise of notification is itself reassuring
dont: Use vague status language: 'Processing' without a timeline is anxiety, not information
Over-reassure: 'Do not worry! Your host will get back to you soon!' -- this patronizes the guest and provides no useful information
Hide the elapsed time: showing 'Submitted 14 hours ago' is more comforting than hiding the clock, because it proves the system is tracking
Make the guest feel they must monitor: 'Check back soon for updates' creates an obligation to poll, which is the opposite of assurance
copy_guidelines.example_good: Waiting on Nneka. Submitted 14h ago. Hosts typically respond within 48h. We will notify you when she responds.
copy_guidelines.example_bad: Your proposal is being reviewed. Please check back later for updates.

animation_feel.feel_description: A patient pulse. During waiting states, the current pipeline stage uses a very slow, barely perceptible breathing animation on the action assignment tag (opacity oscillates between 0.8 and 1.0 over 3 seconds). This communicates 'the system is alive and watching' without creating urgency. The sensation is like seeing the steady blink of a charging indicator -- it confirms activity without demanding attention. When the status changes (host responds), the breathing stops and the stage transition animation plays, creating a crisp contrast between waiting and progress.
animation_feel.duration_range: 3000ms breathing cycle during waiting states; 300-400ms for stage transition animations

tension_relief.tension_point: The guest submitted a proposal or date change request and does not know if it was seen, is being reviewed, or was forgotten.
tension_relief.relief_point: The pipeline shows exactly who must act, how long ago the request was sent, and what the expected response time is. A push notification confirms the moment the host responds.
tension_relief.timing: Partial relief is immediate (status display on submission). Full relief arrives when the host responds (push notification + pipeline update). The design must provide enough partial relief that the guest does not feel compelled to text the host or check the platform repeatedly.

personalization_signals: Use the host's actual name in status messages: 'Waiting on Nneka' not 'Waiting on host'
Show the host's typical response time if data is available: 'Nneka usually responds within 12 hours'
After the first proposal, subsequent proposals skip instructional text and show just the status
If the guest has previously experienced a fast host response, set expectations accordingly: 'Nneka responded to your last request in 6 hours'

anti_patterns.pattern: A waiting state with no timeline, no action assignment, and no future agency
anti_patterns.reason: Open-ended, information-free waiting triggers helplessness -- the most disempowering emotion in a platform experience. The guest cannot plan, cannot act, and cannot even estimate when they will be able to plan or act. This is the emotional state that drives off-platform workarounds (texting the host) and eventually platform abandonment.
anti_patterns.example_bad: Your proposal is under review. We will let you know when there is an update.

coherence_note.note: This element was not explicitly categorized in the coherence report as a reinforcement, contradiction, or extension. Added as a new guest-perspective element.

elements.title: The Administrative Guilt Accumulator: Transforming Obligation Into Reflection
elements.problem: The Stays Manager activates a 'Review' button after every completed stay. Over 13 weeks, unreviewed stays accumulate as a visible to-do list on the page the guest visits weekly. Each unreviewed stay is a small guilt signal: the platform is silently asking 'Why have you not reviewed Week 3 yet?' while the guest is just trying to check their current week status. Kahneman's ego depletion research shows that the guilt from unfinished tasks draws from the same System 2 pool as the tasks themselves -- meaning the guilt is cognitively depleting even when the guest does not act on it. The emotional trajectory is: Week 1-3, the guest dutifully reviews each stay. Week 4-6, reviews become perfunctory (5 stars, no text). Week 7+, the guest stops reviewing but sees the accumulating 'Review' buttons on every visit, creating a background hum of guilt that makes the Stays Manager feel like a nagging parent rather than a helpful dashboard. By Week 13, the guest's emotional association with the Stays Manager is 'the page that makes me feel behind' rather than 'the page that helps me manage my stay.' This emotional contamination damages the guest's entire relationship with the platform.
elements.solution: Eliminate the guilt accumulator by replacing per-stay review buttons with three batched review moments at natural reflection points (Week 4, midpoint, final). Between review moments, the Stays Manager shows no review prompts at all. Completed stays display 'Reviewed' or remain quietly unmarked -- never an active 'Review' button that the guest must consciously choose to ignore. When a batched review moment arrives, it appears as a warm invitation, not an obligation: 'You have been here 4 weeks. How is it going?' rather than 'Rate your stay for Week 1, Week 2, Week 3, and Week 4.' The emotional reframe is: reviewing is a moment of reflection offered at the right time, not an ongoing obligation imposed by the platform's data structure. The guest should feel 'Oh, time to reflect on how this is going' (pleasant) not 'Oh, I still have not reviewed five stays' (guilt).

evidence.quote: An effort of will or self-control is tiring; if you have had to force yourself to do something, you are less willing or less able to exert self-control when the next challenge comes around.
evidence.insight: The guilt of unreviewed stays is itself a form of ego depletion. Each time the guest sees a 'Review' button and decides not to act, they exert self-control (resisting the guilt). This depletion accumulates over weeks, making the Stays Manager feel increasingly burdensome even when the guest is not reviewing.

evidence.quote: Hybrid workers... typically looking for really weeknights or weekdays each week.
evidence.insight: The target guest is a busy professional. Administrative guilt from a housing platform competes with professional obligations for the same depleted cognitive resources. A platform that makes the guest feel 'behind' on reviews while they are already behind on work emails creates an emotional association that discourages return visits.

elements.emotion_rationale: Lightness is the absence of unnecessary weight. The Stays Manager should feel like a surface the guest bounces off of quickly -- check status, see nothing needs attention, leave. Accumulated review obligations add weight that slows each visit and darkens the emotional tone. Lightness is achieved by removing the weight: no visible obligations, no guilt signals, no accumulating to-do list. The guest feels light when the platform asks nothing of them on most visits and offers a natural reflection moment on a few.

do: Frame reviews as reflection: 'You have been here 4 weeks. How is it going?' invites thought rather than demanding compliance
Acknowledge that reviews are optional in the framing: 'If you have a moment' or 'When you are ready'
Pre-fill context so the guest does not have to recall specifics: 'Your stays covered Oct 1-25 at [property]'
After submission, thank briefly and naturally: 'Thanks. Your feedback helps [host name] improve.'
dont: Show accumulating 'Review' buttons on completed stays -- this is the single biggest emotional anti-pattern in the Stays Manager
Use obligation language: 'You have 5 unreviewed stays' or 'Please review your recent stays'
Send reminder emails or notifications about pending reviews -- this extends the guilt off-platform
Make the review a blocking condition for anything: 'Complete your review to access [feature]'
copy_guidelines.example_good: You have been at [property] for 4 weeks now. Got a minute to share how it is going?
copy_guidelines.example_bad: You have 4 unreviewed stays. Please rate your experience for: Week 1, Week 2, Week 3, Week 4.

animation_feel.feel_description: A gentle arrival. The batched review card slides down into the hero position from above with a slow, gravity-like ease -- it descends into view like a note being placed on a table, not like a notification demanding attention. If dismissed, the card slides back up and out with a lighter, faster motion, communicating 'no pressure, it is gone.' The sensation is an invitation that respects a declined response.
animation_feel.duration_range: 250ms entrance, 200ms dismissal (faster out than in, respecting the 'no thanks' decision)

tension_relief.tension_point: The guest sees accumulating unreviewed stays and feels guilty about not completing them, or feels burdened by the platform's persistent ask.
tension_relief.relief_point: With batched reviews, the Stays Manager shows no review obligations on 10 out of 13 weekly visits. The three review moments are framed as invitations, not demands. Dismissing a review prompt has no visible consequence -- no accumulating badge, no guilt signal.
tension_relief.timing: The relief is structural, not momentary: the guest feels lighter on every visit because the page never shows a to-do list. The three review moments each last one visit (if dismissed, they move to secondary position for 2 more visits, then disappear entirely).

personalization_signals: Review prompt references the specific weeks and dates covered, not generic 'your stays'
If the guest submitted a previous batched review, the midpoint review acknowledges it: 'You shared your thoughts at Week 4. How have things been since?'
If the guest's prior review was negative, the review prompt gently checks in: 'You flagged some concerns at Week 4. Have things improved?'
Final review uses a warm lease-end framing: 'Your time at [property] is wrapping up. Looking back, how was it?'

anti_patterns.pattern: Displaying a 'Review' button on every completed stay row in the Stays Table
anti_patterns.reason: Accumulating review buttons create a guilt accumulator that worsens on every visit. By Week 8, the guest sees 5+ unreviewed stays, which makes the Stays Manager feel like a list of failures rather than a helpful dashboard. The emotional contamination from this pattern poisons the guest's entire experience of the page they visit most often.
anti_patterns.example_bad: Week 1: [Review] | Week 2: [Review] | Week 3: [Review] | Week 4: [Review] | Week 5: [Review] -- all visible simultaneously in the stays table.

coherence_note.note: This element was not explicitly categorized in the coherence report as a reinforcement, contradiction, or extension. Added as a new guest-perspective element.

elements.title: Mutual Pledge Card
elements.problem: Booking feels like a one-way consumer transaction rather than two people choosing each other, producing weak commitments that lead to cancellations and distrust.
elements.solution: A split-screen commitment card shown at the acceptance stage of the proposal flow. The left half shows the host's pledge (welcome message, what they commit to providing, their expectations), and the right half shows the guest's pledge (introduction, what they commit to respecting, their stay purpose). Both sides fill in progressively as each party contributes, and a central 'handshake' visual locks when both pledges are complete. The card becomes a permanent artifact visible to both parties throughout the lease.

source_lens.book: Influence The Psychology of Persuasion  Robert Cialdini.pdf

elements.title: People-Like-You Review Filter
elements.problem: Reviews are an undifferentiated mass  a 4.9 from 200 people tells you nothing about whether people in YOUR situation had a good experience, leaving the most persuasive form of social proof (similarity-matched) completely untapped.
elements.solution: A review section enhancement for the listing page that adds horizontally scrollable filter chips above the reviews. Chips represent stay-context categories: 'Remote Workers,' 'Traveling Nurses,' 'Relocating,' '4+ Week Stays,' 'Solo Guests.' Selecting a chip filters reviews to show only those from matching guests, with a summary stat: 'Remote workers rate this space 4.8  workspace quality highlighted in 12 of 15 reviews.' When no filter is active, the full aggregate view shows. A small 'people like you' badge auto-suggests a filter based on the guest's profile.

source_lens.book: Influence The Psychology of Persuasion  Robert Cialdini.pdf

elements.title: Pre-Arrival Conversation Guide
elements.problem: The messaging interface is a blank pipe  neither host nor guest knows what to say, when to say it, or whether communication is even expected, causing pluralistic ignorance that suppresses the trust-building micro-commitments that predict stay satisfaction.
elements.solution: A guided conversation module that appears in the messaging thread between acceptance and move-in. It presents 3-4 suggested conversation topics as expandable cards: 'Arrival Details,' 'Workspace Setup,' 'House Rhythm,' and 'Neighborhood Tips.' Each card includes a pre-written message template the guest can customize and send. A subtle social proof line reads 'Most guests discuss these topics before arriving.' As each topic is covered, it checks off with a satisfying micro-animation. The guide is suggestive, not mandatory  it can be collapsed at any time.

source_lens.book: Influence The Psychology of Persuasion  Robert Cialdini.pdf

elements.title: Post-Review Forward Commitment Bridge
elements.problem: The post-review moment  when the guest has just publicly committed to a positive narrative  is the peak of psychological consistency pressure, but every platform treats it as a dead end instead of a bridge to the next commitment.
elements.solution: A card that appears immediately after the guest submits a positive review (4+ stars). Instead of a generic 'Thanks for your review,' it reflects the guest's own words back to them and offers three forward-commitment paths: (1) Save this host for next time, (2) See this host's upcoming availability, (3) Share your experience to help someone like you find this space. It also surfaces the guest's emerging identity: 'You've now stayed with 3 hosts across 2 cities on Split Lease.' The card is warm, personal, and leverages the peak moment.

source_lens.book: Influence The Psychology of Persuasion  Robert Cialdini.pdf

elements.title: Stay Purpose Selector
elements.problem: Guests arrive at search as anonymous browsers with unspoken, uncommitted preferences  the platform never asks who they are or what they need, leaving the most powerful commitment device (visible preference declaration) completely unused.
elements.solution: A lightweight preference declaration step that appears at the top of the search experience. Three large, illustrated tap targets ask: 'What brings you to Split Lease?' with options like 'Working remotely,' 'Traveling for work,' 'Relocating.' Selecting one triggers a follow-up: 'What matters most?' with 2-3 quick-pick priority chips (e.g., 'Quiet workspace,' 'Close to transit,' 'Budget-friendly'). The selections persist as a visible bar above search results: 'Remote Worker  Workspace matters most.' This bar creates the commitment anchor that Cialdini predicts will drive decisive action.

source_lens.book: Influence The Psychology of Persuasion  Robert Cialdini.pdf

elements.title: Commitment Reassurance Badge
elements.problem: At the peak commitment moment  when the guest is about to submit a proposal  there is zero social proof to reassure them, creating a 'checkout desert' where doubt is highest and psychological support is absent.
elements.solution: A compact reassurance badge that appears on the proposal summary screen, just above the 'Submit Proposal' button. It contains two pieces of dynamically-generated social proof: (1) a host satisfaction metric ('Guests who stayed with Sarah rated their experience 4.9/5') and (2) a commitment-specific reassurance ('97% of guests who proposed to this host had their proposal accepted'). The badge is subtle  it doesn't scream  but its placement at the peak uncertainty moment leverages Cialdini's finding that social proof is most influential during uncertainty.

source_lens.book: Influence The Psychology of Persuasion  Robert Cialdini.pdf

elements.name: Stay-Cycle Micro-Review Pulse
elements.problem_it_solves: Replaces the impossible task of compressing 90 days into a single retrospective form with a one-tap weekly pulse that captures impressions at the moment of peak recall.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No competitor has per-stay-cycle review capture because OTAs have no concept of stay cycles within a lease -- their data model treats every booking as an atomic event with one review opportunity, while Split Lease's Stays Manager creates 13+ natural touchpoints per lease.
elements.description: A compact card that appears at the bottom of the Stays Manager after each weekly stay is marked complete. It shows the stay dates, asks a single sentiment question ('How was this stay?') via three emoji-free tap targets (Great / Fine / Rough), and optionally expands for a one-line note. The card is non-blocking -- the guest can dismiss it and return later. Over 13+ stays, these micro-pulses accumulate into a rich temporal review narrative visible on the guest's review timeline.

visual_spec.layout: Vertical flex container, max-width 400px, centered in Stays Manager column
visual_spec.background: #ffffff with left-side 3px accent border in secondary-purple
visual_spec.color_usage: Secondary purple for the left accent bar and selected state; bg-off-white for hover on tap targets; primary purple for the optional note expand trigger

interaction_spec.default_state: Card visible with three tap targets in neutral state; note field collapsed
interaction_spec.hover: Tap targets gain subtle purple background (rgba(140, 104, 238, 0.08)) and slight scale(1.02)
interaction_spec.click: Selected option fills with secondary-purple background and white text; optional note field slides down with 200ms ease-out; card auto-dismisses after 2 seconds if no note is added
interaction_spec.animation: Card entrance: translateY(8px) to 0 with 300ms ease-out; selection: background-color 150ms; note expand: max-height 200ms ease-out
interaction_spec.responsive: Full-width on mobile with 16px horizontal padding; tap targets become 48px tall minimum touch targets

copy_spec.secondary_text: Feb 3 - Feb 9 at Marcus's Room in Harlem
do: Use conversational tone -- this is a check-in, not a survey
Reference the specific stay dates and property name
Keep the prompt to one line maximum
dont: Never say 'rate' or 'review' -- this is a pulse, not a form
Never use numeric scales -- the three options are sufficient
Never make the note field feel required

elements.html_css:
Feb 3 - Feb 9 Marcus's Room in Harlem
How was this stay?
▲ Great
▬ Fine
▼ Rough
Stay 5 of 13

before_after.before: Booking.com: Zero review capture during a 90-day stay. One post-checkout email triggers a 7-subcategory retrospective form. The guest must compress months of experience into a single session from faded memory.
before_after.after: Split Lease: After each weekly stay, a gentle one-tap pulse appears in the Stays Manager the guest already visits. Over 13 stays, a temporal review narrative accumulates automatically. The end-of-lease review is a confirmation of signals already captured, not a cold-start recall exercise.

elements.name: Stay-Cycle Review Timeline
elements.problem_it_solves: Transforms accumulated micro-review pulses into a visible temporal narrative that rewards the reviewer with a sense of growing contribution and gives future guests a chronological view of the stay experience no competitor offers.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No competitor structures reviews around the chronological phases of a stay because they treat every booking as a single atomic event -- Split Lease is the only platform with per-stay-cycle data to render a temporal review narrative.
elements.description: A horizontal timeline visualization that appears both in the guest's own review history (Reward of the Self) and on the property listing for future guests (Reward of the Hunt). Each weekly stay is a node on the timeline showing the sentiment pulse (Great/Fine/Rough) with optional notes. The timeline reveals patterns over time: a property that starts 'Great' and stays 'Great' for 13 weeks tells a different story than one that dips to 'Rough' at week 6 when the heater broke. For the reviewer, seeing their pulses accumulate provides the Variable Reward that Booking.com's void-after-submission never delivers.

visual_spec.layout: Horizontal scrollable flex container with connected timeline nodes
visual_spec.border_radius: 12px for outer card, 50% for timeline nodes

typography.heading: Inter 16px/700 for section title
typography.body: DM Sans 12px/400 for dates and notes
typography.accent: Inter 11px/600 for labels and node markers

visual_spec.color_usage: Secondary purple for 'Great' nodes, accent-purple at 50% opacity for 'Fine' nodes, text-muted with border for 'Rough' nodes; connecting line in border-light color; active/current node gets a pulsing ring in accent-purple

interaction_spec.default_state: Timeline visible with all completed stay nodes; current stay node has a subtle pulse animation
interaction_spec.hover: Hovering a node expands to show the date range and any note; tooltip appears with 150ms delay
interaction_spec.click: Clicking a node scrolls to the detailed note if one exists; on the listing page, clicking filters the full review text to that period
interaction_spec.animation: Nodes enter sequentially with 50ms stagger on page load; hover tooltip fades in 150ms; connecting line draws left-to-right on first view with 800ms duration
interaction_spec.responsive: On mobile, timeline becomes vertical with nodes stacked; scroll becomes vertical; notes appear inline below each node

copy_spec.secondary_text: 13 weeks at Marcus's Room in Harlem
do: Label by week number for the reviewer's own view
Label by date range for the public listing view
Show the overall pattern, not just individual data points
dont: Never show individual micro-reviews on the public listing without the reviewer's consent
Never display the timeline if fewer than 3 data points exist -- show a progress message instead
Never use red/green traffic-light colors -- stay within the purple palette

before_after.before: Booking.com: A flat composite score (8.7) with no temporal dimension. A 3-month stay and a 2-night visit look identical. No way to see how the experience evolved over time, whether issues were resolved, or when problems occurred.
before_after.after: Split Lease: A visual timeline showing week-by-week sentiment across the entire lease. Future guests can see that the heater broke in week 6 but was fixed the next day -- a story that a flat score can never tell. The reviewer sees their contribution growing each week.

elements.name: Vetting Trust Shield
elements.problem_it_solves: Fills the trust desert for new and low-review listings by surfacing operational vetting data that Split Lease already collects -- employment verification, credit checks, landlord references -- as visible trust signals that function as pre-booking review equivalents.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No OTA performs deep vetting (employment, credit, landlord references) because their business model does not justify it for 2-night stays -- Split Lease already has this data as a core business process, making it a zero-cost trust signal that competitors cannot acquire without rebuilding their entire onboarding.
elements.description: A compact trust shield card that appears on every listing, replacing the empty review section for new properties with concrete operational data. It displays verification badges (ID verified, employment verified, credit checked), behavioral metrics from platform data (average host response time, lease renewal rate, guest completion rate), and vetting status for incoming guests. The card resolves the internal trigger of commitment anxiety ('Is this legit?') that Tag, Patricia, Michael, and Susan all expressed in transcripts, using data the platform already possesses.

visual_spec.layout: Vertical flex card with horizontal badge row and vertical metric list
visual_spec.background: Linear gradient from #ffffff to rgba(252, 250, 255, 1) (subtle purple tint)
visual_spec.border: 1px solid rgba(49, 19, 93, 0.1); top border 2px solid secondary-purple

typography.heading: Inter 15px/700 for shield title
typography.accent: Inter 12px/600 for badge labels and metric values

visual_spec.color_usage: Secondary-purple for verification checkmarks and primary metrics; accent-purple for badge backgrounds; primary-purple for the shield icon and section headings

interaction_spec.default_state: Shield visible with all available badges and metrics; metrics with insufficient data show a 'Building...' state
interaction_spec.hover: Individual badges expand to show verification detail (e.g., 'Employment verified via employer confirmation'); metrics show source count (e.g., 'Based on 47 messages across 6 guests')
interaction_spec.click: Clicking a metric opens a detail popover with the methodology explanation
interaction_spec.animation: Shield entrance: fade + subtle scale from 0.98 to 1 over 200ms; checkmark icons animate with a draw stroke effect on first view
interaction_spec.responsive: Full-width on mobile; badges wrap to 2 rows; metrics stack vertically

copy_spec.secondary_text: Every guest is vetted. Every host is verified.
do: Use 'verified' and 'confirmed' language -- these are facts, not opinions
Show specific numbers where possible (response time, renewal rate)
Frame vetting as the platform doing work the user would have to do themselves
dont: Never expose raw credit scores or financial details
Never say 'unverified' for items not yet checked -- use 'pending' or omit
Never present vetting data as a substitute for reviews -- frame as complementary

before_after.before: Booking.com: A new listing shows an empty review section or irrelevant 2-night tourist reviews. The guest sees 'No reviews yet' and must decide whether to commit $2,550 for 3 months based on photos alone. Tag: 'I don't know if this guy is legit.' Patricia: 'I've already been scammed twice.'
before_after.after: Split Lease: Even with zero traditional reviews, the listing shows 'ID Verified, Employment Confirmed, Credit Checked' badges plus operational metrics: 'Host responds in ~2 hours, 3 of 4 guests renewed their lease.' The trust desert is filled with verifiable facts before the first review is ever written.

elements.name: Priority Picker at Proposal
elements.problem_it_solves: Seeds the review habit at the moment of highest commitment by capturing what matters most to the guest, creating a personalized scaffold that transforms the post-lease review from a generic hotel form into a guided reflection the guest primed themselves for.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No platform uses the booking commitment moment to seed review expectations because OTA booking funnels are terrified of adding any friction -- Split Lease's multi-step proposal flow already has natural pause points where an optional priority question adds negligible friction while loading the next trigger per Eyal's Investment chapter.
elements.description: An optional priority selector that appears at the bottom of the proposal confirmation screen. It presents 8 long-term-housing-native quality dimensions as selectable chips and asks the guest to pick their top 3. These selections are stored and later used to scaffold micro-review prompts and the end-of-lease synthesis. The copy frames it as the platform caring about the guest's specific needs, not extracting data: 'Help us make sure this place works for you.'

visual_spec.layout: Vertical flex within proposal confirmation card; chip grid uses flex-wrap
visual_spec.background: Subtle purple tint: rgba(140, 104, 238, 0.04) section background within white card
visual_spec.border: 1px dashed rgba(140, 104, 238, 0.2) around the priority section
visual_spec.color_usage: Unselected chips: white background with border-light border; selected chips: secondary-purple background with white text; section background uses lightest purple tint to separate from the main card

interaction_spec.default_state: All 8 chips visible in neutral state; counter shows '0 of 3 selected'
interaction_spec.hover: Unselected chips gain light-purple background; selected chips gain slightly darker purple
interaction_spec.click: Chip toggles between selected/unselected with 150ms color transition; counter updates; when 3 are selected, remaining unselected chips dim to 40% opacity
interaction_spec.animation: Section entrance: fade in 200ms when proposal confirmation renders; chip selection: background and text color transition 150ms; counter update: subtle bounce
interaction_spec.responsive: Chips wrap naturally on mobile; full-width section with 16px padding

copy_spec.primary_text: What matters most for your stay?
copy_spec.secondary_text: Pick up to 3 -- we'll check in on these during your lease
do: Frame as the platform caring about the guest: 'Help us make sure this works for you'
Use categories native to long-term housing, not imported from hotel systems
Always keep it optional with a visible skip option
dont: Never make this required -- it must feel like a bonus, not a gate
Never use the word 'review' -- this is about expectations, not evaluation
Never show the guest's priorities to the host before acceptance to prevent discrimination

before_after.before: Booking.com: The booking confirmation page shows property name, dates, and logistics. Zero review-relevant investment is captured. The guest makes no statement about what matters to them. When the post-stay review arrives 90 days later, it is a generic 7-subcategory form with no personalization.
before_after.after: Split Lease: After submitting a proposal, the guest selects 'Quiet neighbors, Kitchen quality, Host communication' as their top 3 priorities. Every weekly micro-review pulse and the end-of-lease synthesis are scaffolded by these priorities: 'You said quiet neighbors mattered most. How has it been?' The review becomes a continuation of a conversation the guest started themselves.

elements.name: Trusted Reviewer Profile Card
elements.problem_it_solves: Creates the reviewer identity and visible impact that Booking.com's anonymous system completely lacks, transforming review contributions from disposable civic acts into accumulated reputation that delivers all three of Eyal's variable reward types: Tribe (social recognition), Hunt (impact metrics), and Self (trust tier achievement).
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No platform has built a reviewer identity system for housing because high-volume OTAs do not need individual reviewer retention -- their volume compensates for any reviewer's absence, while Split Lease's low-volume long-stay model makes every reviewer critical.
elements.description: A profile card that aggregates a user's review contributions across all their stays. It shows total reviews, total stays reviewed, the accumulated timeline of micro-review pulses, a trust tier badge ('Trusted Long-Stay Reviewer' after 2+ completed leases), and impact metrics ('Your reviews were read 234 times'). The card appears in the user's own dashboard (Self reward), is optionally visible to hosts considering their proposal (Tribe reward), and is linked from their published reviews on listings (Hunt reward -- others can see this reviewer's depth of experience).

visual_spec.layout: Horizontal flex for avatar+stats row, vertical stack for badges and metrics
visual_spec.background: #ffffff with subtle gradient overlay at top

typography.heading: Inter 16px/700 for reviewer name
typography.accent: Inter 20px/700 for stat numbers; Inter 11px/600 for badge label

visual_spec.color_usage: Primary-purple for stat numbers and reviewer name; secondary-purple for the trust tier badge background; accent-purple for impact metric highlights; gold (#D4A853 from proposed palette) for the 'Trusted' badge star accent

interaction_spec.default_state: Card visible with current stats and badge; impact metric animates count-up on first view
interaction_spec.hover: Stats show tooltips with breakdowns; badge shows earning criteria
interaction_spec.click: Clicking 'View full history' expands to show all review timelines across stays
interaction_spec.animation: Stats count up from 0 on card entrance (800ms); badge has a subtle shimmer animation on first render; impact number increments with spring easing
interaction_spec.responsive: On mobile, avatar and stats stack vertically; badge wraps below name

copy_spec.secondary_text: Your contributions help the Split Lease community
do: Celebrate depth of contribution: number of stays reviewed, not just number of reviews
Show concrete impact: views, booking influence, property improvements
Use 'Trusted' language that conveys earned credibility, not gamification
dont: Never use leaderboard language -- this is reputation, not competition
Never show the reviewer's identity on specific negative reviews to prevent retaliation
Never make badges feel like gamification with points and levels

ST
Sarah T.
Trusted Long-Stay Reviewer
3
Properties
39
Stay Pulses
14
Months
234 people read your reviews
12 guests booked after reading you
Your heater feedback led to a repair
View full review history →

before_after.before: Booking.com: The reviewer is 'First Name + Country Flag.' Their 15 minutes of labor vanish into an aggregate score. No profile, no history, no impact visibility, no badge, no recognition. The next review request is the same cold-start experience. Ramsey tracks his 4.99 Airbnb rating to two decimal points because that platform at least gives him a number to own.
before_after.after: Split Lease: Sarah T. is a 'Trusted Long-Stay Reviewer' with 39 stay pulses across 3 properties over 14 months. 234 people read her reviews. 12 guests booked after reading them. Her heater feedback led to a repair. Her investment compounds with every stay, creating switching costs and emotional attachment per Eyal's framework.

elements.name: Passive Signal Dashboard Row
elements.problem_it_solves: Converts communication and behavioral data the platform already captures -- message response times, maintenance resolution speed, date change frequency, renewal rates -- into visible review-equivalent quality signals that generate trust without requiring anyone to write a single word.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No competitor synthesizes behavioral data into visible quality signals because OTAs' 2-night bookings generate too few data points for statistically meaningful behavioral scores -- Split Lease's multi-month leases with weekly stays generate hundreds of data points per tenancy.
elements.description: A horizontal row of behavioral metric cards that appears in two contexts: (1) on the listing page below traditional reviews, showing aggregated host behavioral data, and (2) on the host's own dashboard, showing their performance metrics. Each card displays a single behavioral signal with a clear label, the metric value, and a subtle data source indicator ('Based on 47 messages across 6 guests'). The metrics are operational facts, not opinions -- they supplement traditional reviews with verifiable behavioral evidence.

visual_spec.layout: Horizontal scroll or flex-wrap row of equal-width metric cards
visual_spec.background: Each card: #ffffff; row background: transparent on listing page, bg-off-white on dashboard
visual_spec.color_usage: Primary-purple for metric values; accent-purple for metric labels; text-muted for source indicators; secondary-purple for metrics that exceed a 'good' threshold

interaction_spec.default_state: All metric cards visible with current values; cards with insufficient data show 'Building...' state with a progress indicator
interaction_spec.hover: Card elevates slightly with shadow-md; source text becomes fully visible; tooltip shows methodology
interaction_spec.click: Clicking a card on the host dashboard opens a detail view with the trend over time
interaction_spec.animation: Cards enter with 100ms stagger from left to right; metric values count up from 0 on first render (600ms)
interaction_spec.responsive: On mobile, cards stack vertically in a 2x2 grid; scroll is removed

copy_spec.secondary_text: Based on real platform data, not opinions
do: Always show the data source and sample size
Round to meaningful ranges -- '~2 hours' not '1 hour 47 minutes'
Use neutral framing -- present facts, not judgments
dont: Never present a behavioral signal without sufficient data (minimum 3 guests, 10 messages)
Never show individual data points -- always aggregate across guests
Never surface negative signals without context (e.g., a slow response might mean the host was traveling)

elements.html_css:
How this host performs
Based on real platform data, not opinions
Response Time
~2 hrs
Across 47 messages from 6 guests
Maintenance Speed
< 24 hrs
4 issues resolved across 3 leases
Renewal Rate
75%
3 of 4 guests chose to renew
Lease Completion
100%
6 of 6 leases completed fully

before_after.before: Booking.com: Communication quality, maintenance responsiveness, and renewal rates are invisible. The platform has this data in its database (message timestamps, booking patterns) but never surfaces it. The guest's review must reconstruct these from memory. Tammy's same-day maintenance resolution and Kris's repeat-guest discounts are invisible to future guests.
before_after.after: Split Lease: Every listing shows behavioral metrics synthesized from real platform data: 'Response Time: ~2 hours (47 messages, 6 guests). Maintenance Speed: < 24 hrs. 75% renewal rate.' These are not opinions -- they are operational facts that generate trust automatically. The host's responsiveness reviews itself.

elements.name: End-of-Lease Review Synthesis Modal
elements.problem_it_solves: Replaces the cold-start retrospective review form with a synthesis of signals already captured, presenting the guest's own micro-review pulses and priority evaluations back to them for confirmation and optional elaboration -- transforming the review from a 15-minute cognitive exercise into a 2-minute reflection that feels like closing a chapter, not filling out a tax form.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No competitor can build a synthesis review because they have no mid-stay data to synthesize -- they must start from scratch at checkout, while Split Lease's accumulated micro-pulses, priority ratings, and passive signals provide a rich foundation that the guest merely confirms.
elements.description: A full-screen modal that appears when the guest's lease ends. It presents: (1) their stay journey timeline with all micro-pulses visualized, (2) their stated priorities from proposal time with current ratings pre-filled from pulse data, (3) a single open text prompt for anything they want to add, and (4) an impact preview showing how their review will appear to future guests. The modal celebrates the completion ('13 weeks reviewed -- thank you') and shows the guest their Reviewer Profile card updated with this contribution. The Variable Reward is immediate and multi-dimensional: Tribe (your review joins the community), Hunt (your priorities are now scored), Self (your timeline is complete).

visual_spec.layout: Vertical scroll within centered modal (max-width 520px); timeline section, priorities section, text section, celebration section
visual_spec.background: Modal: #ffffff; overlay: rgba(49, 19, 93, 0.4); celebration header: gradient from primary-purple to secondary-purple

typography.heading: Inter 20px/700 for celebration headline
typography.accent: Inter 13px/600 for priority labels and CTA button

visual_spec.color_usage: White text on primary-purple gradient for the celebration header; secondary-purple for CTA button; accent-purple for priority score highlights; standard purple palette for all other elements

interaction_spec.default_state: Modal opens with celebration header animation; timeline and priorities pre-populated from accumulated data; text field empty and optional
interaction_spec.hover: Priority scores can be adjusted by clicking; timeline nodes can be clicked to expand notes
interaction_spec.click: CTA button 'Publish Your Review' submits and transitions to a celebration animation showing the review joining the listing; 'Edit' links allow adjusting any pre-filled data
interaction_spec.animation: Modal entrance: fade + translateY(20px) to 0 over 300ms; celebration header: gradient shimmer on load; timeline draws in with 800ms sequence; confetti-style purple particles on publish
interaction_spec.responsive: Full-screen on mobile with bottom-sheet behavior; sections stack with scroll

copy_spec.secondary_text: Here's your stay story at Marcus's Room in Harlem
micro_copy: This helps future renters make better decisions
do: Celebrate the completion -- this is a milestone, not a chore
Show the guest their own data first, then ask for additions
Frame publishing as a contribution to the community, not an obligation
dont: Never present this as a form to fill out -- it is a synthesis to confirm
Never require the text field -- the micro-pulses and priorities are the review
Never show a generic 'Thank you for your review' -- show specific impact

elements.html_css:
13 weeks reviewed
Here's your stay story at Marcus's Room in Harlem
Your Stay Timeline
10 great, 2 fine, 1 rough
Your Priorities
Quiet neighbors
Great
Kitchen quality
Fine
Host communication
Great
Anything else to add?
This helps future renters make better decisions

before_after.before: Booking.com: 24-48 hours after checkout, an email arrives linking to a blank 7-subcategory form. The guest must recall 90 days, evaluate 7 dimensions, write two text blocks, and submit into a void. 'Thank you for your review.' No celebration, no impact preview, no acknowledgment that what they just did mattered.
before_after.after: Split Lease: At lease end, a modal shows the guest their own story: 13 dots on a timeline, 3 priorities already scored from their weekly pulses, and a single optional text box. The guest confirms what the platform already captured, adds a final note if they wish, and publishes into a celebration that shows exactly how their contribution helps the next person. Two minutes, not fifteen.

elements.name: Platform Identity Hero Section
elements.problem_it_solves: Susan misidentified Split Lease as a real estate brokerage because no page communicates what the service is without human explanation.
elements.description: A landing page hero section that communicates the Split Lease model in under 5 seconds using the guest's natural vocabulary. The headline 'Book the nights you need. Skip the ones you don't.' triggers immediate comprehension relief. Below, three concrete examples show real schedule patterns (Mon-Fri, 3 nights/week, weekends only) with mini day-badge visualizations, making the abstract 'non-continuous nights' concept instantly concrete. A search entry point with schedule presets lets the guest begin searching immediately.

visual_spec.layout: Vertical flex, centered. Hero headline at top, subtitle below, three example cards in a horizontal row, search CTA at bottom.
visual_spec.background: var(--bg-white) with subtle gradient overlay at top

typography.heading: Inter, 36px (--text-4xl), 700 weight, color #31135D
typography.accent: Inter, 12px (--text-sm), 600 weight, color rgb(82, 31, 147) for schedule badges

visual_spec.color_usage: Primary purple (#31135D) for headline establishes brand authority. Text gray for subtitle keeps it subordinate. Purple-tinted off-white (rgb(252, 250, 255)) for example card backgrounds connects to brand. Schedule badges use text-purple for the identity signifier system.

interaction_spec.default_state: Headline, subtitle, three example cards, and search CTA visible on load. No animation on entry -- content is simply present, confident and unhurried.
interaction_spec.hover: Example cards lift with shadow-md on hover. Search CTA shows gradient-purple-hover.
interaction_spec.click: Search CTA navigates to search results with schedule preset pre-selected if an example card was clicked.
interaction_spec.animation: Day badges in example cards use a subtle stagger fade-in (100ms delay per badge) to draw the eye to the schedule visualization.
interaction_spec.responsive: On mobile, example cards stack vertically. Headline drops to 28px (--text-2xl). Day badges remain the same size (32px) for touch targets.

copy_spec.primary_text: Book the nights you need. Skip the ones you don't.
copy_spec.secondary_text: Private rooms and apartments, by the night. Pick your schedule, find your space.
copy_spec.micro_copy: Example labels: 'Weekdays Mon-Fri', '3 nights/week', 'Weekends only'. CTA: 'Find a space'

elements.test_strategy: Five-second usability test (tests-001): show landing page for 5 seconds to 20 participants unfamiliar with Split Lease. Target: 70%+ correctly identify Split Lease as a part-time or partial-week housing service. Zero participants should misidentify it as a real estate brokerage or hotel.
elements.coherence_notes: Reinforces works-001 from prior runs (human-to-digital handoff). First element in the library to use Don Norman's system image principle. Schedule badges use the same visual language (purple pill on off-white) as listing card badges, creating a persistent identity signifier system across pages.

elements.name: Listing Trust Verification Stack
elements.problem_it_solves: Susan demanded physical inspection three times because the listing had no discoverable substitute signifiers for in-person verification.
elements.description: A listing page header component that places three trust signifiers above the fold in a layered stack: (1) a verified photo gallery with a 'Verified by Split Lease' badge, (2) a first-night cancellation guarantee displayed at the same visual prominence as the price, and (3) a host identity card with response time and guest count. The stack follows Susan's decision sequence: see the space (photos) then know I can leave (guarantee) then know the host is real (identity).

visual_spec.layout: Vertical stack. Photo gallery (full width, 280px height) with verification badge overlay at top-left. Below: two-column row with price + guarantee badge on the left and host identity card on the right.
visual_spec.border: 1px solid var(--border-color) on host identity card
visual_spec.border_radius: 12px (--rounded-xl) for photo gallery, 8px (--rounded-lg) for guarantee badge, 12px for host card

typography.heading: Inter, 20px (--text-xl), 700 weight, color #1a1a1a for listing title
typography.body: DM Sans, 14px (--text-base), 400 weight, color #374151 for descriptions
typography.accent: Inter, 12px (--text-sm), 600 weight, white on #31135D for verification badge

spacing.gap: 16px between stack layers, 12px between badge elements

visual_spec.color_usage: Primary purple (#31135D) semi-transparent overlay for verification badge -- brand color as trust signal. Secondary purple for guarantee badge text. Neutral colors for host card to frame the host as a real person.

interaction_spec.default_state: Photo gallery with swipe/arrow navigation, verification badge pinned top-left, guarantee badge and host card visible below without scrolling.
interaction_spec.hover: Photo gallery arrows appear on hover. Host card shows subtle shadow-md elevation. Guarantee badge shows underline on hover to indicate expandable detail.
interaction_spec.click: Guarantee badge click opens a detail sheet (slide up, 200ms) with full cancellation terms. Host card click navigates to host profile. Photo gallery supports full-screen view.
interaction_spec.animation: Verification badge fades in with the gallery (250ms). Guarantee badge is static -- no attention-grabbing animation, just permanent presence like a structural element.
interaction_spec.responsive: On mobile, host card moves below price row. Photo gallery becomes full-width swipeable. Guarantee badge stays adjacent to price.

copy_spec.primary_text: Rita's Private Room  North Bergen, NJ
copy_spec.secondary_text: Private Room  Private Bath  Host present weekday evenings
copy_spec.micro_copy: Badge: 'Verified by Split Lease'. Guarantee: 'Cancel within 24 hours if the space doesn't match'. Host card: 'Rita  Responds in 2 hours  12 prior guests'

elements.test_strategy: A/B test (tests-002): split traffic between current listing page and redesigned page with trust triad. Target: 25%+ higher listing-to-proposal conversion for first-time unassisted guests. Eye-tracking study (tests-007): verify trust triad is fixated within first 6 seconds of scan path.
elements.coherence_notes: Extends the library's existing trust credential work from the host side (Kahneman lens) to the guest side (Norman lens). The no-preview policy explanation transforms an invisible anti-affordance into a signified constraint with visible alternatives. Layer 6 flagged trust as the strongest cross-layer signal; this element is its primary implementation.

elements.name: Space Composition Listing Card
elements.problem_it_solves: Susan's first three questions were about room type, bathroom, and co-occupancy -- but conventional listing cards lead with price and location, burying the primary decision variables for shared housing.
elements.description: A listing card for search results that leads with a three-part space composition label (room type, bathroom privacy, co-occupancy) as the first text element after the photo. A schedule availability badge sits on the photo. The card answers the guest's three prerequisite questions in a single scan line before presenting price and location.

visual_spec.layout: Vertical card. Photo with schedule badge overlay, then space composition label, then price, then location.

typography.heading: Inter, 15px, 600 weight, color #1a1a1a for listing name
typography.body: Inter, 12px (--text-sm), 500 weight, color #1a1a1a for space composition; 400 weight, #6b7280 for co-occupancy
typography.accent: Inter, 11px (--text-xs), 600 weight, uppercase, color rgb(82, 31, 147) for schedule badge

visual_spec.color_usage: Schedule badge uses text-purple on off-white pill (identity signifier system). Space composition uses neutral text-dark for factual descriptors. Co-occupancy uses softer text-gray because it is contextual. Mid-dot separator in text-light-gray.

interaction_spec.default_state: Card shows photo with schedule badge, space composition label, price, and location. All visible without interaction.
interaction_spec.hover: Card lifts with shadow-md. Subtle scale 1.01.
interaction_spec.click: Navigates to full listing detail page.
interaction_spec.animation: Cards fade in with 50ms stagger when search results load.
interaction_spec.responsive: On mobile, cards stack single-column full-width. Photo height reduces to 180px. Space composition stays single line or wraps to two lines max.

copy_spec.secondary_text: Private Room  Private Bath  Host present evenings
copy_spec.micro_copy: Schedule badge: 'WEEKNIGHTS'. Price: '$85/night'. Location: 'North Bergen, NJ  Near Lincoln Tunnel'

elements.test_strategy: Five-second test on listing cards: show search results for 5 seconds and ask 'What kind of space is the first listing?' Target: 85%+ correctly identify room type and bathroom privacy. A/B test card design against current layout measuring click-through rate to listing detail.
elements.coherence_notes: Complements the existing Schedule-First Listing Cards (guest-communicates-006) from the Nneka run. Layer 6 recommended making the primary listing card element contextually adaptive. For shared housing guests like Susan's friend, space composition precedes schedule; for hybrid workers, schedule may precede. Both should be primary elements.

elements.name: Natural-Language Stay Configurator
elements.problem_it_solves: Susan thinks in months and weekday names but the platform requires night counts -- Bryant had to translate the vocabulary twice during the call.
elements.description: A proposal configuration component with preset-based schedule pills (Weekdays, Weekends, Full Week, Custom) and duration cards (About 1 month, About 2 months, 3+ months) that accept the guest's natural vocabulary. A real-time translation summary bar below shows both languages simultaneously: 'Mon-Fri for 2 months = 40 nights at $85/night = $3,400 total'. Every selection produces immediate visual feedback within 200ms.

visual_spec.layout: Vertical stack. Schedule presets row (horizontal pills), duration presets row (horizontal cards), translation summary bar below.
visual_spec.background: var(--bg-white) for container, var(--bg-light) for summary bar
visual_spec.border: 1px solid var(--border-color) for inactive elements, secondary-purple for active
visual_spec.border_radius: 20px (--rounded-pill) for preset pills, 12px for duration cards, 8px for summary bar

typography.heading: Inter, 14px (--text-base), 600 weight for section labels
typography.body: Inter, 14px, 500 weight for summary bar text
typography.accent: Inter, 14px, 600 weight for preset pill labels

spacing.gap: 8px between pills, 12px between duration cards, 24px between sections

visual_spec.color_usage: Secondary purple (rgb(109, 49, 194)) for active preset backgrounds and active duration card borders. White text on active pills. Text-dark on inactive pills. bg-off-white for active duration card backgrounds. bg-light for summary bar.

interaction_spec.default_state: All presets inactive (neutral gray background). Summary bar shows placeholder: 'Select a schedule and duration to see your stay details.'
interaction_spec.hover: Inactive pills show bg-light-gray darkening. Duration cards show subtle shadow.
interaction_spec.click: Tapping a preset pill: background transitions to secondary-purple with white text (150ms). Summary bar updates with opacity pulse (0.5 to 1.0, 300ms). Duration cards show purple border with off-white fill on selection.
interaction_spec.animation: Summary bar text updates with a brief pulse animation to draw attention to the changed value. 'Custom' option reveals calendar grid via height-expand (300ms).
interaction_spec.responsive: On mobile, preset pills wrap to two rows if needed. Duration cards stack 2x2 grid. Summary bar stays full-width and sticky at bottom during scroll.

copy_spec.secondary_text: Mon-Fri for 2 months = 40 nights  $85/night  $3,400 total
copy_spec.micro_copy: Pills: 'Weekdays', 'Weekends', 'Full Week', 'Custom'. Duration: 'About 1 month', 'About 2 months', '3+ months'. Warning: 'Rita requires at least 30 nights. Add 2 more weeks.'
