On listing detail page: identity signifier as a contextual subtitle below the listing title. On demand: 'How it works' expandable section with a 3-step explanation using visual examples. The identity signifier is never absent from any page  it is the persistent system image anchor.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Identity signifier: maximum 8 words. Schedule badge on listing cards: maximum 4 words ('Weeknights available' or 'Mon-Fri stays'). The 'How it works' section: maximum 3 steps, each with a single illustration and one sentence. No internal jargon ('non-continuous,' 'periodic tenancy,' 'lease style') in any guest-facing signifier.
scan_order: Identity headline: 'Book the nights you need' (System 1 comprehension: 'I understand what this is', under 2 seconds)
Schedule badge on listing cards: 'Weeknights' or 'Flexible schedule' (System 1 relevance check: 'Does this match my need?', 2-3 seconds)
Listing-specific details: room type, bathroom, location (System 2 evaluation: 'Is this specific space right?', 3-6 seconds)
Service explanation: 'How it works' section (System 2, only if the guest needs more detail, 6+ seconds)
exclude: Platform jargon as user-facing signifiers: 'non-continuous set of nights,' 'periodic tenancy,' 'lease style,' 'schedule-native housing.'
Marketing language that describes the company rather than signifying the model: 'We connect hosts and guests' tells the guest nothing actionable.
Landing pages that lead with property photos before establishing what the service is. The guest must understand the model before evaluating listings.
Any page where the guest must click 'Learn More' or navigate to a separate page to understand the basic service model.

elements.title: Natural-Language Duration Mapping: Calendar Months and Weekday Presets as Primary Input Signifiers
elements.problem: Susan thinks in calendar months ('one month or two months,' 0:11), weekday names ('Monday to Friday,' implied at 3:58), and space types ('full apartment or is it a bedroom,' 0:43). The platform requires night counts ('30 night minimum,' 1:35) and individual day toggles. Bryant performs the mapping between Susan's vocabulary and the platform's vocabulary twice during the call (0:19-0:35 and 1:35-2:00). Norman's mapping principle states that 'natural mapping, taking advantage of spatial analogies, leads to immediate understanding.' When the input controls use the platform's vocabulary (night counts, lease durations), the guest must perform a cognitive translation from their natural vocabulary (months, weekdays)  a System 2 effort that depletes the same resources needed for the actual decision. The proposal creation form's signifiers must use the guest's vocabulary as the primary framing, with the platform's internal units as secondary annotation.
elements.solution: Design every duration and schedule input to speak the guest's language first and the platform's language second. Duration selection: present presets labeled in calendar time  'About 1 month,' 'About 2 months,' '3+ months'  as the primary input. Show the equivalent night count as a secondary annotation: 'About 2 months (approx. 40 nights at 5 nights/week).' Schedule selection: provide one-tap presets for common patterns  'Weekdays (Mon-Fri),' 'Weekends (Sat-Sun),' 'Full week,' 'Custom'  as the primary input. The custom option reveals individual day toggles only when the presets do not match. A real-time summary line below the selectors performs the mapping visually: 'Mon-Fri for 2 months = 40 nights, starting [date].' This summary is the digital equivalent of Bryant's verbal translation at 1:35-2:00. The pattern is: accept the guest's vocabulary, translate internally, show both languages simultaneously for transparency.

evidence.quote: Like seven nights a week?
evidence.insight: Susan defaults to full-time occupancy because her conceptual model has no category for part-time housing. The duration input must not assume the guest already understands the non-continuous model. Presets labeled 'Weekdays' or '3 nights/week' signify the part-time concept through the input control itself.

evidence.quote: Natural mapping, taking advantage of spatial analogies, leads to immediate understanding. For example, to move an object up, move the control up.
evidence.insight: A calendar-based duration selector where the guest sees weeks highlighted on a visual calendar is a natural mapping. A number field labeled 'minimum nights' is an arbitrary mapping that requires translation. The input control itself must signify the mapping.

evidence.quote: Rita would require a 30 night minimum... five nights a week for like two months would be something that would, could work.
evidence.insight: Bryant translates Susan's '1-2 months' into the platform's '30 night minimum' in real time. The proposal form must perform this same translation visually. The guest enters their natural-language parameters; the form computes and displays the platform's internal values alongside.

evidence.quote: Do five days a week. And then would there be a preference for those days, like weekdays?... It's Monday to Friday will be better.
evidence.insight: Susan's natural expression for the schedule is 'Monday to Friday.' This must be a one-tap preset, not five individual day toggles. Norman's natural mapping principle: the control must match the guest's mental representation of the action.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: calendar-time presets (months, weekday groups) as the first input the guest sees. Secondary: real-time translation summary showing both guest vocabulary and platform units ('Mon-Fri for 2 months = 40 nights at $X/night = $Y total'). Tertiary: custom input fields for guests whose needs do not match any preset. The ordering ensures the guest never encounters the platform's internal vocabulary before seeing their own.
elements.disclosure_pattern: On search: schedule presets as the first filter dimension ('When do you need the space?' before 'Where?' or 'How much?'). On proposal creation: duration presets appear first, followed by schedule presets, then the real-time summary. Custom inputs are hidden behind a 'Custom schedule' toggle and only revealed on demand. The translation summary updates in real time as the guest modifies any input  this is Norman's immediate feedback principle applied to the mapping display.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 4 duration presets visible (1 month, 2 months, 3 months, custom). Maximum 4 schedule presets visible (Weekdays, Weekends, Full week, Custom). The real-time summary is a single line, maximum 15 words. No platform-native terms (night count, lease duration, periodic tenancy) appear without a guest-vocabulary equivalent alongside.
scan_order: Schedule presets: 'Weekdays (Mon-Fri)' / 'Weekends' / 'Full week' (System 1: 'Does my pattern match?', under 2 seconds)
Duration presets: 'About 1 month' / '2 months' / '3+ months' (System 1: 'How long do I need?', 2-3 seconds)
Real-time translation summary: 'Mon-Fri for 2 months = 40 nights, $X total' (System 2: 'What does that actually mean?', 3-5 seconds)
Custom input toggle for non-standard schedules (System 2, only if presets do not match, 5+ seconds)
exclude: Night count fields as the primary duration input. Guests think in months, not nights.
Individual day-of-week toggles as the primary schedule input. A 'Weekdays' preset captures Monday-Friday in one tap.
Platform terminology ('30 night minimum,' 'non-continuous set of nights') without a guest-vocabulary translation alongside.

Duration inputs that do not show a real-time cost calculation. Susan's friend is budgeting a cross-country trip; the financial consequence of the duration choice must be visible as the guest configures it.

elements.title: Negotiation Feedback Timeline: Show What Happened, What Is Happening, and What Happens Next
elements.problem: The Susan call contains a complete negotiation micro-cycle: demand (physical inspection, 2:14)  rejection (not allowed, 3:05)  compromise (first-night cancellation, 3:16). At every exchange, Bryant provides immediate verbal feedback  acknowledgment, explanation, counter-proposal. The platform's negotiation flow is asynchronous: the guest submits a proposal, the host considers it offline, and the response arrives hours or days later. Norman states: 'Feedback must be immediate: even a delay of a tenth of a second can be disconcerting. If the delay is too long, people often give up.' The call demonstrates this directly: when the phone connection drops at 2:42-3:05, both parties scramble with 'Can you hear me?'  trust erodes within seconds of lost feedback. Every hour a proposal sits in 'pending' without informative status updates is an hour the guest's trust decays. The information architecture must replace the verbal negotiation's continuous feedback with a structured timeline that makes the asynchronous process feel transparent and progressing.
elements.solution: Design the negotiation status as a visual timeline that answers three questions at a glance: What happened? What is happening right now? What happens next? The timeline has discrete states, each with a specific signifier: (1) 'Proposal Sent'  timestamp, summary of terms, confirmation that the host was notified. (2) 'Host Reviewing'  host's typical response time ('Rita usually responds within 6 hours'), last activity indicator. (3) 'Host Responded'  the response (accepted, countered, or declined) with specific details visible immediately. (4) 'Your Turn'  if the host countered, the guest sees what changed and what action they can take. (5) 'Agreed' or 'Expired'  final state. At each state, the timeline shows one line of what happened, one line of what is happening, and one line of what comes next. Intermediate feedback ('still waiting') fires at predictable intervals. The pattern is: no state should ever feel like silence. Every moment in the negotiation must have a visible, informative signifier.

evidence.quote: Can you hear me, Susan? Me? Yep. Can you hear me? No, I, yeah. You're you're back. I can hear you. Can you hear me? Yes. I can hear you.
evidence.insight: A 20-second feedback gap in the phone call causes immediate anxiety and scrambling. This is the analog of a platform showing 'pending' for hours with no status update. The information architecture must prevent this feedback vacuum by signifying progress even when nothing has changed ('Rita has not yet responded. Most hosts respond within 6 hours.').

evidence.quote: Feedback must be immediate: even a delay of a tenth of a second can be disconcerting. If the delay is too long, people often give up, going off to do other activities.
evidence.insight: For asynchronous negotiations, 'immediate' means instant acknowledgment of the guest's action plus a realistic timeline for the host's response. The guest must never wonder whether their proposal was received. The timeline signifier replaces 'pending' with 'Host Reviewing  typically responds in 6 hours.'

evidence.quote: I'll be in contact with Rita. And like I said, I'll keep you updated.
evidence.insight: Bryant's promise of future feedback is the only 'next steps' signifier Susan receives. The platform must replace human promises with systematic, visible status timelines  a persistent signifier that does not depend on any individual remembering to follow up.

evidence.quote: Feedback has to be planned. All actions need to be confirmed, but in a manner that is unobtrusive. Feedback must also be prioritized, so that unimportant information is presented in an unobtrusive fashion, but important signals are presented in a way that does capture attention.
evidence.insight: The negotiation timeline must distinguish between high-priority feedback (host countered your proposal  action required) and low-priority feedback (proposal still being reviewed  no action needed). Both are signified, but with different visual urgency.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: current state indicator with one-line description ('Host Reviewing  usually responds in 6 hours'). Secondary: next action signifier ('You will be notified when Rita responds' or 'Your turn: review Rita's counter-proposal'). Tertiary: history of prior states with timestamps ('Proposal sent Feb 17 at 3:42 PM'). The ordering ensures the guest always knows the present state before needing to review the history.
elements.disclosure_pattern: On proposal submission: instant confirmation with timeline visualization showing the current state. While waiting: intermediate feedback at predictable intervals (6 hours, 12 hours, 24 hours) with host response time context. On host response: push notification with the specific response, not a generic 'update available.' On guest's turn: action prompt with the specific terms that changed and a one-tap response option. After agreement: confirmation with move-in date, key terms summary, and next steps.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 3 timeline states visible at once (previous, current, next). Each state is described in one line of maximum 12 words. The full negotiation history is available on demand but never the default view. Counter-offer changes are highlighted with a visual diff  the guest sees only what changed, not the entire proposal restated.
scan_order: Current state badge: 'Host Reviewing' or 'Your Turn' or 'Agreed' (System 1: 'Where are we?', under 1 second)
Timeline context: 'Rita usually responds in 6 hours' or 'Rita countered: 4 nights/week instead of 5' (System 1/2: 'What is happening?', 1-3 seconds)
Next action: 'You will be notified' or 'Review counter-proposal' button (System 2: 'What do I do?', 3-5 seconds)
History: previous states with timestamps (System 2: 'What happened before?', only on demand)
exclude: A generic 'Pending' state with no timeline or response time context. Every waiting state must signify expected duration.
Identical notification patterns for different events. A counter-offer and a status update must look and feel different.
Negotiation history that requires navigating to a separate page. The timeline is inline, on the same screen as the current state.
Counter-offers presented as full proposal restates. Only the changed terms should be highlighted; unchanged terms are dimmed or collapsed.

elements.title: Proxy Booking Information Structure: Two Roles, Two Information Needs, One Booking Flow
elements.problem: Susan is booking on behalf of a friend from Oregon. She says 'I can give you a deposit on her behalf' (2:34), 'I'm setting up all appointments for her' (3:58-4:31), and 'before she puts her tickets' (2:14). The platform's information architecture assumes a single-user model: the person searching, evaluating, and proposing is the person staying. Norman's conceptual model principle states that 'a conceptual model is an explanation, usually highly simplified, of how something works. It doesn't have to be complete or even accurate as long as it is useful.' The one-guest-one-user model is not useful when proxies are involved. The proxy (Susan) needs information about logistics, payments, and host communication. The occupant (friend) needs information about the space, check-in procedures, and house rules. If the information architecture does not distinguish these two roles, both users receive either too much irrelevant information or miss critical role-specific information. The proxy booking affordance exists (you can fill out forms and pay for someone else), but without a signifier indicating this is possible, Susan would either pretend to be the guest or abandon.
elements.solution: Add a role-selection signifier at the start of the proposal flow: 'Booking for yourself?' / 'Booking for someone else?' This single toggle restructures the information architecture for the rest of the journey. When 'Booking for someone else' is selected: (1) The proposal form collects two profiles  coordinator (Susan: contact info, payment method, local presence) and occupant (friend: name, arrival date, needs). (2) Confirmation and status updates are sent to both users, but with role-appropriate content: the coordinator receives logistics and payment updates; the occupant receives check-in details and house rules. (3) During the active lease, the Stays Manager shows the coordinator a management view (payment history, upcoming stays, date change tools) and the occupant an operational view (current stay details, House Manual, host contact). (4) The information architecture constrains each role's affordances: the coordinator can pay and reschedule; the occupant can check in, submit cleaning photos, and write reviews. Neither is overwhelmed with the other's information.

evidence.quote: I like to see the place and I can give you a deposit on her behalf and she's ready to come whenever I can find her spot.
evidence.insight: Susan explicitly describes the proxy pattern: she inspects and pays, the friend occupies. The information architecture must capture this split-responsibility model and deliver role-appropriate information to each person.

evidence.quote: People need some way of understanding the product or service they wish to use, some sign of what it is for, what is happening, and what the alternative actions are.
evidence.insight: If the platform offers no signifier for proxy booking, Susan must either pretend to be the guest (creating incorrect data) or abandon. The role-selection toggle is a signifier that makes the proxy affordance discoverable: 'You can book for someone else, and here is how.'

evidence.quote: She's going to be out most of the day, you know, she has done appointments and all I'm setting up all appointments for her.
evidence.insight: Susan manages logistics remotely while her friend occupies the space locally. The active lease information architecture must support this distributed pattern: one person sees the management view, the other sees the operational view.

evidence.quote: Good conceptual models are the key to understandable, enjoyable products: good communication is the key to good conceptual models.
evidence.insight: The platform's conceptual model must communicate a two-person booking structure clearly. Without distinct signifiers for the coordinator role and the occupant role, both users struggle to understand what actions are available to them and which information is relevant.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: role-selection signifier at the start of the proposal flow ('Booking for yourself?' / 'Booking for someone else?'). Secondary: role-specific information panels  the coordinator sees payment and scheduling; the occupant sees space details and check-in. Tertiary: shared information (listing details, host profile) available to both roles without duplication. The ordering ensures the system knows which role it is serving before presenting any information.
elements.disclosure_pattern: At proposal start: role-selection toggle, prominent and early in the flow (before any form fields). After role selection: the form restructures to collect coordinator profile and occupant profile sequentially, not simultaneously. During negotiation: status updates go to both users, but the coordinator receives logistics-focused summaries and the occupant receives space-focused summaries. During active lease: the Stays Manager renders a different primary view based on role  management for coordinator, operations for occupant. Both can access the other's view on demand.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: The role-selection toggle adds exactly one decision (2 options) to the start of the flow. Each role's profile requires maximum 4 fields (name, contact, relationship, specific needs). The dual-notification system sends maximum 2 messages per event  one per role  each containing maximum 3 data points relevant to that role. No user sees information intended for the other role unless they explicitly request it.
scan_order: Role selection: 'Booking for yourself?' / 'Booking for someone else?' (System 1: 'This service understands my situation', under 2 seconds)
Coordinator profile: name, contact, payment method (System 2: 'What do you need from me?', 2-5 seconds)
Occupant profile: name, arrival date, special needs (System 2: 'What does my friend need?', 5-8 seconds)
Role-specific information panels during active lease (System 1 on repeat visits: 'Show me what is relevant to my role', under 3 seconds)
exclude: A single-user form that forces the proxy to enter their own name as the guest. This creates incorrect records and a broken conceptual model.
Proxy booking hidden behind account settings or a help article. The signifier must appear at the natural decision point (start of proposal flow), not in a configuration menu.
Identical notifications sent to coordinator and occupant. Each role needs different information; sending everything to everyone creates noise.
A requirement for the occupant to create an account before the coordinator can complete the booking. Susan must be able to book on her friend's behalf without the friend being on the platform.

elements.title: Move-In Knowledge-in-the-World: House Manual as Chronological Action Sequence, Not Topic Reference
elements.problem: Susan's entire call is organized around preventing a catastrophic move-in failure for her friend flying from Oregon. The friend has never been to the space, has no local knowledge, and arrives with only the listing's digital signifiers as her conceptual model of the space. Norman distinguishes between 'knowledge in the head' (what the guest remembers from the listing) and 'knowledge in the world' (what is available in the environment at the moment of action). At move-in, the guest's knowledge in the head is limited and potentially distorted. She needs knowledge in the world: how to enter the building, find the room, use the Wi-Fi, contact the host if something is wrong, and exercise the cancellation guarantee if the space does not match. The House Manual is the primary vehicle for this knowledge, but only if it is organized by the guest's action sequence at arrival, not by topic category. Norman: 'A good conceptual model allows us to predict the effects of our actions. Without a good model, we operate by rote, blindly.' A topic-organized manual ('Wi-Fi,' 'Appliances,' 'Neighborhood') forces the guest to search for the right section at each step. A chronological manual ('Step 1: Enter the building,' 'Step 2: Find your room') maps directly to the action sequence.
elements.solution: Structure the House Manual as a chronological move-in sequence that maps to the guest's physical actions on arrival, with the cancellation guarantee as the most prominent element. The sequence is: (1) Access: building entry code, floor, apartment number, key/lockbox location. (2) Verify: a mini-checklist comparing listing claims to physical reality  private bathroom? private room? the bed and kitchen items shown in photos? (3) Connect: Wi-Fi network and password, host contact for immediate issues. (4) Safety net: first-night cancellation guarantee terms and how to exercise them  this is the most important signifier at move-in because it is the safety mechanism that made the booking possible. (5) Settle: house rules, shared space protocols, quiet hours, laundry, trash. (6) Explore: neighborhood basics, transit, grocery. Each section is expandable, one screen per step, with the current step always visible. Co-occupancy status is disclosed at Step 2 ('You may encounter Rita in common areas on weekends') because Susan specifically asked 'Would somebody else be in the place when she's there?' (1:20).

evidence.quote: I have to go and see the space and just to make sure that everything is legit. You know how sometimes people give you all kind of run around.
evidence.insight: Susan's anxiety is about the gap between listing claims and physical reality. The move-in verification checklist (Step 2) directly addresses this: it gives the guest a structured way to confirm the space matches the listing, transforming anxiety into actionable verification.

evidence.quote: Two of the most important characteristics of good design are discoverability and understanding. Discoverability: Is it possible to even figure out what actions are possible and where and how to perform them?
evidence.insight: At move-in, the guest must discover how to enter, verify, connect, and contact  all without prior physical experience. A chronological House Manual makes each action discoverable in the sequence the guest needs it, not in the sequence a content organizer categorized it.

evidence.quote: Would somebody else be in the place when she's there?
evidence.insight: Co-occupancy is a critical move-in variable that Susan surfaced in the evaluation call. If the guest discovers unexpected co-occupants at arrival, every prior trust signifier is invalidated. Co-occupancy status must be disclosed before arrival and re-confirmed in the House Manual's verification step.

evidence.quote: A good conceptual model allows us to predict the effects of our actions. Without a good model, we operate by rote, blindly; we do operations as we were told to do them; we can't fully appreciate why, what effects to expect, or what to do if things go wrong.
evidence.insight: The House Manual is the guest's conceptual model of the space and its rules. Norman's principle dictates that it must enable the guest to predict what happens at each step and know what to do if something goes wrong. The chronological structure does this by pairing each action with its expected outcome and its fallback.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: current step in the move-in sequence (access instructions on arrival, verification checklist on entry, Wi-Fi on settling). Secondary: cancellation guarantee  always visible as a persistent footer or banner during the first 24 hours, regardless of which step the guest is viewing. Tertiary: house rules and neighborhood details, available once the guest has completed access and verification. The ordering mirrors the guest's temporal needs: get in  check it  connect  know your rights  settle.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Pre-arrival (24 hours before): push notification with access instructions only (Step 1). No other details  reduce cognitive load to one action. On arrival: House Manual opens to Step 1 (access), with Steps 2-6 visible as a collapsed sequence below. After entering: Step 2 (verification checklist) expands automatically. Cancellation guarantee is a persistent banner during the first 24 hours. After first night: banner transitions from cancellation guarantee to house rules summary (Step 5). During active lease: House Manual shifts to reference mode (searchable by topic) after the first week, since the chronological sequence is no longer needed.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 1 step visible in detail at a time. Each step contains maximum 4 data points (e.g., Step 1: building address, entry code, floor number, door/lockbox description). The verification checklist (Step 2) has maximum 5 items matching the listing's primary claims. The cancellation guarantee summary is maximum 2 sentences. Total House Manual: 6 steps, never more than one screen of content per step.
scan_order: Current action step: building access code or verification item (System 1: 'What do I do right now?', under 2 seconds)
Cancellation guarantee banner: 'Not what you expected? You can cancel within 24 hours' (System 1 safety: 'I have an exit', 2-3 seconds)
Next step preview: collapsed title of the following step (System 1: 'What comes after this?', 3-4 seconds)
Host contact: quick-access button for immediate issues (System 2: 'How do I get help?', 4-5 seconds)
exclude: Topic-organized manual sections ('Wi-Fi,' 'Appliances,' 'Neighborhood') as the default structure. Chronological action sequence is the default; topic search is a secondary mode available after the first week.
Cancellation terms buried in a separate legal page or terms document. The guarantee must be a visual signifier at move-in, not a policy to look up.
House Manual content that assumes the guest read it before arrival. Each step must be self-contained and comprehensible at the moment of action.

Co-occupancy information disclosed for the first time at move-in. It must be signified on the listing page and re-confirmed in the House Manual  the guest should never be surprised by someone else in the space.

elements.title: Listing Space Composition Signifier: Room Type, Bathroom, and Co-Occupancy as Primary Descriptors
elements.problem: Susan's first three questions in the call are: 'Is it a full apartment or is it a bedroom?' (0:43), 'What about a bathroom?' (1:08), and 'Would somebody else be in the place when she's there?' (1:20). These three questions  space type, bathroom privacy, and co-occupancy  constitute the guest's primary decision variables for shared housing. Yet conventional listing information architecture leads with photos, price, and location. For a platform where many listings involve shared spaces, the guest's first question is not 'Where is it?' or 'How much?' but 'What am I sharing and with whom?' Norman's signifier principle states that people need 'some sign of what it is for, what is happening, and what the alternative actions are.' The listing card must signify the space composition  what the guest gets exclusively, what is shared, and who else is present  as its primary information layer, before price, location, or amenities.
elements.solution: Restructure listing cards and listing page headers to lead with a space composition signifier: a compact, scannable description of what the guest gets. The format is a three-part label: (1) Space type: 'Private Room' or 'Full Apartment' or 'Shared Room.' (2) Bathroom: 'Private Bath' or 'Shared Bath.' (3) Co-occupancy: 'Host present on weekends' or 'No other occupants' or 'Shared with 1 other guest.' This three-part label appears as the first text element on every listing card in search results and as the subtitle on every listing detail page. It answers Susan's first three questions in a single scan line. On the listing detail page, the space composition section expands to show: which rooms are private, which are shared, when the host or other occupants are present, and how common spaces (kitchen, living room) are used. The pattern is: lead with what the guest is sharing, because that is the primary anxiety in shared housing.

evidence.quote: Is it a full apartment or is it a bedroom? ... What about a bathroom? ... Would somebody else be in the place when she's there?
evidence.insight: Susan asks three questions in rapid succession, all about space composition. These are not secondary details  they are the primary decision variables that determine whether the listing is even worth evaluating. The information architecture must surface these answers before any other listing details.

evidence.quote: Signifiers communicate where the action should take place... signifiers must be perceivable, else they fail to function.
evidence.insight: The space composition label is a signifier that communicates what kind of space the listing affords. If this signifier is absent or buried in a details section, the guest must read the full description or call an agent to answer their primary question. The signifier fails if it requires effort to find.

evidence.quote: Would somebody else be in the place when she's there? ... She is going to be there, but she does, she goes out to go to work.
evidence.insight: Bryant explains that the host (Rita) will be present but goes to work during the day. This temporal co-occupancy pattern  host present on some days, absent on others  is critical information that a simple 'Shared' or 'Private' label cannot convey. The listing needs a co-occupancy schedule signifier: 'Host present weekdays during evenings; out during business hours.'

evidence.quote: When the system image is incoherent or inappropriate, then the user cannot easily use the device.
evidence.insight: If the listing shows beautiful photos of an empty apartment but the guest arrives to find a host and their belongings everywhere, the system image was incoherent  the photos implied 'full apartment' but the reality is 'shared space.' The space composition signifier prevents this incoherence by setting accurate expectations upfront.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: three-part space composition label (space type + bathroom + co-occupancy) as the first text element on every listing card and page header. Secondary: expanded space details  which rooms are private, which are shared, host/occupant schedule. Tertiary: amenities, features, and house rules that depend on the space composition (e.g., 'shared kitchen: guest shelf in fridge'). The ordering ensures the guest's primary anxiety (what am I sharing?) is answered before secondary evaluation (what features does it have?).
elements.disclosure_pattern: On listing cards in search results: three-part label visible immediately, no tap required ('Private Room  Private Bath  Host present weekends'). On listing detail page: space composition section at the top, before photos or price. On expand: detailed room-by-room breakdown with co-occupancy schedule. This matches Susan's question order: space type (0:43)  bathroom (1:08)  co-occupancy (1:20)  the information reveals in the sequence the guest naturally asks.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Three-part label: maximum 8 words total. Expanded space composition: maximum 5 line items (private bedroom, private/shared bath, kitchen access, common areas, co-occupancy schedule). Co-occupancy schedule: maximum 1 sentence ('Host works 9-5 weekdays; present evenings and weekends'). No ambiguous terms: 'Shared' must always specify with whom and when.
scan_order: Space type: 'Private Room' or 'Full Apartment' (System 1: 'What kind of space is this?', under 1 second)
Bathroom: 'Private Bath' or 'Shared Bath' (System 1: 'Do I have my own bathroom?', 1-2 seconds)
Co-occupancy: 'Host present weekends' or 'No other occupants' (System 1: 'Who else is there?', 2-3 seconds)
Expanded space details: room breakdown, schedule, house rules (System 2: detailed evaluation, 3-6 seconds)
exclude: Listing cards that lead with price or location before space composition. For shared housing, what you share matters more than what you pay until the space type is acceptable.
Co-occupancy information buried in the description paragraph or in house rules. It must be a primary signifier, not a discovery-by-reading detail.
Ambiguous labels like 'Shared Space' without specifying what is shared, with whom, and when. 'Shared' is not a useful signifier; 'Private Room, Shared Kitchen with Host' is.
Photos that imply a different space composition than reality (empty apartment photos when a host lives there). Photo captions must align with the space composition label.

elements.title: Layered Trust Verification Visual Stack: Photo Gallery, Guarantee Badge, and Host Card as Above-the-Fold Trust Triad
elements.problem: Susan demands physical inspection three times (2:14, 3:05, 3:42) because the listing's visual signifiers are insufficient to replace in-person verification. Her friend is flying from Oregon  the cost of a wrong decision includes an airline ticket, not just a booking fee. Susan's prior scam experiences ('you know how sometimes people give you all kind of run around,' 2:22) mean her System 1 default for remote housing is 'likely fraud.' Norman states that anti-affordances (the no-preview policy) must be discoverable and perceivable, with substitute signifiers prominently displayed. The listing page's visual hierarchy must place trust verification evidence  verified photos, cancellation guarantee, host identity  at the highest position in the visual hierarchy, above property features, amenities, and price. Currently, no visual pattern exists that structures trust evidence as the primary visual layer rather than supplementary detail.
elements.solution: Design the listing page's visual hierarchy so that trust verification occupies the top of the visual stack, with three distinct visual signifiers forming an above-the-fold trust triad: (1) A full-bleed verified photo gallery with a purple 'Verified by Split Lease' badge (--primary-purple background, white text, --rounded-pill shape) anchored to the gallery's top-left corner. Photos must cover the exact elements Susan asked about: room, bathroom (1:08), common areas, building entrance. The badge uses --shadow-purple-sm for subtle elevation to distinguish it from photo content. (2) A first-night cancellation guarantee badge displayed with equal visual weight to the nightly price. The badge uses --bg-off-white background with --secondary-purple text and a Feather 'shield' icon at --icon-sm size. It sits immediately beside or below the price, not in a separate section. Norman: 'Affordances exist even if they are not visible. For designers, their visibility is critical.' (3) A host identity card with verified photo (--avatar-md, --rounded-full), name in --font-weight-semibold, response time in --text-gray, and guest count. The card uses --shadow-sm elevation on --bg-white with --border-color border. These three signifiers must be perceivable within 6 seconds of page load without scrolling.

evidence.quote: I do have to see the room before she puts her tickets. I have to go and see the space and just to make sure that everything is legit. You know how sometimes people give you all kind of run around.
evidence.insight: Susan's demand for visual verification is a trust requirement rooted in prior negative experiences. The listing page's visual hierarchy must place verification evidence where the eye lands first  the photo gallery zone  not as supplementary detail below the fold.

evidence.quote: To be effective, affordances and anti-affordances have to be discoverable  perceivable. If an affordance or anti-affordance cannot be perceived, some means of signaling its presence is required: I call this property a signifier.
evidence.insight: The no-preview policy is an anti-affordance with no visual signifier. The trust triad serves as the perceivable substitute: verified photos replace in-person viewing, the cancellation badge replaces the safety of being able to walk away after seeing the space, and the host card replaces the face-to-face meeting. Each must be visually distinct and immediately scannable.

evidence.quote: If I like the room in the bathroom, I can, should have pictures. And she said, it's okay. I'll give you the deposit right there.
evidence.insight: Susan explicitly identifies photos as the acceptable visual substitute for physical inspection AND immediately couples it with readiness to pay. The visual design must treat the photo gallery as the primary conversion mechanism  the element that transforms distrust into deposit readiness.

evidence.quote: Signifiers communicate where the action should take place... signifiers must be perceivable, else they fail to function.
evidence.insight: The verification badge on photos, the guarantee badge near the price, and the host identity card are all signifiers that communicate trustworthiness. Each must be visually distinct from decorative elements  using the purple brand color, elevated shadow, and iconography that signals verification rather than marketing.

colors: --secondary-purple (rgb(109, 49, 194)) for guarantee badge text and shield icon
--text-gray (#6b7280) for response time and guest count
typography: Inter 600 (--font-weight-semibold) at --text-sm (12px) for verification badge label
Inter 600 at --text-base (14px) for guarantee badge text
Inter 600 at --text-md (16px) for host name
Inter 400 (--font-weight-normal) at --text-sm (12px) for response time and guest count
spacing: --spacing-2xl (24px) margin below the photo gallery before property details begin
new_tokens_needed: --trust-badge-bg: rgba(49, 19, 93, 0.85)  semi-transparent purple overlay for verification badge on photos, ensuring readability over varied photo backgrounds
--trust-guarantee-border: rgba(109, 49, 194, 0.2)  subtle purple border for the guarantee badge, distinguishing it from general UI badges

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA minimum. Verification badge: white text on --primary-purple (#31135D) = 13.5:1 contrast ratio (AAA). Guarantee badge: --secondary-purple text on --bg-off-white requires verification  rgb(109, 49, 194) on rgb(252, 250, 255) yields approximately 5.2:1 (AA pass). Host card text: --text-dark on --bg-white = 16.1:1 (AAA). All trust signifiers must pass AA at minimum because trust elements cannot be ambiguous or hard to read.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The eye sees the photo gallery first (largest visual element, full-width). Within the gallery, the verification badge is the first text element perceived (top-left anchor, high-contrast purple on photo). Below the gallery, the guarantee badge and price sit at the same visual level (equal font weight, adjacent positioning). The host identity card follows as a self-contained unit. Property features, amenities, and description begin only after all three trust signifiers are visible. The pattern is: TRUST first, DETAILS second.
elements.brand_alignment: The purple verification badge directly uses the brand's primary color (#31135D) as a trust signal, reinforcing the association between the Split Lease brand and verified quality. The guarantee badge uses --secondary-purple for interactive/actionable elements, consistent with the style guide's CTA color system. The host card uses neutral colors (--bg-white, --text-dark, --text-gray) to frame the host as a real person rather than a branded element. Purple-tinted shadows (--shadow-purple-sm) on the verification badge create a subtle brand glow that connects trust evidence to the Split Lease visual identity.

elements.title: Platform Identity Signifier: Persistent Visual Anchor Communicating the Non-Continuous Model
elements.problem: Susan misidentifies Split Lease as a real estate brokerage (4:55: 'Real estate Agent'). She does not understand the non-continuous nights model ('Like seven nights a week?' at 0:43). Norman warns that 'hand-lettered signs pasted on products are the equivalent of poor design'  when you need to explain what something is, the design itself has failed. The platform's visual identity carries no perceivable signifier that communicates 'part-time housing' to a first-time visitor. The system image is incoherent because no visual element consistently communicates what this service is across pages. Every page the guest encounters  landing, search results, listing detail  must carry a visually consistent identity signifier that functions like a wayfinding marker: it tells the guest 'you are in a part-time housing platform' before they evaluate any specific listing.
elements.solution: Design a persistent identity signifier that appears on every page, using consistent visual treatment to build recognition through repetition. The signifier is a compact badge or tagline that communicates the core model in the guest's vocabulary. Visual specification: (1) On the landing page, the identity signifier is the hero headline: 'Book the nights you need' in Inter --font-weight-bold at --text-4xl (36px), color --primary-purple. Below it, a one-line subtitle in Inter --font-weight-normal at --text-lg (18px), color --text-gray: 'Part-time rooms and apartments, by the night.' (2) On listing cards in search results, a compact schedule badge appears as the first text element below the photo: a pill-shaped label (--rounded-pill, --bg-off-white background, --text-purple text) reading 'Weeknights' or 'Flexible' or 'Mon-Fri'  the available schedule pattern in 1-2 words. (3) On the listing detail page, the same schedule badge appears as a subtitle directly below the listing title, before the price. The pattern is: the identity signifier uses a consistent visual treatment (purple text on off-white pill) across all pages so the guest recognizes it as a system-level marker, not a listing-specific detail.

evidence.quote: Real estate Agent.
evidence.insight: Susan's misidentification reveals that no visual element on the platform communicates its category. The identity signifier must be visually prominent enough that a 2-second glance at any page tells the guest 'this is a part-time housing platform,' not a real estate brokerage, not an Airbnb, not a hotel.

evidence.quote: The designer of the product and the person using the product form somewhat disconnected vertices of a triangle... the entire burden of communication is on the system image.
evidence.insight: The system image is the visual totality that the user perceives. If every page lacks a visual signifier for 'part-time housing,' the system image communicates nothing about the service category. The identity signifier must be as persistent as a logo  present on every page, consistently styled, immediately recognizable.

evidence.quote: Like seven nights a week?
evidence.insight: Susan's default conceptual model for housing is full-time occupancy. The identity signifier must visually interrupt this default model. The schedule badge ('Weeknights,' 'Mon-Fri') on every listing card serves as a repeated visual correction: this is NOT full-time, this is part-time, this is specific nights.

evidence.quote: People need some way of understanding the product or service they wish to use, some sign of what it is for, what is happening, and what the alternative actions are.
evidence.insight: The identity signifier is a signifier at the service level, not the component level. It does not signify a button or a form field  it signifies what the entire platform IS. Its visual treatment must be elevated above component-level badges through size, color, and placement.

colors: --primary-purple (#31135D) for hero headline on landing page
--text-purple (rgb(82, 31, 147)) for schedule badge text on listing cards and detail pages
--text-gray (#6b7280) for subtitle text on landing page
typography: Inter 700 (--font-weight-bold) at --text-4xl (36px) for landing page hero headline
Inter 400 at --text-lg (18px) for landing page subtitle
Inter 600 (--font-weight-semibold) at --text-xs (11px) for schedule badge on listing cards, with --letter-spacing-medium (0.05em) for uppercase treatment
Inter 500 (--font-weight-medium) at --text-sm (12px) for schedule badge on listing detail page
spacing: --spacing-xs (4px) vertical padding inside schedule badge pill
--spacing-sm (8px) horizontal padding inside schedule badge pill
--spacing-4xl (32px) margin below hero headline on landing page
--spacing-sm (8px) gap between schedule badge and listing title on detail page
new_tokens_needed: --identity-badge-bg: #F3F0F8  a slightly more purple-tinted background than --bg-off-white, specifically for the identity signifier badges so they are visually distinguishable from general UI pills

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA minimum. Hero headline: --primary-purple (#31135D) on --bg-white (#ffffff) = 13.5:1 (AAA). Schedule badge: --text-purple (rgb(82, 31, 147)) on --bg-off-white (rgb(252, 250, 255)) requires verification  approximately 7.1:1 (AAA pass). Subtitle: --text-gray (#6b7280) on --bg-white = 4.6:1 (AA pass, borderline). If the proposed text color revision to #5A6370 is adopted, contrast improves to 5.9:1.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: On the landing page, the eye sees the hero headline first (largest text, brand color, top of page). On listing cards, the eye sees the photo first, then the schedule badge (first text element, colored pill that stands out from neutral card text). On the listing detail page, the eye sees the listing title, then the schedule badge directly below (before price or location). The pattern is: the identity signifier is always the first or second element in the scan path on every page type.
elements.brand_alignment: The identity signifier uses the primary brand purple for the most important instance (hero headline) and the text-purple variant for repeated instances (schedule badges), creating a visual hierarchy within the brand color family. The off-white pill background connects to the platform's warm purple-tinted aesthetic (--bg-off-white, --off-white) established in the style guide. The uppercase treatment with --letter-spacing-medium for card badges follows the style guide's label convention, making the schedule badge feel like a native UI element rather than an added sticker.

elements.title: Space Composition Label: Three-Part Visual Signifier for Room Type, Bathroom, and Co-Occupancy
elements.problem: Susan's first three questions in the call are about space composition: 'Is it a full apartment or is it a bedroom?' (0:43), 'What about a bathroom?' (1:08), 'Would somebody else be in the place when she's there?' (1:20). These three questions  space type, bathroom privacy, co-occupancy  constitute the primary decision variables for shared housing. Yet conventional listing card designs lead with photos, price, and location. For a platform where many listings involve shared spaces, the guest's first question is not 'Where is it?' or 'How much?' but 'What am I sharing and with whom?' Norman's signifier principle demands that the answer to this question be perceivable without effort. The visual design must surface space composition as a scannable, standardized label that the guest can evaluate in under 2 seconds per listing card.
elements.solution: Design a three-part space composition label as the first text element on every listing card, immediately below the photo. The label uses a consistent visual format: three short descriptors separated by a mid-dot () character, each using a Feather icon prefix for rapid scanning. Visual specification: (1) Format: '[icon] Private Room  [icon] Private Bath  [icon] Host present evenings'  all on one line or wrapping to a maximum of two lines. (2) Typography: Inter --font-weight-medium at --text-sm (12px), color --text-dark for the space type and bathroom descriptors, color --text-gray for the co-occupancy descriptor. The co-occupancy element is intentionally softer because it is contextual information, not a hard attribute. (3) Icons: Feather 'home' for space type, Feather 'droplet' for bathroom, Feather 'users' for co-occupancy, all at --icon-xs (16px), color matching their text. (4) On the listing detail page, the same label appears as a horizontal bar below the listing title, with each descriptor expanding on tap/click to show details (e.g., 'Host present evenings' expands to 'Rita works 9-5. She is typically home evenings and weekends. Common areas are shared.'). (5) The label sits above price and location, because for shared housing, space composition is the prerequisite filter before budget evaluation.

evidence.quote: Is it a full apartment or is it a bedroom? ... What about a bathroom? ... Would somebody else be in the place when she's there?
evidence.insight: Susan asks three questions in rapid succession, all about space composition. These are not secondary details  they are the primary decision variables. The visual design must answer all three in a single scan line on every listing card.

evidence.quote: Signifiers communicate where the action should take place... signifiers must be perceivable, else they fail to function.
evidence.insight: The space composition label is a signifier that communicates what kind of space the listing affords. If the label is absent, buried, or requires reading a paragraph description, it fails as a signifier. The three-part format with icons enables perception in under 2 seconds.

evidence.quote: Would somebody else be in the place when she's there? ... She is going to be there, but she does, she goes out to go to work.
evidence.insight: Co-occupancy is temporal, not binary. 'Shared' is not a useful label; 'Host present evenings' is. The visual design must communicate WHEN sharing occurs, not just WHETHER sharing occurs.

evidence.quote: When the system image is incoherent or inappropriate, then the user cannot easily use the device.
evidence.insight: If photos show an empty apartment but the guest arrives to find a host and their belongings, the system image was incoherent. The space composition label prevents this by setting accurate visual expectations that align with the physical reality.

colors: --text-dark (#1a1a1a) for space type and bathroom descriptors
--border-color (#e5e7eb) for bottom border of the expanded detail section on listing pages
typography: Inter 500 (--font-weight-medium) at --text-sm (12px) for space type and bathroom labels
Inter 400 (--font-weight-normal) at --text-sm (12px) for co-occupancy label
Inter 400 at --text-sm (12px) for expanded co-occupancy detail text, color --text-description (#374151)
spacing: --spacing-xs (4px) gap between icon and text within each descriptor
--spacing-md (12px) margin below the space composition label before price/location
--spacing-lg (16px) padding inside the expanded detail section

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA minimum. --text-dark (#1a1a1a) on --bg-white = 16.1:1 (AAA). --text-gray (#6b7280) on --bg-white = 4.6:1 (AA pass). If adopting the proposed revision to #5A6370, contrast rises to 5.9:1. Icons inherit their label's color, maintaining the same contrast ratio. The mid-dot separator does not carry semantic information and is decorative, so its lower contrast (--text-light-gray at 2.6:1) is acceptable per WCAG guidance on decorative elements.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: On listing cards, the eye scans: photo  space composition label  price  location. The space composition label is positioned to be the FIRST text the guest reads after the photo, because it answers the prerequisite question ('Is this the kind of space I need?') before budget or location questions become relevant. On the listing detail page, the label sits in the header zone between the title and the price, functioning as a subtitle that qualifies the listing before evaluation begins.
elements.brand_alignment: The space composition label uses neutral colors (--text-dark, --text-gray) rather than brand purple because it is informational, not promotional. It communicates facts about the space, not brand identity. This maintains the visual distinction between trust/identity signifiers (purple) and factual/descriptive signifiers (neutral), consistent with the style guide's color usage patterns. Feather icons follow the style guide's icon library policy.

elements.title: Natural-Language Duration and Schedule Selectors with Real-Time Visual Translation
elements.problem: Susan thinks in calendar months ('one month or two months,' 0:11) and weekday names ('Monday to Friday'). The platform requires night counts ('30 night minimum,' 1:35). Bryant performs the vocabulary translation twice in the call. Norman's mapping principle states that 'natural mapping, taking advantage of spatial analogies, leads to immediate understanding.' The proposal creation form's visual design must accept the guest's natural vocabulary and translate it visually in real time, the way Bryant did verbally. The visual challenge is: how to design input controls that feel like natural language (months, weekdays) while displaying the platform's internal calculation (night count, total price) as a secondary layer that builds, not breaks, the guest's conceptual model.
elements.solution: Design duration and schedule input controls as preset-based selectors with a real-time translation summary bar. Visual specification: (1) Schedule presets: a horizontal row of pill-shaped toggle buttons ('Weekdays', 'Weekends', 'Full Week', 'Custom'). Each pill uses --rounded-pill, --bg-light-gray when inactive, --secondary-purple background with --white text when active. Active state transitions use --transition-fast with --easing-ease. (2) Duration presets: a row of selectable cards ('About 1 month', 'About 2 months', '3+ months', 'Custom'). Each card uses --rounded-xl, --border-color border when inactive, --secondary-purple border with --bg-off-white background when active. (3) Translation summary bar: a horizontal bar below the selectors, --bg-light background with --rounded-lg, displaying the computed result in Inter --font-weight-medium at --text-base: 'Mon-Fri for 2 months = 40 nights  $X/night  $Y total'. The summary updates in real time as the guest modifies selections, with each change producing a subtle pulse animation (--transition-base, opacity 0.5  1.0) to draw attention to the updated value. (4) 'Custom' options reveal a calendar grid or individual day toggles only when tapped, keeping the default view clean. The calendar grid uses the day badge component from the style guide (--day-badge-selected-bg for active days).

evidence.quote: Like seven nights a week?
evidence.insight: Susan defaults to full-time because she has no visual model for part-time housing. The schedule presets ('Weekdays,' 'Weekends') serve as visual signifiers for the part-time concept  the guest does not need to understand 'non-continuous nights,' they just need to tap the button that matches their pattern.

evidence.quote: Natural mapping, taking advantage of spatial analogies, leads to immediate understanding.
evidence.insight: Pill-shaped preset buttons are a natural mapping: each button represents one recognizable schedule pattern, and tapping it is the equivalent of saying 'Monday to Friday.' A number field labeled 'minimum nights' is an arbitrary mapping that requires cognitive translation.

evidence.quote: Rita would require a 30 night minimum... five nights a week for like two months would be something that would, could work.
evidence.insight: Bryant computes the translation verbally. The translation summary bar performs this same function visually: it shows both the guest's natural selection ('Mon-Fri for 2 months') and the platform's computation ('40 nights at $X'), maintaining transparency and building the correct conceptual model.

evidence.quote: Feedback must be immediate: even a delay of a tenth of a second can be disconcerting.
evidence.insight: The real-time summary update with pulse animation provides Norman's immediate feedback: the guest sees the consequence of their selection (night count, total cost) within 100ms. No spinner, no page reload, no delay.

colors: --bg-light-gray (#f3f4f6) for inactive preset pills and inactive duration cards
--secondary-purple (rgb(109, 49, 194)) for active preset pill background and active duration card border
--text-dark (#1a1a1a) for inactive preset pill text and duration card labels
--chat-purple (rgb(75, 71, 206)) for active day badges in calendar grid (or --day-badge-selected-bg if proposed tokens adopted)
typography: Inter 600 (--font-weight-semibold) at --text-base (14px) for preset pill labels
Inter 500 (--font-weight-medium) at --text-md (16px) for duration card primary labels ('About 2 months')
Inter 400 at --text-sm (12px) for duration card secondary annotations ('approx. 40 nights')
Inter 500 at --text-base (14px) for translation summary bar text
Inter 600 at --text-sm-md (13px) for day badges in calendar grid
spacing: --spacing-2xl (24px) vertical gap between the selector rows and the summary bar
new_tokens_needed: --input-active-bg: rgba(109, 49, 194, 0.06)  very subtle purple wash for active duration card backgrounds, lighter than --bg-off-white to prevent the active state from feeling heavy when multiple cards are on screen

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA minimum. Active preset pill: --white text on --secondary-purple (rgb(109, 49, 194)) = approximately 6.3:1 (AA pass). Inactive preset pill: --text-dark (#1a1a1a) on --bg-light-gray (#f3f4f6) = approximately 14.5:1 (AAA). Summary bar: --text-description (#374151) on --bg-light (#f9fafb) = approximately 9.2:1 (AAA). Day badge active: --white on --chat-purple (rgb(75, 71, 206)) = approximately 5.5:1 (AA pass). All interactive elements meet 48px minimum touch target per style guide accessibility requirements.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The eye scans: schedule presets (first row, horizontal, colorful when active)  duration presets (second row, card format)  translation summary bar (bottom, neutral background, computed result). The active state (purple fill or border) draws the eye to the guest's current selection. The summary bar is deliberately lower in hierarchy (neutral background, medium text weight) because it is a readout, not an input  the guest interacts with the presets, and the summary reflects the consequence.
elements.brand_alignment: Active states use --secondary-purple, consistent with the style guide's CTA color for interactive elements. The pill shape (--rounded-pill) follows the style guide's button convention. Day badges use the same visual pattern as the Split Lease signature day badge component defined in the style guide. The translation summary bar's neutral background (--bg-light) establishes it as an informational zone rather than an interactive zone, maintaining the style guide's distinction between action elements (purple) and information elements (neutral).

elements.title: Negotiation Timeline: Visual Progress States with Prioritized Feedback Urgency
elements.problem: The Susan call contains a real-time negotiation with immediate verbal feedback at every exchange. The platform's negotiation is asynchronous  the guest submits a proposal and waits hours or days. Norman states: 'Feedback must be immediate: even a delay of a tenth of a second can be disconcerting.' When the phone call drops for 20 seconds at 2:42-3:05, both parties scramble with 'Can you hear me?'  trust erodes instantly from feedback loss. The visual design challenge is: how to make an asynchronous process feel transparent and progressing, rather than silent and abandoned. Every moment in the negotiation must have a visible, informative signifier. The visual pattern must distinguish between different urgency levels  a counter-offer requiring action looks different from a 'still waiting' status  so the guest develops a visual vocabulary for negotiation states.
elements.solution: Design the negotiation status as a vertical timeline with discrete visual states, each with a distinct color and icon treatment that communicates urgency at a glance. Visual specification: (1) Timeline structure: a vertical line (2px, --border-color) with circular state nodes (--icon-sm size, 20px diameter) at each step. Completed states use a solid purple circle (--secondary-purple fill, Feather 'check' icon in white). The current state uses a larger pulsing circle (24px, --secondary-purple border, --bg-off-white fill) with a subtle pulse animation (scale 1.0  1.05, --transition-slow, infinite, ease-in-out). Future states use an empty circle (--border-color border, --bg-white fill). (2) State labels: each node has a one-line label (Inter --font-weight-semibold at --text-base, --text-dark) and a one-line context (Inter --font-weight-normal at --text-sm, --text-gray). Example: 'Host Reviewing' / 'Rita usually responds in 6 hours.' (3) Urgency differentiation: 'Your Turn' states use --accent-coral (proposed) or --protocol-danger as an attention color  the node circle uses coral/red border, the label is bolded, and a subtle left-border accent (3px, --accent-coral) highlights the entire row. 'Still Waiting' states use the neutral pulse. 'Resolved' states (accepted/declined) use --secondary-purple for acceptance or --text-gray for decline. (4) Counter-offer changes are shown as an inline diff: changed terms highlighted with --bg-off-white background and --secondary-purple left border, unchanged terms dimmed to --text-light-gray.

evidence.quote: Can you hear me, Susan? Me? Yep. Can you hear me? No, I, yeah. You're you're back. I can hear you. Can you hear me? Yes. I can hear you.
evidence.insight: A 20-second feedback gap causes immediate anxiety. The pulsing current-state node is the visual equivalent of a heartbeat  it communicates 'the system is alive and processing' even when nothing has changed, preventing the 'Can you hear me?' anxiety in the digital context.

evidence.quote: Feedback has to be planned. All actions need to be confirmed, but in a manner that is unobtrusive. Feedback must also be prioritized, so that unimportant information is presented in an unobtrusive fashion, but important signals are presented in a way that does capture attention.
evidence.insight: The urgency differentiation (purple for routine, coral/red for action-required) implements Norman's feedback prioritization. Routine states (host reviewing, proposal sent) are calm purple. Action-required states (your turn, counter-offer) use the warm accent color to capture attention without alarming.

evidence.quote: I'll be in contact with Rita. And like I said, I'll keep you updated.
evidence.insight: Bryant's human promise of ongoing updates is replaced by the timeline's visual persistence  the guest can return to the timeline at any time and immediately see the current state, the context, and the next expected event. No human promise needed.

evidence.quote: Feedback must be immediate: even a delay of a tenth of a second can be disconcerting. If the delay is too long, people often give up, going off to do other activities.
evidence.insight: The subtle pulse animation on the current state node provides continuous visual feedback that the process is active, even during long waits. This is the visual equivalent of a loading indicator, but softer and more persistent  it does not demand attention, it simply confirms aliveness.

colors: --secondary-purple (rgb(109, 49, 194)) for completed state nodes and accepted state
--bg-off-white (rgb(252, 250, 255)) for current state node fill and counter-offer diff background
--border-color (#e5e7eb) for timeline line and future state node borders
--text-light-gray (#9ca3af) for dimmed unchanged terms in counter-offer diffs
--protocol-danger (#DC3545) or proposed --accent-coral (#E85D4C) for 'Your Turn' urgency accent
--white for check icon inside completed nodes
typography: Inter 600 (--font-weight-semibold) at --text-base (14px) for state labels
Inter 400 (--font-weight-normal) at --text-sm (12px) for state context and timeline details
Inter 700 (--font-weight-bold) at --text-base (14px) for 'Your Turn' urgency label
Inter 500 at --text-sm (12px) for counter-offer diff text
spacing: --spacing-md (12px) horizontal gap between node circle and label text
--spacing-sm (8px) gap between label and context line
new_tokens_needed: --timeline-pulse-color: rgba(109, 49, 194, 0.15)  the subtle purple glow used for the pulsing current-state animation ring, lower opacity than --shadow-purple-sm to avoid visual heaviness on sustained animation

--urgency-accent: #E85D4C  warm coral for action-required states (aligns with proposed --accent-coral), needed because the current production palette has no warm attention-capture color outside of --protocol-danger which carries 'error' connotations rather than 'your turn' connotations

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA minimum. State labels: --text-dark on --bg-white = 16.1:1 (AAA). Context lines: --text-gray on --bg-white = 4.6:1 (AA pass). Urgency accent: --accent-coral (#E85D4C) or --protocol-danger (#DC3545) on --bg-white  both exceed 4.5:1 for text (coral: approximately 4.5:1, danger: approximately 5.5:1). Completed node: white check icon on --secondary-purple = approximately 6.3:1 (AA pass). The pulse animation must respect prefers-reduced-motion: when reduced motion is active, replace the pulse with a static purple ring (--secondary-purple border, no animation).
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: The eye scans the timeline top-to-bottom, with the pulsing current-state node drawing primary attention (motion attracts the eye). Within each state, the label is read first (semibold, dark), then the context (regular, gray). 'Your Turn' states break the scan pattern with the coral accent, pulling the eye to the action-required state regardless of its position in the timeline. Completed states recede (check icon, no motion) so the current and next states dominate the visual field.
elements.brand_alignment: The timeline uses --secondary-purple for progress and completion states, consistent with the style guide's use of this color for positive interactive outcomes. The --border-color line maintains the understated structural aesthetic of the style guide. The proposed warm urgency accent (--accent-coral) aligns with Paula Scher's proposed color revision that adds warmth to balance the cool purple palette. Purple-tinted shadows on the pulsing node (--shadow-purple-sm) subtly reinforce the brand identity even in status communication. The prefers-reduced-motion support follows the style guide's accessibility requirements.

elements.title: Move-In House Manual: Chronological Visual Sequence with Persistent Cancellation Safety Banner
elements.problem: Susan's friend is flying from Oregon with no prior physical experience of the space. At move-in, the gap between digital signifiers (listing photos, description) and physical reality is maximum. Susan's entire call is organized around preventing a catastrophic move-in failure. Norman distinguishes between 'knowledge in the head' (what the guest remembers) and 'knowledge in the world' (what is available at the moment of action). The House Manual must deliver knowledge-in-the-world at the exact moment the guest needs it, organized by the guest's physical action sequence at arrival, not by topic category. The cancellation guarantee  which Bryant improvised at 3:16  must be the most visually prominent element during the first 24 hours, because it is the safety net that made the entire booking possible. The visual design challenge is: how to present a multi-step reference document that feels like a guided walkthrough on a phone screen, with one clear action per view and a persistent safety signal.
elements.solution: Design the House Manual as a mobile-first stepped sequence with a persistent cancellation guarantee banner. Visual specification: (1) Stepped sequence: a vertically scrolling page with numbered step cards, each occupying roughly one screen height. Each card has a step number (Inter --font-weight-bold at --text-2xl, --primary-purple, opacity 0.15 as a large background numeral), a step title (Inter --font-weight-semibold at --text-lg, --text-dark), and 3-4 data points (Inter --font-weight-normal at --text-base, --text-description). Steps: 1-Access, 2-Verify, 3-Connect, 4-Safety Net, 5-Settle, 6-Explore. (2) Persistent cancellation banner: a fixed-position bar at the bottom of the viewport during the first 24 hours. --gradient-purple-primary background (linear-gradient from #31135D to #5a2d8f), white text (Inter --font-weight-semibold at --text-sm), Feather 'shield' icon, message: 'Not what you expected? Cancel within 24 hours.' The banner uses --shadow-dark-sm for upward shadow to distinguish it from content. After 24 hours, the banner transitions (--transition-slow) to a dismissible notification and then disappears. (3) Step 2 (Verify) contains a visual checklist comparing listing claims to physical reality. Each item has a Feather 'check-circle' icon (--secondary-purple when confirmed, --border-color when pending) and a one-line label matching the listing's primary claims: 'Private bathroom,' 'Private room,' 'Wi-Fi works.' (4) The current step is visually emphasized: --bg-white card with --shadow-md elevation, while completed steps collapse to --bg-light with --shadow-sm. Upcoming steps show only their title and number, expanding as the guest progresses.

evidence.quote: I have to go and see the space and just to make sure that everything is legit. You know how sometimes people give you all kind of run around.
evidence.insight: Susan's anxiety is about the signifier-to-reality gap. The verification checklist (Step 2) directly addresses this by giving the guest a structured visual tool to confirm the space matches the listing. Each checked item transforms anxiety into confirmed trust.

evidence.quote: Two of the most important characteristics of good design are discoverability and understanding. Discoverability: Is it possible to even figure out what actions are possible and where and how to perform them?
evidence.insight: At move-in, every action (enter building, find room, connect Wi-Fi, contact host) must be discoverable from the House Manual. The stepped sequence makes each action discoverable in the order the guest needs it. The persistent banner makes the most critical affordance (cancellation) discoverable at all times.

evidence.quote: There would be something set up where if you come the first night and it's not something that would work, you have the flexibility to cancel.
evidence.insight: Bryant's improvised cancellation guarantee is the most important trust affordance in the journey. The persistent bottom banner makes it visually impossible to miss  it is the last thing the guest sees on every screen during the first 24 hours, reinforcing that they have a safety net.

evidence.quote: A good conceptual model allows us to predict the effects of our actions. Without a good model, we operate by rote, blindly.
evidence.insight: The numbered step cards create a conceptual model of the move-in process: the guest can see how many steps there are, which step they are on, and what comes next. This predictability reduces anxiety because the guest is never lost in the process  Norman's discoverability applied to a temporal sequence.

colors: --primary-purple (#31135D) for step numbers (at 0.15 opacity as background numerals) and gradient banner start color
typography: Inter 700 (--font-weight-bold) at --text-2xl (28px) for step background numbers
Inter 600 (--font-weight-semibold) at --text-lg (18px) for step titles
Inter 400 (--font-weight-normal) at --text-base (14px) for step content
Inter 600 at --text-sm (12px) for cancellation banner text
Inter 500 at --text-base (14px) for checklist item labels
spacing: --spacing-sm (8px) gap between banner icon and text
new_tokens_needed: --step-number-opacity: 0.08  for the large background step numeral, needs to be visible enough to provide orientation but light enough not to interfere with step content readability. 0.15 may be too heavy on mobile screens; 0.08 provides subtler guidance
--banner-safe-area-bottom: env(safe-area-inset-bottom, 0px)  for the persistent cancellation banner on notch-equipped mobile devices, ensuring the banner does not overlap with the home indicator

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA minimum. Banner text: --white on --primary-purple (#31135D) = 13.5:1 (AAA). Step titles: --text-dark on --bg-white = 16.1:1 (AAA). Step content: --text-description (#374151) on --bg-white = approximately 9.4:1 (AAA). Checklist confirmed icons: --secondary-purple on --bg-white = approximately 5.2:1 (AA pass). The gradient banner must maintain at least 4.5:1 contrast for white text across its entire gradient range (#31135D to #5a2d8f  both exceed 7:1 for white text). The persistent banner must not obscure critical content  minimum 16px spacing between the last content element and the banner top edge.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: On initial load, the eye sees the active step card (highest elevation, white background, largest text). The cancellation banner is perceived peripherally (bottom-fixed, dark background, small text) as a safety signal that does not compete with the current step's content. As the guest progresses, completed steps collapse (lower elevation, muted background), keeping the active step as the visual focus. The background step numeral provides orientation ('I am on step 3 of 6') without demanding attention. The verification checklist icons (Step 2) draw the eye through their color change (gray  purple) as items are confirmed, creating visual momentum.
elements.brand_alignment: The gradient cancellation banner uses --gradient-purple-primary, directly from the style guide's brand gradient system. The step number treatment (primary purple at low opacity) creates a branded structural element that is uniquely Split Lease  the deep purple numeral as a watermark. Feather icons follow the style guide's icon library policy. The shadow elevation system (--shadow-sm for collapsed, --shadow-md for active) follows the style guide's shadow hierarchy. Mobile-first design with safe area handling aligns with the style guide's responsive approach.

elements.title: Proxy Booking Visual Mode: Dual-Role Interface with Role-Colored Information Zones
elements.problem: Susan is booking on behalf of a friend from Oregon. She says 'I can give you a deposit on her behalf' (2:34) and 'I'm setting up all appointments for her' (3:58-4:31). The platform's visual design assumes a single user viewing a single interface. When two roles (coordinator and occupant) share one booking, the interface must visually distinguish whose information is displayed and whose actions are available. Norman's signifier principle requires that 'people need some way of understanding what is happening and what the alternative actions are.' If the proxy sees her friend's check-in instructions mixed with her own payment details, the conceptual model breaks  she does not know which information is for her and which is for the friend. The visual design must create a role-aware interface that uses color, layout, and labeling to signify 'this is for you' versus 'this is for the occupant.'
elements.solution: Design a visual role-differentiation system that activates when 'Booking for someone else' is selected. Visual specification: (1) Role toggle at proposal start: two cards side by side  'Booking for myself' (left, default active) and 'Booking for someone else' (right). Active card uses --secondary-purple border and --bg-off-white background. Inactive card uses --border-color border and --bg-white background. Each card has a Feather icon: 'user' for self, 'users' for proxy. (2) After proxy mode activation, the form splits into two visually distinct sections with a subtle color-coding system. Coordinator section: left-border accent (3px, --secondary-purple), label prefix 'Your' (Your name, Your contact, Your payment). Occupant section: left-border accent (3px, --accent-blue #4A90E2), label prefix using the occupant's name once entered or 'Guest' before entry (Guest name, Guest arrival date, Guest needs). (3) During active lease, the Stays Manager shows a role indicator badge at the top: 'Managing for [Friend's Name]' in a pill badge (--secondary-purple background, white text, --rounded-pill). Information panels are color-coded: coordinator-relevant panels (payment history, schedule management) have a subtle --bg-off-white background; occupant-relevant panels (check-in details, House Manual) have a subtle --bg-info (#f0f7ff) background. (4) Both roles can access all information, but their role-specific information is visually primary (full opacity, above the fold) while the other role's information is visually secondary (accessible via a 'View guest details' / 'View coordinator details' toggle).

evidence.quote: I like to see the place and I can give you a deposit on her behalf and she's ready to come whenever I can find her spot.
evidence.insight: Susan describes the split-responsibility pattern: she pays, the friend stays. The visual design must make this split legible  the coordinator's payment zone and the occupant's stay zone are visually distinct so neither person is confused about which information belongs to whom.

evidence.quote: People need some way of understanding the product or service they wish to use, some sign of what it is for, what is happening, and what the alternative actions are.
evidence.insight: The role-colored zones are signifiers that communicate 'this section is about YOUR role in the booking.'
