before_after.before: On FF search results, all listings look identical: photo, price, location. A nurse cannot distinguish a veteran host with 30 perfect stays from a first-time lister. Quality hosts invest in furnishing, communication, and maintenance but receive no platform-visible reward.
before_after.after: On Split Lease, search results show Trusted and Established badges. Quality hosts earn visible differentiation. Guests can filter for trusted hosts. The badge links to the full Trust Ledger. Quality investment has a visible platform reward, breaking the race-to-the-bottom that undifferentiated listings create.

implements_principles: communicates-003: Trust Credential Stack (mechanism before promise)
Zero to One: Breaking perfect competition through quality differentiation
Thiel: 'In perfect competition, a business is so focused on today's margins that it can't plan for a long-term future'

elements.name: Availability Truth Indicator
elements.problem_it_solves: On Furnished Finder, search results include occupied properties because FF has no booking data and hosts have no incentive to update availability. Nurses waste precious time contacting hosts who respond 'Sorry, it is already rented.' The Availability Truth Indicator provides real-time, booking-verified availability status on every listing, eliminating phantom listings entirely.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No directory-model platform can guarantee availability because they do not process bookings. The Availability Truth Indicator is only possible on a platform that controls the booking and stay lifecycle. It transforms availability from self-reported (unreliable) to system-verified (trustworthy).
elements.description: A compact status indicator on every listing card in search results and on listing detail pages. Three states: Available Now (green dot + 'Available from {date}'), Upcoming (amber dot + 'Available from {date}'), and Booked (no listing shown in default search -- filtered out automatically). The indicator includes a 'Last verified' timestamp that updates automatically when stay data changes. On listing detail pages, a mini calendar strip shows the next 90 days of availability at a glance. The calendar integrates with the host's cross-platform calendar if enabled.

visual_spec.layout: Inline indicator, height 20px, positioned below listing location in search cards
visual_spec.dot_size: 8px with subtle pulse animation for 'available now'

interaction_spec.default: Status dot and text visible. Verified timestamp visible on hover or always on detail page.
interaction_spec.hover: On search card: tooltip shows exact available date range and source ('Verified by booking data'). On detail page: calendar strip highlights on hover to show exact dates.
interaction_spec.filter: Search filter chip: 'Available now' / 'Available within 2 weeks' / 'Available within 30 days'
interaction_spec.calendar_interaction: Clicking on the calendar strip on the detail page selects dates for a proposal. Available ranges glow on hover.
interaction_spec.animation: Available Now dot: subtle pulse (opacity 0.6 to 1.0, 2s infinite). State change: cross-fade 200ms.
interaction_spec.responsive: Indicator scales to fit mobile cards. Calendar strip becomes scrollable on narrow screens.

do: Always show a specific date, not a range -- specificity builds trust
Use 'Verified by booking data' not 'Last updated' -- verification > timestamp
Filter out booked listings from default search to eliminate phantom listings entirely
dont: Never show 'Contact to check availability' -- that is FF's model and the problem we solve
Never display a 'last updated' timestamp without booking verification -- timestamps alone signal unreliability
Never show booked listings in search results unless the user explicitly requests all listings

elements.html_css:
Status Variants

Available from Mar 14 Verified by booking data
90-Day Calendar Strip (Detail Page)
Availability -- next 90 days

before_after.before: On FF, a nurse searches for housing in Boston, finds 15 results, contacts 5, and discovers 3 are already occupied. She has wasted 2 days of her tight timeline on phantom listings. FF has no way to know which listings are available because they process no bookings.
before_after.after: On Split Lease, every listing shows a verified availability status. Booked properties do not appear in search results. The nurse sees only properties she can actually book. The 90-day calendar strip shows exact availability windows. Zero time wasted on phantom listings.

implements_principles: Zero to One: Technology allows us to do more with less
communicates-001: Anchor with known data before asking for decisions

effort.estimated_scope: 2 sprints for core indicator + search filter, +2 sprints for cross-platform calendar sync

elements.name: Housing Career Dashboard
elements.problem_it_solves: On Furnished Finder, the 8th housing search is as cold-start as the 1st. The platform has no memory of past stays, preferences, or outcomes. A travel nurse who has used FF for 3 years receives no benefit from her loyalty. The Housing Career Dashboard creates a persistent, learning profile that makes every search faster and more accurate than the last.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No mid-term housing platform builds longitudinal intelligence. The Housing Career Dashboard requires end-to-end data: search behavior, booking decisions, stay outcomes, reviews, and return patterns. FF has only search behavior. This creates the switching cost that Thiel identifies as essential for durable monopoly: leaving SL means abandoning your housing history.
elements.description: A personal dashboard accessible from the main navigation, showing the guest's complete housing history and learned preferences. The top section shows a summary: 'N stays across M cities, average rating given: X, preferred stay length: Y weeks.' Below, a timeline of past stays with micro-review snippets, host names, and quick-rebook options. A 'Your Preferences' section shows learned preferences (inferred from past stays + explicitly set): neighborhood type, price range, must-have amenities, commute tolerance. These preferences auto-populate search filters when the guest starts a new search. A 'Recommended for You' section shows new listings that match the learned profile. For hosts, a parallel version shows occupancy analytics, revenue trends, and tenant satisfaction over time.

visual_spec.layout: Single-column dashboard, max-width 720px, centered. Header hero with summary stats, followed by card sections.
visual_spec.hero_gradient: Linear gradient from #31135D to rgb(109, 49, 194), text in white

interaction_spec.stay_cards: Click to expand full stay detail: review given, host response, photos from that stay.
interaction_spec.preferences: Each preference is editable: click to toggle or adjust. Changes persist and affect future search results.
interaction_spec.rebook: 'Stay again' button on each past stay card sends the guest to the host's current listing with dates pre-populated.
interaction_spec.recommendations: Recommended listings update in real time as preferences change. Tap to view listing detail.
interaction_spec.animation: Hero stats count up on first load (400ms). Stay timeline cards stagger in (50ms delay each). Preference toggles: smooth spring transition.
interaction_spec.responsive: Full-width on mobile. Hero stats stack in 2x2 grid. Stay timeline becomes vertical scroll.

preference_examples.amenities: Dedicated workspace, In-unit laundry, Near transit

copy_spec.empty_state: Your housing career starts with your first stay. Each stay teaches us what you love -- and what to avoid.
do: Show how preferences were learned: '(learned from 4 stays)' builds trust in the algorithm
Include the 'Stay again' shortcut -- repeat bookings are the highest-value conversion
Celebrate milestones: '5th stay completed!' -- this builds identity and switching costs
dont: Never show the career dashboard to first-time users -- they have no career yet. Show the empty state instead.
Never auto-apply preferences without showing them first -- the user must feel in control of what the platform 'knows'
Never display negative stay data prominently -- the career is aspirational, not judgmental

before_after.before: A nurse on her 8th FF search starts from scratch: type a city, scroll through listings, contact strangers, hope for the best. The platform knows nothing about her 7 previous stays, preferred neighborhoods, price sensitivity, or which host types worked well. The 8th search is identical to the 1st.
before_after.after: A nurse on her 8th SL search opens her Housing Career Dashboard: 7 stays completed, preferences learned, recommended listings pre-filtered. She can rebook a past host with one tap or start a new search with her preferences pre-loaded. The 8th search takes 5 minutes because the platform remembers the first 7.

implements_principles: Zero to One: Last mover advantage through stored value and switching costs
works-001: System 1 recognition (the dashboard shows her own data, not a blank search)
communicates-002: Single-sum display (summary stats at top, details on demand)

effort.estimated_scope: 5-6 sprints for core dashboard + preference learning, +2 sprints for recommendation engine

elements.name: Legitimacy Ladder Pre-Message Panel
elements.problem_it_solves: It prevents users from entering message flow with pure speed framing by making trust evidence, guarantees, and unknowns visible before first contact.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: Roomster and peers rush users to chat; this element makes transparency itself the default, including explicit unknowns that most marketplaces hide.
elements.description: This panel appears above listing actions and enforces a trust-first reading order: claim, evidence, guarantee, unknown. Users can still message quickly, but they see risk context first and get a structured disconfirming checklist. The component converts vibe-based trust into evidence-based trust without removing choice.

visual_spec.layout: Two-column surface in a 960px container: left trust ladder rails and right action stack; collapses to single column under 768px.
visual_spec.background: var(--bg-white) on top of a subtle var(--bg-off-white) radial wash.
visual_spec.border: 1px solid var(--border-color) with top accent strip in var(--secondary-purple).
visual_spec.color_usage: Primary purple anchors hierarchy, secondary purple marks verified states, accent purple highlights unresolved unknowns and caution prompts.

interaction_spec.default_state: Four ladder rows are visible with status chips for Claimed, Verified, Guaranteed, and Unknown.
interaction_spec.hover: Row card elevates with purple-tinted shadow and reveals one-line audit detail.
interaction_spec.click: Clicking a row opens inline evidence text and source timestamp.
interaction_spec.animation: Rows fade-up in 220ms stagger; chip color transitions in 200ms ease-in-out.
interaction_spec.responsive: On mobile, rows become full-width stacked cards with 48px minimum tap targets and CTA pinned below ladder.

copy_spec.secondary_text: Review what is verified, what is guaranteed by Split Lease, and what still needs your confirmation.
copy_spec.micro_copy: Buttons: 'Message host now', 'Run disconfirming checklist'. Labels: 'Claimed', 'Verified by ID + lease docs', 'Guaranteed payment rail', 'Unknown: in-person room condition'.
do: Lead with evidence language before urgency language.
Name unknowns directly in plain words.
Keep guarantees concrete and time-bound.
dont: Do not reduce trust to one badge.
Do not hide unknowns behind expandable legal text.
Do not gate core trust evidence behind paywalls.

elements.html_css:
Split Lease Trust Ladder

Trust check before you message

Room on W 109th St is available for Mon-Thu stays. Review claim, evidence, guarantee, and unknown in one pass.

Claimed: private furnished roomClaimed

Host states private bedroom, in-unit laundry, and weekly cleaning rotation.

Verified: ID + lease authorityVerified

Government ID matched and lease authority documents checked 2 days ago.

Guaranteed: payment protection railGuaranteed

Split Lease holds funds until move-in checklist completion.

Unknown: current room conditionUnknown

No recent live walkthrough in last 14 days. Schedule verification call.

Disconfirming checklist

Before first message, confirm high-risk details.

  • Request a same-week live video walkthrough.
  • Confirm exact move-in and move-out handoff process.
  • Review utility split and cleaning responsibilities.

before_after.before: Roomster pushes users from listing browse to messaging with minimal pre-message trust architecture, so legitimacy checks happen late and inconsistently.
before_after.after: Split Lease inserts a transparent legitimacy ladder before messaging so users evaluate claim, evidence, guarantee, and unknown by default.

elements.name: Probability-Aware Match Card
elements.problem_it_solves: It stops users from using rank position and headline rent as proxies for quality by surfacing response, fit, and trust probabilities with cost clarity.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: Competitors optimize for browse volume; this card makes uncertainty explicit and explains why a listing is recommended, reducing heuristic errors.
elements.description: Each search result card includes three calibrated likelihood cues and one total monthly number before fee breakdown. Users can inspect drivers like response speed, rule compatibility, and verification recency without leaving search. This turns ranking from black-box salience into explainable decision support.

visual_spec.layout: Horizontal card with left media block, middle listing details, and right probability stack; wraps to vertical under 768px.
visual_spec.background: var(--bg-white) with subtle top highlight gradient from rgba(140,104,238,0.10).
visual_spec.border: 1px solid var(--border-color) with selected state using 2px inset ring in var(--secondary-purple).
visual_spec.color_usage: Primary purple anchors key numbers, secondary purple visualizes probability bars, accent purple is used for explanatory tags and uncertainty notes.

interaction_spec.default_state: Card shows monthly total, three probability bars, and 'why this match' bullets.
interaction_spec.hover: Card elevates and probability bars brighten with a subtle glow.
interaction_spec.click: Selecting card opens details while preserving probability summary at top.
interaction_spec.animation: Bars animate width over 450ms ease-out on load; hover transition 200ms.
interaction_spec.responsive: On mobile, probability stack moves below price with full-width bars and 48px action buttons.

copy_spec.primary_text: Likely match for your Tue-Thu schedule
copy_spec.secondary_text: $1,780 total monthly cost includes rent, platform fee, and utilities estimate.
copy_spec.micro_copy: Labels: 'Response likelihood 88%', 'Fit likelihood 79%', 'Trust confidence 91%'. CTA: 'View full rationale'.
do: Show one all-in monthly number before detailed fees.
Explain each probability with plain drivers.
Use confidence language, not certainty language.
dont: Do not present black-box scores without reason text.
Do not separate fees from first visible price.
Do not overpack the card with low-value metrics.

before_after.after: Split Lease exposes response, fit, and trust probabilities with all-in monthly cost so users compare options with calibrated context.

elements.name: Guided Commitment Rail Modal
elements.problem_it_solves: It replaces unstructured money-and-terms negotiation in chat with explicit staged commitments and reversible checkpoints.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: Instead of handing users off to ad hoc messaging, Split Lease owns the riskiest decision moments with visible state and next-action defaults.
elements.description: The modal guides both parties through four commitment stages: intent, terms, verification, and fund authorization. Every stage has one clear outcome and one fallback path, reducing pressure-driven mistakes. Critical terms stay structured and traceable while preserving conversational speed.

visual_spec.layout: Centered modal with left progress rail and right stage content in a 400px max-width desktop card; full-width sheet on mobile.
visual_spec.background: Modal surface var(--bg-white) over var(--overlay-dark) backdrop.
visual_spec.border: 1px solid var(--border-color) with active step ring in var(--secondary-purple).
visual_spec.color_usage: Primary purple for sequence hierarchy, secondary purple for active state and action controls, accent purple for caution and reversible-state hints.

interaction_spec.default_state: User lands on current stage with progress rail, required fields, and explicit next action.
interaction_spec.hover: Action buttons raise with purple shadow; step pills intensify contrast.
interaction_spec.click: Primary action advances one stage; secondary action opens reversible path or request-edits branch.
interaction_spec.animation: Modal enters with 260ms fade/scale; stage transitions slide horizontally in 220ms.
interaction_spec.responsive: Under 600px modal becomes bottom sheet with sticky action bar and 48px controls.

copy_spec.secondary_text: Verify handoff details before payment authorization. You can still request edits after this step.
copy_spec.micro_copy: States: 'Intent confirmed', 'Terms aligned', 'Verification in review', 'Authorization pending'. Actions: 'Advance to authorization', 'Request term edits'.
do: Show current stage and next required action at all times.
Use reversible language before final authorization.
Keep money movement tied to explicit verification completion.
dont: Do not bury key terms inside chat threads.
Do not present final payment actions without stage context.
Do not remove edit paths before final consent.

elements.html_css:
Commitment rail

1. Intent confirmed
2. Terms aligned
3. Verification in review
4. Authorization pending
Step 3 of 4

Verify handoff details before payment authorization

You can still request edits after this step. No funds are released until move-in checklist is confirmed.

Move-in handoff
Tue, Mar 3 7:30 PM lobby key exchange
Utility split
Internet included, electricity capped at $45/month
Visit-before-sign
Live walkthrough booked for Sat, Mar 1
Reversible window
24h edit window remains after this stage

before_after.before: Roomster hands users into free-form chat for high-stakes commitment and money sequencing, creating ambiguity and pressure-based errors.
before_after.after: Split Lease provides a staged commitment rail with explicit states, reversible checkpoints, and verification gates before authorization.

elements.name: Outcome Memory Loop Card
elements.problem_it_solves: It prevents post-stay learning loss by capturing concrete outcomes and automatically feeding them into future search and proposal defaults.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: Where competitors stop after match, this element creates compounding decision quality by turning each stay into reusable evidence.
elements.description: This feedback card appears at reflection points and asks only high-signal prompts tied to future decisions. It summarizes what worked, what failed, and what should become next-cycle defaults. Users see immediate value because the next search is pre-tuned from their own outcomes.

visual_spec.layout: Single card with top outcome summary, three reflection chips, and bottom auto-applied defaults preview.
visual_spec.background: var(--bg-white) with a soft diagonal purple highlight.
visual_spec.border: 1px solid var(--border-color) with left emphasis bar in var(--secondary-purple).
visual_spec.color_usage: Primary purple for summaries, secondary purple for selected reflections and defaults, accent purple for prompts that need follow-up.

interaction_spec.default_state: Card shows one-minute debrief with prefilled events from active stay timeline.
interaction_spec.hover: Reflection chips brighten and lift slightly with purple shadow.
interaction_spec.click: Selecting chips updates auto-applied defaults preview in real time.
interaction_spec.animation: Card enters with 240ms fade-up; preview updates cross-fade in 180ms.
interaction_spec.responsive: On mobile, chips wrap to full width and primary action remains fixed at bottom with 48px height.

copy_spec.secondary_text: Capture what mattered in this stay and we will apply it to your next shortlist automatically.
copy_spec.micro_copy: Prompts: 'Handoff was smooth', 'Utility expectations were unclear', 'Quiet hours matched'. CTA: 'Save and apply to next search'.
do: Ask only decision-relevant reflection prompts.
Show exactly which defaults will update next cycle.
Keep completion under one minute.
dont: Do not turn reflection into a long survey.
Do not collect notes without visible next-cycle impact.
Do not frame retention as reminders alone.

elements.html_css:
One-minute debrief, better next match

Capture what mattered in your Feb stay on W 109th St and apply it to your next shortlist.

Handoff
On time, no key issue
Utilities
Electricity exceeded cap once
Quiet hours
Fully matched
Handoff was smooth Utility expectations were unclear Quiet hours matched Kitchen sharing was tighter than expected

Auto-applied to next search

  • Prioritize listings with documented key handoff protocol.
  • Show utility cap terms in first-card summary.
  • Increase quiet-hours compatibility weight in ranking.

before_after.before: Roomster provides little post-outcome structure, so users rely on noisy memory and repeat preventable mistakes.
before_after.after: Split Lease captures outcome signals quickly and converts them into explicit defaults for future matching and commitment decisions.

elements.name: Gift-First Onboarding Card
elements.description: A personalized onboarding card that shows the host pre-filled details from their agent call before requesting any account creation or form input. The card displays the agent's name, property details, guest names, and an earnings estimate as gifts -- all before any sign-up form appears. This implements the gift-before-gate reciprocity pattern.
elements.problem_it_solves: Hosts who arrive at the platform after an agent call see a generic sign-up form that ignores everything they discussed. This breaks the reciprocity chain from the call and makes the platform feel cold and institutional. The gift-first card demonstrates that the platform already knows the host and has prepared value for them.

elements.name: Ghost Roommate Guest Profile Card
elements.description: A three-tier progressive disclosure guest profile card that transforms strangers into known people. Tier 1 shows the guest's human story (name, age, one-line summary). Tier 2 reveals schedule and employment details on expansion. Tier 3 (expandable) shows vetting results. Each tier is a deliberate gift that reduces the host's stranger-anxiety through Cialdini's reciprocity pattern.
elements.problem_it_solves: Sherene's core anxiety is 'I don't like dealing with strangers. And then two strangers that change.' Static guest profile cards present all information at once in a flat format, missing the progressive disclosure that Bryant uses on the call to convert strangers into known people. This card replicates the conversational revelation of personal details.

elements.name: Contrast-Anchored Pricing Display
elements.description: A pricing display that uses Cialdini's contrast principle to show the ghost roommate premium. Displays the standard single-guest earning as a muted anchor, then the ghost roommate premium as the dominant number, making the premium feel like a generous concession from the platform. Includes a value stack of included services above the price to implement the gift-before-price pattern.
elements.problem_it_solves: Sherene's baseline is 'barely breaking even' at $40/night. Without contrast anchoring, $1,200/month is just a number. With the anchor ($800 single guest), $1,200 feels like a significant premium. The value stack (cleaning management, lockbox, daily payments) frames the price as a fair exchange, not a bare number.

elements.name: Daily Payment Notification Card
elements.description: A daily payment notification card that transforms a financial transaction into a reciprocity gift. Names the guest, specifies the night, shows the payment amount, and includes a running monthly total with progress bar. Each notification is a small gift from the platform that reinforces the host's calm during the active lease.
elements.problem_it_solves: Generic payment notifications ('$40.00 deposited') are transactional and habituate quickly. This card ties each payment to a specific person and night, maintaining the personal reciprocity connection that Bryant established on the call. The running total contextualizes each daily payment within the larger arrangement.

elements.name: Thursday Handoff Tracker
elements.description: A three-step handoff tracker showing the weekly ghost roommate transition: Greg's check-out, room readiness, and Johan's check-in. Uses a horizontal stepper with real-time status updates. This is the most anxiety-sensitive interaction in the ghost roommate model -- the moment when 'two strangers that change' becomes tangible.
elements.problem_it_solves: The Thursday handoff is where Sherene's stranger anxiety peaks. Without visibility into the handoff progress, she must wonder: Did Greg clean? Is Johan arriving? Is everything okay? This tracker makes the three-party reciprocity exchange visible in real time, converting anxiety into calm through transparency.

elements.name: Rejection-Then-Retreat Listing Simplifier
elements.description: A retreat offer card that appears when the host hesitates on the full listing wizard. The full wizard dims in the background while a simplified 3-field Quick Start card rises, framed as a concession from the platform: 'That is a lot of steps. How about we start with just the basics?' Implements Cialdini's rejection-then-retreat technique to recover hosts who would otherwise abandon.
elements.problem_it_solves: The 6-step listing wizard is a large request. Hosts who feel overwhelmed have only two options: complete all 6 steps or leave. This card provides a third option -- a graceful retreat to a 3-field Quick Start that captures essential data while preserving the reciprocity chain for later completion.
elements.html_css:
Create your listing

That is a lot of steps. How about we start with just the basics?

We already know most of what we need from your call with Bryant. Just confirm these three things and we will get your listing started.

You can complete the remaining details anytime. We will save everything.

elements.name: Cumulative Gift Ledger for Retention
elements.description: A retention summary card showing the cumulative value delivered across the entire lease: total earnings, total payments, successful handoffs, and incident-free record. Frames the renewal as a continuation of proven success rather than a new commitment. Uses the gift-ledger concept from Cialdini's reciprocity framework to create gratitude through visible accumulated value.
elements.problem_it_solves: At renewal time, the host evaluates the arrangement based on memory, which is skewed by recency bias and negativity bias. This card counters both biases by presenting the objective, cumulative record of everything the platform delivered -- making the total value undeniable and the renewal decision feel like continuing something good, not taking a new risk.

elements.name: Relationship Timeline Card
elements.problem_it_solves: Sonder's anonymous support queue erases all context between interactions -- the guest is a ticket number, not a person. This card makes the host-guest relationship visible, cumulative, and actionable during the active lease.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No apartment-hotel or mid-term housing platform displays the ongoing relationship between host and guest as a visual timeline. Hotels show booking confirmations. Airbnb shows reviews after checkout. Split Lease shows the relationship as it develops -- week by week, stay by stay, message by message -- making the intangible feel of 'being known' into a tangible UI.
elements.description: A compact card that appears in the Stays Manager sidebar, showing the host-guest relationship history at a glance. It displays: total weeks together, communication streak (consecutive weeks with at least one message exchange), cumulative micro-review average, and a mini-timeline of stay highlights (first stay, 1-month milestone, best-rated week). The card subtly evolves as the relationship deepens -- at 4+ weeks the border gains an accent, at 8+ weeks a 'Returning Guest' badge appears. The card is visible to both host and guest, reinforcing the shared understanding.

visual_spec.layout: Vertical card, 100% width of Stays Manager sidebar, max-width 360px
visual_spec.border: 1px solid #e5e7eb with left accent that evolves: weeks 1-3 transparent, weeks 4-7 rgba(109,49,194,0.3), weeks 8+ rgb(109,49,194)
visual_spec.color_usage: Primary purple for milestone markers and the evolved left border accent. Secondary purple for metric values. Accent purple for the returning-guest badge background. Off-white for the timeline strip background.

interaction_spec.default_state: Card visible with relationship metrics and mini-timeline. Full history collapsed.
interaction_spec.hover: Card gains shadow-md. 'View full history' link underlines.
interaction_spec.click: Clicking opens a slide-over panel with the complete relationship timeline: every stay, every micro-review, every message thread summary.
interaction_spec.animation: Left border accent fades in over 400ms when the relationship crosses a threshold (4 weeks, 8 weeks). Milestone dots on the timeline pulse once (scale 1.0 to 1.1 to 1.0, 300ms) when first displayed.
interaction_spec.responsive: Full-width on mobile. Metrics row wraps to 2x2 grid below 320px.

copy_spec.secondary_text: 8 weeks together -- Returning Guest
copy_spec.micro_copy: Metric labels: 'weeks together', 'messages exchanged', 'avg stay rating'. CTA: 'View full history'. Milestone labels: 'First stay', '1 month', 'Best week'.
do: Use the host's first name, not 'your host'
Frame metrics as relationship markers, not performance metrics
Show the communication streak to reward engagement from both sides
dont: Never show '0 messages exchanged' -- use 'Start a conversation' instead
Never display relationship metrics that make the guest feel surveilled
Never use corporate language like 'Your Account Manager' or 'Property Contact'

elements.html_css:

messages

before_after.before: On Sonder, the guest messages support and gets a random agent who has never heard of them. After 30 nights, the platform has no record of the relationship. On checkout, the guest evaporates from the system.
before_after.after: On Split Lease, the Stays Manager sidebar shows 'Your stay with Dana -- 8 weeks together, 14 messages, 4.8 avg rating.' The relationship is visible, cumulative, and valued by both sides. When the guest rebooks, the card carries forward.

elements.name: Temporal Stay Arc Banner
elements.problem_it_solves: Sonder's active stay experience is identical on day 1 and day 30 -- the same static app content, zero acknowledgment of temporal progression. This banner makes the temporal arc of the stay visible and evolving.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No accommodation platform acknowledges that your relationship with a space deepens over time. Hotels treat every night identically. Sonder's app shows the same content on night 1 and night 30. Split Lease's Temporal Stay Arc Banner changes its message, its content, and its suggestions based on which week of the lease the guest is in -- making the stay feel like a journey, not a static state.
elements.description: A contextual banner at the top of the Stays Manager that adapts its content to the guest's temporal position in the lease. Week 1: 'Welcome to Bushwick -- here are Dana's tips for your first week.' Week 4: 'You've been here a month -- guests who stayed this long loved these spots.' Week 8: 'Two months in -- here is what previous guests discovered by this point.' Week 13: 'Your final week -- want to extend? Here are your options.' The banner includes a subtle progress indicator showing where the guest is in the lease arc, and each temporal phase unlocks new content cards below the banner.

visual_spec.layout: Full-width banner, max-width matching Stays Manager container. Height adapts to content, minimum 80px.
visual_spec.background: Gradient from bg-off-white to white, with subtle purple radial glow in the progress indicator area
visual_spec.border: 1px solid rgba(109,49,194,0.15) with bottom border only
visual_spec.border_radius: 12px top corners, 0 bottom (attached to content area below)
visual_spec.color_usage: Primary purple for the week label and progress dots. Secondary purple for action links. Accent purple glow behind the current-week indicator. Off-white background to separate the banner from the Stays Manager content below.

interaction_spec.default_state: Banner shows current temporal phase message, progress indicator, and 1-2 contextual content suggestions.
interaction_spec.hover: Content suggestion cards gain subtle lift (translateY -1px) and shadow-sm.
interaction_spec.click: Clicking a content suggestion expands inline or navigates to the relevant content (neighborhood guide, extension flow, etc.).
interaction_spec.animation: Banner content cross-fades (opacity transition, 300ms) when the guest enters a new temporal phase. Progress indicator dot scales from 0.8 to 1.0 when active.
interaction_spec.responsive: Full-width on mobile. Progress indicator wraps below message text. Content suggestions stack vertically.

copy_spec.secondary_text: Guests who've been here this long say the Saturday farmers market on Flushing Ave is worth the walk. Dana's tip: 'The courtyard is quietest before 8am.'
copy_spec.micro_copy: Progress labels: 'Arriving', 'Settling In', 'At Home', 'Winding Down'. Action: 'See neighborhood guide'. Phase indicator: 'Week X of Y'.
do: Change the banner content at least once per temporal phase (roughly every 3-4 weeks)
Mix host tips with previous-guest insights for authenticity
Use the neighborhood name, not generic location references
dont: Never show the same banner content two weeks in a row
Never make the temporal arc feel like a countdown to checkout
Never use week numbers without emotional context -- 'Week 5' means nothing; 'Getting Settled' means everything

elements.html_css:
Getting Settled Week 5 of 13

Guests who've been here this long say the Saturday farmers market on Flushing Ave is worth the walk. Dana's tip: "The courtyard is quietest before 8am -- perfect for morning coffee."
🏪
Neighborhood favorites
3 spots guests rated highest after month-long stays
💬
Message Dana
Ask about weekend plans or building tips

before_after.before: On Sonder, the app shows the same static information (wifi password, appliance instructions, emergency numbers) on day 1 and day 30. No temporal awareness, no evolving content, no acknowledgment that the guest's relationship with the neighborhood has deepened.
before_after.after: On Split Lease, the Stays Manager banner says 'Week 5 of 13 -- Getting Settled' and surfaces neighborhood tips that match the guest's temporal phase. Host insights and previous-guest wisdom appear at the right moment, making the stay feel like it gets better the longer you're there.

elements.name: Hypothesis Confidence Meter
elements.problem_it_solves: Sonder asks guests to commit $3,000-6,000 based on photos and a star rating -- a full product commitment without an MVP test. This card reframes the trial night as a hypothesis test and shows the guest their confidence level building step by step.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No accommodation platform explicitly frames the booking decision as a testable hypothesis. Hotels assume the photo is sufficient. Airbnb relies on reviews. Split Lease's Hypothesis Confidence Meter shows the guest exactly what they've validated (trial night, host meeting, neighborhood check) and what's still untested, turning the high-stakes booking into a low-risk learning process.
elements.description: A compact card displayed during the proposal creation flow that shows the guest their current 'confidence level' in the booking decision. It lists three hypothesis-validation steps: (1) Trial Night -- 'Have you stayed here?' (2) Host Connection -- 'Have you met the host?' (3) Neighborhood Verified -- 'Have you visited the area?' Each step shows validated/not-yet status. Completing more steps increases the confidence indicator. The card does not block booking -- guests can proceed at any confidence level -- but it frames the trial night as the rationale step, not the exceptional one.

visual_spec.layout: Vertical card, fits within proposal flow sidebar, max-width 340px
visual_spec.color_usage: Secondary purple for completed validation steps. Gray for pending steps. Primary purple for the confidence label. Off-white background for the step list area.

interaction_spec.default_state: Card shows all three hypothesis steps with their current validation status. Confidence level displayed as text, not a percentage.
interaction_spec.hover: Uncompleted steps show a subtle 'Book a trial night' or 'Schedule a Zoom' tooltip.
interaction_spec.click: Clicking an uncompleted step navigates to the relevant action (trial night booking, Zoom scheduling, neighborhood guide).
interaction_spec.animation: When a step transitions from pending to validated, the checkmark fades in (opacity 0 to 1, 200ms) and the step text color transitions from gray to purple (200ms).
interaction_spec.responsive: Full-width on mobile. Steps stack naturally.

copy_spec.secondary_text: Most guests feel ready after a trial night. You can book anytime.
copy_spec.micro_copy: Step labels: 'Trial night completed', 'Host meeting done', 'Neighborhood visited'. Confidence levels: 'Just browsing', 'Getting comfortable', 'Ready to commit'. CTA: 'Book a trial night -- $95'.
do: Frame the trial night as the normal path, not the cautious path
Show that most successful leases started with a trial
Keep the tone encouraging, not gatekeeping
dont: Never block the booking based on confidence level -- this is guidance, not a gate
Never shame guests who book without a trial ('You haven't tried yet!')
Never use percentage-based confidence -- it feels clinical and arbitrary

elements.html_css:
Your booking confidence Getting comfortable
Most guests feel ready after a trial night. You can book anytime.
Trial night completed
Jan 14 -- Dana's apartment, Bushwick
Host meeting done
Zoom call with Dana -- 12 min
Neighborhood visited
Walk the area to check commute, safety, noise
See guide

before_after.before: On Sonder, booking a 30-night stay requires committing $3,000-6,000 based on photos and a star rating. No trial, no host meeting, no neighborhood verification. The guest makes a high-stakes commitment with low-fidelity information.
before_after.after: On Split Lease, the Hypothesis Confidence Meter shows what you've validated: trial night (done), host meeting (done), neighborhood visit (pending). You can book at any confidence level, but the system frames trial-first as the normal path, reducing commitment risk through validated learning.

elements.name: Commuter Schedule Matcher
elements.problem_it_solves: Sonder's discovery asks 'Where are you going? When?' -- the traveler question. This form asks 'What days do you go to the office? Where is your office?' -- the commuter question. It recognizes that Split Lease's actual users are hybrid workers and life-transitioners, not tourists.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No accommodation platform in any category starts with office days and commute patterns as the primary search input. Every platform -- Sonder, Airbnb, Furnished Finder, Hotels.com -- starts with destination and dates. Split Lease's Commuter Schedule Matcher declares a new category by asking a question nobody else asks.
elements.description: A compact discovery form that replaces the standard 'city + dates' search with a commuter-first flow. Step 1: Select your office days (Mon-Fri toggles). Step 2: Enter your office location (address or neighborhood). Step 3: See matched listings with commute time overlay. The form communicates 'we understand you live in two places' before the guest has seen a single listing. It is the front door to the Commuter OS.

visual_spec.layout: Centered form within a hero section, max-width 520px. Two-step flow with inline transitions.
visual_spec.background: White card on gradient background (primary-purple to secondary-purple radial glow)
visual_spec.border_radius: 16px for outer card, 8px for input fields
visual_spec.color_usage: Primary purple for the heading and selected day badges. Secondary purple for the CTA button gradient. Accent purple for hover states on day toggles. White card surface contrasts against the purple gradient background.

interaction_spec.default_state: Day toggles unselected. Office location field empty. CTA disabled until at least one day selected.
interaction_spec.hover: Day toggles gain purple tint on hover. CTA button brightens.
interaction_spec.click: Selecting a day toggle fills it with secondary-purple and white text. CTA becomes active after first day selected. Clicking CTA transitions to matched results with commute time overlay.
interaction_spec.animation: Day toggles: background transition 150ms ease. CTA: gradient shift 200ms. Results appear with 300ms fade-up.
interaction_spec.responsive: Day toggles remain in a single row on mobile (compact sizing). Office field goes full-width. CTA full-width on mobile.

copy_spec.primary_text: Which days are you in the office?
copy_spec.secondary_text: Find a room near work for just your office days. No lease, no commute.
copy_spec.micro_copy: Day labels: 'M', 'T', 'W', 'T', 'F'. Office field placeholder: 'Office address or neighborhood'. CTA: 'Show rooms near my office'. Helper: 'You only pay for nights you stay.'
do: Use 'office days' not 'check-in dates' -- this is commuter language
Emphasize partial-week economics: 'just your office days'
Show commute time in results, not just distance
dont: Never ask for check-in/checkout dates upfront -- that's the hotel model
Never show nightly rate without monthly context -- commuters think in monthly budgets
Never assume 5 days -- most hybrid workers need 2-3 days

elements.html_css:
For hybrid workers

Which days are you in the office?

Find a room near work for just your office days. No lease, no commute.

You only pay for nights you stay -- average $65/night for Mon-Wed

before_after.before: On Sonder, discovery asks 'Where are you going? When?' -- the traveler question. A hybrid worker who needs a room near the office 3 days a week must translate their commute pattern into hotel-style dates, losing the core identity of their need in the process.
before_after.after: On Split Lease, discovery asks 'Which days are you in the office? Where is your office?' -- the commuter question. The platform speaks the guest's language from the first interaction, declaring that this is a product built for people who live in two places.

elements.name: Neighborhood Knowledge Feed
elements.problem_it_solves: Sonder drops guests into neighborhoods with zero local intelligence -- they Google everything, Yelp everything, and figure it out alone. This feed aggregates host tips and guest micro-review mentions into a living neighborhood guide that gets richer with every stay.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No apartment-hotel builds collaborative neighborhood intelligence from residents. Hotels have concierges who serve tourists. Airbnb has Guidebooks that hosts create once and rarely update. Split Lease's Neighborhood Knowledge Feed is a living document that accumulates insights from every guest who stays -- creating the kind of local knowledge that usually takes months of living somewhere to develop.
elements.description: A scrollable feed within the listing detail page and the Stays Manager that displays neighborhood insights sourced from the host and from previous guest micro-reviews. Each entry is a compact card: the source (host tip vs. guest discovery), the insight ('The coffee shop on Knickerbocker closes at 2pm on Sundays'), the timestamp, and a relevance tag (Food, Work, Transit, Safety, Social). The feed is sorted by recency and relevance to the guest's temporal phase. Hosts can pin their top 3 tips. Guests can add insights through their micro-reviews. The feed is specific to the unit's address, not a generic neighborhood overview.

visual_spec.layout: Vertical feed within a scrollable container, max-width 480px, max-height 400px with scroll
visual_spec.background: #ffffff for cards, var(--bg-off-white) for feed background
visual_spec.border: 1px solid #e5e7eb for the feed container, none for individual cards
visual_spec.color_usage: Purple accent tags distinguish categories. Host tips get a subtle left-border accent in secondary purple. Guest discoveries have no left border. Tag pills use rgba(109,49,194,0.1) background with secondary-purple text.

interaction_spec.default_state: Feed shows 4-5 most recent insights. Scroll for more. Filter pills at top (All, Food, Work, Transit, Safety).
interaction_spec.hover: Individual insight cards gain subtle shadow-sm on hover.
interaction_spec.click: Clicking a filter pill filters the feed. Clicking an insight card expands to show full context and any related insights.
interaction_spec.animation: New insights appear with fade-in (opacity 0 to 1, 200ms) and slide-down (translateY -8px to 0). Filter transition: 150ms opacity crossfade.
interaction_spec.responsive: Full-width on mobile. Filter pills scroll horizontally.

copy_spec.secondary_text: From Dana and 6 previous guests
copy_spec.micro_copy: Filter labels: 'All', 'Food', 'Work', 'Transit', 'Safety', 'Social'. Source labels: 'Dana's tip', 'Guest discovery'. Empty state: 'Be the first to share a neighborhood tip -- add one in your next stay review.'
do: Use specific street names and landmarks, not generic area references
Attribution matters -- 'Dana's tip' or 'Guest who stayed 8 weeks' is more trustworthy than anonymous
Prioritize practical intel (hours, noise levels, prices) over opinion (ratings, 'best in the city')
dont: Never include business advertising disguised as tips
Never show outdated tips without a timestamp -- 'Added 3 months ago' provides recency context
Never aggregate tips so heavily that the individual voices disappear -- the feed's value is in specificity, not consensus

before_after.before: On Sonder, the guest gets a generic recommendations list sourced by corporate. After 30 nights in a neighborhood, the platform has learned nothing about the area from the guest's experience. The next guest starts from zero.
before_after.after: On Split Lease, the Neighborhood Knowledge Feed shows 'From Dana and 6 previous guests' -- specific, attributed, temporal tips about coffee shops, transit, safety, and weekend activities. Each guest's stay enriches the guide for the next guest. The neighborhood becomes a known place, not a blank map.

elements.name: Outcomes Dashboard: What We've Learned
elements.problem_it_solves: Sonder measured progress by unit count (outputs) instead of guest satisfaction (outcomes). This dashboard makes Split Lease's hypothesis-driven learning visible: what experiments are running, what we've learned, and what's changing as a result.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No accommodation platform shares its learning process with users. Hotels announce new amenities. Airbnb updates policies. Split Lease shows what hypotheses it tested, what it learned, and what changed -- positioning itself as a platform that gets better because it listens, not because it scales.
elements.description: A compact 'What We've Learned' section that appears on the guest's account dashboard (and optionally on the host dashboard). It shows 2-3 recent product improvements framed as hypothesis results: 'We tested: weekly check-in messages during stays. We learned: guests who received check-ins rated their stays 0.4 points higher. We changed: all stays now include a Week 2 check-in from the host.' Each entry links the improvement back to actual guest feedback, closing the build-measure-learn loop visibly. The section updates monthly and rotates entries.

visual_spec.layout: Full-width section within the account dashboard, max-width 640px
visual_spec.color_usage: Primary purple for section heading. Secondary purple for hypothesis labels and result highlights. Off-white background to distinguish from the main dashboard content.

interaction_spec.default_state: Section shows 2-3 hypothesis result cards with tested/learned/changed format.
interaction_spec.hover: Individual result cards gain subtle shadow-sm.
interaction_spec.click: Clicking a card expands to show the full hypothesis, the data collected, and links to related features.
interaction_spec.animation: Cards fade in on scroll (Intersection Observer, 200ms stagger between cards).
interaction_spec.responsive: Full-width on mobile. Cards stack naturally.

copy_spec.secondary_text: Split Lease tests and improves based on real guest feedback.
copy_spec.micro_copy: Card labels: 'We tested:', 'We learned:', 'We changed:'. Section footer: 'Have an idea? Tell us in your next stay review.'
do: Use specific numbers ('0.4 points higher', '23% more responses') not vague claims
Credit guest feedback explicitly -- 'Based on feedback from 47 guests'
Frame improvements as evidence-based, not opinion-based
dont: Never announce features without showing the hypothesis that led to them
Never use marketing language ('exciting new feature!') -- use learning language ('we tested and learned')
Never show improvements that cannot be traced to real feedback

elements.html_css:
What we've learned this month Feb 2026
Split Lease tests and improves based on real guest feedback.
We tested Sending a host check-in message at the start of Week 2 for all stays over 4 weeks.
We learned Guests who received check-ins rated their stays 0.4 points higher on average. 82% said the message made them feel "cared about."
We changed All stays over 4 weeks now include a prompted Week 2 host check-in. Based on feedback from 47 guests.
We tested Showing commute time from listing to the guest's stated office location on search results.
We learned Guests who saw commute time were 31% more likely to send a proposal. The #1 requested feature in exit surveys.
We changed Commute time is now displayed on all search results when the guest enters an office location.
Have an idea? Tell us in your next stay review

before_after.before: Sonder measured progress by unit count: '10,000 units in 40 cities.' No visibility into what they learned from guests, what they tested, or what changed as a result. The guest is a data point, not a learning partner.
before_after.after: Split Lease shows 'What we've learned this month' -- specific hypothesis tests, specific results, specific changes. The guest sees that their feedback led to real improvements, closing the build-measure-learn loop visibly and honestly.

elements.name: Legitimacy Chain Panel
elements.problem_it_solves: Users currently start conversations while still wondering whether the person and listing are legitimate, creating early trust drop-off.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: Category incumbents optimize for message volume; this element makes legitimacy proof the default starting condition before chat.
elements.description: A top-of-listing panel that displays four explicit trust states: identity proof, role proof, payment readiness, and unresolved unknowns. It preserves speed to message, but forces visible evidence ordering before first contact. The panel also includes a one-click disconfirming checklist so users can test assumptions, not just confirm them.

visual_spec.layout: Two-column panel in desktop (evidence list + action rail), stacked on mobile.
visual_spec.border: 1px solid #e5e7eb with 3px top accent in secondary purple.
visual_spec.color_usage: Primary purple anchors headings, secondary purple marks verified states, accent purple marks unresolved unknowns.

interaction_spec.default_state: Four rows visible with status chips: Verified, Partial, Pending, Unknown.
interaction_spec.hover: Row elevates with purple-tinted shadow and reveals source timestamp.
interaction_spec.click: Click opens inline evidence details and source trail.
interaction_spec.animation: Rows fade-up with 180ms stagger and chip color transition over 200ms.
interaction_spec.responsive: Below 768px rows stack full-width and CTA rail moves below evidence list with 48px buttons.

copy_spec.secondary_text: See what is verified, what is still uncertain, and what Split Lease guarantees.
copy_spec.micro_copy: Actions: 'Message now', 'Run disconfirming checklist'. Labels: 'Identity verified', 'Role verified', 'Payment rail ready', 'Unknowns to confirm'.
do: Name unknowns directly.
Keep proof language concrete.
Show evidence source and recency.
dont: Do not collapse trust into one badge.
Do not hide unknowns in legal footnotes.
Do not gate proof behind paywalls.

elements.html_css:
Trust check before you message

See what is verified, what is uncertain, and what Split Lease guarantees.

Identity proofVerified
Role proofVerified
Payment readinessPartial
Unknowns to confirmPending

before_after.before: Roomster-style discovery rushes users to chat with limited structured trust proof.
before_after.after: Split Lease introduces visible evidence tiers before first message so users can compare risk explicitly.

elements.name: Commitment State Rail Drawer
elements.problem_it_solves: High-stakes terms and payment sequencing currently spill into unstructured chat where responsibility and next action are unclear.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: Lead-funnel competitors avoid owning commitment liability; this element makes Split Lease own the riskiest decision moment with explicit states.
elements.description: A side drawer with four commitment states: intent, term alignment, verification, and authorization. Each state has one required decision, one owner, and one due time. Users can still chat, but canonical terms are versioned in the drawer and cannot drift into text chaos.

visual_spec.layout: Right-side drawer on desktop, bottom sheet on mobile.
visual_spec.background: White surface over dark translucent overlay.
visual_spec.border: 1px solid #e5e7eb with active step ring in secondary purple.
visual_spec.color_usage: Primary purple for hierarchy, secondary purple for active state, accent purple for caution states.

interaction_spec.default_state: Current state and next owner task visible at top.
interaction_spec.hover: Action buttons gain purple shadow and stronger contrast.
interaction_spec.click: Primary action advances state; secondary action requests edits with audit trail.
interaction_spec.animation: Drawer slides in over 240ms; state card transitions over 180ms.
interaction_spec.responsive: Below 640px becomes full-width bottom sheet with sticky action footer.

copy_spec.secondary_text: Verify terms before authorization. Every next action has a clear owner and deadline.
copy_spec.micro_copy: States: 'Intent confirmed', 'Terms aligned', 'Verification in progress', 'Authorization pending'. Actions: 'Advance', 'Request edits'.
do: Keep ownership explicit.
Show reversible language before final authorization.
Preserve term history.
dont: Do not bury terms in chat.
Do not ask for payment before verification.
Do not hide deadlines.

elements.html_css:

before_after.before: Users finalize risky commitments in ad hoc text threads.
before_after.after: Split Lease introduces a staged, auditable commitment rail with explicit ownership and deadlines.

elements.name: Availability Truth Timeline
elements.problem_it_solves: Users spend effort on dates that appear available but fail later due to cross-platform conflicts and manual reschedule drift.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: Most competitors show static availability snapshots; this element exposes synchronized state history and conflict certainty before users negotiate.
elements.description: A compact timeline card attached to listing and proposal views. It shows latest sync source, confidence level for each date block, and a clear conflict flag when availability changed. Reschedule requests reuse the same timeline so users do not lose context between search and agreement.

visual_spec.layout: Vertical card with timeline rail and confidence badges.
visual_spec.color_usage: Secondary purple for reliable states, amber for warning states, red for conflicts.

interaction_spec.default_state: Shows three latest sync events with confidence tags.
interaction_spec.hover: Timeline nodes enlarge slightly and reveal source platform.
interaction_spec.click: Clicking an event opens date-level diff and recommended fallback dates.
interaction_spec.animation: New sync events enter with 160ms fade-slide.
interaction_spec.responsive: On mobile nodes stay vertical with full-width tap targets.

copy_spec.secondary_text: Last synced 6 minutes ago. 2 dates changed since your last view.
copy_spec.micro_copy: Labels: 'High confidence', 'Needs confirmation', 'Conflict detected'. Action: 'See alternatives'.
do: Surface recency and source.
Show conflicts early.
Tie fallback dates to the same context.
dont: Do not hide stale data behind generic timestamps.
Do not separate reschedule from source-of-truth timeline.
Do not show false certainty.

elements.html_css:
Availability truth

Last synced 6 minutes ago. 2 dates changed since your last view.

Airbnb hold detected for ThuConflict

before_after.before: Users discover date conflicts late and coordinate reschedules through manual back-and-forth.
before_after.after: Split Lease surfaces synchronized availability truth and conflict-aware alternatives before commitment.

elements.name: Outcome Compounding Debrief Card
elements.problem_it_solves: Without structured closeout, each new housing cycle restarts from scratch and users do not benefit from prior outcomes.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: Competitors end value at match; this element captures lived-outcome signals and converts them into next-cycle defaults.
elements.description: A one-minute debrief card shown at key milestones and lease end. It asks three high-signal prompts, then previews exactly which trust and matching defaults will update for future decisions. The card links active-stay observations to retention value so users feel compounding benefit.

visual_spec.layout: Single card with quick prompts above an auto-updated defaults preview.
visual_spec.background: White surface with subtle purple diagonal wash.
visual_spec.border: 1px solid #e5e7eb with left accent stripe in secondary purple.
visual_spec.color_usage: Primary purple for summary, secondary purple for selected prompts, accent purple for next-cycle update hints.

interaction_spec.default_state: Three prompt chips and a hidden defaults preview.
interaction_spec.hover: Prompt chips brighten and lift slightly.
interaction_spec.click: Selecting chips reveals updated defaults in real time.
interaction_spec.animation: Defaults preview cross-fades in 180ms.
interaction_spec.responsive: On mobile chips stack and primary CTA is fixed to card footer with 48px height.

copy_spec.primary_text: One minute now, safer next match
copy_spec.secondary_text: Tell us what worked and we will carry it into your next shortlist automatically.
copy_spec.micro_copy: Prompts: 'Handoff smooth', 'Rules mismatch', 'Communication reliable'. CTA: 'Save and apply'.
do: Keep completion under a minute.
Show direct next-cycle impact.
Prioritize decision-relevant prompts.
dont: Do not ask long survey questions.
Do not collect feedback without visible payoff.
Do not frame retention as reminders only.

elements.html_css:
One minute now, safer next match

Tell us what worked and we will apply it to your next shortlist.

Handoff smoothRules mismatchCommunication reliable
Next-cycle updates: prioritize listings with explicit handoff protocol, elevate hosts with stable communication history.

before_after.before: Post-stay feedback is thin, so each new decision starts with little reusable trust memory.
before_after.after: Split Lease captures high-signal outcomes and rewrites future matching defaults automatically.

elements.name: Price Calculator Panel
elements.problem_it_solves: Budget-constrained guests like Tamycka need to see total configured cost as the primary number, not per-night rate, with all fees included and savings highlighted.
elements.description: A live price calculator panel for the listing page that inverts the standard e-commerce price hierarchy. The total cost for the guest's configured schedule is the dominant visual element (28px bold primary purple), with per-night rate as secondary context and a savings indicator in success purple. Includes day-of-week selectors, a duration stepper, and an 'Includes all fees' transparency line. Updates optimistically on interaction.

elements.description: A compact social proof badge system for listing pages featuring two badge types: a general recurring-guest badge (DM Sans pill showing guest count and average stay) and a family-friendly verification badge (shield icon with blue accent showing family count and safety features). elements.description: An inline review prompt card that appears in the Stays Manager timeline after a completed stay. Features a one-tap 5-star rating, optional one-line note, and a completed state that shows the guest's contribution as part of their commitment evidence. Dismissible without penalty. Includes running average display for guests with 3+ reviews.

elements.name: Proposal Confirmation Card
elements.problem_it_solves: After proposal submission (the guest's biggest commitment), the confirmation must capitalize on Cialdini's racetrack confidence spike by reflecting the specific decision, normalizing it with social proof, and providing forward momentum.
elements.description: A proposal confirmation card that appears after the guest submits their proposal. Shows the specific proposal details (host name, schedule, price, savings), social proof normalization ('Join X recurring guests'), and a concrete next step with expected timeline. Designed to reinforce the commitment decision and prevent post-submission doubt.

elements.problem_it_solves: First-time guests like Tamycka have deep process uncertainty (7 questions in one phone call) that the platform must answer proactively with a compact, social-proof-enhanced process overview.
elements.description: A compact 4-step process explainer module that answers the seven process questions Tamycka asked in her call. Each step is under 10 words. The module includes social proof normalization ('200+ guests have done this') and is designed to appear on the homepage and listing pages without scrolling. Breaks pluralistic ignorance by showing that the process is well-trodden.
