elements.name: Host Identity Card (Face-First Listing Header)
elements.problem_it_solves: Listing pages bypass the brain's fastest trust system (FFA face recognition) by showing empty rooms instead of the human who lives there.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No rental platform in the category places a host's face, bio, and trust credentials above the fold on a listing page. By activating the fusiform face area within 170ms of page load, Split Lease creates an instant trust assessment that competitors cannot replicate without fundamental business model changes.
elements.description: A card component that appears at the top of every listing page, showing the host's photo (circular, 80px), first name, a one-line bio, response time badge, and verification indicators. The card uses the primary purple palette for the verification badges and warm typography to feel personal rather than institutional. The host's face is the first thing the guest's brain processes.

visual_spec.layout: Horizontal flexbox, 100% width, max-width 680px, centered. Host photo on the left, text content stacked on the right.
visual_spec.background: var(--bg-white) with var(--shadow-purple-sm) for subtle purple-tinted elevation

typography.heading: Inter, 18px, 600 weight, var(--text-dark) -- host's first name
typography.body: DM Sans, 14px, 400 weight, var(--text-gray) -- bio line
typography.accent: Inter, 12px, 600 weight, var(--secondary-purple) -- badges and verification

visual_spec.color_usage: Primary purple for verification badges. Accent purple for response time indicator. White background to keep focus on the face. Purple-tinted shadow for brand cohesion.

interaction_spec.default_state: Card displays host photo, name, bio, response badge, and verified indicators
interaction_spec.hover: Card shadow deepens to var(--shadow-purple-md). Subtle scale(1.01) transform.
interaction_spec.click: Navigates to expanded host profile with full bio, all listings, and guest testimonials
interaction_spec.animation: Card entrance: fade-in with translateY(8px) to translateY(0), 300ms ease-out
interaction_spec.responsive: On mobile (< 600px), stack photo above text in vertical flex. Photo size reduces to 64px.

copy_spec.secondary_text: Sarah M. | Upper West Side, Manhattan
do: Use first name only for warmth
Keep bio under 120 characters
Show response time as approximate
dont: Never show 'No photo available' without an alternative trust signal
Never use formal titles (Mr., Ms.)
Never show response times that would alarm ('responds in 3 days')

elements.html_css:
S
Meet Your Host
Sarah M. Verified Host

Product designer who travels for work. Quiet, tidy, and happy to share the kitchen. Upper West Side near the 1 train.

Responds in ~2 hours 4.9 from 12 guests Hosting since 2024

before_after.before: HotPads listing page: photo carousel of empty rooms, spec grid (beds, baths, price), a generic 'Contact Property' button. Zero faces. Zero identity. The FFA is never activated.
before_after.after: Split Lease listing page: host's face and name appear above the fold, with a bio that reads like a person, not a spec sheet. The guest's brain evaluates trustworthiness in 170ms through dedicated neural hardware. The listing feels like meeting someone, not browsing a database.

elements.name: Narrative Listing Description (Story-Format Living Preview)
elements.problem_it_solves: Listing descriptions are specification lists that engage shallow processing, bypassing the brain's narrative processing system which produces deeper comprehension and more accurate memory.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No rental platform structures listing descriptions as lived-experience narratives. By presenting 'A Week in This Space' instead of a feature checklist, Split Lease engages the brain's story processing pathways (Thing #33) and provides the anecdotal evidence (Thing #74) that is more persuasive than any specification grid.
elements.description: A structured narrative section that replaces the traditional spec-list listing description with a time-based story: 'Your Monday Morning,' 'Your Wednesday Evening,' 'Your Weekend.' Each time block includes sensory details (light, sound, proximity) that help the guest imagine living there. The section includes a resident micro-quote from a previous guest, providing the anecdotal evidence that Weinschenk proves is more persuasive than data.

visual_spec.layout: Single column, max-width 640px. Time blocks stacked vertically with subtle separator lines.
visual_spec.background: var(--bg-off-white) for the section, var(--bg-white) for each time block card
visual_spec.border: None on section. 1px solid var(--border-color) on time block cards with left border accent 3px var(--accent-purple)
visual_spec.border_radius: var(--rounded-lg) (8px) on each time block card

typography.heading: Inter, 20px, 700 weight, var(--primary-purple) -- 'A Week in This Space'
typography.body: DM Sans, 15px, 400 weight, var(--text-description) -- narrative text, line-height 1.7
typography.accent: Inter, 13px, 600 weight, var(--accent-purple) -- time block labels

spacing.padding: var(--spacing-2xl) vertical, var(--spacing-xl) horizontal on each time block

visual_spec.color_usage: Off-white background creates warmth. Accent purple on time labels draws the eye through the narrative. Primary purple on the section heading anchors the content. The resident quote uses a subtle purple-tinted background to differentiate from host-written content.

interaction_spec.default_state: First two time blocks visible, remaining blocks collapsed with 'Read the full week' link
interaction_spec.hover: Time block cards get subtle shadow lift on hover
interaction_spec.click: 'Read the full week' expands remaining time blocks with smooth height animation
interaction_spec.animation: Progressive disclosure: blocks fade in sequentially with 100ms stagger
interaction_spec.responsive: On mobile, time labels become inline badges above the narrative text instead of left-aligned labels

copy_spec.secondary_text: Here's what living here actually feels like, from the people who know.
do: Use sensory language (light, sound, proximity)
Include specific details (street names, transit times, local spots)
Keep each time block to 2-3 sentences
dont: Never use marketing language ('vibrant neighborhood', 'beautiful apartment')
Never include specs in the narrative (save those for the spec section)
Never fabricate details -- only write what the host or previous guests can verify

elements.html_css:
A Week in This Space

Here's what living here actually feels like, from the people who know.

Monday Morning

East-facing windows fill the bedroom with light by 7am. The coffee shop on Amsterdam Ave opens at 6:30 -- it's a 2-minute walk. The 1 train at 79th Street is three blocks south; you'll be at Penn Station in 18 minutes.

Wednesday Evening

The kitchen is fully stocked for cooking. Sarah is usually out on Wednesdays, so you'll have the space to yourself. The building is quiet after 9pm -- no street noise on the fourth floor.

Your Weekend

Riverside Park is a 5-minute walk west. The Fairway Market on Broadway has everything you'll need. Sarah keeps a shelf cleared in the fridge and a drawer in the bathroom vanity for your things.

From a previous guest

"The commute was exactly what I needed -- 20 minutes door to door. Sarah left a note with the wifi password and restaurant recommendations. Felt like staying with a thoughtful friend, not a stranger."

-- Marcus T., stayed 3 months (Jan - Mar 2026)

before_after.before: HotPads listing description: 'Spacious 2BR in vibrant neighborhood! Hardwood floors, stainless steel appliances, laundry in building. Close to transit. No pets.' -- a specification list that engages shallow processing.
before_after.after: Split Lease listing narrative: a time-based story that tells you what Monday mornings feel like, what the commute is, who shares the space and when. The brain processes this through narrative pathways (Thing #33), producing deeper comprehension and more accurate memory than any spec list.

elements.name: Search Session Memory Bar
elements.problem_it_solves: Every search session starts from cognitive zero -- no memory of what was viewed, what changed, or where the user left off -- forcing recall instead of recognition across sessions.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No rental platform in the category provides cross-session memory or search journey awareness. By converting recall tasks to recognition tasks (Thing #22), Split Lease respects the brain's actual memory architecture instead of pretending users have infinite recall capacity.
elements.description: A persistent bar at the top of the search results page that appears for returning users. It shows: listings viewed in the last session, new listings since last visit, favorited count, and a one-click 'Resume where you left off' action. The bar transforms the search experience from stateless to stateful, acknowledging the guest's accumulated work.

visual_spec.layout: Horizontal flexbox bar, full width, height 56px. Stats on the left, resume action on the right.

typography.heading: Inter, 14px, 600 weight, var(--text-dark) -- 'Welcome back'
typography.accent: Inter, 13px, 600 weight, white on var(--secondary-purple) -- resume button

visual_spec.color_usage: Off-white background is subtle and non-intrusive. Secondary purple on the resume CTA draws action focus. New listings count uses accent purple to signal freshness.

interaction_spec.default_state: Bar shows stats: viewed count, new count, favorited count, and a resume CTA
interaction_spec.hover: Resume button background shifts to var(--accent-purple). Stat items become underlined links.
interaction_spec.click: Resume: scrolls to last-viewed listing with a brief highlight animation. Stats: filter the search view (e.g., 'New' shows only new listings).
interaction_spec.animation: Bar slides down from top with 200ms ease-out on page load
interaction_spec.responsive: On mobile, bar stacks: stats on first line, resume button on second line. Full width.

copy_spec.secondary_text: You viewed 8 listings | 3 new since Tuesday | 2 favorites
do: Use specific numbers and dates, not vague ('recently')
Celebrate progress ('3 favorites -- getting closer!')
dont: Never show the bar for first-time visitors
Never make it feel like surveillance ('We tracked your 47 page views')
Never block content -- the bar must be dismissible

elements.html_css:
Welcome back
8 viewed | 3 new since Tuesday | 2 favorites

before_after.before: HotPads: every search session starts from zero. No 'viewed before' indicators, no 'new since last visit' badges, no session continuity. Users must recall from memory which listings they already evaluated.
before_after.after: Split Lease: returning users see their search journey summarized -- what they viewed, what's new, where they stopped. Recognition replaces recall (Thing #22). The search feels like a partnership, not a reset.

elements.name: Comparison Tray (4-Item Working Memory Scaffold)
elements.problem_it_solves: Users cannot meaningfully compare more than 4 listings at once (Thing #20), yet platforms present 30+ with no comparison tooling, forcing shallow satisficing instead of deep evaluation.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No rental listing platform provides structured comparison limited to working memory capacity. The 4-item tray is not arbitrary -- it is neurologically determined. By designing for the brain's actual limit, Split Lease enables better decisions than any platform showing more options.
elements.description: A floating bottom tray that holds up to 4 listing cards for side-by-side comparison. When the guest adds a listing to the tray, it appears as a compact thumbnail. At 4 items, the tray shows a 'Compare Now' action and prevents adding more without removing one (enforcing the working memory limit). The compare view highlights only the attributes that differ between listings, reducing cognitive load.

visual_spec.layout: Fixed bottom bar, 72px height, flex row. Listing thumbnails on the left, action buttons on the right.
visual_spec.background: var(--bg-white) with var(--shadow-xl) for strong elevation

typography.heading: Inter, 13px, 600 weight, var(--text-dark) -- listing names in tray
typography.body: Inter, 11px, 400 weight, var(--text-gray) -- prices in tray
typography.accent: Inter, 13px, 600 weight, white -- compare button text

visual_spec.color_usage: White background with strong purple-tinted shadow for clear elevation. Secondary purple on Compare button. Accent purple on the item count badge. Subtle purple border on selected item thumbnails.

interaction_spec.default_state: Hidden when empty. Slides up when first listing is added. Shows compact listing thumbnails.
interaction_spec.hover: Tray items show a remove (x) button on hover. Compare button shifts to accent-purple.
interaction_spec.click: Compare Now: opens full-screen comparison view. Thumbnail: navigates to that listing. X button: removes from tray with slide-out animation.
interaction_spec.animation: Tray entrance: slide-up from bottom, 300ms ease-out. Items enter with 150ms scale-up. Items exit with 200ms scale-down and slide-out.
interaction_spec.responsive: On mobile, tray becomes a compact pill showing count only ('3 to compare'). Tap expands to full tray view as an overlay.

copy_spec.secondary_text: Add up to 4 listings to compare side by side
micro_copy: Tray full -- remove one to add another
do: Show the 4-item limit as a feature, not a constraint
Highlight what differs between listings, not what's the same
dont: Never allow more than 4 items
Never force comparison -- the tray is optional
Never auto-add listings to the tray

elements.html_css:
Search results would appear here
UWS Studio $1,180/mo
Harlem 1BR $1,050/mo
BK Heights $1,220/mo
3 of 4

before_after.before: HotPads: 30+ identical listing cards with a heart button as the only organizational tool. Users hold listings in working memory, open multiple browser tabs, or take screenshots to compare.
before_after.after: Split Lease: a floating tray holds exactly 4 listings (the working memory limit). Side-by-side comparison highlights only what differs. The platform does the scaffolding work the brain cannot.

elements.name: Proposal Status Pipeline
elements.problem_it_solves: After submitting a proposal, guests enter a black box with zero progress visibility, destroying the three motivation drivers (progress, mastery, control) at peak investment.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No rental listing platform shows where your inquiry stands in a process. The status pipeline transforms the most anxious moment of rental search -- the wait after inquiry -- into a structured journey with clear milestones. This directly activates the goal gradient effect (Thing #50): users feel more motivated as they see progress toward a goal.
elements.description: A horizontal pipeline showing 4-5 stages of the proposal lifecycle: Sent, Viewed, Responding, Counter-Offer/Accepted, and Confirmed. Each stage has a timestamp, an icon, and a brief description. The current stage is highlighted in accent purple with a subtle pulse animation. Previous stages show completion checkmarks. Future stages are greyed but visible, giving the guest a mental model of the full process.

visual_spec.layout: Horizontal flexbox pipeline, max-width 720px, centered. Stages connected by lines. Full card wrapping the pipeline.
visual_spec.background: var(--bg-white) for the card, var(--bg-off-white) for the page

spacing.gap: Stage circles are evenly distributed across the pipeline width

visual_spec.color_usage: Completed stages use success purple (#4B47CE) for checkmarks. Current stage uses accent purple with pulse. Future stages use light gray. The connecting line transitions from purple (completed) to gray (upcoming).

interaction_spec.default_state: Pipeline shows all stages with current stage highlighted and pulsing
interaction_spec.hover: Completed stages show tooltip with timestamp and detail on hover. Current stage shows expected next action.
interaction_spec.click: Current stage expands to show detail card with host activity info and next steps.
interaction_spec.animation: Current stage has a subtle pulse (opacity 0.7 to 1.0, 2s infinite). Stage transitions animate with a 500ms progress fill along the connecting line.
interaction_spec.responsive: On mobile (< 600px), pipeline converts to a vertical timeline with stages stacked. Active stage is expanded, others are collapsed.

copy_spec.secondary_text: Upper West Side Studio | $1,180/mo | Mon-Thu
do: Use the host's first name throughout
Show expected timelines based on host history
Celebrate progress at each stage ('Sarah viewed your proposal!')
dont: Never show fake progress
Never say 'Under Review' when nothing is happening
Never hide the stage names -- transparency is the trust signal

elements.html_css:
Your Proposal to Sarah M.

Upper West Side Studio · $1,180/mo · Mon–Thu

Proposal Sent Today, 2:15 PM
Viewed by Host 10 min ago
3
Host Responds Expected ~4 hrs
4
Accepted —
5
Confirmed —
Sarah typically responds in 4 hours

before_after.before: HotPads: 'Message sent.' Then silence. No status, no timeline, no visibility into whether the landlord received, read, or will ever respond to the inquiry. The most motivated moment meets a progress vacuum.
before_after.after: Split Lease: a live status pipeline shows exactly where the proposal stands. 'Viewed by Host' with a timestamp. 'Sarah typically responds in 4 hours.' Progress is visible, mastery develops (the guest learns the process), and control is maintained (the guest can message, modify, or withdraw at any point).

elements.name: Active Stay Weekly Check-In Card
elements.problem_it_solves: Listing platforms disappear at move-in, abandoning the longest phase of the rental lifecycle and missing the habit-formation window that builds loyalty for the next search.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No rental listing platform has any involvement in the active tenancy. The weekly check-in card is the atomic unit of active-stay engagement: a 15-second interaction that confirms the upcoming stay, surfaces any actions needed, and captures a one-tap micro-review. After 13 repetitions (one per week in a standard quarter), the habit is formed.
elements.description: A card that appears in the Stays Manager each week, showing the upcoming stay dates, host name, a 'Confirm This Week' button, and a one-tap mood indicator from the previous stay. The card is designed for sub-30-second interaction: glance at dates, confirm, rate, done. The mood indicator is a simple 3-option scale (great/fine/concern) that accumulates into a temporal narrative of the living experience.

visual_spec.layout: Vertical card, max-width 400px. Dates at top, actions in middle, micro-review at bottom.

typography.heading: Inter, 16px, 600 weight, var(--text-dark) -- 'This Week'
typography.body: DM Sans, 14px, 400 weight, var(--text-gray) -- dates and host name
typography.accent: Inter, 13px, 600 weight, white on success purple -- confirm button

visual_spec.color_usage: White card with purple shadow for elevation. Success purple (#4B47CE) on the confirm button. Accent purple on day badges. The micro-review options use subtle purple tinting to stay within the palette.

interaction_spec.default_state: Card shows upcoming dates, host name, confirm button, and last week's micro-review prompt
interaction_spec.hover: Confirm button brightens. Day badges show tooltip with date.
interaction_spec.click: Confirm: button animates to checkmark with success state. Micro-review: option scales up briefly on selection.
interaction_spec.animation: Confirm: button morphs from 'Confirm This Week' to a checkmark with a 200ms scale-bounce. Micro-review selection: selected option scales to 1.1x briefly then settles.
interaction_spec.responsive: Full-width on mobile with slightly reduced padding. Day badges remain horizontal.

copy_spec.secondary_text: Mon Feb 23 - Thu Feb 26
do: Use host's first name for warmth
Keep the entire interaction under 30 seconds
Make the micro-review feel optional but easy
dont: Never require the micro-review to proceed
Never ask more than one review question per week
Never make the card feel like work -- it should feel like a quick check-in

before_after.before: HotPads: the platform disappears at move-in. Zero involvement in the active tenancy. No lease management, no check-ins, no stay confirmation, no review mechanism. The guest's relationship with the platform ends.
before_after.after: Split Lease: a weekly check-in card confirms the upcoming stay in one tap and captures a micro-review of the previous stay. After 13 weeks, the habit is formed (Thing #60), the review narrative has accumulated, and the guest's relationship with the platform is deeper than any search tool could create.

elements.name: Resident Social Proof Badge (Micro-Review Accumulator)
elements.problem_it_solves: Zero social proof exists at the trust-critical moment of listing evaluation, forcing guests to make $20,000+ annual commitments based on photos and specs alone.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No rental listing platform for medium/long-term stays displays resident reviews on listing pages. The micro-review accumulator takes the weekly one-tap reviews from active guests and surfaces them as a temporal narrative on the listing: not a single star rating, but a story of how the experience unfolded over weeks.
elements.description: A compact badge component that appears on listing cards in search results and prominently on the listing detail page. It shows the aggregate rating, number of reviews, and a micro-quote from the most recent review. On the detail page, it expands to show the temporal narrative: a timeline of weekly micro-reviews showing how satisfaction evolved over the stay.

visual_spec.layout: Inline badge for search cards (compact). Expandable section for listing detail page (full).
visual_spec.background: Transparent on search cards. var(--bg-off-white) section on detail page.
visual_spec.border: 1.5px solid rgba(75, 71, 206, 0.2) on the compact badge
visual_spec.border_radius: var(--rounded-pill) (20px) for compact badge. var(--rounded-lg) (8px) for expanded section.

spacing.padding: 6px 12px for compact badge. var(--spacing-xl) for expanded section.

visual_spec.color_usage: Success purple (#4B47CE) for the rating number -- aligning with the trust signal palette. Subtle chat-purple tinting on the badge border. The temporal timeline uses accent purple dots for each weekly review.

interaction_spec.default_state: Compact badge showing rating, count, and most recent micro-quote fragment
interaction_spec.hover: Badge background fills to rgba(75, 71, 206, 0.06). Quote extends to full text.
interaction_spec.click: On listing detail page: expands to show full temporal review timeline. On search card: navigates to listing detail page's review section.
interaction_spec.animation: Badge entrance: subtle scale from 0.95 to 1.0 with 200ms ease-out. Timeline expansion: height animation with 300ms ease-out.
interaction_spec.responsive: Compact badge stays inline on all sizes. Expanded timeline stacks vertically on mobile.

copy_spec.secondary_text: "Felt like staying with a thoughtful friend" -- Marcus T.
do: Always show the most recent micro-quote, not the highest-rated
Show the temporal pattern (ratings over time), not just the aggregate
Use first name and stay duration for attribution
dont: Never fabricate reviews
Never show reviews older than 6 months as 'recent'
Never hide negative feedback -- surface it with the host's response

before_after.before: HotPads: zero reviews on listing pages. No social proof of any kind from previous residents. Guests make $20,000+ annual commitments based on photos and a landlord's self-written description.
before_after.after: Split Lease: accumulated micro-reviews from actual guests, displayed as a temporal narrative showing how the experience evolved over weeks. One review from week 12 saying 'honestly felt like home' is more persuasive than any specification grid (Thing #74: anecdotes > data).

elements.title: Pre-Populated Listing Confirmation Card
elements.description: A single-screen confirmation card that displays all listing data captured from an agent call. Each field shows a label, pre-filled value, and a check icon indicating confirmed status. Fields can be toggled to edit mode by clicking the value. Missing items (photos) are highlighted. A single 'Looks Good' button confirms the entire listing. Designed for passive hosts who should scan and approve in under 60 seconds.

elements.title: Crowd Range Pricing Indicator
elements.description: A minimal horizontal bar that shows the host's price relative to comparable listings in their area. The host's price is displayed prominently above the bar, with the crowd range shown as a thin bar below. A position marker indicates where the host's price falls within the range. No recommendations, no judgments -- pure informational context. Designed to be scannable in under 3 seconds.

elements.name: House Welcome Card: Pre-Move-In Community Activation
elements.problem_it_solves: Guests move into shared houses with zero knowledge of who they will live with -- the anti-magic moment that PadSplit normalizes.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No shared-housing platform introduces you to your housemate before you arrive. This card transforms the anxious gap between acceptance and move-in into a warm social preview that builds trust before the first handshake.
elements.description: A card shown to guests after their proposal is accepted, displaying their co-tenant's anonymized profile: work schedule pattern, lifestyle preferences (quiet/social, early bird/night owl), a short personal intro, and their Passport score if they have one. Includes a 'Send a hello' action that initiates a brief introductory message. The card is designed to feel like meeting a neighbor, not evaluating a roommate.

visual_spec.layout: Vertical card, max-width 420px. Top section: co-tenant avatar placeholder (abstract pattern, not a face) with schedule overlap visualization. Middle section: preference chips and personal intro. Bottom section: CTA button.
visual_spec.color_usage: Primary purple for the heading and schedule overlap bars to signal brand trust. Secondary purple for preference chips and the CTA. Off-white background for the intro section to create visual separation. Success color (#4B47CE) for the Passport score indicator.

interaction_spec.default_state: Card appears with a subtle slide-up animation (0.3s ease-out) after proposal acceptance. Co-tenant profile loads with a gentle fade-in.
interaction_spec.hover: Card elevates with shadow transition (--shadow-sm to --shadow-md). CTA button shifts from secondary-purple to accent-purple.
interaction_spec.click: 'Send a hello' opens an inline message composer with a pre-filled friendly template the guest can customize.
interaction_spec.animation: Schedule overlap bars animate in from left to right (0.4s ease-out, 0.1s stagger). Preference chips fade in sequentially (0.2s each).
interaction_spec.responsive: Full-width on mobile with reduced padding (16px). Schedule visualization stacks vertically below 400px.

copy_spec.secondary_text: Here's a preview of who shares the space at 142 W 72nd St. You'll overlap on weekday evenings and weekends.
micro_copy: Schedule preferences: Night owl, Quiet mornings, Social weekends
do: Use warm, conversational tone -- this is a social introduction, not a data report
Frame schedule overlaps as useful information, not compatibility scores
Show the Passport score as a trust signal, not a rating
dont: Don't use 'compatibility match' language -- this isn't a dating app
Don't show a numerical compatibility percentage
Don't display the co-tenant's real name or photo without their explicit opt-in

elements.html_css:
Meet your housemate

Weekly schedule overlap
You
Them

Shared Housing Passport: 4.8
26 positive micro-reviews across 2 leases
View full house profile

before_after.before: PadSplit: Member gets approved, receives a move-in date, key code, and house rules PDF. Walks into a house of strangers on day one. No profiles, no introductions, no social context. The first time they learn anything about their housemates is when they hear them through the walls.
before_after.after: Split Lease: After acceptance, guest sees a House Welcome Card with their co-tenant's schedule overlap, lifestyle preferences, personal intro, and Passport score. They can send a hello message before move-in day. By the time they walk through the door, they already know a name, a rhythm, and a shared context.

elements.name: Engagement Ladder Progress Strip
elements.problem_it_solves: PadSplit's member experience is a flatline -- month 1 and month 12 are identical. There is no progressive value, no engagement ladder, no reason to deepen engagement over time.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No shared-housing platform rewards tenure with progressively valuable capabilities. This strip transforms the Stays Manager from a billing portal into an engagement engine that reveals new value at each milestone.
elements.description: A horizontal progress strip integrated into the Stays Manager dashboard, showing the guest's current engagement tier and what unlocks next. Three tiers visible: 'Getting Settled' (weeks 1-4), 'Established' (weeks 5-8, unlocks coordination tools and co-tenant feedback), and 'House Anchor' (weeks 9+, unlocks profile influence, priority dates, and deposit credit). Current tier is highlighted with a progress indicator. The next unlock is teased with a subtle preview.

visual_spec.layout: Full-width horizontal strip, height 72px. Three tier segments with connecting progress bar. Fits within the Stays Manager header area.
visual_spec.background: Linear gradient from rgba(49, 19, 93, 0.03) to rgba(109, 49, 194, 0.06)
visual_spec.color_usage: Completed tier segments use secondary-purple fill. Current tier uses a pulsing accent-purple dot. Future tiers use muted gray. The progress bar uses a gradient from secondary-purple to accent-purple.

interaction_spec.default_state: Strip shows three tier labels with icons, a progress bar at the current position, and a subtle 'Next: [unlock name]' preview for the upcoming tier.
interaction_spec.hover: Hovering over any tier reveals a tooltip with the full list of capabilities at that tier.
interaction_spec.click: Clicking the current tier opens a detail panel showing earned capabilities, progress toward the next tier, and what actions accelerate progression.
interaction_spec.animation: Progress bar fills with a smooth animation (0.6s ease-out) on page load. Current tier dot pulses gently (2s infinite). Next-tier teaser fades in after progress bar completes.
interaction_spec.responsive: On mobile, tiers stack vertically as a compact timeline. Progress indicator shifts to a vertical bar on the left.

copy_spec.secondary_text: Week 6 of 13 -- Established
do: Use milestone language, not gamification language -- 'Established' not 'Level 2'
Show concrete capabilities that unlock, not abstract points
Frame progression as natural tenure recognition, not a grind
dont: Don't use XP, points, or score language -- this isn't a game
Don't show a percentage that makes early weeks feel demotivating ('15% complete')
Don't gate essential features behind tiers -- date changes and basic tools are always available

elements.html_css:
Your engagement at 142 W 72nd St Week 6 of 13

Weeks 1-4

Weeks 5-8

before_after.before: PadSplit: Member dashboard shows upcoming payment and payment history. Month 1 and month 12 are identical. No progression, no milestones, no reason to deepen engagement. The dashboard is a billing portal.
before_after.after: Split Lease: The Stays Manager header shows your engagement tier, progress toward the next unlock, and what capabilities await. Each week brings you closer to new value. The dashboard evolves with you.

elements.name: Shared Housing Passport Profile Card
elements.problem_it_solves: PadSplit members build zero portable reputation -- months of on-time payments and good behavior generate no transferable value. Every new lease starts from scratch.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No shared-housing platform creates a cumulative, portable trust profile. This card is the guest's professional identity in the shared-housing world -- a living document that compounds trust over time and creates real switching costs.
elements.description: A profile card that displays the guest's Shared Housing Passport: a cumulative trust score built from weekly micro-reviews, payment reliability, co-tenant feedback, and tenure across leases. Shows the trust score as a prominent number, a temporal graph of micro-review trends, key metrics (consecutive positive weeks, total leases, payment reliability), and verified trust signals. This card appears on the guest's profile (visible to prospective hosts), on the House Welcome Card (visible to prospective co-tenants), and in search results (as a trust badge).

visual_spec.layout: Card with header badge area, score display, metric strip, and trust timeline. Max-width 380px.
visual_spec.background: #ffffff with a subtle top gradient banner (primary-purple to secondary-purple)
visual_spec.color_usage: Purple gradient header conveys authority and trust. Score uses primary-purple for gravitas. Metric icons use success-color (#4B47CE). Timeline uses secondary-purple for positive weeks, muted gray for neutral.

interaction_spec.default_state: Card displays the score, top metrics, and a sparkline of recent weeks. Compact view suitable for embedding in other contexts.
interaction_spec.hover: Card elevates. Sparkline expands to show individual week markers with scores.
interaction_spec.click: Expands to full Passport view with detailed timeline, lease history, and endorsements.
interaction_spec.animation: Score counts up from 0 to current value on first view (0.8s ease-out). Sparkline draws left-to-right (0.6s ease-out). Metrics fade in with stagger (0.15s each).
interaction_spec.responsive: Full-width on mobile. Score and sparkline stack vertically. Metrics become a scrollable horizontal strip.

copy_spec.secondary_text: Trust built over time, verified by the people you've lived with.
do: Frame as a professional credential, not a report card
Emphasize the narrative ('26 consecutive positive weeks') over the number (4.8)
Show the trajectory -- is the score improving, stable, or declining?
dont: Don't make it look like a credit score dashboard
Don't show raw review text on the compact card -- save detail for the expanded view
Don't display a score below 3.0 publicly -- below that threshold, show 'Building your Passport' instead

elements.html_css:
Shared Housing Passport

Verified since October 2025

4.8
Trust Score
26 consecutive positive weeks
2
Leases
100%
On-time
26
Positive weeks
Identity verified · Background checked · 2 host endorsements

before_after.before: PadSplit: A member who paid on time for 12 months and received glowing reviews has the same platform status as someone who signed up yesterday. Move to a new house or a new platform, and all trust evaporates. Zero portable reputation, zero switching cost.
before_after.after: Split Lease: Your Shared Housing Passport accumulates trust with every weekly micro-review. After 2 leases and 26 positive weeks, your 4.8 Trust Score gives you priority placement, reduced deposits, and a verified profile that hosts trust on sight. Leave Split Lease, and you lose all of it.

elements.name: House Anchor Badge and Influence Panel
elements.problem_it_solves: PadSplit does not identify, tool, or reward the members who do disproportionate community-building labor -- the 'hard side' at the house level that Chen identifies as critical to network stability.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No shared-housing platform formally recognizes the member who makes the house work. This badge and panel transform invisible community labor into visible, rewarded status.
elements.description: A badge that appears on the Stays Manager and guest profile once House Anchor status is earned, along with an influence panel that gives Anchors specific tools: preview profiles of incoming co-tenants (Passport data), write the welcome note new co-tenants see during pre-move-in onboarding, and submit a house community referral (invite a specific person to their specific house). The badge includes concrete benefits: priority date selection and a deposit credit toward their next lease.

visual_spec.layout: Badge: inline element 28px tall, pill shape. Panel: dropdown panel max-width 360px, attached to the badge location.
visual_spec.background: Badge: gradient from #31135D to secondary-purple. Panel: white with subtle purple-tinted top border.
visual_spec.border: Panel: 1px solid #e5e7eb, 3px top border in secondary-purple
visual_spec.color_usage: Badge uses the primary-to-secondary purple gradient to convey earned authority. Star icon in white. Panel actions use secondary-purple for CTAs. Benefit indicators use success-color (#4B47CE).

interaction_spec.default_state: Badge appears inline in the Stays Manager header and on the guest profile. Subtle shimmer animation on first earn.
interaction_spec.hover: Badge shows a tooltip: 'House Anchor -- tap to see your influence tools.'
interaction_spec.click: Opens the influence panel with three action areas: Preview incoming co-tenants, Write welcome note, Refer a friend to this house.
interaction_spec.animation: Badge entrance: scale from 0.8 to 1.0 with overshoot (0.4s spring easing). Panel: slides down from badge position (0.2s ease-out).
interaction_spec.responsive: Badge remains inline at all sizes. Panel becomes a full-width bottom sheet on mobile.

copy_spec.secondary_text: You've earned influence at 142 W 72nd St.
micro_copy: Invite a friend to this house
do: Frame as earned recognition, not a job assignment
Emphasize 'influence' not 'control' -- Anchors shape, they don't gatekeep
Show concrete benefits alongside tools
dont: Don't use 'manager' or 'admin' language -- Anchors are peers, not bosses
Don't imply Anchors can block co-tenants -- they preview and advise, not veto
Don't make the badge look corporate -- it should feel like a community honor

elements.html_css:
Your Stays Manager

Your influence at 142 W 72nd St

You've earned community tools through 10 weeks of positive engagement.

Preview incoming co-tenant
See their Passport before they move in
Write a welcome note
Your message appears during their onboarding
Invite a friend to this house
Community referral -- both of you get a bonus
Priority dates: active
Deposit credit: $75

before_after.before: PadSplit: Every member is identical -- same rules, same interface, same relationship with the platform. The member who coordinates trash schedules, mediates conflicts, and welcomes newcomers gets the same treatment as someone who just pays rent and stays in their room. The hard side is invisible and unrewarded.
before_after.after: Split Lease: After 9+ weeks of positive engagement, guests earn the House Anchor badge with concrete tools (preview incoming co-tenants, write welcome notes, refer friends) and real benefits (priority dates, deposit credit). The hard side is identified, empowered, and retained.

elements.name: House Personality Search Card
elements.problem_it_solves: PadSplit search hides the most important variable in shared housing -- the people -- forcing guests to make life decisions based on room specs and price alone.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No shared-housing platform lets you search by house personality. This card makes the social composition of a house visible during search, transforming room-shopping into community-finding.
elements.description: A search result card that leads with the house personality rather than room specs. Shows a brief auto-generated house summary based on co-tenant profiles and micro-review themes, schedule compatibility indicator (low/medium/high overlap with the searching guest's stated schedule), lifestyle chips (quiet, social, early bird, etc.), and the house's aggregate Passport score. Price and amenities are secondary, visible but not dominant. The card answers 'who lives here?' before 'what does the room cost?'

visual_spec.layout: Horizontal card, full search-result width. Left section: house photo (40% width). Right section: personality summary, compatibility indicator, chips, then price/details row at bottom.

spacing.padding: 0 (image flush left) with 16px padding on text section

visual_spec.color_usage: Primary purple for personality headline. Compatibility indicator uses a color scale: high overlap = success-color (#4B47CE), medium = accent-purple, low = text-gray. Lifestyle chips use the same style as the House Welcome Card for consistency.

interaction_spec.default_state: Card displays house photo, personality headline, compatibility badge, 2-3 lifestyle chips, price, and a subtle co-tenant count indicator.
interaction_spec.hover: Card elevates with shadow transition. Compatibility indicator expands to show schedule overlap detail.
interaction_spec.click: Navigates to full listing page with House Welcome Card content (co-tenant profiles, schedule visualization, full personality description).
interaction_spec.animation: Cards stagger-fade in during search results load (0.15s delay between each). Compatibility badge pulses gently on high-compatibility results.
interaction_spec.responsive: Stacks vertically on mobile: photo on top (full width), personality content below.

copy_spec.secondary_text: Night-shift healthcare and remote developers. Shared kitchen active on weekends. Minimal weekday overlap.
do: Lead with personality, not price -- the personality is what differentiates from PadSplit
Use natural language for house descriptions, not tag-soup
Show compatibility as a gentle signal, not a hard match score
dont: Don't show co-tenant names or identifiable photos in search results
Don't make low-compatibility results look like warnings -- some guests prefer minimal overlap
Don't hide price entirely -- it's still a decision factor, just not the headline

elements.html_css:
2 co-tenants
Quiet professionals · Upper West Side
High match

Healthcare consultant and remote developer. Shared kitchen active on weekends. Minimal weekday overlap -- ideal for professionals who value quiet evenings.

Quiet evenings Clean kitchen Early risers
$185/week
4.7
1 co-tenant
Social creatives · Williamsburg
Moderate match

Freelance designer, in town Mon-Wed. Loves cooking together and neighborhood exploration. Social house with flexible shared-space norms.

Social kitchen Flexible hours Creative space
$210/week
4.5

before_after.before: PadSplit: Search results show room photo, '$175/week,' 'East Atlanta,' 'Private Room,' 'Parking Available.' No information about who lives there, what the house culture is, or whether you'd be compatible. You search for a room, not a home.
before_after.after: Split Lease: Search results lead with house personality ('Quiet professionals'), show compatibility with your schedule ('High match'), and display lifestyle chips that tell you what living there is actually like. You search for a community, and the room comes with it.

elements.name: House Continuity Welcome Note
elements.problem_it_solves: Every co-tenant transition in PadSplit recreates the Cold Start Problem at the house level -- no institutional knowledge transfer, no welcome ritual, no preserved social context across turnovers.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No shared-housing platform preserves house culture across turnovers. This welcome note, written by the House Anchor, bridges the social gap between departing and arriving co-tenants, preventing the perpetual cold start.
elements.description: A section within the pre-move-in House Welcome flow that displays a personal welcome note written by the current House Anchor (or host). The note includes practical tips specific to this house (where to find extra towels, the best coffee spot nearby, parking quirks), the house's unwritten norms (quiet after 10pm, kitchen cleanup same-day, packages go on the side table), and a personal greeting. This note is updated by the Anchor each time a new co-tenant is arriving and persists across turnovers, becoming a living house manual written by the people who actually live there.

visual_spec.layout: Full-width section within the pre-move-in flow. Card-style container with an author attribution header and a freeform content area.
visual_spec.background: Warm off-white (rgb(252, 250, 255)) with a left border accent in secondary-purple
visual_spec.border: 1px solid #e5e7eb, with 3px left border in secondary-purple
visual_spec.color_usage: Left border accent in secondary-purple signals this is a personal message, not system-generated. Author attribution uses primary-purple for the name. Tip bullets use a subtle purple dot. The warm background differentiates this from data-driven sections.

interaction_spec.default_state: Note displays with the author's attribution and Anchor badge, followed by the welcome message and house tips. Collapsed if longer than 5 lines, with 'Read more' expand.
interaction_spec.hover: No hover state -- this is a reading section, not an interactive element.
interaction_spec.click: 'Read more' expands the full note. 'Say thanks' button sends a pre-filled appreciation message to the Anchor.
interaction_spec.animation: Fades in with a handwritten-style motion (slight rotation settle, 0.3s ease-out) to feel personal, not generated.
interaction_spec.responsive: Full-width on all sizes. Left border becomes a top border on mobile for thumb-friendly layout.

copy_spec.primary_text: A note from your House Anchor
copy_spec.secondary_text: Sarah has been at 142 W 72nd St for 8 months and knows the ins and outs.
do: Encourage Anchors to write naturally -- this should feel like a text from a friend, not a hotel concierge manual
Include practical specifics that only a resident would know
Show when the note was last updated to signal freshness
dont: Don't auto-generate the note content -- it must be authentically written by the Anchor
Don't require a minimum length -- a three-sentence warm welcome is better than a forced essay
Don't display the Anchor's full name without consent -- first name and initial is sufficient

elements.html_css:
S
Sarah K. Anchor
At 142 W 72nd St since June 2025
Updated 3 days ago

Hey! Welcome to the apartment. I'm a healthcare consultant -- usually here Tue through Thu evenings. The place is really comfortable and the neighborhood is great for walking. Looking forward to sharing the space with you.

House tips
  • Extra towels and linens are in the hallway closet, top shelf
  • Best coffee within walking distance is Birch on Columbus -- they know the building
  • Street parking is free after 7pm on the north side of 72nd
  • Kitchen cleanup norm: same-day dishes, shared supplies are under the sink
  • The radiator in the bedroom takes about 20 minutes to warm up -- turn it on when you arrive
This note is from your House Anchor

before_after.before: PadSplit: New member receives a house rules PDF and a key code. No personal welcome, no resident tips, no sense of who lives there or how the house works. Every move-in recreates the Cold Start Problem because no social context survives turnovers.
before_after.after: Split Lease: Before move-in, the guest reads a personal welcome note from the House Anchor: practical tips only a resident would know, the house's unwritten norms, and a warm greeting. The house's social capital persists across turnovers because the Anchor maintains it.

elements.name: Community Referral Invitation Card
elements.problem_it_solves: PadSplit referrals are generic platform marketing -- a member shares a link for a cash bonus, and the referred person ends up in a random house. Referrals generate volume without strengthening any house's network.
elements.why_this_is_a_signature: No shared-housing platform lets you invite a specific friend to your specific house. This transforms referrals from a marketing mechanism to a community-building mechanism, generating the Acquisition Effect that Chen identifies as essential for Escape Velocity.
elements.description: A card available to House Anchors (and after a tenure threshold, all guests) that lets them invite a specific person to their specific house. The card shows what the invited person will see: the house personality, the inviter's welcome note, and a personal message. The referral is tied to a specific house, not the generic platform, meaning the invited person arrives with a pre-existing social connection. Both parties receive a community bonus (deposit credit, not just cash) that incentivizes house-level referrals over platform-level ones.

visual_spec.layout: Card with a preview section (showing what the invitee will see) and a simple invite form. Max-width 440px.
visual_spec.color_usage: Primary purple for the heading. The preview section uses off-white background to simulate what the invitee will see. The bonus indicator uses success-color. The invite button uses the standard secondary-purple CTA style.

interaction_spec.default_state: Card shows the invite headline, a preview of the house personality card the invitee will see, and fields for the friend's name and message.
interaction_spec.hover: Preview section elevates slightly. Send button shows hover state.
interaction_spec.click: Send button generates a unique invite link tied to this specific house. Confirmation shows: 'Invitation sent! If [Name] joins 142 W 72nd St, you both earn a $50 deposit credit.'
interaction_spec.animation: Preview section pulses gently to draw attention. Success state shows confetti-style purple particles (subtle, 1.5s).
interaction_spec.responsive: Full-width on mobile. Preview section becomes scrollable if it extends below fold.

copy_spec.primary_text: Invite a friend to your house
copy_spec.secondary_text: Know someone who'd be a great fit at 142 W 72nd St? Invite them directly -- they'll see your personal recommendation.
micro_copy: Both of you earn a $50 deposit credit
Your friend will see the house personality and your welcome note
This isn't a generic referral -- it's a community invitation
do: Frame as a community invitation, not a marketing referral
Emphasize the personal connection: 'your friend' not 'a new user'
Show the mutual benefit clearly
dont: Don't use 'refer a friend' language -- use 'invite' instead
Don't make the cash incentive the headline -- the community connection is the headline
Don't allow invitations to generic platform signup -- the invitation must be to a specific house

elements.html_css:
Invite a friend to your house

Know someone who'd fit at 142 W 72nd St? Send them a personal invitation -- they'll see the house personality and your welcome note before they apply.

Your friend will see
Quiet professionals · Upper West Side
Your house personality + your personal welcome note
If your friend joins this house, you both earn a $50 deposit credit

This is a community invitation, not a generic referral. Your friend applies to this specific house.

before_after.before: PadSplit: Member shares a generic referral link for a $50 cash bonus. The referred person enters PadSplit's generic application flow and may end up in a completely different city. Referrer and referred have no connection within the platform. The referral generates volume without strengthening any house network.
before_after.after: Split Lease: Guest invites a specific friend to their specific house. The friend sees the house personality, the inviter's welcome note, and applies to that house directly. Both receive a deposit credit when the friend moves in. The referral strengthens the house's atomic network because the new co-tenant arrives with a pre-existing social connection.

elements.name: Guest Occupancy Day-Badge Row
elements.description: A compact 7-circle day-badge row (M T W T F S S) that visually communicates a guest's weekly occupancy pattern at a glance. Active stay days use the brand purple fill; inactive days use a muted grey. This is the primary visual anchor in any guest-related card, enabling hosts like Dana to assess guest type in under 2 seconds.

elements.design_rationale: Dana's primary decision criterion is guest occupancy pattern (Mon-Thu vs. full-week). Refactoring UI's hierarchy principle states that the most important information must be the most visually prominent. The day-badge row communicates occupancy pattern through visual weight (filled vs. empty circles) rather than text labels, enabling 2-second assessment. Uses production style guide's --chat-purple for active badges and --bg-light-gray for inactive.

elements.name: Guest Proposal Card with Type-First Hierarchy
elements.description: A proposal card that places guest occupancy pattern and compatibility badges above dates and pricing, implementing the type-first information hierarchy discovered through Dana's call. The card enables quick accept/reject decisions based on guest type, with inline action buttons for time-starved hosts.
elements.html_css:

elements.design_rationale: Implements the type-first hierarchy from works-001: guest name and day-badge row are positioned above dates and pricing. The 3px purple left border signals this is an actionable card (looks-004). Compatibility badges (looks-005) show at-a-glance match against host preferences. Inline accept/decline buttons (behaves-001) enable quick decisions without navigating to a detail view. Uses production purple palette (#31135D, #4B47CE, rgb(109, 49, 194)).

elements.name: Status-First Host Dashboard
elements.description: A dashboard layout that places the current status headline and action queue above all other content, designed for hosts who check in 5-second bursts between flights. Three visual tiers: status (dominant), actions (medium weight), activity feed (below fold).
elements.html_css:
Welcome back, Dana
Allen arrives Monday
Stay #6 of 10 Furnished Room with Private Roof Garden
All previous stays clean
Action needed (1)
Review proposal from Maya Torres
2 days left to respond
Recent activity
Allen checked out Cleaning photos received
Thursday, Feb 20 at 6:14 PM
Payment processed $340.00 deposited
Wednesday, Feb 19
Allen arrived Stay #5 started
Monday, Feb 17 at 5:30 PM
elements.design_rationale: Implements communicates-003 status-first architecture with three visual tiers. Status headline uses Tier 1 text (20px, bold, dark) per looks-002. Action cards have purple left accent border per looks-004 to signal actionability. Activity feed uses Tier 3 styling (13px, grey) and sits below fold. Generous spacing (24px gaps between sections) per looks-003 creates scannable breathing room. Constrained to 640px width per Refactoring UI's 'you don't have to fill the whole screen.'

elements.name: Between-Stay Status Display
elements.description: A timeline-based status display for the period between guest stays (e.g., Friday through Sunday for a Mon-Thu guest). Shows the last stay outcome, cleaning photo status, and next arrival date. Designed to communicate calm reassurance to absent hosts who check their phone between flights.
elements.html_css:
Next stay
Allen arrives Monday, Feb 24
Stay #6 of 10 MonThu
Allen checked out
Thursday, Feb 20 at 6:14 PM
Cleaning photos received
Thursday, Feb 20 at 6:32 PM
+2
Allen arrives
Monday, Feb 24 3 days from now
5 stays completed All photos received
elements.design_rationale: Implements communicates-005 (empty state as status communication) and feels-002 (calm authority). The timeline format gives structure to the between-stay period, communicating that the system is tracking the cycle. Completed events use filled purple dots; upcoming events use outlined dots. Cleaning photo thumbnails provide tangible evidence that the guest left the space clean (addressing Dana's anxiety from the fish-cooking experience). The reliability badge at bottom builds cumulative trust. Uses generous white space and Tier 1/2/3 text hierarchy.

elements.name: Guest Preference Quick-Set Panel
elements.description: A rapid-selection panel for setting guest preferences during listing creation. Uses toggle chips and a day-badge selector that can be completed in 3-4 taps. Pre-populates defaults based on agent call notes, treating the host as an expert whose preferences are already known.
elements.html_css:
Guest Preferences
Based on your conversation with Bryant, we've set some defaults. Adjust anything that doesn't look right.
Preferred Stay Days
Guest Type
Secondary address only
Guest must have another primary residence
4 nights/week MonThu Travel professionals & hybrid workers Secondary address required
elements.design_rationale: Implements works-004 (negative experience screening filter) and behaves-004 (quick-set interaction) and feels-004 (expert recognition). Pre-selects defaults based on call notes, treating Dana as the expert whose preferences are already understood. The subtitle references Bryant by name, bridging human trust to digital trust. Toggle chips require single taps (100ms feedback per behaves-004). The summary bar gives immediate confirmation of combined preferences. Uses constrained options per Refactoring UI's 'designing by process of elimination.'

elements.name: Patient Follow-Up Email Template
elements.description: An email template for post-call follow-up that embodies the 'respectful patience' principle. Minimalist, sent from the agent's name, with a single CTA and explicit 'no rush' language. Designed for hosts who cannot engage immediately due to personal circumstances.
elements.html_css:
Bryant via Split Lease
Info about Allen's interest in your space
Hi Dana,
Great talking with you today. As I mentioned, Allen is looking for a MonThu arrangement starting around April. He'd be a secondary-address guest exactly the type you described preferring.
Here's the link with more details whenever you have a moment. Absolutely no rush.
View Allen's profile
Bryant
Host Advisor Split Lease
You're receiving this because Bryant spoke with you about your Furnished Finder listing. Reply to this email anytime it goes directly to Bryant.
elements.design_rationale: Implements feels-003 (respectful patience) and communicates-004 (value proposition through contrast). Email is sent from Bryant's name (not 'Split Lease Team'), maintaining human trust bridge. Subject line references the specific guest (Allen) and space, creating associative coherence with the call. Body text is under 50 words, uses 'no rush' explicitly, and contains a single CTA. The guest type (Mon-Thu, secondary address) is mentioned to mirror Dana's stated preferences. The purple palette and Inter font maintain brand consistency.

elements.name: Listing Import Confirmation Flow
elements.description: A review-and-confirm interface for imported listing data. Shows pre-filled fields with check indicators for successfully mapped data and accent highlights for fields needing attention. Designed for experienced hosts who already have listings on other platforms.
elements.html_css:
Review Your Imported Listing
We imported your listing from Furnished Finder. Everything looks good just confirm the details below.
Imported from Furnished Finder
furnishedfinder.com/listing/12345
Property Details
Title Furnished Room with Private Roof Garden
Type Private Room
Parking Garage nearby
Available from April 1, 2026
Split Lease extras
Guest Preferences (New)
Preferred stays Set preferences
Lease style Select style
elements.design_rationale: Implements works-003 (listing import) and feels-004 (expert recognition). Pre-filled fields with check icons communicate 'we already know your listing.' The import source badge with Furnished Finder URL confirms the data provenance. Split Lease-specific fields are separated in a section with a purple accent border (looks-004) and labeled as 'Split Lease extras' (not 'required fields'). The 'Publish listing' button is prominently available even before completing extras, per Refactoring UI's 'build the simple version first.'

elements.name: Notification Priority Escalation Card
elements.description: A notification card for time-sensitive actions that shows deadline information prominently and adapts its visual urgency based on proximity to deadline. Used for proposals awaiting response, date change approvals, and other actions with expiration timelines.
elements.html_css:
Priority Ample Time
Proposal from Maya Torres
MonThu 12 weeks Secondary address
2 days left
Escalation Deadline Approaching
Date change request from Allen
Swap Feb 24 Feb 25 Allen's stay #6
Expires today
Batch Informational
Daily summary
3 listing views Allens stay completed Payment processed
elements.design_rationale: Implements works-005 (asynchronous communication for absent hosts) and behaves-003 (notification escalation). Three visual tiers match the notification system: Priority cards have purple left accent border, Escalation cards have amber accent border and 'Expires today' badge, Batch items have no accent and lighter styling. Deadline badges use Refactoring UI's 'combine labels and values' principle: '2 days left' instead of 'Deadline: Feb 22.' Guest context (occupancy pattern, stay number) is shown inline, saving the host from needing to tap into details.

elements.name: Day-of-Week Flexibility Selector
elements.description: A horizontal row of tappable day chips (Mon-Sun) with three visual states: selected (solid purple), flexible (purple outline), and available (gray). Guests tap to set their ideal days and mark flexible alternatives. Real-time match count updates when days are toggled. This is the core interaction for expressing nights-of-the-week preferences without agent assistance.
elements.html_css:
Your preferred nights
Tap to select ideal days. Double-tap for flexible days.

elements.design_rationale: The day-chip selector is the single most important self-service interaction for the nights-of-the-week model. Tyler spent 10+ minutes verbally negotiating day flexibility with an agent  this component reduces that to 10 seconds of tapping. The three-state encoding (selected/flexible/available) captures the nuance Tyler expressed: 'Saturday through Wednesday is ideal, but I'm flexible.' The real-time match count provides the immediate feedback that the Hook Model's Action phase requires: toggle a day, see the impact instantly.

elements.name: Listing Match Quality Card
elements.description: A search result card that prominently displays a match quality score (fraction of requested nights available) overlaid on the listing photo. Shows the guest's personalized monthly price for their specific day pattern, not just the host's posted rate. Includes location confirmation and a subtle flexibility bonus indicator.
elements.html_css:
🏠
4/5 match
Nina's Chelsea Studio
Chelsea, Manhattan
$1,920 /month
For your Sat-Wed pattern · Private bath
M
T
W
Th

Sa

elements.design_rationale: The match quality card addresses the information architecture gap Tyler experienced: he had no way to know if a listing's available days matched his needs without a phone call. The match badge (4/5) is the first thing the eye hits, communicating the most critical criterion for nights-of-the-week housing. The personalized monthly price ($1,920 for YOUR pattern) replaces the confusing posted-rate-vs-your-rate disconnect that caused Tyler's anxiety. The flexibility bonus line ('Shift to Sun-Wed to save $180/mo') makes the guest's flexibility feel valuable, not like a concession.

elements.name: Price Decomposition with Day-Rate Bars
elements.description: A visual price breakdown showing per-night rates as horizontal bars, with the guest's total monthly cost prominently displayed. Weekend premium nights are visually distinguished. A 'what-if' toggle shows how shifting days affects the total price, giving the guest control over their spending.

Switch to Sun–Thu (drop Sat, add Thu) to pay $1,740/mo — save $180/month by swapping one weekend night for a weeknight.
elements.design_rationale: Tyler anchored on $1,800 (Nina's posted rate) and explicitly said 'don't push up the price.' This component makes pricing fully transparent: each night's rate is visible, weekend premiums are labeled, and the total is decomposed into understandable parts. The 'what-if' box gives the guest control over their spending by showing exactly how day shifts affect price. IBM Plex Mono for prices signals precision and data trustworthiness per the taste model.

elements.name: This-Week Stay Card with One-Tap Check-In
elements.description: The primary dashboard card for active lease guests. Shows this week's stay details with a personalized welcome, host avatar, and a prominent one-tap check-in button. After check-in, transforms to show the checked-in state with progressive enhancement options (arrival time, notes). Designed to feel like opening a door to your own space, not logging into an admin panel.
elements.html_css:
Week 5 of your Chelsea lease
Welcome back to Chelsea
Saturday, Jan 3 – Wednesday, Jan 7
N
Nina's Studio
Holiday lights on 9th Ave this week!
24
nights total
5/5
space care
4.9

elements.design_rationale: This card is the anchor of the weekly hook cycle. It must feel warm and personal ('Welcome back to Chelsea') rather than administrative ('Booking #4521 confirmed'). The one-tap check-in is designed to be faster than texting the host (under 3 seconds). The stay stats (nights total, space care streak, rating) provide 'reward of the self'  the guest sees their responsible co-resident identity accumulating. Nina's personal note ('Holiday lights on 9th Ave') adds variable reward  each week's card has something slightly different.

elements.name: Space Care Photo Upload with Streak Counter
elements.description: End-of-stay photo upload flow that transforms the cleaning obligation into a pride-building ritual. Guides the guest to capture 3 quick photos, shows upload progress, then reveals their space care streak. Reframes 'cleaning photos' as 'Space Care' to shift the emotional framing from obligation to pride.
elements.html_css:
Space Care
Snap 3 quick photos before you head out
Kitchen
Bathroom
Main room
5/5
Perfect Space Care streak
Nina sees your care when she checks in next
Skip this time
elements.design_rationale: Tyler agreed to self-cleaning as a cost-saving measure, but without positive emotional framing it becomes a chore. Rebranding as 'Space Care' and adding a streak counter transforms the cleaning obligation into a pride-building ritual per the Hook Model's 'reward of the self.' The guided 3-photo flow (kitchen, bathroom, main room) reduces cognitive load to near-zero. The streak counter ('5/5 Perfect Space Care') provides the mastery reward that drives habit formation. The skip link preserves autonomy per Eyal's warning against forced loops.

elements.name: Guest Requirements Profile Strip
elements.description: A persistent, collapsible summary strip that follows the guest through search, listing evaluation, and proposal creation. Shows key parameters (location, days, budget, duration) as tappable chips. Auto-builds from the guest's interactions  no explicit profile setup required. Each parameter is editable inline. Serves as visible stored value (investment) that increases switching costs.
elements.html_css:
Your search:
Chelsea
Sat–Wed
~$2,000/mo
Dec–Jan+
Clear all
elements.design_rationale: During Tyler's call, the agent spent 15 minutes extracting requirements that were then stored only in the agent's notes. This profile strip makes the guest's investment visible: they can see exactly what the system knows about them (Chelsea, Sat-Wed, ~$2,000, Dec-Jan+). Per Eyal's Investment theory, visible stored value increases switching costs  the guest won't want to re-enter these preferences on another platform. The auto-build mechanism means the profile grows passively through normal search actions, not through an explicit setup wizard.

elements.test_criteria: 80% of premium hosts recall seeing protection signals without prompting. Comfort score increases by 2+ points (on 10-point scale) when this card is present vs absent. Support tickets about guest vetting decrease by 30%.

elements.name: Agent Welcome Bridge Card

elements.description: The first screen a guest sees when arriving at Split Lease (often from Craigslist or email link). Answers 'What is this?' in one sentence, resolves 'Is this legitimate?' with three trust signals, and provides a single primary action to browse listings. No sign-up gate. Personalized when referral source is known.
