elements.title: Atomic Network Assembly: Specific Tenant-Property Match Before Platform Onboarding
elements.problem: Traditional platform onboarding asks the host to create an account, then a listing, then wait for matches. But hard-side hosts like Dimitri have zero motivation to invest in a generic platform. Dimitri only engaged because Bryant had specific guests (Ariel and Amber) for his specific apartment. If the platform had asked him to sign up first and browse later, he would never have responded. The Cold Start Problem is not 'build it and they will come'  it's 'bring the match, then build the platform around it.'
elements.solution: Reverse the onboarding sequence: present the specific match first, then onboard the host into the platform as a way to facilitate that match. (1) The first platform touchpoint must show Dimitri his specific apartment with Ariel and Amber already interested. (2) Account creation happens inline with reviewing the match, not as a prerequisite. (3) The listing is auto-populated from agent call notes, not built from scratch. (4) The platform introduces itself as 'the way to make this specific deal happen securely,' not as 'a marketplace for subletting.'

evidence.quote: Thanks for calling me back actually. So this is for the summertime, correct?
evidence.insight: Dimitri engaged because of a specific deal (summer sublet), not because of a platform. The match came first.

evidence.quote: The atomic network is the smallest possible network where there are enough people for the product to become useful.
evidence.insight: For Split Lease, the atomic network is one host + one guest pair + payment guarantee. The platform must prove value at this smallest unit before scaling.

evidence.quote: We matched Ariel and Amber as roommates. They both came to us individually looking for a space in the lower Manhattan Midtown area.
evidence.insight: Bryant presents the pre-assembled match. He doesn't say 'sign up on our platform.' He says 'here are two people who need your apartment.'

evidence.source: coldstart-network-effects.txt, Ch 13 (Come for the Tool, Stay for the Network)
evidence.quote: Come for the Tool, Stay for the Network  the idea that you can attract users with a compelling single-player utility.
evidence.insight: The 'tool' for Dimitri is: vetted tenants for your specific summer sublet. The 'network' comes later  a marketplace of recurring seasonal guests.

elements.user_goal: Find reliable tenants for my specific apartment during my specific travel period, without having to screen and manage them myself.
elements.company_goal: Convert hard-side hosts by leading with a specific, high-value match rather than a generic platform value proposition. Increase host conversion from first-contact to listing-creation.
elements.time_budget: The first platform touchpoint must convey the match in under 30 seconds. If the host doesn't see their apartment and the interested guests within the first screen, they will close the tab.
anti_goals: DO NOT require account creation before showing the match. The match is the hook; the account is the scaffolding.
DO NOT present Split Lease as a 'marketplace' to a host who sees himself as doing a one-time sublease. Frame it as a service for THIS deal.
DO NOT hide the guests behind the platform. Dimitri wants to see Ariel and Amber's information, not 'You have 2 interested guests  sign up to see.'
DO NOT make the host build a listing before seeing demand. Demand-first, supply-later.
elements.success_metric: First-touch-to-listing conversion rate for agent-recruited hosts: target above 50%. Time from first platform interaction to published listing: under 5 minutes for hosts with agent call notes.

elements.title: Dual Verification Transparency: Platform Vetting Alongside Host Verification
elements.problem: Dimitri demands personal verification of tenants ('driver's license, because you never know') even if Split Lease has already vetted them. Most marketplaces treat platform vetting as a replacement for personal verification. But for the hard side of the network, this creates a trust gap: they don't trust the platform's vetting because they don't trust the platform yet. The Cold Start Problem reveals that trust is earned at the atomic network level  the first transaction  and cannot be front-loaded by assertions.
elements.solution: Show both the platform's verification AND the information the host needs for personal verification, side by side. (1) When presenting a guest, show Split Lease's vetting results (credit check, references, ID verification) alongside the guest's personal details that the host would traditionally request (name, ID, employment). (2) Frame the platform's vetting as complementary to the host's judgment, not a replacement. Language like 'We've already checked  here's what we found, and here's the full picture for you' bridges institutional and personal trust. (3) Allow the host to request additional verification (video call, in-person meeting) through the platform, not around it.

evidence.quote: Your company, but still have their information, their driver's license, because you never know, I wouldn't be on the safe side.
evidence.insight: Dimitri wants BOTH: Split Lease's institutional backing AND personal access to tenant documents. The platform must satisfy both needs simultaneously.

evidence.quote: To attract the hard side, you need to solve a problem so hard, and so important, that they are willing to join and participate in an ecosystem alongside others.
evidence.insight: The hard problem isn't just finding tenants  it's finding tenants AND letting the host verify them. Solving only half (finding but not showing) doesn't clear the bar.

elements.user_goal: See everything I need to personally verify my tenant, while also knowing the platform has done its own checks.
elements.company_goal: Build trust at the atomic network level by transparently showing verification work, converting skeptical hard-side hosts into platform advocates.
elements.time_budget: Guest verification details must be accessible within 2 taps from the proposal card. Full verification report viewable in under 30 seconds.
anti_goals: DO NOT hide guest personal information behind 'platform verified' badges. Show the data, not just the result.
DO NOT force the host to choose between platform vetting and personal vetting. Support both simultaneously.
DO NOT make video call or in-person meeting requests go outside the platform. If Dimitri wants to show the apartment via video, the platform should facilitate it.
DO NOT present verification as a one-time gate. Dimitri wants ongoing visibility into who is in his apartment.
elements.success_metric: Percentage of hosts who view the full verification report before accepting a proposal: target above 70%. Reduction in 'who is this person' support tickets: target 40% decrease.

elements.title: Time-Bounded Atomic Network: Convert Within the Urgency Window or Lose the Host
elements.problem: Dimitri gave a one-week deadline: 'ideally I want to like take care of things within next week.' He is simultaneously evaluating other potential tenants. The Cold Start Problem is a race: the atomic network (Dimitri + Ariel/Amber + Split Lease) must form before Dimitri's alternative option (direct sublease) closes the window. Every day of delay increases the probability that Dimitri fills the apartment independently.
elements.solution: Design the onboarding-to-deal pipeline with explicit time awareness. (1) After the agent call, the first platform touchpoint must arrive within hours, not days. (2) The entire flow  match presentation, listing creation, guest review, deal acceptance  must be completable in a single session. (3) Show the host a visible countdown or timeline: 'Ariel and Amber are reviewing your space. Expected response: 2 days.' This transforms waiting time from dead time into tracked progress. (4) If the host has not engaged within 48 hours, trigger a personal follow-up from the agent (not a platform email).

evidence.quote: Ideally I want to like take care of things within next week.
evidence.insight: One-week window. After that, Dimitri fills the apartment through other channels and Split Lease loses the atomic network.

evidence.quote: See if they're just trying to get back to me as soon as possible.
evidence.insight: Speed is a proxy for reliability. If the platform is slower than a direct text exchange, it signals bureaucratic overhead.

evidence.quote: Anti-network effects describe what happens when a network is too small to be useful... everyone will leave.
evidence.insight: A one-host, two-guest network is fragile. If any party loses patience (Dimitri's 1-week window), the anti-network effect collapses the whole unit.

elements.user_goal: Resolve my summer sublease situation within a week, whether through Split Lease or direct dealing.
elements.company_goal: Compress the onboarding-to-first-deal timeline to under 7 days for agent-recruited hosts, preventing hard-side attrition to alternative channels.
elements.time_budget: First platform touchpoint within 4 hours of agent call. Listing creation completable in 10 minutes. Guest review and deal acceptance within 48 hours of listing publish.
anti_goals: DO NOT send a 'Welcome to Split Lease!' email without deal-specific content. Generic onboarding emails waste the urgency window.
DO NOT require steps that don't directly advance the specific deal (e.g., 'Complete your profile' or 'Set your preferences').
DO NOT let the pipeline stall silently. If the guest hasn't responded, proactively notify the host with a timeline.
DO NOT treat the host's urgency as a negotiation lever. Respect the timeline as a constraint, not an opportunity.
elements.success_metric: Percentage of agent-recruited hosts who complete first deal within 7 days of initial call: target above 40%. Median time from call to published listing: under 24 hours.

elements.title: Remote Host Visibility Loop: Overseas Monitoring Without Active Management
elements.problem: Dimitri will be in Europe for 3 months while guests occupy his apartment. He has an 8-year emotional attachment to the property. Without visibility into the apartment's condition, he will either (a) contact tenants directly, bypassing the platform, or (b) build anxiety that prevents him from relisting. Chen's Escape Velocity framework shows that engagement effects drive retention  but engagement for a remote host means passive monitoring, not active management.
elements.solution: Create an automatic visibility loop that keeps the remote host informed without requiring action. (1) Weekly status updates pushed to the host: 'Week 3 of 12: Everything is running smoothly. Rent received. Cleaning photos available.' (2) Cleaning photos from guests viewable in the app with timestamps. (3) Utility usage summaries (if tracked) to flag unusual patterns. (4) A 'quiet mode' for hosts who don't want alerts unless something is wrong  but with a weekly digest that proves the platform is watching.

evidence.quote: I will be in Europe, actually for work.
evidence.insight: 3-month absence creates a monitoring gap. The platform must fill this gap or the host will fill it by contacting tenants directly.

evidence.quote: The Engagement Effect describes the increase in engagement that happens as the network grows.
evidence.insight: For a remote host, engagement = opening the app to check status. If the status is always 'no updates,' the host stops checking and disengages. Proactive updates keep the engagement loop alive.

evidence.quote: I've been there eight years.
evidence.insight: 8-year emotional investment. This isn't a generic rental property  it's his home. Monitoring anxiety is proportional to attachment.

elements.user_goal: Know that my apartment is safe and well-maintained while I'm 5,000 miles away, without having to actively manage tenants.
elements.company_goal: Maintain host engagement during active leases to drive retention and referrals. Prove platform value through visibility, not just matchmaking.
elements.time_budget: Weekly digest: 30 seconds to scan. Individual updates: 5 seconds to read. Photo review: 15 seconds total.
anti_goals: DO NOT require the host to check the platform proactively. Push updates to them.
DO NOT send generic 'everything is fine' messages without evidence. Attach cleaning photos, payment confirmations, or specific data.
DO NOT alarm the host with every minor issue. Reserve push notifications for action-required items; use digests for status.
DO NOT cut the host out of communication with tenants. Facilitate it through the platform, but don't block it.
elements.success_metric: Weekly digest open rate for remote hosts: above 60%. Platform bypass rate (host contacting tenants directly): below 20%. Relist rate for hosts who completed their first overseas lease: above 50%.

elements.title: Traditional Sublease Language Translation: Map Platform Terms to Host's Mental Model
elements.problem: Dimitri uses traditional sublease vocabulary: 'sublease agreement,' 'one month deposit first month,' 'current tenant.' Split Lease introduces new concepts: 'custom rental agreement,' 'supplemental agreement,' 'guests,' 'proposals.' Each unfamiliar term creates a micro-friction that accumulates into skepticism. When Bryant mentions 'custom rental agreement' (3:41), Dimitri responds with confusion ('well, I've never usually dealt directly...'). Chen's Tipping Point framework shows that adoption barriers at the individual level prevent atomic networks from forming.
elements.solution: Map every platform term to its traditional sublease equivalent, and use the host's vocabulary first. (1) 'Guest' should be introduced as 'tenant' first, then parenthetically as 'we call them guests on the platform.' (2) 'Proposal' should map to 'sublease interest' or 'rental application.' (3) The 'custom rental agreement' should be framed as 'your standard sublease, plus a payment guarantee from Split Lease.' (4) In the UI, use the host's vocabulary in primary text and the platform's vocabulary only in secondary/system text. (5) Never assume the host knows platform jargon. If Dimitri says 'sublease agreement,' the UI should echo 'sublease agreement,' not correct it to 'lease.'

evidence.quote: Standard sublease agreement... So split lease the company that I'm with, we have a custom rental agreement.
evidence.insight: Dimitri says 'standard sublease agreement.' Bryant introduces 'custom rental agreement' and 'supplemental agreement.' Two new terms in one breath. This is the vocabulary gap that causes cognitive friction.

evidence.quote: LinkedIn used personal invitations... making the new product feel familiar, not foreign.
evidence.insight: Invitation mechanics work by reducing foreignness. The same principle applies to vocabulary: use the host's existing terms to make the platform feel like an extension of what they already know.

elements.user_goal: Understand what I'm agreeing to in my own terms, without learning a new vocabulary.
elements.company_goal: Reduce evaluation-to-onboarding dropout caused by vocabulary mismatch. Accelerate deal completion by eliminating 'what does this mean?' moments.
elements.time_budget: Zero additional time. Language translation should be invisible  the host should never notice they're learning platform terms.
anti_goals: DO NOT correct the host's vocabulary. If they say 'tenant,' the platform says 'tenant.'
DO NOT introduce platform-specific terms without mapping them to familiar equivalents first.
DO NOT use legal jargon in the UI. 'Custom rental agreement' is legal language. 'Your sublease, guaranteed by Split Lease' is human language.
DO NOT assume the host cares about the distinction between 'proposal' and 'application.' They care about: who wants my apartment, and are they reliable.
elements.success_metric: Support tickets containing 'what does X mean' or 'I don't understand' for new hosts: target below 5% of total interactions. Time spent on agreement review screens: decrease by 30% with translated language.

elements.title: Match-First Information Hierarchy for Hard-Side Recruitment
elements.problem: The current listing creation flow presents empty forms before showing demand. For hard-side hosts like Dimitri who were recruited by agents with a specific match, this inverts the information hierarchy. Dimitri's motivation is not 'I want to list my apartment'  it's 'I want to see if Ariel and Amber are right for my apartment.' The information architecture must lead with what the host cares about (the match) and follow with what the platform needs (the listing).
elements.solution: Restructure the first-time host experience to lead with the specific match. Scan order: (1) Guest profiles with names, verification status, and interest details, (2) The host's property as the agent described it (pre-filled), (3) What the host needs to do to make this deal happen (minimal steps). This is a demand-led information architecture: show the value first, collect the input second.

evidence.quote: We matched Ariel and Amber as roommates. They both came to us individually looking for a space in the lower Manhattan Midtown area.
evidence.insight: Bryant leads with the match, not the platform. The first-time host page must mirror this: Ariel and Amber's profiles first, listing wizard second.

evidence.quote: Come for the Tool, Stay for the Network.
evidence.insight: The 'tool' is the specific match. The information hierarchy must present the tool before asking the host to invest in the network.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: guest match (who wants your space). Secondary: property details (pre-filled from agent notes). Tertiary: platform mechanics (agreements, payment structure). The host's eyes must land on human faces and names before any form field.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Progressive: Show guest summary first (name, photo, dates, verification badge). Expand to full verification details on tap. Property details shown as a confirmation screen (pre-filled), not a creation wizard.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Maximum 3 information elements on the first screen: guest name/photo, dates they need, verification status. All other details are expandable.
scan_order: Guest profiles (Ariel and Amber)
Their requested dates (July-September)
Verification badges (credit check, references)
Your property summary (pre-filled)
Next step button
exclude: Platform introduction/marketing copy
Generic 'how it works' sections
Pricing calculator (show after property confirmation)
Feature comparison tables

elements.title: Dual-Track Verification Display: Platform Evidence + Personal Access
elements.problem: Dimitri needs two types of verification information simultaneously: (1) what Split Lease has verified (credit check, references, ID), and (2) personal documents he can review himself (driver's license, contact info). Current marketplace patterns show only platform verification badges ('Verified') without exposing the underlying data. For a host who 'usually doesn't deal with third parties,' a badge is insufficient  he needs the evidence.
elements.solution: Create a two-column verification display: Left column shows Split Lease's institutional verification (with methodology). Right column shows the guest's personal documents accessible to the host (with privacy-appropriate redaction). Both columns visible simultaneously, not in separate tabs.

evidence.quote: Still have their information, their driver's license, because you never know.
evidence.insight: Dimitri explicitly requires personal document access. A 'Verified' badge without the underlying document is not enough.

evidence.quote: The hard side of the network is the small percentage of people that typically end up doing most of the work within the community.
evidence.insight: Hard-side users demand more information because they bear more risk. The information architecture must accommodate this asymmetric risk profile.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: verification summary (all checks passed/pending). Secondary: specific check results with evidence (credit score range, reference quotes, ID match). Tertiary: raw documents for host review (redacted as needed).
elements.disclosure_pattern: Layer 1: Badge strip (Verified, Verified, Verified). Layer 2: Expandable rows showing each check with detail. Layer 3: Document viewer for personal review. Host can go as deep as they want without leaving the page.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Badge strip: 3-5 items max. Expanded view: one check at a time. Document viewer: one document at a time with zoom.
scan_order: Verification badge strip (all green = proceed)
Any amber/pending items (action required)
Specific check the host cares most about (credit/references)
Personal documents on demand
exclude: Platform marketing about verification process
Legal disclaimers (move to a dedicated section)
Verification methodology details (available on expand, not default)

elements.title: Remote Host Status Architecture: Push-First, Digest-Based
elements.problem: Dimitri will manage his apartment from Europe across timezones. A pull-based information architecture (host logs in to check status) fails for two reasons: (1) timezone differences make real-time checking impractical, and (2) absence of updates is indistinguishable from absence of monitoring. The host needs pushed information that proves the platform is watching even when the host is not.
elements.solution: Design a push-first status architecture: (1) Weekly digest email/notification summarizing everything the host needs to know (rent status, cleaning photos, upcoming guest schedule, issues). (2) Real-time push notifications only for action-required items (lease issue, payment failure). (3) In-app dashboard designed for 10-second timezone-shifted check-ins: status headline first, details below fold. (4) The digest should be a complete snapshot  the host should never need to open the app to understand their property's status.

evidence.quote: I will be in Europe, actually for work.
evidence.insight: 6+ hour timezone difference means the host checks status at off-peak hours. The information must be self-contained in whatever format they check (email, notification, app).

evidence.quote: The Engagement Effect describes the increase in engagement that happens as the network grows.
evidence.insight: For a remote host, the engagement loop is: receive digest -> scan status -> feel reassured -> continue using platform. If the digest stops or becomes uninformative, the loop breaks.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: property status headline ('All good' or 'Action needed'). Secondary: this week's events (rent received, cleaning photos, guest schedule). Tertiary: cumulative metrics (total income, stays completed, ratings).
elements.disclosure_pattern: Email digest: full status in body (no 'click to see more' for critical info). Push notification: one-line status. App dashboard: headline + expandable sections. Each channel must be independently complete.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Weekly digest: scannable in 30 seconds. Maximum 5 status items. If nothing happened that week, the digest says 'Quiet week  everything is on track' with one evidence point (rent confirmed, cleaning photos received).
scan_order: Status headline (green/amber/red)
This week's key event (rent, guest arrival, cleaning)
Next week's schedule
Income summary (if check-in day is near payment)
exclude: Marketing messages in status digests
Feature announcements
Requests for reviews or feedback (separate communication)
Any content not directly related to property status

elements.title: Agreement Translation Architecture: Sublease Terms in Host's Language
elements.problem: Bryant introduces three agreement concepts in 22 seconds: 'custom rental agreement,' 'agreement between yourself and the guests,' and 'supplemental agreement between split lease and the landlord.' Dimitri processes this as a wall of unfamiliar terms overlaid on his known model ('standard sublease agreement'). The information architecture must present these agreements in a structure that maps to the host's existing mental model, not the platform's legal structure.
elements.solution: Present agreements as a visual mapping: 'What you know' (left) -> 'What we add' (right). (1) Start with the host's familiar frame: 'Your standard sublease agreement.' (2) Show what Split Lease adds as a transparent layer: payment guarantee, guest vetting, 24/7 support. (3) The legal documents themselves are presented only after the host understands the conceptual structure. (4) Use visual hierarchy to distinguish between 'your agreement with the guest' (primary, in host's language) and 'Split Lease's guarantee to you' (secondary, as added value).

evidence.quote: Standard sublease agreement... we have a custom rental agreement... supplemental agreement between split lease and us, the landlord.
evidence.insight: Three new concepts introduced in rapid succession. The host's response ('obviously, well, I've never usually dealt directly') shows cognitive overload.

evidence.quote: Making the new product feel familiar, not foreign.
evidence.insight: Agreements should feel like a familiar sublease with extra protection, not a foreign contract with new obligations.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Primary: 'Your sublease, guaranteed by Split Lease' (one-line summary). Secondary: What's the same (standard sublease terms). Tertiary: What's different (payment guarantee, vetting process). The host reads the familiar before the novel.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Summary -> Side-by-side comparison -> Full agreement text. The host can accept after the summary if they trust the agent; they can drill into full text if they want detail.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Summary screen: under 50 words. Comparison view: maximum 5 rows (what's same vs. what's added). Full agreement: standard legal text with section headers that use sublease vocabulary.
scan_order: One-line summary ('Your sublease + our guarantee')
What stays the same (deposit, monthly rent, rules)
What Split Lease adds (payment guarantee, vetting, support)
Full agreement (on expand)
exclude: Legal jargon in the summary view
References to 'supplemental agreement' as a primary concept
Fee structure details before the host understands the agreement structure
Comparison to other platforms

elements.title: Human-First Visual Treatment for Agent-Recruited Hosts
elements.problem: Agent-recruited hosts like Dimitri arrive at the platform expecting a continuation of a human conversation, not a corporate SaaS interface. If the first visual impression is a generic marketplace with stock photos and marketing copy, it triggers the same 'third party' distrust that Dimitri expressed on the call. The visual design must feel personal and specific, not institutional and generic.
elements.solution: Use human-scale visual elements: agent photos, guest avatars, property thumbnails. Minimize abstract branding elements (logos, hero sections, feature grids) in favor of concrete, person-specific content. The visual hierarchy should prioritize faces > places > actions > text. Typography should feel like a well-designed email from Bryant, not a marketplace landing page.

evidence.quote: I usually don't deal with third parties.
evidence.insight: The visual design must NOT look like a third party. It must look like Bryant's personal tool for managing Dimitri's sublease.

evidence.quote: LinkedIn sent personal emails... the product felt like an extension of your professional network, not a new website.
evidence.insight: Invite-only products succeed by looking personal, not institutional. The visual design for agent-recruited hosts should feel invited, not marketed-to.

typography: Inter 600 for names and property titles
Inter 400 for body text and descriptions
DM Sans 500 for agent name attribution
new_tokens_needed: --surface-personal: a warm off-white tint (rgb(252, 250, 255)) specifically for agent-mediated content cards to distinguish them from platform-generated content

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA minimum. Agent names and guest names must use --text-dark (#1a1a1a) on light backgrounds for maximum readability. Verification badges must maintain 4.5:1 contrast ratio.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Faces and names are always Tier 1 (largest, darkest, first position). Property details are Tier 2. Platform mechanics are Tier 3 (smallest, lightest). No page should have platform branding as Tier 1.
elements.brand_alignment: Taste model: 'Warm, not cold. Soft backgrounds, not stark white. Trustworthy, not corporate.' Agent-mediated pages should use warmer backgrounds (off-white with purple tint) rather than stark white to create a personal, letter-like quality.

elements.title: Verification Evidence Visual Language: Show, Don't Badge
elements.problem: Platform verification badges ('Verified' with a checkmark) are a visual shorthand that assumes trust in the verifying institution. Dimitri doesn't trust the institution yet. A green checkmark next to 'Credit Check: Passed' tells Dimitri nothing he can independently verify. The visual language must show evidence, not just results.
elements.solution: Replace abstract verification badges with evidence-forward visual treatments. (1) Show the verification tier (credit score range, not just 'passed'). (2) Use document thumbnails for personal verification (redacted driver's license preview). (3) Reference quotes from landlord references, styled as testimonials. (4) The visual treatment should resemble a professional background check report, not a marketplace trust badge.

evidence.quote: Their driver's license, because you never know.
evidence.insight: Dimitri wants to see the document, not a badge saying the document was checked. Visual design must show evidence, not abstractions.

evidence.quote: Solve a hard problem so important that they are willing to join.
evidence.insight: The visual representation of verification IS the hard problem solution. If it looks convincing, the host joins. If it looks like marketing, they don't.

typography: Inter 600 for verification item labels
Inter 400 for evidence details
IBM Plex Mono 500 for data-backed values (credit score ranges, reference counts)

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA. Verification status text must be readable without color alone (use icons + text labels). Document preview thumbnails must have visible borders to distinguish from surrounding content.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Evidence > Badge > Methodology. The host sees the evidence first (document thumbnail, reference quote), the badge second (Verified), the methodology third (how we verified, on expand).
elements.brand_alignment: Taste model: 'Mono for data/trust (prices, stats, badges). IBM Plex Mono signals precision and reliability.' Verification data should use monospace for credit scores, reference counts, and date stamps to signal factual precision.

elements.title: Timezone-Aware Status Card for Remote Hosts
elements.problem: A remote host checking their property status from a different timezone at 11 PM local time needs a visual design optimized for quick scanning under fatigue. Current dashboard patterns use equal visual weight for all status items. A remote host needs a single dominant visual element (status: OK or NOT OK) with supporting details available but not competing for attention.
elements.solution: Use a single-headline status card with color-coded background: (1) Green-tinted background = everything is fine, scan complete in 3 seconds. (2) Amber-tinted background = something needs attention, details below. (3) Red-tinted background = action required now. The headline should be the only thing the host reads when checking from their phone in bed in Paris. Details are collapsed by default.

evidence.quote: I will be in Europe, actually for work.
evidence.insight: Europe = 6-9 hour timezone shift. Host will check status at night, before bed. Visual design must work for fatigued, timezone-shifted scanning.

evidence.quote: The Engagement Effect describes the increase in engagement as the network grows.
evidence.insight: The status card IS the engagement loop for remote hosts. If it's too complex to scan, the host stops opening the app and engagement dies.

typography: Inter 700 at 20px for status headline
Inter 400 at 13px for detail text
IBM Plex Mono 500 at 14px for dates and amounts
new_tokens_needed: --status-ok-bg: a very subtle green-purple tint for 'all clear' status cards
--status-attention-bg: a warm amber tint for 'needs attention' cards

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA. Status headline must be readable in dark mode AND light mode (remote hosts may check at night with dark mode). Background color tints must be subtle enough to not alarm but distinct enough to differentiate status levels.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Single headline > evidence thumbnail (cleaning photo or payment confirmation) > detail list. The headline alone must convey the full status. Everything else is supplementary.
elements.brand_alignment: Taste model: 'Confident, not flashy. The product speaks through clarity, not decoration.' Status cards must be devoid of decoration  no illustrations, no icons for the sake of icons. The headline IS the design.

elements.title: Urgency-Aware Timeline Visual for Deal Progression
elements.problem: Dimitri's 'within next week' deadline creates urgency that the platform must visually acknowledge. If the deal progression looks open-ended (no dates, no timeline, no countdown), it conflicts with the host's sense of urgency. Conversely, if it looks like a pressure tactic (countdown timers, red urgency badges), it triggers the 'third party' distrust.
elements.solution: Use a gentle timeline visual that shows deal progression with dates. (1) Horizontal or vertical progress line showing: agent call (completed) -> host review (current) -> guest confirmation (next) -> deal signed (end). (2) Dates on each step, including the host's stated deadline as a soft reference point. (3) No countdown timers or red urgency. Instead, use proximity language: 'Ariel is ready  review when you have a moment.' The urgency is in the specificity (real dates, real names), not in the visual treatment.

evidence.quote: Ideally I want to like take care of things within next week.
evidence.insight: The host has a deadline. The visual must acknowledge it without pressuring.

evidence.quote: If there aren't enough users on a social network and no one to interact with, everyone will leave.
evidence.insight: The timeline visual communicates that the other side (guests) is actively engaged. This counters the anti-network effect of a silent, empty platform.

typography: Inter 600 at 14px for step labels
Inter 400 at 12px for dates and descriptions

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA. Completed vs. pending steps must be distinguishable by color AND shape (filled dot vs. outlined dot) for accessibility.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Current step is visually dominant (larger dot, bolder text, active color). Completed steps are visible but recessive. Upcoming steps are lightest. The host's eye should land on 'what's happening now' first.
elements.brand_alignment: Taste model: 'Premium-accessible. Feels high quality without feeling exclusive.' The timeline should look like a high-end project tracker, not a cheap progress bar. Generous spacing, refined typography, no animation gimmicks.

elements.title: Instant Match Presentation with Deferred Account Creation
elements.problem: The standard marketplace interaction flow is: sign up -> create profile -> browse. For agent-recruited hosts, this inverts the motivation. Dimitri was recruited to see a specific match (Ariel and Amber). Requiring account creation before showing the match introduces friction at the exact moment of peak interest. Chen's 'Magic Moment' concept shows that users must experience the product's value before they invest in the infrastructure.
elements.solution: Present the match as an interactive preview accessible via a magic link (no account required). (1) Agent sends a personalized link after the call. (2) Link opens directly to the match page: Ariel and Amber's profiles + Dimitri's pre-filled property. (3) Account creation is triggered only when the host takes an action that requires it (accept proposal, upload photos, view full documents). (4) The magic link persists for 7 days and bookmarks progress.

evidence.quote: I texted it to you. So the, that you, this is your cell phone, I'm going to text it to you.
evidence.insight: Dimitri prefers text-based communication. The magic link should arrive via text from Bryant, not from a platform email. The interaction model is: text arrives -> tap link -> see match -> decide.

evidence.quote: The Magic Moment is the first experience where users 'get' why the product is valuable.
evidence.insight: Dimitri's magic moment is seeing that two vetted tenants want his specific apartment for his specific dates. This must happen BEFORE any friction (account creation, form filling).

states.default: Magic link page showing match summary: guest profiles, property preview, agent attribution. No login wall.
states.loading: Skeleton loading with property address visible immediately (parsed from URL). Guest profiles load within 1 second.
states.empty: If the match is no longer available, show: 'This match has been filled, but Bryant has other interested guests for your space. [Contact Bryant].'
states.error: If the link is expired: 'This link has expired. [Text Bryant to get a new one].' Direct to human, not to platform signup.
states.success: After account creation: smooth transition to full match view with verification details unlocked. No page reload.

elements.transition_principle: No page transitions for account creation. Inline modal overlays the match page. After account creation, the modal dismisses and the match page enriches with additional data (verification details, messaging). The host never loses context.

timing.response_target: Match page loads within 2 seconds of tap. Account creation modal appears within 100ms of action trigger.
timing.easing: ease-out for modal appearance. No spring/bounce animations  this is a trust context, not a playful one.
timing.rationale: Dimitri is evaluating the platform's professionalism. Fast, clean transitions signal competence. Slow or playful animations signal informality.

elements.journey_state_awareness: First-time visitors via magic link see a simplified interface. Returning visitors see their progress preserved. If the host has already reviewed the match, the page shows their last action and next step.
edge_cases: Link opened on desktop vs. mobile (responsive design critical)
Link shared with someone other than the host (show 'This was prepared for Dimitri  is that you?')
Agent updates the match after link was sent (show 'Updated' badge on changed elements)
Host opens link before guests have completed their profiles (show pending profile state)

elements.title: Video Tour Scheduling Within the Platform
elements.problem: Dimitri offers to show the apartment in person or via video tour: 'I can arrange with the current tenant to either show them the apartment personally... or do a video tour, whatever works for them.' This interaction currently happens outside the platform (direct text/email). If the platform can facilitate video tours, it keeps the interaction in-platform and captures the conversion moment.
elements.solution: Embed a video tour scheduling interaction within the proposal review flow. (1) After the host reviews guest profiles, offer 'Schedule a Video Tour' as a secondary action alongside Accept/Decline. (2) The scheduler shows the host's timezone (Europe) and the guests' timezone, with overlapping availability. (3) Video tour happens via the platform (integrated video call or Zoom link). (4) After the tour, the platform prompts the host to accept or decline with the tour context fresh.

evidence.quote: I can arrange with the current tenant to either show them the apartment personally, they're New York... or do a video tour, whatever works for them.
evidence.insight: Dimitri's current solution: coordinate with his tenant to show the apartment. The platform should replace this coordination, not require it.

evidence.quote: Products need to be 'better' in a way that matters to the hard side.
evidence.insight: Scheduling a video tour across timezones is a specific problem the platform can solve better than manual text coordination.

states.default: 'Schedule Video Tour' button visible on proposal review page, styled as secondary action.
states.loading: Calendar loading with shimmer effect. Host's timezone and guest's timezone shown immediately.
states.empty: If no overlapping availability in the next 7 days: 'No times match this week. Share your availability and we'll find a slot.'
states.error: If scheduling fails: 'We'll text Bryant to coordinate manually. He'll find a time that works.'
states.success: Tour scheduled confirmation with calendar invite sent to all parties. 'You'll get a reminder 15 minutes before.'

elements.transition_principle: Video tour scheduling opens as an inline expansion below the proposal card, not a new page. After scheduling, the expansion collapses and a 'Tour scheduled: [date]' badge appears on the proposal card.

timing.response_target: Calendar loads within 1.5 seconds. Scheduling confirmation appears within 300ms of selection.
timing.easing: ease-out for expansion/collapse. No bounce.
timing.rationale: Scheduling is a logistical interaction. Fast, functional, no decorative transitions.

elements.journey_state_awareness: The video tour option appears only when the host has not yet accepted/declined the proposal. After the tour, the accept/decline buttons become more prominent (visual promotion from secondary to primary). If the host is in a different timezone than the guest, the timezone difference is highlighted.
edge_cases: Host wants to have current tenant show the apartment (add 'Invite someone else to show' option)
Guest is not available for video (offer photo walkthrough as alternative)
Host cancels tour (prompt reschedule, not immediate decline of proposal)
Technical issues with video (automatic fallback to phone call with number provided)

elements.title: Cross-Timezone Push Notification with Quiet Hours
elements.problem: Dimitri in Europe will receive notifications on NYC time. A 2 PM notification in New York is 8 PM or later in Europe. Critical updates (payment received, cleaning photos) are informational; urgent updates (lease issue, property emergency) need immediate attention. The notification system must respect the host's local timezone while ensuring urgent items are never delayed.
elements.solution: Implement timezone-aware notification queuing. (1) Non-urgent notifications (payments, cleaning photos, status updates) are queued and delivered during the host's local daytime hours (8 AM - 8 PM in their timezone). (2) Urgent notifications (property emergency, lease violation) bypass quiet hours and deliver immediately. (3) The host's weekly digest is sent at their preferred local time (default: 9 AM local). (4) The host can customize quiet hours and urgency thresholds.

evidence.quote: I will be in Europe, actually for work.
evidence.insight: 6-9 hour timezone shift. Unmanaged notifications will arrive at inappropriate local times, training the host to ignore or silence them.

evidence.quote: The Engagement Effect describes the increase in engagement that happens as the network grows.
evidence.insight: Well-timed notifications drive engagement. Poorly-timed notifications kill it. A notification that wakes a host at 3 AM in Paris has negative engagement value.

states.default: Notifications queued and delivered in local daytime window. Badge count updates silently.
states.loading: No loading state visible  notifications queue invisibly.
states.empty: If no notifications in the weekly digest: 'Quiet week at 30th Street. Everything is running smoothly.'
states.error: If notification delivery fails: retry with exponential backoff. After 3 failures, add to weekly digest as fallback.
states.success: Notification delivered with soft haptic (mobile) or subtle sound (desktop). No intrusive modals.

elements.transition_principle: Notifications appear as non-blocking toasts that auto-dismiss after 5 seconds. Urgent notifications pin to the top of the screen until acknowledged.

timing.response_target: Non-urgent: queued, delivered within local daytime window. Urgent: delivered within 30 seconds of trigger.
timing.easing: ease-in for notification appearance, ease-out for auto-dismiss.
timing.rationale: Non-urgent notifications should feel gentle and informational. Urgent notifications should feel immediate but not alarming.

elements.journey_state_awareness: The system detects the host's timezone from their last login location or device settings. If the host travels (detects timezone change), it adjusts quiet hours automatically. If the host hasn't opened the app in 14+ days, the system sends a gentle re-engagement notification with a status summary.
edge_cases: Host travels between timezones frequently (use most recent timezone, not profile timezone)
Host has multiple properties in different timezones (per-property notification settings)
Guest sends cleaning photos at 3 AM host time (queue for morning delivery)
Property emergency at 4 AM host time (deliver immediately with clear 'URGENT' label and sound)

elements.title: One-Session Deal Completion Flow
elements.problem: Dimitri wants things done 'within next week.' But the standard flow (onboard -> list -> wait for proposals -> review -> accept) spans multiple sessions and multiple days. For agent-recruited hosts with pre-matched guests, the entire flow should be completable in a single session. Chen's atomic network theory predicts that speed of first-transaction is critical: the longer the gap, the higher the probability the hard-side user defaults to alternatives.
elements.solution: Create a single-session deal completion flow for agent-recruited hosts. (1) Magic link opens to match preview (no account needed). (2) Host reviews guest profiles and property summary. (3) Account creation happens inline (email + password, 30 seconds). (4) Property details are confirmed (pre-filled from agent notes, 60 seconds). (5) Deal terms are reviewed and accepted (dates, pricing, agreement, 2 minutes). (6) Total flow: under 5 minutes from link-open to deal-signed.

evidence.quote: Within next week.
evidence.insight: One-week deadline. A one-session flow converts urgency into action. Multi-session flows lose the urgency to competing alternatives.

evidence.quote: The atomic network is the smallest possible network where there are enough people for the product to become useful.
evidence.insight: The atomic network for Dimitri (apartment + Ariel/Amber + guarantee) must form in one session. If it requires multiple sessions, the anti-network effect (Dimitri finds tenants elsewhere) takes hold.

states.default: Linear flow with progress indicator: Review Match (1/4) -> Confirm Property (2/4) -> Review Terms (3/4) -> Accept (4/4).
states.loading: Each step loads data from agent notes. Skeleton states show pre-filled field shapes so the host sees the flow's structure immediately.
states.empty: If agent notes are incomplete: 'Bryant is still preparing your details. We'll text you when everything is ready.' Do NOT show an empty form.
states.error: If any step fails: save progress, show 'Something went wrong. Bryant has been notified. You can pick up where you left off.' Include agent's direct contact.
states.success: Final step: confetti-free confirmation. 'Deal confirmed. Ariel and Amber will be notified. Bryant will send you the agreement to review.' Clean, professional.

elements.transition_principle: Slide transitions between steps (left-to-right). Back button always available. Progress bar updates with smooth fill animation. No full-page reloads between steps.

timing.response_target: Each step transition under 300ms. Form submissions under 1 second. Total flow under 5 minutes for hosts with complete agent notes.
timing.easing: ease-out for step transitions. No spring animations  professional, not playful.
timing.rationale: Speed signals competence. A 5-minute deal flow proves the platform is faster than direct dealing, which is the core value proposition for hard-side hosts.

elements.journey_state_awareness: If the host leaves mid-flow, they can return via the same magic link and pick up at their last step. Progress is preserved for 7 days. If the host hasn't completed the flow in 48 hours, Bryant gets a notification to follow up.
edge_cases: Host wants to review the agreement before accepting (expand inline, don't navigate away)
Host wants to counter the proposed terms (inline term editor at step 3)
Host's current tenant hasn't moved out yet (show estimated availability, allow provisional acceptance)
Host wants to add another property to the same deal (defer, offer after first deal completes)

elements.title: Earned Skepticism Respect: Treat Third-Party Distrust as Reasonable, Not Resistant
elements.problem: Dimitri's third-party skepticism ('I usually don't deal with third parties') is often treated by platforms as a conversion barrier to overcome. But from the host's perspective, this skepticism is earned  after 8 years of managing his own sublease process, he has a system that works. The emotional error is treating his skepticism as resistance rather than intelligence. If the platform tries to overcome his skepticism with persuasion, it confirms his worry. If it respects his skepticism by giving him MORE information and control, it earns his trust.
elements.solution: Design the emotional arc to validate the host's skepticism explicitly. (1) Language should acknowledge: 'You've been managing your apartment for 8 years. You know what works.' (2) The platform positions itself as additive, not replacing: 'Here's everything you'd normally check, plus our additional verification.' (3) Control is never taken away  the host can always revert to direct dealing with the agent as backup. (4) The emotional goal is not 'trust us' but 'verify us, and decide for yourself.'

evidence.quote: I usually don't deal with third parties.
evidence.insight: This is not a complaint  it's a value statement. Dimitri values direct control. The platform must honor this value, not circumvent it.

evidence.quote: The hard side of the network is the small percentage that typically end up doing most of the work within the community.
evidence.insight: Hard-side users have earned their skepticism through experience. They've seen platforms come and go. Emotional respect for this experience is the price of admission.

elements.emotion_rationale: A host who has managed his own sublease process for 8 years needs to feel that the platform makes him SAFER, not less in control.

do: Acknowledge the host's existing expertise
Use language that positions the platform as the host's tool
Provide verifiable evidence, not promises
Say 'verify for yourself' not 'trust us'
dont: Use persuasive sales language ('Join thousands of hosts!')
Minimize the host's concerns ('Don't worry, we handle everything')
Use urgency as a manipulation tactic
Suggest the host doesn't know what they're doing
copy_guidelines.example_good: You've managed your space at 30th Street for 8 years. Here's what we found when we vetted Ariel and Amber  review it yourself.
copy_guidelines.example_bad: Don't worry about tenant screening! Our rigorous vetting process ensures only the best guests. Join Split Lease today!

animation_feel.feel_description: Solid and grounded. Information appears calmly, not enthusiastically. No celebration animations, no confetti, no exclamation points.
animation_feel.duration_range: 150-300ms for transitions. Nothing slower than 300ms  snappy signals competence.

tension_relief.tension_point: Host sees a platform insert itself between them and their tenant. 'Who are these people and why should I let them manage my apartment?'
tension_relief.relief_point: Host sees their specific apartment details (from the call), their agent's name and photo, and complete verification data for the specific tenants. 'Oh, Bryant set this up. And I can see everything.'
tension_relief.timing: Relief must come within 10 seconds of the first platform touchpoint. If the host has to search for the relief, the tension hardens into rejection.

personalization_signals: Agent name (Bryant) prominently displayed
Property address from the call (30th St between 8th and 9th)
Guest names (Ariel and Amber) from the call
Travel dates mentioned in the call (July-September)

anti_patterns.pattern: Generic trust badges without evidence
anti_patterns.reason: A 'Verified' badge from an untrusted platform carries zero weight. It's the platform verifying itself.
anti_patterns.example_bad: Showing 'Ariel: Verified' with a green checkmark but no underlying evidence.

anti_patterns.pattern: Removing the host's ability to contact guests directly
anti_patterns.reason: If the platform walls off direct communication, it confirms the 'third party controlling things' fear.
anti_patterns.example_bad: 'For your safety, all communication goes through Split Lease.' Dimitri hears: 'We're keeping you away from your own tenants.'

elements.title: Overseas Peace of Mind: Proactive Reassurance Without Alarming
elements.problem: Dimitri will be 5,000 miles from his 8-year home while strangers live in it. The default emotional state is anxiety. The platform can either feed this anxiety (too many notifications, alarming language) or relieve it (proactive evidence that everything is fine). The emotional design challenge is to communicate 'we're watching' without communicating 'there's something to watch out for.'
elements.solution: Design the active lease experience around proactive evidence of normalcy. (1) Weekly digests lead with 'Everything is fine at 30th Street'  not 'Here are your updates.' The framing is reassurance-first, details-second. (2) Cleaning photos are presented as evidence of care, not surveillance output. (3) Payment confirmations include the running total ('You've earned $X of $Y this summer') to transform anxiety into satisfaction. (4) The tone is 'your apartment is in good hands' not 'we're monitoring your tenants.'

evidence.quote: I've been there eight years.
evidence.insight: 8-year emotional attachment means every week of the overseas lease carries background anxiety. The platform must proactively address this without the host having to ask.

evidence.quote: The Engagement Effect describes the increase in engagement as the network grows.
evidence.insight: Positive emotional engagement (reassurance) drives retention. Negative emotional engagement (anxiety-driven checking) drives churn.

elements.emotion_rationale: An overseas host's default state is worry. The platform must shift the default to calm through evidence, not assertion.

do: Lead with the positive ('Rent received, everything is on track')
Attach evidence (cleaning photo thumbnail, payment amount)
Use the property address as a grounding detail ('30th Street is quiet this week')
Show cumulative progress ('You've earned $4,200 of your summer goal')
dont: Use alarm language for routine events ('ALERT: Guest checked out')
Send notifications without content ('You have an update. Click to view.')
Use surveillance language ('Guest activity report')
Neglect to send updates when everything is fine (silence = anxiety for remote hosts)
copy_guidelines.example_good: All good at 30th Street this week. Ariel's cleaning photos look great. $1,400 deposited. You've earned 46% of your summer income.
copy_guidelines.example_bad: Alert: Guest checkout detected. View cleaning verification status.

animation_feel.feel_description: Calming, like watching a loading bar that's already complete. Status cards should appear as though they've been quietly waiting, not urgently arriving.
animation_feel.duration_range: 200-400ms. Slightly slower than transactional screens to convey 'no rush, everything is fine.'

tension_relief.tension_point: It's Wednesday in Paris and the host hasn't heard anything about this week's stay. Are the tenants still there? Did they pay?
tension_relief.relief_point: Weekly digest arrives at 9 AM Paris time: 'Week 4 of 12 at 30th Street. Ariel arrived Monday, everything is running smoothly. Cleaning photos from last week look great.'
tension_relief.timing: Weekly  the digest is the primary tension-relief mechanism. If the host needs to check before the digest, the app dashboard shows the same information immediately.

personalization_signals: Property address (30th Street)
Guest names (Ariel and Amber)
Specific week number ('Week 4 of 12')
Cumulative income vs. summer goal
Host's timezone-appropriate delivery time

anti_patterns.pattern: Sending 'all clear' notifications that look like alerts
anti_patterns.reason: A notification that makes the host's phone buzz should not be 'Everything is fine.' Save buzzes for action-required items.
anti_patterns.example_bad: Push notification: 'Update: No issues this week at your property.' This trains the host to associate platform notifications with anxiety.

elements.title: Time-Respecting Urgency: Honor the Host's Deadline Without Pressure
elements.problem: Dimitri says 'within next week' and 'as soon as possible.' This urgency is real but fragile  if the platform converts it into pressure tactics (countdown timers, 'Act now!' copy), it triggers the third-party manipulation fear. The emotional challenge is to move fast without looking like you're selling fast.
elements.solution: Match the host's urgency with responsiveness, not pressure. (1) Every response to Dimitri should come fast (hours, not days) to signal 'we respect your timeline.' (2) Never use artificial urgency ('This match expires in 24 hours!'). Instead, use natural urgency: 'Ariel is also looking at another option this week. Let Bryant know when you'd like to connect.' (3) The platform's speed should speak for itself: if the listing is pre-filled, the agreement is ready to review, and the guests have already been vetted, the host feels 'this platform moves at my pace' rather than 'this platform is rushing me.'

evidence.quote: Ideally I want to like take care of things within next week.
evidence.insight: The urgency is the host's, not the platform's. The platform should serve the urgency, not create it.

evidence.quote: Uber's Ops teams individually recruited drivers with lightning-fast responses.
evidence.insight: Speed of response is the expression of urgency, not marketing language. If the platform is fast, the host feels urgency is respected. If the platform sends 'hurry up' messages, the host feels manipulated.

elements.emotion_rationale: The host wants to feel 'things are moving' not 'I'm being pushed.' Momentum comes from visible progress, not from pressure.

do: Show visible progress ('Your listing is 80% complete from your call with Bryant')
Provide specific timelines ('Ariel usually responds within 24 hours')
Offer the host initiative ('Review when you're ready  we're all set on our end')
Reference the host's own deadline respectfully ('You mentioned wanting to move quickly')
dont: Use countdown timers or expiration language
Create false scarcity ('Only 2 guests available!')
Send 'reminder' emails more than once per action item
Imply the host is slow if they haven't acted yet
copy_guidelines.example_good: Everything's ready for you to review  Ariel and Amber's profiles, your pre-filled listing, and the agreement. Take a look when you have 5 minutes.
copy_guidelines.example_bad: Hurry! Ariel and Amber won't wait forever. Complete your listing now before they find another space!

animation_feel.feel_description: Snappy and efficient. Interactions complete quickly, conveying 'we're not wasting your time.' Think of a well-oiled professional tool, not an eager salesperson.
animation_feel.duration_range: 100-200ms. Faster than the standard 200-300ms to convey efficiency.

tension_relief.tension_point: Host submits their interest but doesn't know when the guests will respond. Clock is ticking on his alternative options.
tension_relief.relief_point: Real-time status: 'Ariel viewed your listing 2 hours ago. Amber is reviewing now. Expected response: tonight.'
tension_relief.timing: Within 4 hours of host action. If the guest hasn't responded in 24 hours, Bryant follows up manually and the host gets a personal update.

personalization_signals: Reference to the host's stated timeline ('You mentioned next week')
Real-time guest activity ('Ariel viewed your listing')
Agent responsiveness ('Bryant has been notified')
Pre-filled data as evidence of speed ('We captured everything from your call')

anti_patterns.pattern: Countdown timers on match pages
anti_patterns.reason: Countdown timers are sales manipulation tactics. They signal 'we're trying to pressure you,' which directly triggers Dimitri's third-party distrust.
anti_patterns.example_bad: This match expires in 47:23:15. Accept now to secure your guests!

elements.name: Host-Sees-Guest-Perspective Card
elements.description: A cross-journey card that shows the host what the guest sees about their listing and property. Includes the guest's view of the listing photos, the cleaning protocol, and the house manual. Allows the host to preview the guest experience from their own dashboard, building empathy and reducing anxiety about what guests are being shown. Fills the 'cross-journey elements' gap  host seeing guest's perspective.
elements.fills_gap: Cross-journey elements  host seeing guest's perspective
elements.html_css:

elements.behavioral_notes: Tabs switch views between Listing, House Manual, and Reviews perspectives. 'Visible/Partial/Hidden' badges show exactly what guests can see at each stage. The 'Edit' link takes the host to the relevant section. This card evolves ds-ui-1000-003 (status-first dashboard) by adding a perspective-switching dimension, combines ds-ui-0801-004 (Stays Manager) guest-facing data with the host view, and extends ds-ui-0800-002 (Protection Shield) by showing the guest-facing version of verification.
elements.emotional_intent: Control and transparency. The host should feel 'I know exactly what my tenants are seeing about my apartment, and I can change anything I don't like.' This directly addresses Dimitri's third-party skepticism by making the platform transparent.
elements.test_criteria: 70%+ of hosts who view this card report feeling 'in control' of their listing presentation. 25%+ of hosts edit their listing after seeing the guest perspective. Time spent on the card: under 30 seconds.

elements.name: Micro-Review Prompt Card
elements.description: A one-tap micro-review card that appears on the host dashboard after each guest stay. Instead of a traditional post-lease review, this captures a quick thumbs-up/thumbs-down plus one optional sentence after EACH stay. Over a 12-week lease, this accumulates 12 micro-reviews into a temporal narrative. Fills the 'review/rating UI' gap. Compounds on the space care photo streak concept from ds-ui-1001-005 by applying the same habit-loop principle to reviews.
elements.fills_gap: Review/rating UI  no micro-review or rating elements exist yet
elements.html_css:
A

How was Ariel's stay?

Stay #4 of 12 · Checked out Thursday

Quick check: how did this week go at 30th Street?
3 of 12 stays reviewed
elements.behavioral_notes: Appears on the host dashboard within 24 hours of guest checkout. One-tap response (thumbs up or 'something to note'). Optional text field for details. The streak dots (3/12 stays reviewed) create the same habit-loop as ds-ui-1001-005's space care streak. Over time, 12 micro-reviews create a temporal narrative more valuable than a single post-lease review. For remote hosts like Dimitri, this is the weekly engagement touchpoint from Europe.
elements.emotional_intent: Low-effort engagement. The host should feel 'this takes 5 seconds and helps me track how things are going from overseas.' The streak visual provides accumulating evidence of a successful lease.
elements.test_criteria: Micro-review completion rate above 70% per stay. Average time to complete under 15 seconds. Hosts who micro-review show 30%+ higher retention than those who don't.

elements.name: In-Platform Chat Thread with Agent Context
elements.description: A messaging thread between host and guest with the agent (Bryant) as a visible third participant. Messages from the agent are visually distinguished. The host can toggle between 'direct to guest' and 'through agent' messaging modes. Fills the 'messaging/communication UI' gap. Compounds on the agent trust bridge concept by making the agent present in digital communication, not just initial onboarding.
elements.fills_gap: Messaging/communication UI  no in-platform chat elements
elements.html_css:
D
A
B
30th Street Lease
Dimitri, Ariel · Bryant (advisor)
Bryant connected you on Feb 19. All communication is logged here.
Ariel
Hi Dimitri! Thanks for considering us. The apartment looks great. Would it be possible to do a video tour this weekend?
Today, 2:14 PM

Today, 3:45 PM (Paris time)
Bryant can coordinate the video tour if you'd like. Just say the word.
elements.behavioral_notes: Three-party chat with agent as a visible but non-intrusive participant. Agent messages use dashed-border styling to distinguish from direct host-guest messages. The 'Direct/Via Bryant' toggle lets the host choose whether to message the guest directly or route through the agent. Timezone display in message timestamps helps overseas hosts. This evolves ds-ui-0800-003 (Agent Welcome Bridge) from a one-time card into a persistent communication channel, and extends ds-ui-1000-006 (Patient Follow-Up Email) from async email into real-time chat.
elements.emotional_intent: Control with backup. The host should feel 'I can talk to my tenant directly, but Bryant is right here if I need him.' This directly addresses Dimitri's 'I usually deal directly' preference while maintaining the platform's value.
elements.test_criteria: 60%+ of hosts use in-platform chat vs. off-platform communication. Agent-mediated messages resolve issues 2x faster than direct messages. Chat engagement correlates with 20%+ higher deal completion rate.

elements.name: Guest Arrival House Manual Card
elements.description: A mobile-first house manual card that appears in the guest's Stays Manager on their arrival day. Shows key move-in information: lockbox code, Wi-Fi password, house rules, emergency contacts, and neighborhood essentials. Collapsible sections with icons. The host creates this once and it's shown to every guest automatically. Fills the 'house manual / move-in checklist' gap.
elements.fills_gap: House manual / move-in checklist  no guest onboarding elements for arrival

The card is created by the host once during listing creation and auto-populated with property-specific data. This evolves ds-ui-1001-004 (This-Week Stay Card) by providing the content guests need on arrival, extends ds-ui-0801-004 (Stays Manager) by adding a 'House Manual' tab, and compounds ds-ui-1000-005 (Guest Preference Quick-Set) by using the same pre-filled-from-call pattern for property details.
elements.emotional_intent: Welcome and preparedness. The guest should feel 'I have everything I need to settle in' and the host should feel 'my guests have clear instructions without me having to text them from Europe.'
elements.test_criteria: 90%+ of guests access the house manual on their first arrival day. Support tickets about 'how do I get in' decrease by 60%. Host satisfaction with guest arrivals increases by 25%.

elements.name: Host Notification Escalation Timeline
elements.description: A notification preference panel that lets the host configure escalation levels for different event types. Three tiers: Silent (in weekly digest only), Normal (push notification during daytime), Urgent (immediate push any time). Pre-configured defaults for remote hosts with timezone detection. Fills the 'guest-side notifications' gap by also showing what notifications the guest receives. Compounds on the timezone-aware notification pattern from this run's behaves-003.
elements.fills_gap: Guest-side notifications  notification escalation exists for hosts only; this adds guest notification visibility

The 'What Ariel receives' section shows the host what their guest gets notified about  this is the cross-journey visibility that ds-ui-0802-001 provides for listing content, applied to notifications. Compounds on ds-ui-0800-005 (Auto-Renewal Notification) notification patterns, ds-ui-1000-003 (Status-First Dashboard) status architecture, and ds-ui-1000-004 (Between-Stay Status) timeline-based status.
elements.emotional_intent: Control and calm. The host should feel 'I've configured exactly how much I want to know, and I can see what my guest is being told.' This addresses Dimitri's overseas monitoring anxiety by giving him explicit control over information flow.
elements.test_criteria: 80%+ of remote hosts (timezone offset 4+ hours) configure at least one notification preference. 'Too many notifications' complaints decrease by 50%. 'Not enough updates' complaints decrease by 40%.

elements.name: Weekly Calendar Strip with Stay Visualization
elements.description: A horizontal weekly calendar strip that shows the current and next 4 weeks of the lease. Each day is a small cell colored by state: guest-present (purple fill), guest-absent (gray), exception-modified (dashed outline), today (ring highlight). Replaces the pure card-based approach with a temporal view. Fills the 'calendar/scheduling views' gap  everything in the library is card-based, no calendar.

Exception days (dashed outline) use the same visual language as ds-ui-1001-007's date modification panel and ds-ui-1001-001's flexible day indicator. elements.name: Magic Link Match Preview Page
elements.description: The first page an agent-recruited host sees when they tap the magic link from their agent's text. Shows the specific guest match, the host's pre-filled property, and a clear next step  all without requiring account creation. This is the 'magic moment' page that must convert third-party-skeptical hosts by showing specific value immediately. Compounds on the agent trust bridge, status-first dashboard, and listing import patterns.
elements.fills_gap: Cross-journey elements  the first moment where host and guest perspectives meet in one view
