elements.behavioral_notes: This page loads from a magic link sent via text by the agent. No login required. The agent bar at top establishes trust continuity from the call. Guest profiles show verification badges. Property details are pre-filled from agent call notes (mirroring ds-ui-1000-007's import confirmation pattern). The 'Review Full Profiles' button leads to an inline account creation modal (email + password only). The 'Schedule Video Tour' button is the secondary action for hosts like Dimitri who want to verify in person first. The 'No account needed to review' note addresses the third-party signup barrier.
elements.emotional_intent: Recognition and momentum. The host should feel 'Bryant set this up for me specifically. These are real people who want my specific apartment. Things are already moving.' This is the magic moment that converts skepticism into engagement.
elements.test_criteria: Magic link open rate above 70%. Match page to 'Review Full Profiles' click-through above 50%. Time from link-open to first action under 3 minutes. 40%+ of hosts complete the full flow in a single session.

elements.title: Self-Articulating UI  Every Design Decision Must Explain Itself
elements.problem: Theodore's 14-minute call consisted entirely of the agent explaining things the UI should communicate: what SplitLease is (00:24), how bids work (07:35), why you can't see the apartment first (04:17), and what the 40% discount requires (12:43). The UI currently relies on human agents to 'articulate its design decisions'  the very failure Greever's book identifies as the #1 reason designs fail to get support. Every screen has information but lacks rationale.
elements.solution: Every critical UI element must include its own 'why'  not just what it shows, but why it works this way. Implement 'articulation microcopy' at every decision point: (1) Next to the 24-hour inspection model, show 'Why do we do this? Same reason Airbnb doesn't show apartments before booking  but we give you 24 hours and a full refund.' (2) Next to the bid submission, show 'This tells us you're interested and your budget  we'll match you with hosts whose schedule complements yours.' (3) On discovery, show 'Not Airbnb. Not a lease. The affordable middle: 6+ week stays, split by days of the week, at 40-60% less than short-term rentals.' The pattern: information + articulation = understanding.

evidence.quote: Now I am confused.
evidence.insight: Confusion at the most basic level  guest doesn't know if he's a host or a guest. The UI fails to articulate what SplitLease even IS.

evidence.quote: The difference between a good designer and a great designer is the ability to not only solve the problem, but to also articulate how the design solves it in a way that is compelling.
evidence.insight: Greever's core principle applied to product UI: every screen must not just function but articulate WHY it functions this way.

evidence.quote: When you rent your apartment over Airbnb, does anybody come to see your apartment? That's true. That's fair. That's a good point.
evidence.insight: The agent's reframing technique (compare to familiar model) instantly resolved the guest's critical objection. This reframing must be embedded in the UI.

elements.user_goal: Understand what I'm signing up for without needing to call someone  every step should explain its own purpose.
elements.company_goal: Reduce agent dependency for basic platform comprehension, enabling self-service discovery and reducing CAC per guest.
elements.time_budget: 3 seconds to scan the articulation microcopy next to any decision point. If it takes longer, it's too much text.
anti_goals: DO NOT add long explanatory paragraphs  use micro-articulations (1-2 sentences max)
DO NOT use industry jargon ('periodic tenancy', 'occupancy tax exemption')  use conversational reframing like the agent does
DO NOT make articulations dismissible/hidden behind 'learn more' links  they must be visible at the decision moment
elements.success_metric: Reduction in agent calls that cover topics the UI should explain. Target: 50% fewer 'how does this work?' calls within 90 days of implementation.

elements.title: Reframing Over Explaining  Use Familiar Mental Models to Overcome Objections
elements.problem: Theodore's biggest objection was not seeing the apartment before signing (04:07-04:20). The agent didn't explain the policy  he REFRAMED it by comparing to Airbnb ('does anybody come to see your Airbnb apartment?'). Theodore instantly conceded: 'That's true. That's fair. That's a good point.' (04:50). The UI currently explains policies but doesn't reframe them. Explaining says 'here's how it works.' Reframing says 'it works like something you already trust.'
elements.solution: At every point where the guest encounters an unfamiliar process, provide a reframing comparison to a familiar service. (1) 24-hour inspection  'Like Airbnb, but with a 24-hour satisfaction guarantee and full refund option.' (2) Bid/proposal system  'Think of it like making an offer on a rental  you tell us what works for you, we find the match.' (3) Split scheduling  'Like a gym membership  you have your days, someone else has theirs.' (4) Agent matching  'Like a recruiter finding your ideal apartment  but you never pay a broker fee.' The pattern: anchor on the familiar, then differentiate.

evidence.quote: When you rent your apartment over Airbnb, does anybody come to see your apartment? That's true. That's fair.
evidence.insight: Reframing resolved a critical objection in 5 seconds. Explanation would have taken minutes and may not have worked at all.

evidence.quote: A UX Strategy for Responding... Tactics Are Actions.
evidence.insight: Greever identifies that effective responses to stakeholder objections are tactical, not informational. Reframing is a tactic; explaining is just information.

elements.user_goal: Feel like I already understand how this works because it's like something I've used before.
elements.company_goal: Reduce objection-based dropouts at critical conversion points (listing evaluation, acceptance) by pre-emptively reframing unfamiliar processes.
elements.time_budget: 2 seconds to read the reframe. One sentence max.
anti_goals: DO NOT use the comparison to imply SplitLease is just like Airbnb  the reframe must highlight the DIFFERENCE (better protection, lower price)
DO NOT reframe everything  only the 3-4 biggest objection points identified from call analysis
DO NOT use negative comparisons ('unlike Craigslist, we actually verify hosts')  keep it positive
elements.success_metric: Conversion rate at listing_evaluation  proposal_creation gate. Target: 15% increase when reframing microcopy is added vs. explanation-only version.

elements.title: Matching Progress Visibility  Show the Work Being Done During the Wait
elements.problem: Theodore submitted a bid and was told to wait 2-3 weeks (08:40). During this time, the platform does significant work (batched matching, schedule analysis, host outreach), but the guest sees NOTHING. Greever identifies this as a severity-CRITICAL communication gap: 'Follow up fast' and 'Do something, even if it's wrong' (Ch 9). The guest's only update mechanism is calling the agent. Meanwhile, Airbnb provides instant booking confirmation. The 2-3 week silent period is the highest-severity dropout risk in the guest journey.
elements.solution: Make the matching process visible and progressive. (1) Upon bid submission, show a matching pipeline visualization: 'Your preferences  Scanning hosts  Filtering schedules  Ranking matches  Agent review  Introduction.' (2) Send weekly progress updates: 'We reviewed 12 potential hosts this week. 3 have compatible schedules. Your agent Robert is reviewing the best options.' (3) Show partial results early: 'We found 2 strong matches for your Friday-Sunday pattern in Manhattan. Your agent will reach out by Wednesday.' (4) If no matches yet, say so honestly: 'Weekend-only patterns take slightly longer to match  we're expanding our search to adjacent neighborhoods.' The pattern: transparency about the work being done eliminates the void that causes dropout.

evidence.quote: Give us two to three weeks to complete the process... So I may get back with you even sooner, maybe next week.
evidence.insight: Theodore's relief at hearing 'sooner, maybe next week' shows that timeline visibility reduces anxiety. The UI must provide this without requiring a call.

evidence.quote: Follow Up Fast... Do Something, Even If It's Wrong.
evidence.insight: Greever's post-meeting principle applies perfectly to post-bid communication: any update is better than silence. The matching process must 'follow up fast' with progress visibility.

elements.user_goal: Know that something is happening with my request, even if there's no result yet  I need to feel like my time investment is being respected.
elements.company_goal: Reduce post-bid dropout (currently the longest silence gap in the guest journey) by maintaining engagement through the 2-3 week matching period.
elements.time_budget: 5 seconds to check matching status. The update must be scannable, not a paragraph.
anti_goals: DO NOT show fake progress  if nothing has happened, say 'Still searching' honestly
DO NOT overwhelm with technical matching details  keep updates human and outcome-focused
DO NOT make the guest feel like they're in a queue  frame it as 'personalized search in progress'
elements.success_metric: Post-bid retention at 7 days and 14 days. Target: 80% of guests who submit a bid should still have the app installed / be checking email at Day 14.

elements.title: Discount Tier Value Articulation  Make the Bargain Visible Throughout the Lease
elements.problem: Theodore signed up for the 40% discount (flexibility + cleaning), but the value of this bargain is only articulated at signup (12:07-12:55). Over 16 weeks of active lease, the guest does chores and accepts schedule flexibility without any ongoing reminder of what this effort is worth. Greever says 'managing expectations' is essential (Ch 10)  but here the expectation was set once and never reinforced. After week 4, the discount feels like an obligation rather than a bargain.
elements.solution: At every weekly stay, show the guest a running 'Value Tracker' that articulates the bargain: (1) 'This week you saved $X by keeping the space clean and being flexible with your schedule.' (2) 'Total savings to date: $X across Y weeks  that's Z% less than comparable Airbnb stays.' (3) After each cleaning photo submission, immediately show: 'Cleaning confirmed  your 40% discount is active for next week.' (4) If the guest misses a cleaning submission, show the value at risk: 'Submit your Space Care photos to keep your $X weekly savings active.' The pattern: continuous articulation of the value exchange prevents the discount from becoming invisible.

evidence.quote: For less flexibility and willing to do some chores, you get a 40% discount.
evidence.insight: Theodore eagerly accepted the trade-off when articulated clearly. This clarity must persist throughout the lease, not disappear after signup.

evidence.quote: Managing Expectations... Over, but Never Done.
evidence.insight: Greever's principle that communication is ongoing applies directly: the discount bargain must be continuously re-articulated, not set-and-forget.

elements.user_goal: See exactly how much money I'm saving each week because of my effort  make the cleaning and flexibility feel rewarding, not burdensome.
elements.company_goal: Reduce mid-lease churn by maintaining the perceived value of the discount tier. Increase cleaning compliance by linking it to visible savings.
elements.time_budget: 3 seconds to scan the weekly savings summary on the Stays Manager dashboard.
anti_goals: DO NOT make the value tracker feel like a threat ('Submit photos or lose your discount')  frame it as a reward
DO NOT compare to Airbnb prices in a way that makes the guest feel cheap  frame as 'smart savings'
DO NOT track flexibility separately from cleaning  bundle them as one 'effort' metric
elements.success_metric: Cleaning photo submission rate for discount-tier guests. Target: 90% weekly submission rate when value tracker is visible vs. current baseline without it.

elements.title: Weekend Pattern Optimization  Acknowledge and Support the Less Common Configuration
elements.problem: Theodore wants Friday-Sunday stays, which the agent acknowledged is less common and 'a little more tricky' (11:32). Most existing UI elements (day-badge selectors, match cards) are optimized for weekday patterns because most guests are hybrid workers. Weekend guests get the same generic experience with potentially fewer matches and no acknowledgment that their pattern requires different expectations. Greever's 'anticipate reactions' principle (Ch 3) means the UI should address the weekend guest's unique concerns proactively.
elements.solution: Detect weekend-dominant patterns and provide tailored experiences: (1) Show match probability feedback: 'Weekend stays have 12 available hosts in Manhattan  here are your best matches.' (2) Suggest complementary configurations: 'Add Thursday night to increase your matches by 40%.' (3) Highlight weekend-friendly hosts who specifically want weekend occupancy. (4) Adjust pricing expectations: 'Weekend nights average $X  but your 16-week commitment reduces the effective rate by Y%.' The pattern: acknowledge the guest's specific situation and provide guidance, not just generic search results.

evidence.quote: What I am concerned is your location. If you are starting seriously strict in locations, that's where things might be a little more tricky.
evidence.insight: The agent proactively set expectations about weekend matching difficulty. The UI must do the same  showing match count and suggestions for improving it.

evidence.quote: Anticipate Reactions... Create a Support Network.
evidence.insight: Anticipating the weekend guest's reaction to fewer matches (frustration, doubt) and proactively addressing it with suggestions and transparency.

elements.user_goal: Know upfront how many options exist for my specific weekend pattern, and get guidance on how to improve my chances.
elements.company_goal: Convert weekend guests who would otherwise drop off due to perceived lack of inventory, by providing guidance that expands their consideration set.
elements.time_budget: 5 seconds to see match count and optimization suggestions.
anti_goals: DO NOT tell the guest their pattern is 'uncommon' or 'difficult'  say 'We have X weekend-friendly hosts in your area'
DO NOT force pattern changes  suggest alternatives as additions, not replacements
DO NOT show empty search results without guidance  always show next-best options
elements.success_metric: Weekend-pattern guest conversion rate from search  proposal. Target: within 80% of weekday-pattern conversion rate.

elements.title: Protection Model Progressive Reveal  Build Trust Through Staged Disclosure
elements.problem: Theodore's biggest anxiety was committing without seeing the space (04:07). The agent resolved it with a 3-step explanation: (1) sign lease, (2) 24-hour inspection, (3) full refund if unsatisfied. But this protection model is buried in terms or absent from the listing page entirely. Greever's 'set the context' principle (Ch 3) says the most important information must be presented before asking for commitment.
elements.solution: Reveal the protection model progressively across phases: On listing pages, show a compact 'Protection Shield' with icons for each safeguard. On proposal confirmation, expand to show the full 3-step process. On acceptance, show a timeline of what happens next. The information architecture follows Greever's 'optimize for memory'  each phase reinforces the same 3 protections with increasing detail. Never make the guest feel unprotected at a decision point.

evidence.quote: You have no obligation for anything until you sign the lease. We hold the payment until you spend at least 24 hours.
evidence.insight: The 3-step protection model is the single most persuasive argument in the guest journey. It must be architecturally prominent.

evidence.quote: Set the Context... Optimize for Memory.
evidence.insight: Greever says critical information must be repeated in different contexts to stick. The protection model needs to appear on listings, proposals, and acceptance  each time with slightly more detail.

elements.hierarchy_principle: Protection guarantees are PRIMARY on any page that asks for financial commitment. Pricing is SECONDARY. Terms/details are TERTIARY.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Phase 1 (listing): Icon strip with 3 shields  '24h guarantee | Money held by SplitLease | Full refund option'. Phase 2 (proposal): Expandable card with each step explained in one sentence. Phase 3 (acceptance): Full timeline showing what happens from signing through 24-hour inspection.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Max 3 protection points at any given phase. No more than 15 words per point. Use icons to reduce reading load.
scan_order: Protection guarantee badges
Price/financial commitment
Action button (propose/accept)
exclude: Legal terms and conditions at the listing level
Detailed cancellation policy language until acceptance phase
Security deposit mechanics until acceptance

elements.title: Bid/Proposal Purpose Articulation  Show What Submitting Actually Does
elements.problem: Theodore asked 'What is kind of the purpose of submitting a bid? Will you let me know higher?' (07:35-07:47). He thought it was an auction. The proposal submission flow provides no articulation of what the submission does, what happens next, or what the guest should expect. This is severity-CRITICAL per Greever's framework: the guest takes the most important action in the journey without understanding it.
elements.solution: Redesign the proposal submission confirmation to answer Greever's Big Three: (1) What problem does it solve? 'Your proposal tells hosts you're interested and at what price  they can accept, counter, or pass.' (2) How does it affect you? 'You'll hear back within 5-7 days. No obligation until you both agree.' (3) Why is it better? 'Unlike bidding wars, we match you 1:1 with compatible hosts.' Show a visual pipeline: Submitted  Agent Review  Host Introduction  Your Decision.

evidence.quote: What is kind of the purpose of submitting a bid? Will you let me know higher?
evidence.insight: The guest's mental model (auction) is completely wrong. The UI must replace this mental model proactively.

evidence.quote: What problem does it solve? How does it affect the user? Why is it better than the alternative?
evidence.insight: Greever's Big Three questions are the exact framework for articulating what a proposal submission does.

elements.hierarchy_principle: What happens next is PRIMARY. What you submitted is SECONDARY. Terms/edit options are TERTIARY.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Immediately after submission: animated pipeline showing 4 steps. Current step highlighted. Expected timeline for each step. Agent name and photo if assigned.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Max 4 pipeline steps visible. Each step: icon + 4-word label + estimated time.
scan_order: Pipeline visualization (where you are now)
Expected next step and timing
What you submitted (summary)
Edit/cancel option
exclude: Internal matching algorithm details
Other guests who bid on the same listing
Host's decision criteria or competing bids

elements.title: Platform Identity Declaration  Differentiate From Short-Term Rentals in 5 Seconds
elements.problem: Theodore simultaneously submitted to SplitLease and Airbnb (00:11), indicating zero comprehension of the difference. The agent spent 2 minutes explaining the core differentiator: no short-term occupancy taxes, minimum 6 weeks, split scheduling (06:22-06:53). This is severity-CRITICAL for discovery: if the guest doesn't understand what SplitLease IS, every subsequent design decision fails. Greever's 'everyone is a designer' chapter argues that the FIRST thing a stakeholder needs is context  what are we even talking about?
elements.solution: On every discovery-phase surface (homepage, landing pages, search results header), show a 3-column comparison: 'Airbnb = Nightly stays, expensive, short-term | Traditional Lease = 12 months, locked in, no flexibility | SplitLease = 6+ weeks, your days only, 40-60% less than Airbnb.' Use icons and bold numbers, not paragraphs. The comparison must take 5 seconds to scan and answer: 'Why would I use this instead of what I already know?'

evidence.quote: I also submitted an Airbnb request.
evidence.insight: The guest sees SplitLease and Airbnb as interchangeable. The UI's first job is to break this equivalence.

evidence.quote: Set the Context... The most important thing you could ask is 'What are we trying to communicate?'
evidence.insight: The VP's question to Greever applies to SplitLease's homepage: before showing features, communicate WHAT you are and WHY you exist.

elements.hierarchy_principle: 'What is SplitLease' is PRIMARY on any discovery surface. Listings/search are SECONDARY. Company info is TERTIARY.
elements.disclosure_pattern: Landing page hero: 3-column comparison (5 seconds). Below fold: single-sentence explainer with video. Search header: persistent reminder 'Mid-term stays, your days only.'
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: Max 3 comparison columns. Max 6 words per cell. One number per column (price, duration, flexibility metric).
scan_order: 3-column comparison strip
Key differentiator in bold (40-60% less)
CTA to browse/search
exclude: Company history/founding story on discovery pages
Detailed feature lists before the guest understands the concept
Testimonials before identity is established

elements.title: Weekly Savings Dashboard  Articulate the Discount Value Continuously
elements.problem: Theodore signed up for the 40% discount tier (12:07), but once in the active lease, the UI provides no ongoing articulation of what this discount is worth in concrete terms. Greever says 'being articulate means success'  the discount must be articulated weekly, not just at signup. Without continuous value visibility, the cleaning/flexibility obligation feels like unpaid labor rather than a smart deal.
elements.solution: On the guest Stays Manager, show a persistent 'Your Savings' module: weekly savings, cumulative savings, and comparison to Airbnb equivalent. After each cleaning photo submission, animate the savings counter increasing. After each schedule flex accommodation, show 'Your flexibility saved $X this week.' The information hierarchy: savings total (PRIMARY)  this week's breakdown (SECONDARY)  Airbnb comparison (TERTIARY).

evidence.quote: For less flexibility and willing to do some chores, you get a 40% discount.
evidence.insight: The 40% figure is the anchor  but it means nothing without a dollar amount. $X saved this week is concrete; 40% is abstract.

evidence.quote: Business... Design... Research... Choose a Message.
evidence.insight: Greever says choose ONE message per communication. For the savings dashboard, the message is: 'Your effort is paying off  here's the proof.'

elements.hierarchy_principle: Cumulative savings total is PRIMARY (big number, bold). This week's savings is SECONDARY. Airbnb comparison is TERTIARY (smaller, contextual).
elements.disclosure_pattern: Default view: savings total + this week. Expand: per-week breakdown. Tap: comparison to Airbnb equivalent pricing.
elements.cognitive_load_constraint: One big number (cumulative savings). Two supporting data points (this week, vs. Airbnb). No more.
scan_order: Cumulative savings total ($X saved so far)
This week's contribution (+$X)
Airbnb comparison context
exclude: Cleaning compliance percentage as a standalone metric
Flexibility score without dollar translation
Historical graphs or charts that require interpretation

elements.title: Protection Shield Visual Language  Trust Iconography System
elements.problem: The 24-hour protection model, security deposit held by SplitLease, and refund guarantee are the most persuasive trust signals in the guest journey (Theodore's entire call turned on these). But there's no visual language for financial protection. Trust signals compete with pricing, listing details, and photos for visual attention. Greever notes that 'being articulate imparts intelligence'  the visual treatment of protection must feel authoritative, not decorative.
elements.solution: Create a 'Protection Shield' visual system: (1) A shield icon with 3 horizontal stripes (one per protection layer) in gradient purple. (2) Place it on a subtle off-white background (--bg-off-white) with a thin purple border. (3) Use DM Sans semibold for the protection labels  slightly softer than Inter to convey care rather than corporate authority. (4) Each protection point gets a checkmark icon in secondary purple. The visual weight should be equivalent to the price display  protection and price are co-primary.

evidence.quote: We hold the payment until you spend at least 24 hours in the property to make sure that the property corresponds exactly to what was advertised.
evidence.insight: The protection model resolved Theodore's commitment anxiety. The visual treatment must convey the same authority and completeness.

evidence.quote: Imparts intelligence... Demonstrates intentionality... Expresses confidence... Shows respect.
evidence.insight: Greever's four qualities of articulate design apply directly to visual trust signals  they must look intelligent, intentional, confident, and respectful.

typography: DM Sans, 600, 13px for protection labels
Inter, 500, 12px for protection descriptions
new_tokens_needed: --shield-icon-gradient: linear-gradient(135deg, #31135D 0%, rgb(109, 49, 194) 100%)  for the protection shield icon fill

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA minimum. Protection labels (#31135D on #FCFAFF) = 12.8:1  exceeds AA. Check icons (secondary purple on off-white) must be at least 3:1 for non-text elements.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Protection Shield has equal visual weight to price display. Both use bold/semibold, both get dedicated visual containers. Protection appears ABOVE or BESIDE the price, never below.
elements.brand_alignment: Aligns with taste model's 'Trustworthy, not corporate' principle. DM Sans softens the authority without reducing it. Purple gradient shield connects protection to the brand palette.

elements.title: Articulation Microcopy Typography  Conversational Explanations at Decision Points
elements.problem: The UI currently presents information in two modes: headlines (big, bold) and body text (small, gray). But articulation microcopy  the conversational 'why this works this way' explanations  doesn't fit either mode. It needs to feel like the agent speaking, not like documentation or marketing. Greever distinguishes between 'what the design does' and 'why it's the right choice'  these require different visual treatments.
elements.solution: Create a distinct visual treatment for articulation microcopy: (1) Use a subtle background tint (--bg-off-white or rgba(49,19,93,0.04)) to visually separate it from standard content. (2) Set in Inter 400, 13px, --text-description (#374151)  conversational weight, not instructional. (3) Maximum 2 lines. (4) Preceded by a small icon (info-circle or lightbulb in --text-light-gray). (5) Rounded corners (--rounded-lg, 8px) on the background container. This creates a 'quiet voice' that the eye can find when needed but doesn't compete with primary content.

evidence.quote: The agent's tone throughout: conversational, reassuring, not lecturing. 'I'm pretty sure I would be able to help you out' (14:09).
evidence.insight: The agent's voice is the model for articulation microcopy: confident, casual, brief. Not formal, not legal, not marketing.

evidence.quote: Establish a Positive Persona... Change Your Vocabulary.
evidence.insight: Greever says the communicator's persona matters as much as the content. Articulation microcopy must feel like a knowledgeable friend, not a manual.

typography: Inter, 400, 13px, 1.5 line-height for microcopy text

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA. #374151 on rgb(252,250,255) = approximately 9.5:1  exceeds AA.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Articulation microcopy is a SUPPORT tier  visually present but not competing with headlines or CTAs. The background tint makes it findable; the small font size makes it unobtrusive.
elements.brand_alignment: Aligns with taste model's 'Confident, not flashy'  the microcopy doesn't shout; it's there when needed. 'Human language, real data'  conversational tone matches the agent's voice.

elements.title: Matching Pipeline Visualization  Progress Through Stages
elements.problem: During the 2-3 week matching period, the guest has no visual representation of progress. Timeline or pipeline visualizations in the current design system are limited to the between-stay timeline (ds-ui-1000-004). The matching process needs its own visual language that communicates stages, current position, and expected duration without looking like a shipping tracker or a loading bar.
elements.solution: Create a horizontal pipeline visualization using connected nodes: (1) Each stage is a circle (28px) connected by a thin line (2px, --border-color). (2) Completed stages: filled purple (--secondary-purple), checkmark icon in white. (3) Current stage: outlined purple (--secondary-purple border, white fill), pulsing subtle animation. (4) Future stages: filled --bg-light-gray, no icon. (5) Below each node: stage label (Inter, 500, 11px, --text-gray). (6) Below current stage: estimated time (Inter, 400, 11px, --secondary-purple). The horizontal layout implies forward progress; the pulsing current node implies active work.

evidence.quote: Give us two to three weeks... all the bids submitted on one week goes through the matching process next week.
evidence.insight: The matching process has real stages (submission  batch review  host matching  introduction) that can be visualized as a pipeline.

evidence.quote: From IDEA to IDEAL... Putting It All Together.
evidence.insight: Greever's progression model (present, discuss, refine, agree) maps to the matching pipeline. The visual must show the guest that progress is a journey with known stages.

typography: Inter, 500, 11px for stage labels
Inter, 400, 11px for time estimates
new_tokens_needed: --animation-pulse: subtle opacity pulse 0.8-1.0 at 2s interval  for current pipeline stage

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA. Purple nodes on white background: sufficient. Labels (#6b7280 on #fff) = 4.6:1  meets AA for small text.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Pipeline sits at SECONDARY tier on the matching status page. Current stage has the most visual weight (outline + pulse). Total pipeline width should not exceed 400px to prevent overwhelming the guest.
elements.brand_alignment: Aligns with taste model's 'Fast response, gentle settle' animation philosophy. The pulse is subtle (opacity, not size or position), conveying 'work in progress' without anxiety.

elements.title: Reframing Comparison Cards  Side-by-Side Familiar vs. New
elements.problem: Theodore's mental model was shaped by Airbnb. The agent's most effective technique was reframing by comparison ('does anyone come to see your Airbnb?'). Visually, the platform has no pattern for showing side-by-side comparisons that help guests reframe their expectations. Existing card patterns are for content display, not conceptual reframing.
elements.solution: Create a 2-column comparison card pattern: (1) Left column labeled 'What you might expect' (--bg-light-gray background, --text-gray text). (2) Right column labeled 'How SplitLease works' (--bg-off-white background, --primary-purple text). (3) Each row shows one concern with a crossed-out misconception on the left and the reality on the right. (4) Right column gets a subtle purple left-border (3px, --secondary-purple) per existing actionable-card pattern. (5) Max 3 rows per comparison card. The visual asymmetry (gray left, purple-tinted right) guides the eye toward the SplitLease approach.

evidence.quote: When you rent your apartment over Airbnb, does anybody come to see your apartment?
evidence.insight: The comparison resolved the objection instantly. The visual pattern must achieve the same reframing effect.

evidence.quote: Why is it better than the alternative?
evidence.insight: Greever's third question for every design decision. Comparison cards answer this visually.

typography: Inter, 500, 13px for comparison points
Inter, 600, 12px, uppercase, --text-light-gray for column headers

elements.contrast_requirements: WCAG AA. All text colors meet minimum contrast on their respective backgrounds.
elements.visual_hierarchy_rule: Right column (SplitLease approach) has stronger visual weight through tint + purple accent. Left column is intentionally muted to guide the eye toward the reframe.
elements.brand_alignment: Aligns with taste model's 'Premium-accessible'  the comparison doesn't attack competitors, it elevates SplitLease through contrast.

elements.title: Contextual Reframing Tooltips  Anticipatory Objection Resolution
elements.problem: Theodore objected to signing before seeing the apartment (04:07). The agent resolved it in real-time. The UI cannot have real-time conversations, so it must anticipate the objection and present the reframe at exactly the right moment  when the guest encounters the unfamiliar process. Current tooltip/popover patterns are informational, not persuasive.
elements.solution: Implement contextual reframing tooltips that trigger at known objection points: (1) When the guest first encounters '24-hour inspection' language, show a non-modal tooltip anchored to the term with the Airbnb reframe. (2) Tooltip appears on first encounter, then auto-collapses to an info icon on return visits. (3) The tooltip should feel like a conversation, not a help article: 'Think about it like Airbnb  nobody sees the apartment before booking. But with us, you get 24 hours and your money back if it's not right.' (4) Dismissing the tooltip marks the objection as resolved  it won't reappear.

evidence.quote: No, no, not before you signed the lease... When you rent your apartment over Airbnb, does anybody come?
evidence.insight: The objection-reframe-acceptance cycle took 30 seconds verbally. The tooltip must achieve the same in 5 seconds visually.

evidence.quote: Anticipate Reactions... Do a Dress Rehearsal.
evidence.insight: Greever says anticipating reactions is preparation for the meeting. In UI terms, contextual tooltips are dress rehearsals for every guest objection.

states.default: Info icon (small circle-i) next to the triggering term, subtle --text-light-gray color
states.loading: Not applicable  content is pre-loaded
states.empty: Not applicable  reframing content is static
states.error: Not applicable  no network dependency
states.success: After reading, icon changes to a check  'Got it' state. Tooltip collapses to icon only on subsequent visits.

elements.transition_principle: Tooltip appears with a gentle fade-in (300ms, ease-out) from below the anchor point. Feels like someone leaning in to explain, not a popup demanding attention.

timing.response_target: 0ms  tooltip content is pre-loaded, no fetch required
timing.easing: ease-out
timing.rationale: Instant appearance with gentle settle. The reframe must be available at the exact moment of confusion, not after a loading delay.

elements.journey_state_awareness: First-time visitors see the tooltip auto-expanded. Return visitors see only the info icon. Guests who have already submitted a proposal never see the tooltip again  the objection is resolved.
edge_cases: Guest on mobile: tooltip must be full-width bottom sheet, not a floating popup
Guest who signed up via agent: may not need the reframe  check if agent call is logged
Multiple objection points on the same page: stagger tooltips, never show more than 1 at a time

elements.title: Proposal Status Live Tracker  Ambient Progress During Matching Wait
elements.problem: After submitting a bid, Theodore enters a 2-3 week void with zero feedback (08:40). The matching process is batched weekly, meaning real updates happen in bursts separated by days of silence. The UI must fill this void with meaningful status without fabricating progress. Greever's 'follow up fast' principle (Ch 9) applies: any communication is better than silence.
elements.solution: Create a live tracker that combines real events with contextual information: (1) Default state shows the pipeline at 'Agent Review' with timestamp of last activity. (2) When batched matching runs, update to 'Scanning hosts with compatible schedules...' (3) Show partial results as they emerge: '3 potential matches found  your agent is reviewing compatibility.' (4) Include estimated next update time: 'Next matching batch: Monday.' (5) Between batches, show contextual content: 'While you wait: 4 new listings in Manhattan match your weekend pattern.' This keeps the page alive without fabricating progress.

evidence.quote: All the bids submitted on one week goes through the matching process next week.
evidence.insight: The batched nature of matching means updates are infrequent. The tracker must bridge the gaps with honest, contextual information.

evidence.quote: Follow Up Fast... Do Something, Even If It's Wrong.
evidence.insight: Greever's urgency about post-meeting communication applies: any feedback during the wait period reduces dropout risk.

states.default: Pipeline visualization showing current stage (e.g., 'Agent Review'), last activity timestamp, next estimated update
states.loading: Subtle pulse animation on the current pipeline node when a batch is processing
states.empty: Never truly empty  if no matches yet, show: 'Expanding search to additional neighborhoods' with contextual listings
states.error: If matching takes longer than expected: 'Your weekend pattern is taking a bit longer to match  Robert is actively searching. Updated ETA: [date]'
states.success: Match found! Card transforms to show host preview with CTA: 'Your agent found a match  review the introduction'

elements.transition_principle: Pipeline updates animate left-to-right (nodes filling in sequence). New matches appear with a gentle slide-down from the pipeline. The overall feel is 'things are progressing' without urgency or anxiety.

timing.response_target: Pipeline loads instantly from cached state. Real-time updates (if websocket connected) appear within 1 second. Fallback: poll every 30 minutes.
timing.easing: ease-in-out for pipeline transitions
timing.rationale: The tracker exists between sessions  it must load instantly when the guest checks their status. Updates between visits are stored and revealed on load.

elements.journey_state_awareness: Tracker adapts based on pattern type: weekend patterns show longer estimated timelines with an explanation. Weekday patterns show shorter estimates. If the guest has multiple active proposals, tracker shows a summary view with expandable details.
edge_cases: Guest checks status multiple times per day with no new updates  show 'No new activity since [time]' honestly, don't re-animate old events
Match found but guest doesn't log in for 3 days  send push notification/email with match preview
All proposals rejected by hosts  show 'We're submitting your interest to new hosts' rather than a dead-end state

elements.title: Savings Counter Animation  Value Reinforcement on Every Weekly Action
elements.problem: Theodore's 40% discount requires weekly cleaning and flexibility compliance. Without tangible feedback on each action's value, the discount becomes invisible  the guest only notices the effort, not the reward. Current UI patterns show cleaning photo submission as a task completion, not a value-generating action.
elements.solution: After every cleaning photo submission, animate a savings counter that shows the concrete dollar impact: (1) Photo submitted  brief processing animation (300ms). (2) Counter increments with an odometer-style number roll: '+$X saved this week.' (3) Cumulative total updates with a subtle grow animation: 'Total savings: $X.' (4) Comparison line appears: 'Equivalent Airbnb cost for this week: $Y.' The animation sequence: upload  acknowledge  calculate  reveal savings  celebrate. Total sequence: 1.5 seconds.

evidence.quote: Did you sign up for the 40% discount? Okay, good.
evidence.insight: Theodore signed up eagerly. The enthusiasm must be maintained through visible value on every weekly action.

evidence.quote: Being Articulate Means Success... Expresses confidence.
evidence.insight: The savings animation articulates the platform's value proposition with each weekly interaction  confidence through demonstration, not just claiming.

states.default: Savings summary card showing cumulative total and this week's status (pending/confirmed)
states.loading: Photo upload progress bar with percentage. Once uploaded: 'Confirming your Space Care...'
states.empty: Before first cleaning submission: 'Submit your first Space Care photos to activate your weekly savings tracker'
states.error: Photo upload failed: 'Upload didn't complete  try again to keep your savings active this week' with retry button
states.success: Savings counter increments with odometer animation. Brief confetti particle effect (3 particles, 0.5s, then disappear  restraint per taste model)

elements.transition_principle: The savings reveal should feel like opening an envelope  anticipation  reveal  satisfaction. Not a progress bar, not a loading spinner, but a moment of discovery.

timing.response_target: Photo upload: standard network time. Savings calculation: instant (client-side). Animation sequence: 1.5s total.
timing.easing: ease-out for counter increment, ease-in-out for comparison line appearance
timing.rationale: The animation must be fast enough to feel responsive but slow enough to feel like a moment  this is the weekly 'reward' in the behavioral loop.

elements.journey_state_awareness: Week 1: more enthusiastic animation and explanation. Week 5+: more subtle, just the number increment. Week 10+: cumulative total gets a 'milestone' badge if it crosses $500/$1000.
edge_cases: Guest submits photos but misses the animation (backgrounded app): show savings update on next app open
Guest is behind on cleaning (missed last week): show 'Catch up to keep your streak' rather than punitive messaging
Discount tier changes mid-lease: recalculate and show adjusted savings transparently

elements.title: Concierge Warmth  The Agent's Voice as Emotional Template
elements.problem: Theodore responded most positively when the agent said 'I am your concierge' (10:45) and 'we pay a lot of attention to our customers being happy' (10:49-11:01). The UI has no equivalent emotional warmth  it's functional but impersonal. The gap between the agent's warm, personal tone and the platform's transactional interface creates an emotional drop-off when the guest moves from phone to screen.
elements.solution: Infuse the agent's concierge tone into UI copy throughout the pre-lease journey. (1) Replace 'Submit Proposal' with 'Send Your Interest'. (2) Replace 'Matching in progress' with 'Robert is finding your best options.' (3) Replace 'No results found' with 'We haven't found your perfect match yet  Robert is expanding the search.' (4) Every status update should name the agent, use first person, and communicate care. The emotional target: the guest should feel like the app is Robert speaking to them, not a system processing them.

evidence.quote: I am your concierge... we pay a lot of attention to our customers being happy.
evidence.insight: The 'concierge' label instantly elevated Theodore's engagement. He responded 'I appreciate that'  this is the emotional quality the UI must replicate.

evidence.quote: Establish a Positive Persona... Change Your Vocabulary.
evidence.insight: Greever says the persona you project determines how people receive your message. The UI's persona must be 'knowledgeable concierge' not 'processing system.'

elements.emotion_rationale: Theodore's emotional arc went from confused (00:24) to confident (14:09) entirely through the agent's tone. The UI must replicate this arc: from 'I don't understand this' to 'I'm in good hands.'

do: Name the agent in status messages
Use 'we' and 'your' instead of passive voice
Include one conversational aside per screen ('We think you'll love this neighborhood')
dont: Use system language ('Transaction ID', 'Processing', 'Queue position')
Use urgency language ('Act now', 'Limited time', 'Hurry')
Use generic greetings ('Welcome, user' or 'Hello there')
copy_guidelines.example_good: Robert found 3 spaces that match your weekend pattern. Take a look when you're ready  no rush.
copy_guidelines.example_bad: 3 listings match your search criteria. Review results to proceed.

animation_feel.feel_description: Gentle arrival, like someone placing a cup of coffee in front of you. Nothing slides in aggressively; everything settles into place.

tension_relief.tension_point: After submitting a proposal and entering the 2-3 week wait
tension_relief.relief_point: First status update from the named agent, even if just 'Robert received your interest and is reviewing it'
tension_relief.timing: Relief must arrive within 1 hour of submission. Even if no matching has occurred, the acknowledgment is itself the relief.

personalization_signals: Agent's name and photo in all status messages
Guest's preferred days reflected back in contextual language
Location-specific references ('Weekend spots near Chelsea')

anti_patterns.pattern: Generic system messages without a human sender
anti_patterns.reason: Destroys the concierge feeling that Theodore responded to. System messages feel like a queue; agent messages feel like care.
anti_patterns.example_bad: Your proposal has been submitted. You will be notified when there is an update.

elements.title: Fair Deal Satisfaction  Make the Guest Feel Smart, Not Cheap
elements.problem: Theodore eagerly signed up for the 40% discount tier (12:07), but the framing matters enormously. 'You get a discount because you clean' can feel degrading. 'You're saving 40% because you're flexible and responsible' feels empowering. The agent framed it as a trade: 'for less flexibility and willing to do some chores, you get a 40% discount.' The UI must maintain this 'smart trade' framing throughout the lease, especially during weekly cleaning submissions.
elements.solution: Frame every discount-related interaction as a smart decision, not a cost-cutting compromise. (1) Replace 'Discount tier' with 'Smart Stay tier' or 'Flexible Guest tier.' (2) Savings communications should feel like congratulations: 'Your flexibility saved you $X this week. Smart move.' (3) Cleaning submissions should feel like responsible ownership: 'Space Care confirmed. Nina will appreciate coming home to a clean space.' (4) Never use language that implies the guest is getting a lesser experience  they're getting a BETTER deal because they're a better guest.

evidence.quote: For less flexibility and willing to do some chores, you get a 40% discount.
evidence.insight: The agent framed the discount as a fair TRADE. The emotional quality is 'fair deal'  both sides give and both sides get. The UI must maintain this equity framing.

evidence.quote: Shows respect. You value everyone's opinions and time enough that you're well prepared.
evidence.insight: Greever's 'respect' principle: the UI must respect the guest's effort by framing it as valuable, not as a cost-saving obligation.

elements.emotion_rationale: The guest chose the discount tier because they felt smart about it. Weekly interactions must reinforce that feeling: 'I made a good choice' not 'I have to do chores to save money.'

do: Frame savings as the guest's achievement ('You saved')
Acknowledge the trade-off as a smart decision
Show the host's appreciation for the guest's effort
dont: Use words like 'discount', 'cheap', 'basic' for the tier
Frame cleaning as a requirement or penalty
Compare to non-discount guests ('Unlike Premium guests, you must...')
copy_guidelines.example_good: Space Care complete. You saved $82 this week by keeping the space in great shape. Your total savings: $738.
copy_guidelines.example_bad: Cleaning photos submitted. Your discount has been applied for this billing cycle.

animation_feel.easing: ease-out with slight overshoot on savings counter
animation_feel.feel_description: The savings number should land with a satisfying 'ka-ching' quality  not literally a sound, but the visual equivalent: a number that arrives with emphasis and settles confidently.
animation_feel.duration_range: 400-600ms for the counter animation

tension_relief.tension_point: End of stay, when the guest knows they need to clean and submit photos
tension_relief.relief_point: Savings counter animation after photo submission  the effort is immediately rewarded with a visible dollar amount
tension_relief.timing: Savings reveal within 2 seconds of photo upload confirmation

personalization_signals: Show the specific dollar amount saved THIS week (not just percentage)
Reference the host by name in appreciation context
Cumulative savings milestones ('You've saved enough to cover a whole extra week!')

anti_patterns.pattern: Framing cleaning compliance as a requirement with penalty for non-compliance
anti_patterns.reason: Transforms the 'smart trade' feeling into 'wage labor' feeling. The guest should never feel like they're working for the discount.
anti_patterns.example_bad: WARNING: You did not submit cleaning photos last week. Your discount may be revoked.

elements.title: Confusion-to-Clarity Arc  Every Screen Should Resolve One Question
elements.problem: Theodore started the call confused ('Now I am confused' at 00:24) and ended confident ('I really appreciate our chat and I'll be in touch' at 14:09). This emotional arc happened because the agent resolved one confusion at a time, never piling on. The UI, by contrast, presents ALL information at once  listing details, pricing, rules, photos, schedule  creating cognitive overload that maintains confusion rather than resolving it.
elements.solution: Design each screen/section to resolve ONE question before introducing the next. (1) Discovery: 'What is SplitLease?'  resolved by the comparison strip. (2) Listing page: 'Does this match my needs?'  resolved by the match quality indicator. (3) Pricing section: 'Can I afford this?'  resolved by the personalized monthly total. (4) Protection section: 'Am I safe committing?'  resolved by the protection shield. Each section should feel like a conversation turn: question  answer  next question. This is Greever's 'set the context' principle applied to every UI section.

evidence.quote: From 'Now I am confused' to 'I really appreciate our chat.'
evidence.insight: The emotional arc is confusion  understanding  confidence. Each question resolved builds toward the next. The UI must replicate this sequential resolution.

evidence.quote: Set the Context... Optimize for Memory... Remove Distractions.
evidence.insight: Greever's meeting design principles: set one context at a time, make each point memorable, remove everything that doesn't serve the current question.

elements.emotion_rationale: Each resolved question produces a micro-moment of relief. The cumulative effect of 4-5 micro-reliefs is confidence. Without the sequential resolution, the guest stays in a state of unresolved confusion.

do: Start each section with the question it answers
End each section with a transition to the next question
Use progressive disclosure  don't answer questions the guest hasn't asked yet
dont: Present all information simultaneously
Use tabbed interfaces that require the guest to choose what to learn first
Skip ahead to pricing before explaining the concept
copy_guidelines.example_good: Section header: 'Does this space match your schedule?'  Day badge row  Match indicator  Then: 'Now let's look at what it would cost for your specific pattern.'
copy_guidelines.example_bad: Listing page that shows price, schedule, photos, rules, host info, and protection details all at once with equal visual weight.

animation_feel.feel_description: Each section loads as the previous one is resolved  like turning pages in a conversation. Not a scroll-and-see-everything page, but a progressive reveal.
animation_feel.duration_range: 200-300ms per section transition

tension_relief.tension_point: Each new section heading introduces a question the guest is about to have answered
tension_relief.relief_point: The answer within that section resolves the question before the next one appears
tension_relief.timing: 5-10 seconds per question-answer cycle. The guest should never be in 'confusion' state for more than 10 seconds.

personalization_signals: Sections that are already answered by the guest's preferences are auto-resolved ('Your weekend pattern matches  next question')

anti_patterns.pattern: Showing all information at once and expecting the guest to find what they need
anti_patterns.reason: Creates cognitive overload that maintains confusion. Theodore needed 14 minutes of sequential Q&A  the UI must replicate this, not bypass it.
anti_patterns.example_bad: A listing page with 12 sections all visible simultaneously, requiring the guest to scroll and scan for relevance.

elements.title: Self-Articulating UI Comprehension Test
elements.problem: If the self-articulating UI fails, guests will still need agent calls to understand basic platform mechanics, maintaining high CAC and limiting scale.
elements.solution: Run a task-based usability test where participants must answer 4 questions using only the UI (no agent): What is SplitLease? How does the 24-hour guarantee work? What does submitting a proposal do? What is the 40% discount tier? Score comprehension accuracy.

evidence.quote: Theodore needed 14 minutes of agent explanation for concepts the UI should communicate.
evidence.insight: If the redesigned UI can answer these questions without an agent, the articulation pattern is working.

elements.test_description: Recruit 8 participants unfamiliar with SplitLease. Show them the redesigned listing page with articulation microcopy. Ask them to explain in their own words: (1) What SplitLease is, (2) how the 24-hour guarantee works, (3) what happens when they submit a proposal, (4) what the discount tier offers. Score each answer 0-2 for accuracy.
elements.success_criteria: Average comprehension score of 6/8 or higher (75%). All 4 concepts must average above 1.0/2.0 individually.
elements.failure_meaning: If comprehension is below 6/8, the articulation microcopy is either too subtle (not read) or too complex (not understood). Need to test visibility (is it seen?) separately from clarity (is it understood?).
elements.implementation_hint: Can be run as an unmoderated UserTesting.com study with screen recordings. Key metric is the guest's verbal explanation accuracy, not task completion time.

elements.title: Reframing Effectiveness A/B Test
elements.problem: If reframing comparisons don't work as well in UI form as they did verbally with Theodore, we could be adding complexity without benefit.
elements.solution: A/B test listing pages with and without the reframing comparison card. Variant A: standard listing page with informational text about the 24-hour guarantee. Variant B: listing page with the reframing comparison ('Like Airbnb, but with 24 hours to decide'). Measure conversion from listing_evaluation to proposal_creation.

evidence.quote: That's true. That's fair. That's a good point.
evidence.insight: The verbal reframe had instant impact. The A/B test validates whether the same technique works visually.

elements.test_description: Split traffic 50/50 on listing pages. Control: 'Your payment is held for 24 hours. If the property doesn't match the listing, you get a full refund.' Treatment: 'Think Airbnb  you don't tour the apartment first. But unlike Airbnb, you get 24 hours and a full refund if anything is off.' Measure proposal submission rate.
elements.success_criteria: Treatment shows statistically significant (p<0.05) increase in proposal submission rate, minimum 10% lift.
elements.failure_meaning: If no lift, the reframing technique may require more context than a single comparison line  might need the full comparison card (looks-004) rather than inline microcopy.
elements.implementation_hint: Implement via feature flag on the listing page protection section. Track event: proposal_submitted with variant label. Run for minimum 2 weeks or 200 conversions per variant.

elements.title: Matching Progress Visibility Retention Test
elements.problem: If the matching progress tracker doesn't reduce post-bid dropout, we're adding UI complexity without addressing the core retention issue.
elements.solution: Compare post-bid retention (app opens/email opens at Day 7 and Day 14) for guests with the progress tracker vs. the current experience (no tracker). Secondary metric: agent call volume for 'what's happening with my bid?' questions.

evidence.quote: Give us two to three weeks to complete the process.
evidence.insight: The 2-3 week wait is the highest-risk dropout period. If the tracker keeps guests engaged, it's working.

elements.test_description: Track two cohorts: guests who submitted proposals with the matching tracker visible vs. historical cohort without it. Measure: (1) App opens during matching period, (2) Email open rates for matching updates, (3) Agent call volume for status inquiries, (4) Conversion from proposal  acceptance.
elements.success_criteria: Tracker cohort shows 20% higher 14-day retention (app opens) and 30% reduction in agent status-inquiry calls.
elements.failure_meaning: If retention doesn't improve, the matching progress tracker may not be providing enough value  guests may need CONTENT during the wait (listings, neighborhood info) rather than just progress updates.
elements.implementation_hint: Instrument with analytics events: matching_tracker_viewed, matching_update_received, agent_call_status_inquiry. Compare weekly cohorts. Minimum 50 proposals per cohort.

elements.title: Savings Counter Cleaning Compliance Test
elements.problem: If the savings counter doesn't increase cleaning photo submission rates, the value articulation approach isn't strong enough to drive behavioral compliance.
elements.solution: Compare cleaning photo submission rates for discount-tier guests with the savings counter visible vs. the current experience. Track both submission rate and the emotional quality of the interaction (via optional 1-tap feedback: 'Was this worth it? Yes/No').

evidence.quote: For less flexibility and willing to do some chores, you get a 40% discount.
evidence.insight: The discount motivates signup but may not sustain compliance. The savings counter must maintain motivation over 16+ weeks.

elements.test_description: Split discount-tier guests into control (current cleaning flow) and treatment (cleaning flow + savings counter animation). Track: (1) Weekly cleaning submission rate, (2) Submission speed (seconds from prompt to submission), (3) Streak maintenance (consecutive weeks with submissions), (4) Optional 1-tap feedback score.
elements.success_criteria: Treatment group shows 15% higher weekly submission rate and 20% longer average streak. 1-tap feedback 'worth it' rate above 80%.
elements.failure_meaning: If submission rate doesn't improve, the dollar value framing may not be sufficient  may need to add social comparison ('Most guests in your area submit Space Care within 10 minutes of checkout').
elements.implementation_hint: Track events: space_care_prompt_shown, space_care_submitted, savings_counter_viewed, savings_counter_milestone_reached. A/B split at the user level, not session level.

elements.title: Protection Model Comprehension Test
elements.problem: If the progressive protection reveal doesn't resolve the 'signing before seeing' anxiety, guests will still need agent calls to feel safe committing.
elements.solution: Post-acceptance survey asking: 'Before you submitted your proposal, how well did you understand the 24-hour guarantee? (1-5 scale)' and 'Did the protection information on the listing page help you feel safe committing? (Yes/Somewhat/No)'. Compare responses with the pre-redesign baseline.

evidence.quote: At one point we'll actually get to see the apartment before I signed the lease... That's true. That's fair.
evidence.insight: Theodore's objection was completely resolved by the agent's explanation. The protection reveal must achieve the same resolution without an agent.

elements.test_description: Post-proposal survey (in-app, 2 questions max). Question 1: 'How confident are you that your money is protected?' (1-5 scale). Question 2: 'What would you do if the apartment didn't match the listing?' (free text). Score free text for awareness of 24-hour guarantee and refund option.
elements.success_criteria: Average confidence score of 4.0/5.0 or higher. 80% of free-text responses mention the 24-hour guarantee or refund option unprompted.
elements.failure_meaning: If confidence is below 4.0, the protection information is either not visible enough or not persuasive enough. Test visibility first (do they see it?) before redesigning content.
elements.implementation_hint: Trigger survey 30 seconds after proposal submission. Use in-app modal with 2-question form. Store responses with user journey phase metadata. Run for 100 responses minimum.

elements.title: Journey-Level Confusion-to-Clarity Arc Validation
elements.problem: If the sequential question-resolution arc doesn't work, the guest may still feel confused at proposal submission, leading to abandonment at the final step.
elements.solution: Instrument the listing page with scroll-depth and time-on-section analytics. Track whether guests who engage with each section sequentially (discovery  match  price  protection  propose) have higher conversion than those who skip sections. Validate that the confusion-to-clarity arc produces measurable confidence increase.

evidence.quote: From 'Now I am confused' to 'I really appreciate our chat.'
evidence.insight: The emotional arc happened because questions were resolved sequentially. The page layout must replicate this sequential resolution.

elements.test_description: Track section engagement order on listing pages: (1) Which sections are viewed (scroll depth per section), (2) Time spent on each section, (3) Whether engagement is sequential or random. Correlate with proposal submission rate. Hypothesis: guests who engage sections in the designed order (match  price  protection  propose) convert at 2x the rate of random engagers.
elements.success_criteria: Sequential engagers convert at 1.5x or higher rate than random engagers. Average time to proposal submission decreases by 20%.
elements.failure_meaning: If sequential engagement doesn't correlate with higher conversion, the section order may not match the guest's natural question sequence. Need qualitative research to discover the actual question order.
elements.implementation_hint: Implement intersection observer on each listing page section. Log: section_id, timestamp_entered, timestamp_exited, scroll_position. Build engagement sequence per session. Compare conversion rates by sequence type. Minimum 500 sessions.

elements.name: Protection Shield with Airbnb Reframe
elements.description: A compact trust module for listing pages that visually articulates the 3-layer protection model using shield iconography and an embedded Airbnb reframing comparison. Resolves the #1 guest objection ('I can't see it before signing') without requiring an agent call. Each protection layer is shown as a step with a checkmark, and the reframe comparison sits below in a subtle tinted container.
elements.compounds_on_explanation: Evolves ds-ui-1000-006 (Patient Follow-Up Email) by embedding the agent trust bridge INTO the listing page rather than only in email. Borrows the match-quality visual confidence from ds-ui-1001-002 (Listing Match Quality Card) but applies it to protection guarantees instead of schedule matching. Uses the timeline-node pattern from ds-ui-1000-004 (Between-Stay Status Display) to show the 3-step protection sequence.
elements.fills_gap: Cross-journey elements  this element shows the guest what the HOST also sees (both parties are protected), creating transparency across the host-guest boundary.
elements.html_css:
You're Protected
3-layer guarantee on every booking
No obligation until you sign
Browse, propose, negotiate you only commit when you're ready.
24-hour satisfaction guarantee
Spend your first night. If anything doesn't match the listing, get a full refund.
Payment held by Split Lease
Your money stays with us until you confirm. Security deposit protected too.
How it compares
On Airbnb, you book without touring first. With Split Lease, you get the same convenience plus 24 hours and a full refund if anything is off.
The host sees these same protections both sides are covered
elements.behavioral_notes: Auto-expands on first listing page visit. Collapses to header-only on subsequent visits with an expand toggle. The reframe comparison box is the key persuasive element  it must be visible without scrolling on mobile. The 'host sees' line at the bottom is the cross-journey element that fills a library gap.
elements.emotional_intent: Transform anxiety ('I'm signing blind') into confidence ('I'm better protected here than on Airbnb'). The shield icon and gradient convey institutional strength; the reframing text conveys conversational warmth.
elements.test_criteria: Post-proposal survey: 80%+ of guests who saw the shield module should mention the 24-hour guarantee or refund unprompted when asked 'What would you do if the apartment didn't match?'

elements.name: Matching Pipeline Status Tracker
elements.description: A horizontal pipeline visualization showing the guest's proposal journey from submission to host introduction. Each stage is a connected node with completion status, current-stage animation, and estimated timeline. Designed to fill the 2-3 week silence gap after bid submission. Shows the named agent and partial match results as they emerge.
elements.compounds_on_explanation: Evolves ds-ui-1000-004 (Between-Stay Status Display) from a vertical timeline into a horizontal pipeline for a different context (pre-lease matching vs. active-lease stays). Borrows the persistent profile-strip pattern from ds-ui-1001-006 (Guest Requirements Profile Strip)  the tracker is similarly persistent and follows the guest across pages. Uses the status-first architecture from ds-ui-1000-003 (Status-First Host Dashboard) applied to the guest's negotiation phase.
elements.fills_gap: Messaging/communication UI  the tracker includes an agent message area where the named agent can communicate status updates, serving as a lightweight messaging channel without building a full chat system.
elements.html_css:
Your Weekend Stay Search
FridaySunday in Manhattan 16 weeks starting March
Submitted
Finding matches
Agent review
Introduction
R
Robert, your concierge
I found 2 hosts with weekend availability in Manhattan. Reviewing compatibility now I'll have options for you by Wednesday.

Potential matches (2)
JL
Private room in Chelsea

elements.behavioral_notes: Pipeline nodes animate left-to-right as stages complete. Current stage pulses subtly. Agent messages arrive as push notifications and appear in the tracker. Partial match previews are blurred/minimal until the agent confirms compatibility. The 'next matching batch' line sets explicit timeline expectations.
elements.emotional_intent: Transform the anxiety of silence ('Is anything happening?') into the calm of visibility ('Robert is working on it and I can see progress'). The named agent with avatar creates the concierge feeling Theodore responded to.
elements.test_criteria: Post-bid retention: 80%+ of guests should open the tracker at least once per week during the 2-3 week matching period. Agent call volume for 'what's happening with my bid?' should decrease by 30%.

elements.name: Weekly Savings Value Tracker
elements.description: A persistent dashboard module on the guest Stays Manager that shows cumulative savings from the discount tier, this week's contribution, and an Airbnb comparison. After each Space Care photo submission, the savings counter animates to show the concrete dollar impact. Transforms the cleaning obligation into visible financial reward.
elements.compounds_on_explanation: Evolves ds-ui-1001-005 (Space Care Photo Upload with Streak Counter) by adding the FINANCIAL dimension that the streak alone doesn't capture. Borrows the stay stats pattern from ds-ui-1001-004 (This-Week Stay Card)  both show guest achievement metrics at a glance. Extends ds-ui-1001-003 (Price Decomposition) from a pre-lease pricing tool to an active-lease value tracker, showing how day-rate savings accumulate over time.
elements.fills_gap: Review/rating UI  the savings tracker includes a micro-review prompt ('How was this week's stay? Quick tap') that appears after the savings animation, capturing guest sentiment at the moment of highest satisfaction (just saw their savings). This is the first micro-review element in the library.
elements.html_css:
Your Savings Smart Stay Tier
$738
saved across 9 weeks
That's enough for an extra week of stays!
This week
Space Care confirmed
+$82
Your cost (FriSun, 9 wks) $1,620
Airbnb equivalent $2,358
Your savings $738 (31%)
How was this week's stay?
One tap takes 2 seconds. Your host sees the trend.
elements.behavioral_notes: Savings counter animates (odometer roll) after each Space Care submission. The comparison section uses strikethrough on the Airbnb price to make the savings feel tangible. The micro-review appears only after the savings reveal  timing it at the moment of peak satisfaction. 'Smart Stay Tier' replaces 'Discount Tier' per the emotional framing principle.
elements.emotional_intent: Transform weekly cleaning from obligation to achievement. The big savings number says 'your effort is paying off.' The Airbnb comparison says 'you made the smart choice.' The micro-review says 'your experience matters and your host cares.'
elements.test_criteria: Cleaning submission rate for discount-tier guests increases 15%+ when savings tracker is visible. Micro-review completion rate above 40% (one tap, no friction). Cumulative savings milestone messages ('enough for an extra week!') should be recalled by 60%+ of guests in exit surveys.

elements.name: Move-In Digital House Manual
elements.description: A mobile-optimized digital house manual that replaces physical welcome packets and scattered PDF documents. Organized into scannable sections (check-in, WiFi, house rules, neighborhood, emergency) with one-tap access to the most urgent info. Accessible from the active lease card on the Stays Manager. Includes a first-visit checklist that transforms into a reference guide after the first stay.
elements.compounds_on_explanation: Evolves ds-ui-1001-004 (This-Week Stay Card with Check-In) by extending what happens AFTER check-in  the house manual is the next thing the guest needs. Borrows the chip/toggle selection pattern from ds-ui-1000-005 (Guest Preference Quick-Set Panel) for section navigation. Uses the day-chip visual language from ds-ui-1001-001 (Day-of-Week Flexibility Selector) as a familiar interaction pattern for navigating manual sections.
elements.fills_gap: House manual / move-in checklist  this is the first guest onboarding element for arrival in the library. No existing elements cover the physical-to-digital transition at move-in.
elements.html_css:
Your House Manual
142 W 26th St, Apt 4B Chelsea
JL
Jessica's Space

WiFi & Apps

elements.behavioral_notes: Checklist items are interactive  tap to mark as done. On first visit, items appear as a to-do list. After all items are checked, the section transforms into a reference guide (checkmarks remain, items become collapsible). WiFi password has a one-tap copy button. Emergency info is always visible with high-contrast red accent. The 'Message' button in the header fills the messaging gap.
elements.emotional_intent: Transform the anxiety of arriving at a stranger's space into the confidence of having a guide. The gradient header and host contact create warmth. The checklist creates structure. The WiFi card and emergency bar provide immediate practical value. The overall feeling should be: 'I know exactly what to do.'
elements.test_criteria: First-stay completion of all checklist items: 70%+. WiFi copy button usage: 80%+ on first visit. Emergency info awareness: 90%+ of guests should know where to find emergency contacts when surveyed after move-in.

elements.name: Guest Notification Center with Escalation Tiers
elements.description: A notification center designed specifically for the guest side, with three escalation tiers: Ambient (activity feed), Attention (action needed), and Urgent (time-sensitive). Currently notification escalation exists only for hosts. This fills the guest notification gap by providing structured, non-overwhelming notification management tied to the guest's specific journey context.
elements.compounds_on_explanation: Borrows the action-card pattern from ds-ui-1000-003 (Status-First Host Dashboard) where action items have a purple left-border accent. Extends the urgency model from ds-ui-1001-007 (Date Exception Quick-Modify Panel) where time-sensitive changes need immediate attention. Uses the timeline dot system from ds-ui-1000-004 (Between-Stay Status Display) for the ambient activity feed.
elements.fills_gap: Guest-side notifications  notification escalation exists for hosts only. This element provides the guest equivalent with three tiers matched to guest-specific actions.
elements.html_css:
Notifications

Your host countered your proposal respond within 48 hours

Action Needed
Submit your Space Care photos for this week
Stay #6 checkout Today
Activity
Payment of $270 processed for Week 6
Yesterday
Robert updated your matching status
Monday
Jessica sent a note: "Welcome back!"

elements.behavioral_notes: Three tiers filter automatically based on action type and deadline. Urgent: time-bound actions with consequences. Attention: actions needed but no deadline pressure. Ambient: informational feed. Badge count on the nav reflects only Urgent + Attention items. Ambient items appear read/unread but don't contribute to the badge. Jessica's note in the ambient feed fills the messaging gap without building a full chat system.
elements.emotional_intent: Reduce the anxiety of 'did I miss something?' while avoiding notification fatigue. The three-tier system lets the guest quickly assess: 'Do I need to act NOW (urgent), SOON (attention), or just know about it (ambient)?' The purple accent on attention items connects to the brand without alarming; the red accent on urgent items demands action.
elements.test_criteria: Notification engagement rate: 90%+ of Urgent notifications should be acted on within 48 hours. Attention notifications within 1 week. Ambient feed should be opened at least once per week by 60%+ of active guests.

elements.name: Calendar Week View with Stay Schedule
elements.description: A compact calendar week view that shows the guest's stay schedule in the context of actual dates, not just abstract day-badge chips. Each day cell shows stay status (your night, host's night, available), pricing, and any exceptions. Bridges the gap between the abstract day-badge pattern and real calendar planning. This is the first calendar view in the library  all previous elements are card-based.
elements.compounds_on_explanation: Evolves ds-ui-1001-001 (Day-of-Week Flexibility Selector) from abstract day selection into calendar-grounded date awareness. Borrows the exception-week modification pattern from ds-ui-1001-007 (Date Exception Quick-Modify Panel) and embeds it directly into the calendar view. Uses the price-per-day concept from ds-ui-1001-003 (Price Decomposition with Day-Rate Bars) but shows it in calendar context rather than bar charts.
elements.fills_gap: Calendar/scheduling views  everything in the library is card-based. This is the first calendar element, providing temporal context that day-badge chips alone cannot.

Exception days use dashed red outline and strikethrough. The month-view toggle switches between week and month views. Today indicator (purple dot) orients the guest in time. Calendar syncs with the day-badge pattern  same color coding (purple = your night, gray = host's night).
elements.emotional_intent: Ground the abstract split-schedule concept in real dates. Day-badge chips say 'you stay Friday-Sunday.' The calendar says 'THIS Friday March 6, you check in at Jessica's.' The specificity creates tangibility that builds commitment and reduces the feeling that the arrangement is abstract or uncertain.
elements.test_criteria: Calendar view engagement: 50%+ of active-lease guests should view the calendar at least once per month. Date exception creation rate should be higher from the calendar than from the standalone date exception panel (hypothesis: visual context makes exceptions feel less risky).

elements.name: Host-Guest Perspective Bridge Card
elements.description: A card that shows the guest what the host sees about them  their space care streak, reliability score, and review summary  creating transparency across the host-guest boundary. This is the first cross-journey element in the library: it reveals one user's view of another, building mutual accountability and trust. After completing Space Care, the guest sees: 'Here's what Jessica sees about you.'
elements.compounds_on_explanation: Evolves ds-ui-1001-005 (Space Care Streak Counter) by showing where that streak DATA goes  the host sees it. Borrows the compatibility-badge visual language from ds-ui-1000-002 (Guest Proposal Card)  but reversed: instead of the host seeing guest attributes, the guest sees their own profile as the host perceives it. Uses the stay-stats pattern from ds-ui-1001-004 (This-Week Stay Card) as the data source for the perspective bridge.
elements.fills_gap: Cross-journey elements  host seeing guest's perspective, or vice versa. This is the first element that explicitly bridges the two journey types, showing one party what the other party sees.

elements.behavioral_notes: Appears after Space Care submission (optimally) or accessible from the Stays Manager at any time. The host's actual note is shown only if the host has written one  otherwise a fallback message: 'Jessica hasn't left a note yet  but your stats speak for themselves.' The profile stats are real-time and accumulate across leases. The cross-journey bridge creates mutual accountability: the guest sees what the host sees, motivating continued good behavior.
elements.emotional_intent: Create pride and ownership in the guest's reputation. Seeing '9/9 Space Care' and 'Perfect streak' from the HOST's perspective is more powerful than seeing it from your own dashboard. The host's personal note adds emotional warmth. The overall feeling: 'I'm building a reputation that matters  this host sees me as a great guest.'
elements.test_criteria: Engagement: 60%+ of guests should view the perspective bridge at least once per lease. Behavioral impact: guests who view the bridge should have 10%+ higher Space Care submission rate than those who don't. Emotional impact: post-lease survey question 'Did you feel like a valued guest?' should score 4.2/5.0 or higher.
