Monthly price is displayed as the primary figure in the guest's budget frame. Designed for ESL guests who need recognition-based evaluation rather than text-heavy reading.

elements.title: Plain-Language Summary Card: Three Questions, Three Answers, Zero Jargon
elements.description: A one-page comprehension MVP that answers the three questions Robbie asked during his call: When do I get paid? Who pays? What if they miss a payment? Uses plain language with the host's specific dollar amount ($1,600) and guest names (Ariel and Amber). Designed as a visual summary that precedes legal documents, with a purple left accent border to distinguish it from formal agreements. Implements Lean UX's 'getting out of the deliverables business' principle: the summary is a product designed for comprehension, not a document designed for compliance.
elements.html_css_snippet:
What You Need to Know

When do I get paid?
After your guest's first night each month. Your first payment of $1,600 arrives one day after Ariel and Amber move in.
Who pays?
Ariel and Amber pay Split Lease. Split Lease pays you. You never collect rent directly.
What if they miss a payment?
You still get paid. Split Lease guarantees your rent even if a guest misses their payment.
You will sign two agreements
Rental Agreement
The contract between you and your guests about living in the apartment.
Supplemental Agreement
The contract between you and Split Lease that guarantees your payment.

Includes automatic monthly-to-nightly price translation. Implements Lean UX's waste-removal principle: verification is cognitively cheaper than creation. Based on Robbie offering his existing Craigslist listing twice in two minutes.

elements.title: Category Framing Gate - Why Pay for Nights You Don't Use?
elements.description: Steven arrived in commodity browsing mode, scanning for 'rooms and studios' (03:08). This framing gate interrupts the commodity lens by showing a personalized savings comparison before the guest sees any listings. Thiel warns that 'all failed companies are the same: they failed to escape competition' (Ch 3). By showing Steven that his 16 nights at $1,200/month vs. $2,000 full-time creates an $800 monthly savings, the gate creates a 'wait, what?' surprise moment that breaks the browsing trance and reframes evaluation from commodity (price/location) to category-creator (schedule fit/savings).

elements.title: Agent Trust Bridge - Concierge Welcome Card
elements.description: Steven's trust was built entirely with Bryant on the phone call, who said 'I will be your concierge service' (13:12). Thiel's economies of scale principle means human concierge cannot scale, but trust must transfer gradually from person to platform. This welcome card appears on the guest's first platform visit, bridging the call and the digital experience by showing Bryant's name, the personalized search setup from the conversation, and a floating action button for direct contact. The guest feels 'Bryant is here' rather than being handed off to an anonymous system.

elements.title: Temporal-Match Listing Card - Schedule Fit as Headline
elements.description: Steven's first substantive detail was temporal: 'Monday afternoon, Friday morning, four nights' (02:46). He was flexible on location ('anywhere in it,' 04:12) but fixed on schedule. Standard listing cards lead with photos and location -- commodity dimensions. Thiel's proprietary technology principle (Ch 5) demands a 10x improvement in some dimension. This card leads with a schedule-match badge and pre-computed monthly savings, making Split Lease's monopoly advantage (temporal matching) the first thing the eye hits. No other platform can show 'Perfect Mon-Fri Match' as a listing headline.

elements.title: Progressive Model Explainer - How Time-Sharing Works
elements.description: The agent spent 3+ minutes (08:05-10:43) explaining anchor/filler roles, cleaning obligations, and the 40% discount. Most guests will never get a phone call. This progressive disclosure component delivers the same comprehension in under 15 seconds through three layers: a one-line headline ('you get Mon-Fri, they get weekends'), an expandable visual calendar with role cards, and a deep-dive link. Thiel notes 'the clearest way to make a 10x improvement is to invent something completely new' (Ch 5). The co-tenancy model IS the invention; this explainer makes it comprehensible without making it intimidating.

elements.title: Matching Pipeline Dashboard - Your Match Progress
elements.description: After Steven bids, the agent says 'hopefully next week I'll send you something to consider' (14:06). This creates a 5-7 day information vacuum where the guest has zero visibility. Thiel's inverted lesson: 'A bad plan is better than no plan' (Ch 2). This pipeline dashboard replaces silence with a named 5-stage process, showing Bryant's name, a live 'matches reviewed' counter, and estimated timeframes. The three-way matching complexity (two guests + landlord, 06:44) is made visible and manageable rather than abstract and anxiety-inducing. Each stage transition is a retention signal during the highest-risk dropout window.

elements.title: First-Night Verification Checklist - Welcome to Your First Stay
elements.description: The 24-hour acceptance window (15:32-16:06) is the highest-stakes moment in Steven's journey. He was told about cleaning obligations, deposit protection, and the co-tenant arrangement weeks ago on a phone call. This guided verification walkthrough re-surfaces that information as a warm welcome, not an inspection. Thiel's inverted lesson: 'Sales matters just as much as product' (Ch 2). Move-in is where the sale (the call's promises) meets the product (the physical space). The checklist confirms quality, sets behavioral expectations for cleaning photos, and transitions the guest from provisional to committed with an affirmative 'Everything looks good' tap rather than silence-as-acceptance.

elements.title: Cumulative Value Dashboard - Your Lease at a Glance
elements.description: Steven's 5-6 month lease (02:57, 03:48) creates 24 weekly stays. The agent mentioned the 40% discount once on the call (10:28); by month 3, Steven will have forgotten the magnitude. Thiel's durability principle: 'most of a tech company's value will come at least 10 to 15 years in the future' (Ch 5). This dashboard makes accumulated value visible -- $4,800 saved, 12 of 24 stays completed, 98% reliability score, 4.8 co-tenant harmony. Each weekly update compounds the guest's psychological investment, making departure a visible loss and re-lease the natural default. The savings card in deep purple carries maximum visual gravity as the single most powerful retention number.

elements.title: Zero-Obligation Bid Confirmation - Interest Expressed
elements.description: The agent repeated 'no obligation' twice in one breath (06:15-06:23) and encouraged multiple bids for three-way matching (06:44). The digital bid interaction must match this casual verbal register. Thiel's network effects principle: 'your product must be valuable to its very first users' (Ch 5). This confirmation component appears instantly after the guest taps 'I'm Interested,' showing a warm acknowledgment with Bryant's name, the pre-filled schedule, and a direct link to the pipeline dashboard. Language uses 'Express Interest' instead of 'Submit Bid' to maintain the zero-obligation emotional promise. The sub-line 'Free and non-binding -- withdraw anytime' prevents the commitment anxiety that kills first-time network contributions.

elements.title: Problem-First Discovery Outreach Card - Category-Defining Three-Tier Sequence
elements.description: Kelly rejected Split Lease because Bryant led with the solution (Landon's schedule) instead of the problem (unprotected direct hosting). This three-tier card enforces Play Bigger's 'market the problem, not the solution' principle through visual hierarchy: a warm amber Problem tier dominates, the purple Category tier resolves it, and a quiet Proof tier presents the guest match. The progressive visual weight ensures the host absorbs the risk question before encountering any solution data, preventing the instant category-rejection that occurred on Kelly's call.

elements.title: Risk-Contrast Comparison Card - Category Displacement Through Side-by-Side Risk Dimensions
elements.description: Kelly evaluated her hosting approach on a single dimension (trust through direct vetting) and never considered payment risk, damage liability, or early departure exposure. Play Bigger teaches that category kings sell 'different, not better.' This comparison card frames direct hosting and guaranteed-income hosting as categorically different along risk dimensions, not feature dimensions. The amber risk column carries more visual weight than the purple protection column, ensuring the host absorbs the problem before the solution -- mirroring the Birdseye frozen food ad strategy of making the old category seem incomplete.

elements.title: Vetting Evidence Trail - Inspectable Trust Cards for Control-Oriented Hosts
elements.description: Kelly's core objection was about information depth and personal control: 'I wanted someone who I can get a little bit more information as far as their nursing and just being more confident in who they were.' This component answers her exact question with verifiable evidence organized into expandable cards. Play Bigger's Choice Supportive Bias says Kelly will rationalize direct vetting as superior -- unless the platform's evidence is undeniably more comprehensive. Each card uses document-style formatting with source attribution and dates, creating the feeling of 'I am evaluating this myself' rather than 'someone else approved this for me.' Purple verification badges replace the style guide's no-green rule.

elements.description: Kelly's identity is built on control: 'I'd prefer to just kind of work with individuals directly.' Play Bigger's magic triangle requires product/category fit -- and for control-oriented hosts, the product must feel like 'I decide,' not 'they decided for me.' This proposal card presents lease terms with the host as the explicit decision-maker. Approve and Decline buttons are equally weighted visually, signaling genuine evaluation rather than rubber-stamping. The guaranteed income amount is prominently displayed as the category-defining detail, reframing the proposal from 'here is a tenant' to 'here is your guaranteed income.' All terms are editable, preserving agency.

Play Bigger's 6-10 law shows categories take years to establish. This minimal seed card is sent via SMS 25 minutes after a declined call to replace the wrong category anchor ('matchmaker') with the right one ('guaranteed-income hosting'). Its extreme restraint -- one bold purple headline, two lines of definition, one risk scenario, one personal contact -- ensures the host glances at it once and remembers the category name for months. No CTA, no features, no signup link. The warm close leverages the Michigan connection Bryant and Kelly shared.

Kelly volunteered her Troy, MI identity and mentioned associates with properties -- she is socially embedded in a local hosting network. This notification, triggered only by real geographic adoption milestones, activates belonging rather than FOMO. The large purple count number is the visual focal point, triggering the brain's error signal: 'other property owners near me are doing this.' No CTA, no pitch -- pure informational social proof delivered as a neighborhood update, not platform marketing.

Play Bigger's Jawbone case study shows that even great products fail when vocabulary maps to the existing category. This internal reference card systematically replaces every intermediation term with category-defining vocabulary. Old labels appear faded with strike-through (visually expired), while new labels appear in bold purple (visually authoritative). Agents consult this during calls. The visual pattern makes the vocabulary shift feel like a paradigm replacement, not a word swap.

This dashboard centers the guaranteed payment amount as the dominant visual element (the category-defining value), with lease progress, next payment date, and guest status as supporting data. Every element reinforces 'you are getting paid regardless' -- the category promise that Kelly never heard. For control-oriented hosts, all actions remain host-initiated: they can message the guest, review terms, or request changes, maintaining the agency that makes adoption sustainable.

elements.title: Agent-Continuity Entry Screen - Recognition Before Demand Through Trigger Inheritance
elements.description: June's entire relationship is with Bryant, not the platform. She is personally depleted ('going through a lot of stuff myself') and time-constrained. Saffer's trigger principle states that manual triggers must be recognizable in context -- and June's only recognized trigger is Bryant. This entry screen inherits the agent trigger by making Bryant's name, the property address, and June's exact pricing numbers the first things she sees. The microinteraction structure: the trigger is the email link (agent-initiated), the rule is 'show the host what was discussed, not what is needed,' the feedback is the populated listing preview, and the loop is the persistent agent presence throughout the first lease cycle. No account creation, no orientation, no blank forms -- just recognition.

elements.title: Persistent Rule Verification Strip - Mono-Numeric Feedback That Survives Every Screen
elements.description: June asked 'Are there any fees?' identically twice in the same call (07:32 and 10:59), proving verbal feedback does not persist. Saffer's core axiom is 'Feedback Illuminates the Rules' -- and rules that disappear are rules the host cannot trust. This persistent strip displays June's exact protection rules ($2,690 rent, $2,500 deposit, $140 cleaning, $40 utility cap with guest-paid overage) in a fixed, scannable format that appears on every screen where those rules are actionable. The microinteraction structure: the trigger is any screen navigation, the rule is 'always show host-defined parameters,' the feedback is the strip itself with verification indicators, and the long loop is that the strip persists across the entire lease lifecycle without the host needing to re-verify. The monospace numerics create a visual signature that the host's eye learns to locate by typeface alone.

elements.title: Single-Surface Proposal Decision Screen - Inline Verification with Urgency Without Anxiety
elements.description: June manages multiple properties while depleted and time-constrained. Saffer's rule design principle -- 'Limited Options and Smart Defaults' -- demands that the proposal decision not scatter information across tabs or require navigation to verify terms. This single-surface screen presents the guest profile, verification badges, lease terms, and the host's rules all on one scrollable view. The microinteraction: the trigger is a notification from Bryant ('A guest wants your March dates'), the rules are the host's own terms displayed for verification, the feedback is match/mismatch indicators on each term, and the mode is a spring-loaded decision state where approve/decline are equally weighted. The emotional target from L5 feels-004 is 'urgency without anxiety' -- the host should feel confident deciding quickly because all information is visible, not pressured because information is hidden.

elements.title: Utility Cap Protection Rule Card - Conditional Rule Capture with Visible Enforcement Feedback
elements.description: June's utility cap ($40 with guest-paid overage) is not a preference -- it is a protection mechanism born from repeated painful experiences ('people have been ridiculous with the electric bill... I had to start protecting myself'). Saffer's rule design chapter insists that rules must capture conditional logic, not just binary states. A simple 'utilities included: yes/no' toggle cannot represent '$40 threshold where the owner pays the first $40 and the guest pays anything above that.' This card implements a structured conditional rule with three components: threshold amount, owner responsibility, and overage assignment. The microinteraction: the trigger is the host entering utility terms during listing creation, the rule is the conditional logic (threshold + allocation), the feedback is immediate confirmation in the host's own language, and the enforcement loop shows the rule is active on proposals and lease dashboards. The left-border accent and elevated visual treatment signal that this is a protection rule, not a standard form field.

elements.title: Ambient-to-Alert Lease Health Dashboard - Adaptive Long Loop for Active Lease Monitoring
elements.description: June's utility abuse history ('I have had bills of a hundred, $200') means she will monitor her active lease with hypervigilance unless the platform offloads that burden. Saffer's Long Loops chapter describes adaptive feedback that changes behavior over repeated cycles -- the dashboard should feel calm when everything is normal and escalate visually only when attention is needed. This implements the ambient-to-alert pattern from L3 looks-004: payment status and utility usage default to quiet, ambient indicators (subtle purple tones). When utility usage approaches the $40 cap, the visual treatment escalates from ambient to attention to alert using warm amber. The microinteraction: the trigger is the host visiting the dashboard (or a system-initiated push when thresholds approach), the rules are the host's own protection parameters, the feedback is color-coded status indicators, and the long loop adapts by learning which metrics the host checks most often and surfacing those first. The emotional target is 'vigilance offloading' -- the host trusts the dashboard to watch so she does not have to.

elements.title: Cross-Platform Calendar Disclosure Panel - Acknowledgment Trigger at Commitment Points
elements.description: June lists on Furnished Finder and plans to list with Split Lease simultaneously, creating a calendar conflict that only surfaces when a guest books overlapping dates on both platforms. Saffer's complexity absorption principle ('Absorb Complexity,' Ch. 3, p. 56-59) states that systems should handle complexity the user would otherwise manage manually. But calendar synchronization has a dangerous failure mode: if the platform silently blocks dates without the host understanding why, or worse, allows double-booking, trust collapses. This panel surfaces cross-platform calendar impact at the exact moment it matters -- when the host is about to approve a proposal. The microinteraction: the trigger is a system-detected overlap between the proposal dates and the host's Furnished Finder calendar, the rule is 'always disclose cross-platform impact before commitment,' the feedback is a visual timeline showing which dates are affected, and the mode is a spring-loaded acknowledgment gate that prevents approval without calendar awareness. The emotional target from L5 feels-005 is 'effortless continuity' -- the host should feel that the platform manages her multi-platform complexity, not that it creates new problems.

elements.title: Multi-Unit Listing Manager - Building-Level Inheritance with Unit-Level Override
elements.description: June owns a three-family house and wants to list two apartments. Saffer's 'Don't Start from Zero' principle (Ch. 3, p. 64) means the second listing should inherit everything from the first -- pricing, rules, protection policies, calendar preferences -- with the host only changing what differs between units. Without inheritance, June must re-enter $2,690 rent, $2,500 deposit, $140 cleaning, $40 utility cap, and all vetting preferences for each unit separately. This is the exact cognitive tax that Saffer warns against: 'avoid having the user provide the same piece of information twice.' The multi-unit manager displays the building as a parent container with shared defaults, and individual units as children that inherit those defaults but allow per-unit overrides. The microinteraction: the trigger is the host creating a second listing at the same address, the rule is 'inherit building-level defaults automatically,' the feedback is visual indicators showing which values are inherited vs. customized, and the long loop is that changes to building-level defaults propagate to all units unless individually overridden.

elements.title: Recurring Proof Notification - Earned Trust Through Visible Rule Enforcement Over Time
elements.description: Saffer's Long Loops chapter describes how microinteractions must evolve over repeated use cycles. June's trust was built through Bryant's verbal promises, but platform trust must be earned through repeated proof of enforcement. When the utility cap is enforced correctly for the first time (guest billed for overage above $40), the platform must not let this proof pass silently. When rent arrives on time, the platform must not treat it as invisible. L5 feels-003 defines this as 'Earned Trust Through Recurring Proof, Not Silence' -- every successful enforcement is an opportunity to reinforce the host's decision to use the platform. This notification card is sent after each rule enforcement event: rent deposited, utility cap enforced, guest compliance confirmed. The microinteraction: the trigger is a successful enforcement event (system-initiated), the rule is 'always make enforcement visible,' the feedback is a warm, brief notification with the specific rule and outcome, and the long loop tracks enforcement history so the host can see a pattern of protection over time. The emotional target is 'persistent certainty' -- the host should accumulate evidence that the platform keeps its promises.

This card places the three-pillar concept (your space when you are there, a matched roommate when you are not, your stuff stays) above photos and amenities using a warm surface background, three icon panels with labels, and a single-sentence value proposition. Designed for scanning, not reading. Addresses the highest-risk friction moment in the guest journey: concept confusion at first encounter.

This component eliminates that dependency by making three core protections visible at a glance: non-residency clause, damage deposit, and payment guarantee. Each constraint is a pill-shaped selector at the top of the card, scannable in under 2 seconds. elements.description: A payment status card that shows three distinct states: processing, confirmed, and error. Hemeden nearly abandoned when told payment comes at end of stay (16:20) and only agreed to 24-hours-after-arrival. Norman states 'feedback must be immediate.' This component fills the anxiety window between guest arrival and payment with an optimistic processing indicator, transitions to a confirmed state with prominent amount display, and handles failures with clear explanations. The confirmed state uses a left-accent border and prominent monospace dollar amount, matching the Tier 1 notification treatment from looks-005. Payment is the host's primary feedback signal that the system is working.

This component is a Tier 1 notification that appears at the 4-week mark with a complete status summary (earnings so far, days remaining, guest info) and two clear actions: extend or end. It takes under 60 seconds to complete. Between checkpoints, the dashboard shows a calm status with the next checkpoint date, creating the emotional rhythm of calm-calm-checkpoint-calm that feels-006 prescribes.

Norman warns that 'when the system image is incoherent or inappropriate, the user cannot easily use the device.' This component bridges the verbal model to digital reality by showing the agent's name, the host's call-discussed parameters as editable summary chips ($75/night, max 4 weeks, available Sep 10+, 1 guest), and a pending next-steps checklist. The host should recognize at least 3 call elements within 5 seconds. This is a one-time ceremony that converts conversation into a confirmed digital profile.

elements.title: Call-Echo Guarantee Landing Section
elements.description: A host landing page hero section that mirrors the exact conversational phrases Robert used on the call. Three guarantee headlines appear in high-contrast serif typography on a warm background, producing the phrase-level recognition that Kahneman's cognitive ease research links to truth perception. Diane explicitly said she wanted to 'read the whole website' before committing (15:59), and at 16:38 she couldn't even name the platform. This section ensures that within 3 seconds of landing, she encounters the exact promises she already accepted on the call -- payment guarantee, damage matching, zero host fees -- in the same plain language Robert used. The warm off-white background bridges the emotional gap between the warm call and the cold screen.

elements.title: Sequential Pricing Scenario Card
elements.description: A single-focus pricing card that presents one rate question at a time, mirroring how Robert explained Split Lease's variable pricing on the call (12:29-13:49). Diane's 'I'm familiar' response (14:20) masks a familiarity trap -- she pattern-matched 'per night' to her 15-year hotel model without processing the novel variable-rate structure. This card uses Kahneman's cognitive ease principle: one question per screen maximizes legibility and prevents the overwhelming multi-variable matrix that would spike cognitive strain. The mono typography for dollar amounts signals financial precision, and a live projection shows the real-world consequence of the entered rate, gently activating System 2 at the moment it matters most.

Diane's confident 'I'm familiar' (14:20) was based on pattern-matching 'per night' to her 15-year hotel model. This card surfaces the novel variable-rate structure by showing Guest A at 4 nights/$50 and Guest B at 2 nights/$60, with different weekly totals -- revealing that rate changes based on booking pattern. The card enters with a slightly slower animation (400ms vs 300ms) to signal 'pause and read carefully.'

Multi-property progress is shown via a compact counter. Each element meets the 48px minimum tap target for mobile use during Diane's 90-second schedule gaps. Her instinctive question 'So I don't need them first to see?' (09:48) reveals her evaluation model is physical. The platform restricts direct communication until lease signing (08:47), so this card must provide enough digital information to produce the cognitive ease that in-person meeting would. It leads with the guest's stated purpose (why they need the space), shows a visual weekly schedule, displays verification badges inline, features the guest's own words prominently, and offers a Zoom meeting as a bridge to physical evaluation. Kahneman's research shows information richness produces the ease/intuition cluster that enables experienced hosts to evaluate intuitively rather than suspiciously.

elements.description: A dashboard payment track record component that makes every successful payment a visible, countable mere-exposure event. Diane's COVID experience ('I had pretty good people, steady... some moved out, didn't pay,' 06:23) shows what happens when years of success are invisible -- failures dominate perception. This badge row renders each payment period as a circular badge: filled with purple and a checkmark when paid, outlined when upcoming. A running count in mono typography ('4 of 6 payments on time') and cumulative earnings make the pattern salient. Kahneman's mere exposure research requires conscious perception of repeated positive stimuli for the platform to become a 'safety signal.' Each badge fill is a gentle 300ms animation -- not celebratory, but visible enough to register as a positive exposure event. For multi-property hosts like Diane, a consolidated total across all properties compounds the trust signal.

elements.title: Micro-Task Notification Deep Link Card
elements.description: A deep-linked micro-task card designed for the 90-second gaps in Diane's packed schedule. She described her time constraint as structural: 'the day is never long enough' (00:49), and with three properties across Manhattan and Queens, every friction point is multiplied 3x. Kahneman's observation that 'System 2 is lazy and mental effort is aversive' means the mere perception of effort prevents task initiation. This card shows what a host sees when tapping a notification deep link -- one decision, one property, specific time estimate, and a single primary action. No navigation required. No dashboard to find. No multi-step wizard. Tasks are sequenced across properties rather than bundled, so completing one feels like progress rather than the start of a backlog. The card auto-saves all input so interruption loses nothing.

elements.title: Monthly Cost Comparison Card - Budget-First Listing Evaluation
elements.description: A listing card that leads with the monthly cost for the guest's specific schedule, not the per-night rate. Shomit explicitly says 'I guess mainly I think of this per month and then I break it down per night' (line 65) and anchors his budget at '$2,500/month for a full lease' (line 68) and '$1,500 or less' for Split Lease (line 70). The current platform shows per-night pricing ($66/night), forcing every guest to mentally compute $66 x 4 nights x 4.3 weeks. This card eliminates that cognitive tax entirely. The monthly figure is the largest, boldest number on the card. A savings comparison line shows 'vs. $2,500/mo full-time lease' anchored to the guest's own stated reference frame. The per-night rate appears as a secondary detail. When the guest adjusts their schedule (adding or removing nights), the monthly figure animates smoothly from old value to new, providing the immediate feedback Csikszentmihalyi identifies as essential for flow. The card uses IBM Plex Mono for the savings line to signal data precision.

This component shows a week-long timeline with the guest's days in brand purple and the co-tenant's days in neutral gray, using the day-badge visual language from the style guide. Below the timeline, three concrete facts address the unasked questions: private storage, cleaning between transitions, and no overlap guarantee. The component uses calm, matter-of-fact language ('Your space, your schedule') rather than evocative metaphors. At discovery it shows the concept; at listing evaluation it shows the specific property's shared/private zones. Csikszentmihalyi's 'blind women' insight applies: guests who cannot see the shared-living reality need richer visual feedback to compensate.

elements.description: A persistent process tracker that addresses the two-to-three-week feedback void Shomit describes. When the agent tells him the process takes 'two or three weeks' (line 62), Shomit responds 'So like courtship' -- revealing he perceives the process as uncertain and open-ended. This tracker externalizes the process map as a persistent visual artifact visible on every authenticated page. It shows 5 named steps (Browse, Save, Match, Meet, Sign), the guest's current position highlighted in brand purple, a specific next action, and an estimated timeline. Between milestones, a heartbeat status line provides the 'watching plants grow day by day' feedback Csikszentmihalyi describes. The tracker is compact by default and expands on interaction to show all steps, preventing the process from feeling overwhelming while keeping progress visible. Each milestone completion triggers a smooth spring animation that provides symbolic 'I have succeeded' feedback.

elements.title: Comparison Grid - Side-by-Side Listing Evaluation
elements.description: A comparison grid that enables the landscape-first evaluation Shomit demands before any action. He refuses to bid three times, insisting 'No, I want to see what the other options are' (line 52). This grid presents 2-3 listings side by side with identical data points aligned in rows: monthly cost, neighborhood, available nights, and a property photo. Every card uses the same layout, same typography positions, and same spacing so the guest can scan columns without re-orienting. The guest's schedule is set once at the top and applies to all results. Csikszentmihalyi's challenge-skill balance applies: comparing from memory exceeds working memory capacity, but side-by-side visual comparison brings the challenge within the guest's 'capacity to act.' The grid includes persistent filter controls and a subtle inline prompt that only appears after the guest has viewed multiple listings: 'Ready to save your favorites?'

The phrasing 'is that allowed?' reveals two failures: the guest does not know physical viewing exists, and feels uncertain about his agency in the process. This section surfaces verification proactively between the photo gallery and the save button, positioned exactly where the guest's natural evaluation sequence expects it: see the listing, verify the space, then decide. It offers both 'Schedule a Visit' (if available) and 'Take Virtual Tour' (always available) as distinct pathways. A warm off-white background with a left border accent in brand purple visually differentiates it from surrounding content, creating a 'pause' in the page flow. Csikszentmihalyi's 'blind women' insight applies: guests who cannot see the physical reality need richer compensatory feedback.

elements.description: A preparation card delivered 24-48 hours before the Zoom co-tenant meeting, addressing the social anxiety Csikszentmihalyi identifies: 'if a person feels self-conscious, he or she will dread establishing informal contacts' (lines 295-296). The agent describes the meeting vaguely: 'you will meet on zoom that person, and you will talk to the tourist' (line 57). This card transforms an unstructured, anxiety-producing social interaction into a manageable, structured one. It includes: the co-tenant's first name and professional context, 5 suggested conversation questions, the same day-badge timeline showing the schedule split, and an explicit reassurance: 'You can decline after meeting. No obligation.' The card uses calm, normalizing language and the same visual continuity as the discovery co-tenancy diagram, so the guest recognizes it as a continuation of information they already absorbed.

elements.description: A weekly stays manager for the active lease phase that transforms the passive passage of time into visible engagement markers. Csikszentmihalyi's distinction between pleasure and enjoyment is directly relevant: a comfortable apartment provides pleasure, but the active lease phase must go beyond pleasure to create enjoyment -- 'a sense of novelty, of accomplishment' (line 139). This component shows the current week's schedule, an arrival checklist for move-in, a running history of completed stays, and a co-tenancy status indicator confirming the space was cleaned between transitions. Each week adds a completed stay to the timeline, providing the 'watching plants grow day by day' incremental feedback that sustains engagement across a multi-month lease. A micro-review prompt at each weekly stay cycle supports the review accumulation pattern identified across multiple pipeline runs. The component personalizes to the guest's specific schedule and property.

elements.name: Peer Proof Card with Similarity Badges
elements.description: A compact social proof card that surfaces a similar host's experience before any norm-breaking platform term is introduced. Similarity badges (city, experience years, property tier) appear at the top in mono pill format, with matched dimensions highlighted in solid purple. The outcome quote uses DM Sans for warmth. Designed to be scannable in under 5 seconds so the host processes 'someone like me accepted this' before encountering the deviation. Directly addresses John's rejection rooted in 'what we do in New York city' by showing that NYC landlords with comparable tenure have already accepted the model.

evidence.quote: What we do in New York city as when you sign the lease, you give the checks.
evidence.insight: John's rejection is normative, not financial. He cites collective NYC landlord behavior as the standard. A peer proof card must present counter-evidence from that same collective.

evidence.quote: The principle of social proof operates most powerfully when we are observing the behavior of people just like us.
evidence.insight: Similarity is the key multiplier. The wallet experiment showed 70% compliance from a similar model vs. 33% from a dissimilar one.

elements.html_css:

I had the same concern about payment timing. After my first guest checked in, the payment hit my account in 14 hours. Now I don't even think about it.

First payment received in 14 hours

From Michael R., Upper East Side landlord since 2013

elements.name: Two-Layer Proposal View with Tenant-First Gate
elements.description: A two-phase proposal layout that separates tenant evaluation (Layer A, white surface) from platform terms (Layer B, off-white surface). Layer A presents tenant details -- names, employment, credit, bedroom match -- and a confirmation button. Layer B only appears after the host confirms interest in the tenants. A transition bar acknowledges the positive evaluation before introducing platform mechanics. This directly addresses the pattern from John's call where cooperative tenant evaluation (02:12-03:50) was contaminated by resistant platform-terms evaluation (05:40+) because both were presented in a single undifferentiated stream.

evidence.quote: And do they have a job here in New York city? [...] No, it wasn't no work.
evidence.insight: John was cooperative during tenant evaluation but became resistant during platform terms. Separating these layers preserves the positive evaluation as an anchor.

evidence.quote: We view a behavior as more correct in a given situation to the degree that we see others performing it.
evidence.insight: Tenant evaluation uses familiar social proof (employment checks, credit checks). Platform terms require unfamiliar social proof. Separation allows each to use its appropriate evidence type.

elements.name: Directed Closure Card with Follow-Up Commitment
elements.description: A structured next-step closure card that replaces vague handoffs ('I'll talk to our team') with a specific WHO/WHAT/WHEN commitment. Uses a distinct blue-tinted info background with a left border accent to differentiate from other card types. The agent's name is bold, the timeline is in mono font for precision, and the host is assigned a small reciprocal action. Includes a visual countdown indicator. Directly addresses the conversion-killing vagueness at the end of John's call where Bryant said 'I can talk to our team and see if that's something we can make an exception for' with no name, no timeline, and no host action.

evidence.quote: I can talk to our team and see if that's something we can make an exception for.
evidence.insight: This closure has zero interaction structure: no named person, no timeline, no host action. The directed closure card replaces this dead-end with a structured, time-bound commitment.

evidence.quote: Stare, speak, and point directly at that person and no one else: 'You, sir, in the blue jacket, I need help. Call an ambulance.'
evidence.insight: Specificity eliminates the bystander effect. Naming a person with a specific task and deadline creates accountability.

elements.name: Payment Model Progressive Disclosure Pill
elements.description: A compact data pill used in first-touch materials (emails, landing pages) that previews the payment timing with the mechanism included from the start. Uses mono font on a purple-tinted background for data credibility. This prevents the false expectation that John formed when Bryant said 'guaranteed payments' at 01:31 without specifying timing, leading to a contradictory reveal at 05:56. The pill is designed to be the visual through-line across all three stages of progressive disclosure, appearing identically in first-touch, mid-conversation cards, and full detail views.

evidence.quote: Guaranteed payments to you as the landlord [...] the day after the first night that they stayed.
evidence.insight: The 4-minute gap between 'guaranteed payments' and the actual timing created a false expectation that was then contradicted.

evidence.quote: When we are unsure of ourselves, when the situation is unclear or ambiguous, when uncertainty reigns, we are most likely to look to and accept the actions of others as correct.
evidence.insight: Early, low-stakes exposure to the payment concept reduces the uncertainty spike when details arrive later.

elements.name: Norm Validation Bridge for Payment Terms
elements.description: A payment terms section that leads with norm validation before introducing the platform's model. The top tier acknowledges the host's existing practice ('Most experienced NYC landlords require payment at signing -- that makes sense'). The middle tier shows peer proof from a similar host who initially shared the same concern. The bottom tier presents the actual financial details in mono font. This three-tier layout reverses the current hierarchy (numbers first) to social framing first, addressing John's professional pride ('I've been in this business for a while') by validating his expertise before presenting the alternative as an evolution, not a replacement.

evidence.quote: I've been renting my apartment almost 12 years, back and forth.
evidence.insight: John's 12 years of experience represents professional identity, not just process. Dismissing this triggers defensive rejection.

evidence.quote: I give him my apartment completely. I trust him and they get, trust me too.
evidence.insight: Payment is a trust signal for John, not a financial transaction. The framing must address the trust dimension.

evidence.quote: Some evidence indicates that canned laughter is most effective for poor jokes.
evidence.insight: Social proof is most effective where the proposition is weakest. Payment timing is the platform's weakest proposition -- it needs the strongest social framing.

elements.html_css:

Most experienced NYC landlords require payment at signing -- and that practice exists for good reasons: trust, commitment, and security. Here is how landlords with your experience have expanded on that foundation.

elements.name: First Payment Celebration Notification
elements.description: A ceremonial first-payment notification that marks the emotional conversion point -- the moment theoretical trust becomes experiential trust. Displays the exact amount, exact timing, and comparison to the guaranteed timeline. Uses spring easing on the checkmark for a contained celebration. This is designed for the moment after a skeptical host like John receives their first payment: the notification transforms his 'they say it works' into 'it works.' Includes an invitation to share the experience, seeding the social proof flywheel for future hosts.

evidence.quote: I give him my apartment completely. I trust him and they get, trust me too.
evidence.insight: John's trust model requires proof through experience. The first payment arriving as promised is the moment his emotional framework shifts.

evidence.quote: Not only was this help rapid and solicitous, it was infectious.
evidence.insight: One successful experience creates an emotional cascade. If the host then shares their experience, the social proof flywheel begins.

elements.name: Reciprocal Commitment Response Card
elements.description: A reciprocal commitment card that appears immediately after a host takes a meaningful action (sharing property details, confirming availability). Shows the specific platform action being taken in response, with a timeline. Mirrors John's 'both ways' trust model where every investment expects a visible reciprocal investment. After the host confirms March 15 availability, the card shows that Ariel and Amber have been notified, employment letters are being prepared, and the deposit match is processing -- all specific to the host's action, not generic acknowledgments.

evidence.quote: I give him my apartment completely. I trust him and they get, trust me too.
evidence.insight: John's trust model is explicit reciprocity. The platform must mirror this: host gives, platform gives back visibly.

evidence.quote: It depends if they like it, you know, I liked them. Yeah. Because it's both ways.
evidence.insight: John evaluates relationships bidirectionally. Every unreciprocated host action tips the balance toward 'this is one-sided.'

evidence.quote: Not only was this help rapid and solicitous, it was infectious.
evidence.insight: Reciprocal action is infectious. When the platform visibly reciprocates, it establishes a norm of mutual investment.

elements.title: Eligibility Qualification Gate
elements.description: An inline eligibility checker for the guest discovery phase that surfaces hard service constraints (6-week minimum commitment, 3-week lead time) before any human interaction. Responds within 200ms to the prospect's input with warm, specific feedback about whether their need matches the platform. Prevents the Sophie Charvet pattern: ineligible prospects consuming agent time on calls that could have been self-qualified in 10 seconds. Uses Thaler/Sunstein's stimulus-response compatibility principle -- the discovery signal must match the actual service.

evidence.call_quote: I don't think we can help you with anything, um, before like three weeks. So is that the minimum commitment we require is minimum six weeks after that?
evidence.book_quote: The idea is that you want the signal you receive (the stimulus) to be consistent with the desired action. When there are inconsistencies, performance suffers and people blunder.

elements.title: Dead-End Redirect Card
elements.description: A structured three-tier redirect card shown when a prospect is confirmed ineligible. Tier 1 diagnoses the specific mismatch in concrete terms. Tier 2 reframes with the nearest viable alternative and a count. Tier 3 captures the prospect's email for future re-engagement. Replaces the verbal dead end from Sophie's call ('That's unfortunate that we cannot help you') with a designed, value-capturing path. Implements the Nudge 'Expect Error' principle: ineligible arrivals are predictable system events, not failures.

evidence.call_quote: That's unfortunate that we cannot help you. It's I'm sorry if you ever need something in this type of arrangement, but it was a little more lead time. We'll be happy to help you.
evidence.book_quote: Humans make mistakes. A well-designed system expects its users to err and is as forgiving as possible.

elements.title: Co-Tenancy Schedule Calendar
elements.description: An interactive weekly calendar visualization that replaces the agent's incomprehensible verbal explanation of the co-tenancy model. Shows guest days in active purple and co-tenant days in neutral gray, making the schedule split tangible at a glance. Each day responds to hover/tap with arrival and departure details. Implements Thaler/Sunstein's 'free taste' principle: the guest experiences the arrangement concretely before committing, just as the ice cream shop lets you taste before buying.

evidence.call_quote: The way we do it with the two people was complimentary schedule. So let's say for example, somebody needs Monday through Friday and somebody else needs Friday. So Monday they become, goes to amaze, which use the same space, but in different timeframes.
evidence.book_quote: Even if there are some exotic flavors, the ice cream store can solve the mapping problem by offering a free taste.

elements.title: Smart Default Proposal Form
elements.description: A proposal form pre-populated with smart defaults derived from the guest's search behavior and the listing's most common successful configuration. Transforms the proposal experience from blank-slate paralysis (the chef asking the diner to write the recipe) to prompted confirmation (the chef's recommendation that the diner can adjust). Pre-filled values appear in a visually muted state with source labels; edited values shift to full prominence. Implements Thaler/Sunstein's defaults principle: the path of least resistance becomes submitting a viable proposal rather than abandoning an empty form.

evidence.call_quote: I don't think we can help you with anything, um, before like three weeks. So is that the minimum commitment we require is minimum six weeks after that? Is that something which is going to work for you?
evidence.book_quote: Many people will take whatever option requires the least effort, or the path of least resistance... if, for a given choice, there is a default option, then we can usually expect a large number of people to end up with that option.

elements.description: A diff view that shows exactly what the host changed in their counter-proposal, displayed as before/after comparisons with only modified parameters expanded and unchanged parameters collapsed. Prevents the guest from misinterpreting a counter as a rejection. Implements the Nudge Give Feedback principle: the system provides specific, actionable feedback about what changed and what the guest should do, avoiding 'warning fatigue' from generic notifications.

evidence.call_quote: So is that the minimum commitment we require is minimum six weeks after that? Is that something which is going to work for you?
evidence.book_quote: Warning systems have to avoid the problem of offering so many warnings that they are ignored.

elements.title: Post-Acceptance Checkpoint Flow
elements.description: A sequential three-step forcing-function checkpoint flow for the acceptance-to-move-in transition. Each checkpoint is a compact card (5 key points, under 15 words each) gated behind acknowledgment of the previous step. Prevents postcompletion errors (Thaler/Sunstein's 'gas cap' problem) by making critical follow-up steps unavoidable. Uses positive framing ('Got it, next step') rather than legal language. Progress bar with purple completion indicators builds a sense of accomplishment rather than bureaucratic burden.

evidence.call_quote: This was just, uh, for the month of may actually.
evidence.book_quote: Leaving the gas cap behind is a special kind of mistake psychologists call a postcompletion error. The idea is that when you have finished your main task, you tend to forget things relating to previous steps.

Uses real, personalized savings data in monospace type to signal precision. Counterbalances the 'taxi meter' effect from Thaler/Sunstein: every per-stay task makes the arrangement's cost salient, so the benefit strip makes the arrangement's value equally salient. elements.name: Credibility Triad Strip
elements.description: A compact horizontal strip of three verifiable credibility markers displayed above the fold on any host-facing landing page. Answers Kent's three trust-gate questions  'What is your background?' (02:38), 'How old is this company?' (08:11), and 'How do I check you out?' (06:16)  before the proposition is even presented. Uses IBM Plex Mono for data points to signal precision and reliability. Campbell's herald must be credible for the Call to Adventure to register; this strip establishes institutional legitimacy in under 5 seconds so due-diligence hosts proceed to evaluation rather than closing the tab.

elements.problem_it_solves: Due-diligence hosts like Kent ask credibility questions before evaluating the proposition. Without visible credibility markers above the fold, hosts who discover Split Lease via the website (rather than a phone call) close the tab before the proposition is even read. Kent's relief at learning the company is 5 years old  'So it's not like you're a startup' (08:19)  shows a single credibility fact can shift the entire emotional posture from guarded to open.

elements.name: Evidence Ladder Rung
elements.description: A single rung in the sequential evidence ladder that mirrors the due-diligence host's natural question hierarchy. Each rung answers one question from Kent's 12-question evaluation sequence (01:13-09:31) using a three-layer typographic rhythm: DM Sans semibold headline (the answer), Inter regular body (supporting evidence), and IBM Plex Mono data point (the verifiable fact). Generous vertical spacing between rungs creates distinct visual landmarks along the evaluation path, mapping to Campbell's description of the hero encountering 'the dark forest, the great tree, the babbling spring'  each a discrete waypoint on the journey. Scroll-triggered entrance animation (translate-y 12px, fade in over 300ms) gives each answer its moment of attention.

visual_spec.layout: Vertical stack, max-width 640px, each rung in its own container

typography.data_point: 'IBM Plex Mono', monospace, 13px, font-weight 500, color var(--primary-purple) #31135D

interaction_spec.load_behavior: First rung visible on load. Subsequent rungs animate on scroll into viewport center (translate-y 12px to 0, opacity 0 to 1, 300ms ease-out).
interaction_spec.scroll_behavior: IntersectionObserver triggers entrance when rung enters central 60% of viewport. Fast scroll suppresses animation  rungs appear immediately.
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: All entrance animations disabled, full opacity on load

elements.problem_it_solves: Due-diligence hosts like Kent ask 12 questions in a natural hierarchy: proposition, credibility, economics, vetting, commitment, verification. The current platform has no mechanism to anticipate this sequence or present answers proactively. Hosts who visit the website alone must self-navigate to find answers that Kent extracted through 12 minutes of conversation. The evidence ladder presents these answers in the host's natural evaluation order, not the platform's marketing order.

elements.name: Protective Artifact Card
elements.description: A visually distinct card for threshold-crossing documents  success stories, sample contracts, policy documents. Uses a left-edge purple accent stripe to signal 'this protects you,' differentiating protective artifacts from generic content. Kent requests specific documents at specific emotionally charged moments: success stories (06:16), contracts (09:24), policies (10:02). Campbell calls these 'amulets against the dragon forces.' Each card names the artifact, explains its protective function in 2-3 sentences, shows metadata in mono, and provides a single action to view the full document. Optimistic reveal: container appears in 120ms, content cascades in 120-400ms.

interaction_spec.load_behavior: Optimistic reveal: card container + accent stripe appear in 120ms, title fades in at 160ms, summary at 240ms, metadata at 320ms, action at 400ms. Stagger creates unpacking feel.
interaction_spec.hover: Card shadow deepens to var(--shadow-md). Action text underlines.
interaction_spec.click_action: Opens full document inline (expand) or in new panel. Never navigates away from current context.
interaction_spec.error_state: Card container remains visible with summary. Inline error with retry below last loaded element. Never collapses back.
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: All cascade animations disabled, full content visible on load

elements.problem_it_solves: Kent requests protective artifacts at emotionally charged threshold moments. Currently these are delivered as plain links in an email batch  visually indistinguishable from any other link. The artifact card creates a distinct visual vocabulary for 'this protects you,' with the purple accent stripe immediately classifying the content as a protective document rather than marketing material.

elements.name: Vetting Evidence Grid
elements.description: A 2x2 grid of verification cells displayed within the guest proposal view, showing the four vetting categories Frederick described to Kent: employment, financial, documents, and references. Each cell shows a category icon, status indicator, and one-line result. Purple-tinted backgrounds for passed categories, amber-tinted for flagged. Expandable to reveal full verification details via accordion. Below the grid, a persistent payment guarantee line in IBM Plex Mono states the guaranteed amount  converting Frederick's verbal promise ('we will pay you because we are the one on that' at 03:35) into a visible, permanent platform feature. Campbell: 'for anyone with competence and courage the danger fades'  this grid provides the evidence Kent's competence needs to let his courage follow.

interaction_spec.show_all: Toggle at top of grid: 'Show all details' expands all four simultaneously.

elements.problem_it_solves: Kent's most anxiety-laden question is 'Do you do any vetting of these people?' (04:56). Frederick answers with a process description, but when Kent sees his first proposal, he needs to see the OUTPUT of vetting, not just be told it exists. A green 'Verified' badge is a claim, not evidence. This grid shows exactly what was verified and what was found, enabling the due-diligence host to make an evidence-based accept/reject decision rather than a trust-based one.

elements.name: Post-Call Review Progress Strip
elements.description: A compact horizontal progress indicator included in post-call follow-up emails and the host's platform landing page. Transforms the unstructured post-call void  Kent's 'I'll review it and I'll get back to you' (11:17)  into a visible, sequenced journey. Four labeled steps: Success Stories, Sample Contract, Policies, Follow-Up Call. The current step uses purple background with white text; completed steps use light purple with purple text; future steps use light gray with gray text. Thin connectors between steps signal sequence. Campbell warns that 'Refusal of the summons converts the adventure into its negative' when momentum dies; this strip prevents the post-call void from consuming the call's momentum by showing the host where they are and what comes next.

visual_spec.layout: Horizontal row of 4 step indicators with connectors, max-width 520px

interaction_spec.load_behavior: Static on load. Current step segment fills with a subtle 200ms ease-out animation on first render.
interaction_spec.click: Completed steps are clickable to revisit prior documents. Current and future steps are non-interactive.
interaction_spec.engagement_responsive: Progress advances when host engages with the current document (opens email + clicks link) plus 18-hour cooldown before next delivery.
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: Segment fill animation disabled, static rendering

copy_spec.email_context: Appears at top of each follow-up email: 'Step 2 of 4: Sample Contract'
dont: Send all documents in a single batch
Leave the follow-up timeline open-ended
Use generic marketing emails with no agent attribution

elements.problem_it_solves: Kent's call ends with maximum ambiguity: 'I'll review it and I'll get back to you' (11:17). Frederick sends all documents in a single batch. The post-call void has no visual stages, no progress indicator, and no temporal structure. This strip converts disconnected emails into a visible journey with forward momentum, preventing the 'dull case of the call unanswered' that Campbell warns about.

elements.name: Boundary Configuration Card
elements.description: A prominent, interactive card for setting host control boundaries  minimum stay duration, guest requirements, availability constraints. Kent explicitly rejects the 6-week minimum: 'I don't wanna do anything that short' (09:46). This card surfaces boundary configuration as the FIRST step of listing creation, not an advanced setting. The current value is displayed prominently in IBM Plex Mono at 20px, a segmented selector allows adjustment, and a live consequence preview updates in real time: 'Only proposals for 3+ month stays will reach you.' Campbell's Belly of the Whale describes participation as 'a form of self-annihilation'  this card ensures the host controls the terms of their transformation.

interaction_spec.confirmation: On save, brief message in agent voice: 'Frederick will enforce these terms on every proposal.' Fades after 4 seconds.

elements.problem_it_solves: Kent rejects the 6-week minimum ('I don't wanna do anything that short' at 09:46) but Frederick's verbal assurance ('you can set your listing for longer') has no product counterpart. If the listing wizard defaults to 6 weeks and buries the override in advanced settings, Kent either accepts a boundary that violates his standards or fails to find the control. This card makes boundary configuration the first, most prominent step  respecting that for due-diligence hosts, setting terms is a precondition for participation, not an afterthought.

elements.name: Agent Continuity Banner
elements.description: A persistent, compact banner at the top of every authenticated host page showing the assigned agent's avatar, name, contextual status, and one-tap contact button. Kent's entire trust relationship is with Frederick, not Split Lease. Campbell describes the supernatural aid as 'the benign, protecting power of destiny' whose presence reassures the hero. When Kent transitions from the phone call to the platform, the visual environment changes completely. If the platform makes no reference to Frederick, the guardian vanishes and the hero is alone at the threshold. This banner maintains Frederick's presence digitally  not as decoration, but as the persistent assurance that the protective figure is accessible. Status line updates contextually: 'Available until 6pm' on dashboard, 'I vetted this guest  take a look' on proposal view.

visual_spec.layout: Horizontal banner, full width, fixed height 52px, fixed position or sticky top

color_usage.contact_button: var(--secondary-purple) text, transparent bg, pill border

interaction_spec.status_update: Status line crossfades (200ms) on context changes (page navigation, new events).
interaction_spec.contact_tap: Opens direct communication channel (message, call, or text based on host preference). Zero intermediary screens. No chatbot. No ticket system.
interaction_spec.mobile_collapse: On viewports < 480px, collapses to avatar + contact icon only. Expands on tap to show full name and status.
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: Crossfade instant

Frederick I vetted this guest take a look at their profile
elements.problem_it_solves: Kent's trust is with Frederick personally, not with Split Lease as an institution. Every protective promise came from Frederick: payment guarantee (03:35), vetting assurance (05:05), success stories (06:29), personal phone number (11:00). When the call ends and the platform begins, if the first interaction is a system-generated email from 'Split Lease Support,' the guardian has vanished. The trust built in 12 minutes is destroyed in 12 seconds of impersonal interface. This banner maintains the human guardian's presence across every digital touchpoint.

elements.title: The Presumptive Schedule Correction
elements.description: A lease duration slider that defaults to a 'Standard 12-week Project Stay'. By providing an intentional (but potentially slightly incorrect) anchor, it triggers the guest's 'Need to Correct,' forcing them to specify their exact 16-week or custom requirement with higher accuracy than an empty field.

-40% OFF

elements.title: The Expert Commuter Questionnaire
elements.description: Uses 'Ego Stroking' to elicit high-quality vetting data. Instead of asking 'Are you loud?', it asks the guest for their 'professional insight' on maintaining a quiet environment for other working professionals, which encourages them to describe their own behavior in a positive, self-affirming way.
elements.html_css:
Professional Habit Validation

As a professional commuter, what is your preferred strategy for ensuring a 'Zero-Impact' presence during the work week?

Hosts value the expertise of long-term commuters in maintaining shared space harmony.
elements.psychological_trigger: The Need to be the Expert

elements.title: The 'Commuter Priority' False Constraint
elements.description: Presents the listing with a 'False Constraint' that it is optimized specifically for Monday-Friday stays. This forces the guest to reveal their true scheduling priorities and flexibility (e.g., Theodore admitting he is a weekend commuter) without being asked a direct question about his schedule.
elements.html_css:
Commuter Optimization Constraint

This room is currently reserved for professionals who vacate during weekends. Does this limitation align with your schedule?

elements.title: The Airbnb Pretext Trust Badge
elements.description: Directly addresses the 'No-Visit' anxiety by using Airbnb as a pretext for safety. It frames the 24-hour verification period as a standard 'Guest Protection' feature, normalizing the lack of physical viewing through familiarity.
elements.html_css:
AIRBNB MODEL
Booking Protection Protocol

Like Airbnb, your payment is held in escrow. You have 24 hours after move-in to verify the property or get a full refund.

elements.title: The 'Why' Persona Selector
elements.description: Instead of an open-ended 'Reason for stay' box, this uses 'Labeling' and 'Elicitation' to get the user's persona. By selecting a label like 'Project Specialist' or 'Weekend Professional,' the user provides high-context vetting data without feeling interrogated.
elements.html_css:
Which profile best describes your stay?

Weekend Professional
I work in the city and head home for weekends.
Project Specialist
I'm here for a fixed-term contract (e.g. 12-16 weeks).

elements.name: Discovery Earnings Estimator Card
elements.description: A self-contained earnings card shown to prospective hosts before any registration or sign-up is required. It surfaces local market demand, average host earnings, and guest search volume -- all without asking the host for a single piece of information. Freud's insight that premature civilizational demands trigger instinctual revolt ('we should be much happier if we were to give it up') informs the zero-ask design: the host sees value before the platform asks for anything. The card implements the L1 graduated renunciation principle (value precedes every disclosure), the L2 progressive disclosure architecture (platform gives before it takes), the L3 warm containment pattern, the L4 protective error handling, and the L5 pre-civilizational curiosity emotion (generous demonstration without threshold crossing).

visual_spec.layout: Single card, max-width 480px, centered. Top section: headline earnings figure. Middle section: three supporting metrics in a horizontal row. Bottom section: soft CTA text link, no button.

color_usage.earnings_figure: var(--primary-purple, #31135D) -- brand authority for the headline number
color_usage.metric_icons: var(--secondary-purple, rgb(109, 49, 194)) -- interactive-level purple for visual anchors
color_usage.background_tint: var(--bg-off-white, rgb(252, 250, 255)) -- warm purple tint signals safety before content is read

interaction_spec.load_behavior: Content fades in with a 400ms ease-out upward drift. Earnings figure appears first (staggered 100ms before supporting metrics). No loading spinner -- the card renders with cached or geo-estimated data instantly.
interaction_spec.hover: CTA link underlines on hover with a 200ms transition. Card itself has no hover state -- it should feel like a generous offer, not an interactive target.
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: All fade and drift animations are disabled. Content appears immediately in its final position.

copy_spec.headline: $3,200/mo
copy_spec.subhead: Average host earnings in your area
dont: Never use urgency language ('Limited spots!', 'Sign up now!')
Never ask a question before giving an answer
Never frame the host's current situation as a problem

elements.html_css:
$3,200/mo

Average host earnings in your area

47 professionals

Active searches

12 weeks

Avg. stay length

4.8 / 5

Host satisfaction

Vetted professionals in your neighborhood are looking for weekday spaces. See what your place could earn -- no sign-up required.

See how your space compares
elements.problem_it_solves: Hosts in discovery bounce when the platform demands registration before demonstrating value. Freud identifies this as premature civilizational demand that violates the pleasure principle. This card delivers concrete local earnings data, demand signals, and satisfaction proof without asking for a single piece of information -- protecting the host's pre-civilizational curiosity and making the first contact feel generous rather than extractive.

elements.name: Listing Wizard Progress Card with Auto-Save
elements.description: A dashboard card that shows the host's listing creation progress with a visual completion bar, step-by-step status, and one-click resume or pause controls. This card embodies Freud's insight that listing creation is the peak of instinctual renunciation -- converting private space into public artifact. The auto-save indicator reassures the host that every keystroke is preserved (L4 wizard save-and-resume), the completion bar uses the evidence typographic register to make progress precise (L3 typography), the pause button is frictionless while delete is buried (L4 cautious reversible flows), and the copy treats each step as a dignified exchange rather than a form (L5 dignified surrender). Amber urgency indicators flag incomplete steps without alarm (L3 urgency amber).

visual_spec.layout: Card with 16px padding all around. Top row: listing name + auto-save indicator. Progress bar below. Step checklist with icons. Bottom row: Resume CTA + Pause text link.

color_usage.amber_badge: #c17a28 on #fef3e2 background for steps needing attention

interaction_spec.load_behavior: Card renders instantly from cached draft state. Auto-save indicator shows 'Saved' with a small check icon. If no draft exists, card is not shown.
interaction_spec.hover: Resume button shifts to gradient-purple-hover. Pause link underlines. Step rows highlight with a subtle bg-light tint on hover.
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: Progress bar fill appears at its current width without animation. Check icons appear without fade.

copy_spec.encouragement: Your space is looking great. Two more steps to publish.
dont: Never say 'Your listing is only X% complete' -- frame progress positively
Never use bare imperatives ('Upload photos', 'Set your price')
Never treat the wizard as a form -- each step is a dignified exchange

elements.html_css:
2BR Williamsburg Walk-Up

Saved just now

Your space is looking great. Two more steps to publish.

4 of 6 steps complete

  • Space details
  • Features & amenities
  • Lease style
  • Pricing
  • House rules
  • Photos
elements.problem_it_solves: Hosts abandon the listing wizard at the peak of instinctual renunciation because their investment is not visibly preserved and there is no dignified exit. Freud warns that 'if the deprivation is not made good economically, one may be certain of producing serious disorders.' This card makes every step's progress visible and saved, provides a frictionless pause that preserves all work, and frames completion as building an achievement rather than filling out a form.

elements.name: Host Dashboard Urgency-First Action Panel
elements.description: The top section of the host dashboard that surfaces action-required items with amber urgency indicators, structured as Freud's civilizational order -- predictable, fixed-position, and anxiety-reducing. This panel implements the L2 urgency-first dashboard hierarchy (action required at top, always), the L3 ritual visual cadence (identical layout every visit), the L3 amber-not-red urgency system (warm attention without alarm), the L4 ritual cadence interaction (stay cycle beats surfaced here), and the L5 civilizational rhythm emotion (sustained calm through predictable structure). The panel never rearranges; the host always knows where to look.

visual_spec.layout: Full-width panel at the top of the dashboard. Contains up to 5 action items in a vertical stack. Each item is a single row: icon + description + deadline + primary action button.
visual_spec.border: none (panel is the top zone; border-bottom 1px solid var(--border-color, #e5e7eb) separates it from the status zone below)

color_usage.urgency_badge: #c17a28 text on #fef3e2 background -- warm amber, never red

interaction_spec.load_behavior: Panel renders as the first content on the dashboard. Items appear in urgency order (nearest deadline first). If no actions are pending, the panel shows a calm empty state: 'No pending actions right now. Your listings are active.'
interaction_spec.hover: Individual action items highlight with bg-light tint. Action button underlines on hover.
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: No animations. Items render in their final state immediately.

example_items: New proposal from Sarah Chen -- Respond by Feb 21
Date change request from Marcus -- Review
copy_spec.empty_state: Nothing needs your attention right now. Your listings are active and visible to guests.
dont: Never use red badges for routine attention items -- only for errors
Never mix informational items into the action panel
Never change the panel's position on the page across visits

elements.html_css:
Needs your attention

  • New proposal from Sarah Chen

    Respond by Feb 21

  • 2BR Williamsburg listing is 67% complete

    2 steps remaining

  • Date change request from Marcus

    Awaiting your approval
elements.problem_it_solves: Hosts waste mental energy scanning a disordered dashboard to find what needs their attention. Freud identifies order as 'a kind of repetition-compulsion by which doubt and hesitation shall be avoided.' This fixed-position panel surfaces urgent items first, every visit, in the same place, using warm amber signals that motivate action without triggering the alarm response that red would produce.

elements.name: Proposal Review Card with Trust-First Architecture
elements.description: A proposal card that resolves the host's stranger-threat anxiety by placing guest trust signals (verification, lease history, review rating, stated purpose) above proposal terms (dates, pricing, duration). Freud's Ch V insight that 'men are not gentle, friendly creatures' informs the architecture: the host's instinctual distrust of the stranger must be resolved before they can rationally evaluate terms. The card implements L1 structured proposals as civilizational compliance signals, L2 stranger-threat reduction through the trust-before-terms scan order, L2 bidirectional protection framing on the action buttons, L3 purple authority on trust badges, L3 evidence register for verification data, L4 optimistic commit on accept, and L5 empowered gatekeeping emotion.

visual_spec.layout: Card divided into three zones: Trust Zone (top, purple-tinted), Terms Zone (middle, white), Action Zone (bottom, white with purple CTA). Max-width 520px.
visual_spec.background: Trust zone: var(--bg-off-white, rgb(252, 250, 255)). Terms zone: var(--bg-white, #ffffff). Action zone: var(--bg-white, #ffffff).

interaction_spec.load_behavior: Trust zone renders first (100ms stagger before terms appear). Verification badge and lease count are the first visible data points. Accept button uses optimistic commit -- instant success state, background server call.
interaction_spec.hover: Accept button shifts to gradient-purple-hover. Counter and Decline links underline on hover. Guest avatar has a subtle purple ring on hover.
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: No stagger. All zones render simultaneously. Accept transition is instantaneous.

copy_spec.stated_purpose: Works at Deloitte, needs a weekday space near Midtown for 10 weeks starting March 1.
dont: Never lead with financial terms before trust evidence
Never use urgency language that pressures acceptance
Never label decline as 'Reject' -- use 'Decline'

elements.html_css:
SC

Sarah Chen

Verified

3 leases

Completed

4.9

Avg rating

2025

Member since

Works at Deloitte, needs a weekday space near Midtown for 10 weeks starting March 1.

Dates

Mar 1 -- May 10

10 weeks
