$185/night
elements.problem_it_solves: Hosts freeze or decline proposals because they encounter financial terms before resolving the fundamental question: is this stranger safe? Freud identifies that 'men are not gentle, friendly creatures' and the host's instinct defaults to distrust when trust evidence is buried. This card places verification status, lease history, rating, and stated purpose above all terms, resolving the stranger-threat question within 3 seconds of opening the proposal.

elements.name: Bidirectional Protection Confirmation Dialog
elements.description: A warm, purple-tinted confirmation surface that replaces standard modal dialogs at every point where the platform enforces a rule (date changes, proposal actions, schedule modifications). It leads with a protection headline and shield icon, shows the bidirectional constraint in parallel statements, and offers a single clear action. Freud's 'first requisite of culture is justice -- the assurance that a law once made will not be broken in favour of any individual' drives the design: the host sees both what they cannot do unilaterally and what the guest also cannot do, making the constraint feel like mutual safety rather than one-sided bureaucracy. Implements L1 justice-not-bureaucracy, L2 bidirectional framing, L3 protection surface visual, L4 bidirectional acknowledgment behavior, and L5 safety emotion.

visual_spec.layout: Centered surface (max-width 440px) over a subtle 10% opacity dark backdrop. Three sections stacked: shield icon + headline, two parallel constraint statements, action buttons.

color_usage.surface_bg: var(--protocol-surface, #F7F2FA) -- warm purple tint, not cold white

interaction_spec.load_behavior: Surface fades in over 200ms ease-out with a subtle backdrop. Focus is trapped inside the dialog. Shield icon and headline are announced first to screen readers.
interaction_spec.hover: Primary button darkens slightly. Secondary button background tints to bg-light on hover.
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: Surface appears immediately without fade. Backdrop appears without transition.

copy_spec.headline: Both parties are protected
copy_spec.statement_1: Sarah cannot change your agreed schedule without your approval.
copy_spec.statement_2: You also cannot change the schedule without Sarah's agreement.
copy_spec.summary: This keeps things fair for both of you.
dont: Never lead with the restriction ('Date changes require mutual approval')
Never use legal language ('Per the lease agreement...')
Never use punitive framing ('Failure to respond will result in...')
Never use red for the secondary action unless it is genuinely destructive

elements.html_css:
Both parties are protected

Sarah cannot change your agreed schedule without your approval.

You also cannot change the schedule without Sarah's agreement.

This keeps things fair for both of you.
elements.problem_it_solves: Hosts experience platform rules as one-sided bureaucratic constraints, developing what Freud calls 'antagonism against civilization' that accumulates toward exit at retention. Standard confirmation dialogs feel like legal notices. This protection dialog leads with a shield icon and 'Both parties are protected' headline, presents reciprocal constraints in visual parallel, and transforms the host's experience from 'I am being controlled' to 'I am being protected.'

elements.name: Stay Cycle Ritual Card
elements.description: A per-stay card within the Stays Manager that tracks the three-beat ritual cadence: arrival confirmation, cleaning photo submission, and micro-review. Freud identifies 'order as a kind of repetition-compulsion by which doubt and hesitation shall be avoided' -- this card is that order made concrete. It uses the exact same layout for every stay cycle so the host knows where to find each piece of information without searching. The cleaning photo thumbnail grid (2x2) provides instant visual evidence that the space was respected. The card implements L1 repetitive rituals for anxiety containment, L2 ritual confirmation cadence (three signals at predictable intervals), L3 ritual visual cadence (fixed layout never rearranges), L3 warm containment, L4 three-beat interaction pattern, and L5 civilizational rhythm emotion (sustained calm through predictability).

visual_spec.layout: Card with fixed internal grid: Top row (guest avatar + dates + status badge), middle section (2x2 cleaning photo grid), bottom row (micro-review prompt or summary). Max-width 480px. Layout identical for every stay.

interaction_spec.load_behavior: Card renders from cached stay data. Status badge updates within 1 second of guest confirmation (arrival or cleaning). Photo thumbnails populate progressively as each photo uploads. No loading spinners.
interaction_spec.hover: Photo thumbnails scale up slightly (1.02x) with a subtle shadow on hover, indicating they can be tapped to enlarge. Review prompt underlines on hover.
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: Photo thumbnails appear without scale animation. Status badge updates without slide transition.

copy_spec.cleaning_pending: Cleaning photos pending -- we have reminded Sarah
copy_spec.all_clear: All clear. Your space is in good hands.
dont: Never over-celebrate routine compliance ('Amazing! Photos submitted!')
Never alarm on delayed rituals ('WARNING: Photos not received!')
Never change the card layout between stays

elements.html_css:
SC

Stay 8 of 10

Feb 17 -- Feb 20 · Sarah Chen

Cleaning Submitted
Arrival confirmed
Cleaning photos
Review

Cleaning photos submitted. Your space looks great.
elements.problem_it_solves: During the active lease, hosts experience recurring anxiety about whether the stranger in their space is respecting the arrangement. Information voids between stays fill with worry. Freud's order principle -- 'repetition-compulsion by which doubt and hesitation shall be avoided' -- prescribes predictable rituals. This card provides three structured beats (arrival, cleaning, review) in an identical layout every cycle, giving the host regular evidence that the civilizational contract is holding.

elements.name: Hosting Summary and Retention Continuation Card
elements.description: A celebration card that appears 24 hours after the final stay of a lease, presenting the host's cumulative hosting record before offering a one-action continuation path. Freud's 'narcissism of minor differences' predicts that the host's retrospective assessment will anchor on small grievances unless counteracted by visible cumulative evidence. This card implements L1 host identity as civilizational binding (cumulative narrative raises exit cost), L2 cumulative investment narrative (total earnings, stays, ratings as a scannable summary), L3 evidence display at hero scale (36px earnings in brand purple), L3 evidence typographic register, L4 one-action continuation (re-listing as continuation, not restart), and L5 retrospective worth emotion (accomplishment as the target feeling). The 'Continue Hosting' CTA reactivates the existing listing in one tap -- no wizard, no rebuild.

visual_spec.layout: Card with generous padding. Hero earnings figure at top. Three supporting metrics in a horizontal row. Hosting timeline bar. Continue Hosting CTA. Max-width 520px.

color_usage.hero_earnings: var(--primary-purple, #31135D) -- largest number on the card, brand authority
color_usage.timeline_fill: var(--secondary-purple, rgb(109, 49, 194)) at varying opacity per lease

interaction_spec.load_behavior: Card appears on the dashboard 24 hours after the final stay. Metrics enter with a staggered fade-in: hero earnings first, then supporting metrics 100ms apart, then timeline, then CTA. Continue Hosting uses optimistic commit -- listing reactivates instantly.
interaction_spec.hover: CTA button shifts to gradient-purple-hover. Secondary link underlines on hover. Timeline segments show tooltip with lease details on hover.
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: All metrics appear simultaneously. No stagger or fade animation. CTA appears in final state.

copy_spec.earnings_label: Total earned since you started hosting
dont: Never present re-listing as a new decision ('Ready to host again?')
Never surface negative data in the retention summary
Never introduce new demands at the retention moment ('Update your photos first')
Never use urgency language ('Don't lose your hosting streak!')

elements.html_css:
Your 3rd lease is complete.

$12,400

Total earned since you started hosting

28 stays

Successful

4.8

Avg rating

14 mo

Hosting tenure

Your hosting journey across 3 leases
elements.problem_it_solves: At retention, hosts perform a retrospective cost-benefit analysis where Freud's 'narcissism of minor differences' anchors on small grievances rather than cumulative benefits. Without a visible counter-narrative, the host remembers the one bad week instead of the $12,400 earned. This card presents cumulative evidence at hero scale before any re-listing prompt, frames continuation as a one-tap action (not a restart), and positions the host's record as an achievement worth preserving -- counteracting the natural drift toward exit.

elements.name: Progressive Density Listing Card
elements.description: A three-tier listing card that reveals progressively richer information as the guest interacts, implementing Csikszentmihalyi's complexity ratchet at the search level. Tier 1 (default) shows photo, price, location, and an availability dot. Tier 2 (hover) lifts the card and reveals neighborhood name, image count, host response time, and a save icon. Tier 3 (expanded drawer) slides up transit proximity, a mini availability strip, and a Message Host quick-action. This prevents the A2 boredom zone by matching growing search skill with escalating card complexity, as the user stories demand: 'richer hover states, image counters, availability indicators -- all without leaving the search grid.'

visual_spec.layout: Vertical card, 280px width on desktop grid. Hero photo at full bleed top (aspect 3:2). Content area below with 12px internal padding. Hover content appears as an overlay band at photo bottom. Expanded drawer slides up from card bottom edge, max 64px height.
visual_spec.background: var(--bg-white, #ffffff); card surface uses var(--bg-off-white, rgb(252,250,255)) on hover for warmth

interaction_spec.load_behavior: Cards fade in from opacity 0 to 1 over 200ms ease-out as they enter viewport. Staggered by 50ms per card for a wave effect.
interaction_spec.hover: Card lifts via transform translateY(-2px) and shadow transitions from --shadow-sm to --shadow-purple-md over 0.2s ease-in-out. Tier 2 content fades in simultaneously. Image count badge appears top-right of photo in a frosted pill. Save heart icon appears top-left at 80% opacity, brightens to 100% on icon hover.
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: All transforms and opacity transitions resolve instantly. Card gains a 2px solid var(--secondary-purple) border instead of lift effect.

dont: Use generic 'View Listing' CTA
Show 'Rooms for rent' as category label
Display full address before listing click
Show lease terms on the card

elements.html_css:
1/8

$850/night

Williamsburg, near the L

Responds in 2hrs4.8 stars
3 min to L train
elements.problem_it_solves: Guests whose search skills outgrow flat listing cards enter Csikszentmihalyi's boredom zone (A2) and disengage. Progressive density keeps growing-skill guests in the flow channel by matching their readiness with escalating visual and informational complexity, all without leaving the search grid.

elements.name: Living Map with Proximity Feedback
elements.description: A map component that responds to every guest interaction with contextual visual feedback, implementing Flow's feedback condition at the spatial exploration level. Pins scale based on cursor proximity, neighborhood boundaries fade in on dwell, and price labels appear at zoom thresholds. The user stories demand a map that 'feels alive' with 'the feeling that something is happening' -- this component delivers that aliveness through continuous micro-responses that transform passive map browsing into an active discovery flow activity.

visual_spec.layout: Full-height map panel beside the listing grid (50/50 split on desktop, full-screen toggle on mobile). Map occupies right half with floating controls.
visual_spec.background: Map tiles with standard cartographic styling
visual_spec.border: 1px solid var(--border-color, #e5e7eb) on left edge separating from grid

interaction_spec.load_behavior: Pins appear with scale animation (0.8 to 1.0) over 200ms ease-out as map loads. Pins within viewport render first, off-screen pins load on pan.
interaction_spec.hover: Pins scale based on cursor proximity: 8px at rest, 12px within 60px radius, 16px at cursor nearest. Scaling uses transition 0.1s ease. On 500ms+ dwell in a neighborhood zone, translucent boundary fades in with floating label. Price labels appear at zoom level 14+.
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: All pin scaling resolves instantly. Neighborhood boundaries appear without fade. Price labels appear without animation.

dont: Show exact addresses on pins
Display listing details in map tooltips beyond price
Use color alone to differentiate pin states
Add marketing copy to the map surface

elements.html_css:
Williamsburg
Bushwick
$850

$920

$720

MMyrtle-Wyckoff - 5 min
elements.problem_it_solves: A static map with unresponsive pins violates Flow's feedback condition -- the guest explores spatially but receives no signal that exploration is productive. This component makes the map 'feel alive' by responding to every interaction with contextual richness, transforming passive pin-scanning into active neighborhood discovery.

elements.name: Conversational Message Composer
elements.description: A message composer that transforms the highest cross-activation moment into a social flow activity by showing the host's profile alongside the compose area. It implements Csikszentmihalyi's insight that social interactions are the most powerful flow generators. The host's photo, name, response time, and suggested questions reduce the self-consciousness that destroys flow, while the contextual framing ('Ask Jessica about the room in Williamsburg') turns a form submission into a conversation starter. This is the intermediate challenge between evaluation and proposal that the user stories identify: 'Once someone messages a host, the path to a proposal gets shorter, not longer.'

visual_spec.layout: Slide-up panel from bottom of listing page (mobile) or side panel 380px width (desktop). Two-column internal: host profile strip (left/top) + compose area (right/bottom).
visual_spec.border: 1px solid var(--border-color, #e5e7eb); top border-radius var(--rounded-2xl, 16px) on mobile
visual_spec.border_radius: var(--rounded-2xl, 16px) top corners on mobile; var(--rounded-xl, 12px) on desktop panel

interaction_spec.load_behavior: Panel slides up from bottom over 300ms ease-out. Host profile photo loads first (from cache), response time data populates within 500ms. Suggested question pills fade in staggered by 50ms.
interaction_spec.hover: Suggestion pills darken background on hover. Send button shows subtle scale pulse (0.97 to 1.0) on click. After send, button transitions to checkmark icon with brief purple pulse confirmation.
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: Panel appears instantly without slide. All micro-animations resolve instantly. Confirmation uses color change instead of animation.

copy_spec.post_send: Message sent. [Host Name] usually replies within [X] hours.
copy_spec.next_action: While you wait, explore similar rooms nearby
dont: Use 'Submit inquiry' or 'Send contact request'
Show Subject field -- this is a conversation, not an email
Leave guest in a void after sending with no estimated reply time
Add pressure like 'Hosts prefer detailed messages with dates and budget'

elements.html_css:
Jessica

Usually responds in 3 hours

Curious about this room in Williamsburg?
elements.problem_it_solves: The gap between listing evaluation and proposal creation is the widest emotional chasm in the guest journey -- the guest desires the space but the proposal feels too final. Messaging provides the intermediate Flow challenge that builds confidence and connection, transforming a solitary evaluator into a social participant and making the path to proposal shorter, not longer.

elements.name: Pre-Populated Proposal Builder with Host Preview
elements.description: A proposal form that arrives pre-populated with listing data, implements real-time price feedback, and shows a host-view preview before submission. This directly addresses Csikszentmihalyi's warning that self-consciousness permanently excludes people from enjoyment. Instead of blank fields that maximize anxiety, the guest sees their proposal assembling itself from known data -- transforming 'figure out and fill in' into 'review and confirm.' The staggered pre-population animation communicates 'the system prepared this for you,' and the host-view preview replaces the worry 'will this look right?' with the knowledge 'this is what it looks like.'

visual_spec.layout: Single column form, max-width 520px, centered below listing content. Listing summary card at top (photo thumbnail + address + price), form fields in middle, host-view preview card + submit button at bottom.
visual_spec.border: Form sections separated by 1px solid var(--border-color, #e5e7eb)
visual_spec.border_radius: var(--rounded-xl, 12px) for outer container; var(--rounded-lg, 8px) for preview card

interaction_spec.load_behavior: Form expands downward from listing content (height 0 to auto, 300ms ease-out). Pre-populated fields fill in with 50ms stagger animation -- each value appears sequentially, creating a 'being prepared for you' effect. Price total calculates and appears last with a brief purple highlight pulse.
interaction_spec.hover: Date fields show calendar picker on focus. Price total updates in real-time as dates change with 400ms highlight pulse. Submit button shows scale pulse (0.97) on click, transitions to progress indicator, then checkmark on success.
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: Form appears instantly. Pre-populated fields appear simultaneously. Price updates without color pulse. Submit resolves to checkmark without animation.

copy_spec.message_placeholder: Introduce yourself or ask a question...
copy_spec.preview_heading: This is what [Host Name] will see
copy_spec.reassurance_text: You can modify this before [Host Name] accepts.
copy_spec.trust_micro: Payment held securely until 48hrs after move-in
copy_spec.post_submit: Your proposal is on its way to [Host Name]. Hosts typically respond within 24 hours.
dont: Use 'Submit' or 'Commit to Lease' on the button
Show legal disclaimers before the form content
Leave fields blank with robotic placeholders like 'MM/DD/YYYY'
Add 'Reason for stay' or 'Employment status' fields

elements.html_css:

elements.problem_it_solves: Blank proposal forms maximize the self-consciousness that Csikszentmihalyi identifies as a permanent bar to enjoyment. The guest worries about 'creating the wrong impression' when every field demands content they must generate from scratch. Pre-populated fields, real-time price feedback, and a host-view preview replace anxiety with confidence, transforming proposal creation from a scary form into a guided assembly.

elements.name: Collaborative Negotiation Comparison Card
elements.description: A side-by-side comparison interface that transforms negotiation from a binary accept/reject verdict into a collaborative agon (Csikszentmihalyi's term for competitive games where opponents 'seek together'). Changed elements are highlighted with pre-calculated financial impact, market calibration data provides context for evaluating reasonableness, and a 'Suggest a modification' option gives the guest agency beyond yes or no. This prevents the alienation Csikszentmihalyi describes as being 'constrained by the social system to act in ways that go against their goals.'

visual_spec.layout: Full-width card with two-column comparison: 'Your proposal' (left) vs 'Jessica's adjustment' (right). Changed values highlighted. Financial impact summary below. Three action buttons at bottom.

interaction_spec.load_behavior: Card slides in alongside the original proposal context over 300ms ease-out. Changed elements pulse briefly with an amber highlight that settles to the purple tint background. Financial impact number counts up over 500ms.
interaction_spec.hover: Action buttons show standard hover states. 'Suggest a modification' expands to reveal guided fields for which elements to adjust. Market context tooltip appears on hover over the context bar.
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: Card appears instantly. Changed elements show highlight without pulse. Financial impact number appears without count animation.

copy_spec.heading: Jessica adjusted the terms
copy_spec.host_pattern: Jessica has accepted modifications in [X] of [Y] past negotiations
dont: Use 'Counter-offer received' as adversarial framing
Present only Accept/Decline without a modify path
Force the guest to calculate differences mentally
Add urgency pressure like 'Expires in 24 hours'

elements.problem_it_solves: A binary accept/reject negotiation interface creates what Csikszentmihalyi calls alienation: the guest is constrained to act against their goals. Without calibration data, the guest experiences anomie -- they cannot tell if the counter is fair. This component resolves both by providing market context, pre-calculated impact, and a modification path that transforms negotiation from a verdict into collaborative skill-stretching.

elements.name: Acceptance Celebration and Orientation Bridge
elements.description: A two-beat acceptance experience that first celebrates the guest's completed journey (acknowledging their transformation from searcher to resident) and then immediately orients them toward move-in preparation. Csikszentmihalyi warns that A4 (the peak flow state after acceptance) 'does not represent a stable situation either' -- without a new challenge, engagement collapses into post-decision anxiety. The celebration beat rewards psychic energy invested; the orientation beat channels it into the next flow activity. This prevents the post-acceptance vacuum where worry accumulates between confirmation and move-in.

visual_spec.layout: Full-width confirmation card centered on page. Top section: listing photo (large), host name, confirmed terms rendered as a welcome summary. Bottom section: 'What happens next' timeline with 3-4 steps. Max-width 600px.
visual_spec.background: var(--bg-off-white, rgb(252,250,255)) for outer area; var(--bg-white, #ffffff) for card

interaction_spec.load_behavior: Card expands from center over 400ms ease-out. Listing photo scales gently from 0.95 to 1.0. A single subtle purple glow ring pulses once around the card (800ms) and fades. Timeline steps appear staggered by 100ms after the celebration section settles.
interaction_spec.hover: Timeline steps highlight on hover with left-border color shift to purple. CTA buttons show standard hover states.
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: Card appears instantly without animation. Glow ring uses opacity change (0 to 0.3 to 0) instead of shadow pulse. Timeline steps appear simultaneously.

copy_spec.confirmation_line: You and [Host Name] agreed on [duration] at $[rate]/night starting [date].
copy_spec.step_1: Today: Lease documents arrive via email
copy_spec.step_2: This week: Access your House Manual
copy_spec.journey_acknowledgment: After exploring [N] rooms and messaging [N] hosts, you found your place.
dont: Reduce to 'Proposal accepted. Transaction ID: 48291'
Use legal language in the celebration moment
Leave the guest without a next step after 'Congratulations!'
Add friction like 'Complete your profile to unlock House Manual'

elements.problem_it_solves: The current acceptance experience reduces a multi-phase journey culmination to a confirmation dialog. Csikszentmihalyi says flow activities 'transformed the self by making it more complex' -- acceptance should honor that transformation. Without immediate orientation toward move-in, the guest's elevated engagement collapses into post-decision anxiety as A4 becomes unstable without a new challenge.

elements.name: Evolving Stays Manager with Complexity Ratchet
elements.description: A Stays Manager page design that evolves across three lifecycle phases (orientation, rhythm, reflection) within a stable layout skeleton, implementing Csikszentmihalyi's complexity ratchet for the platform's highest-frequency touchpoint. Visited 13+ times per lease, this is where flow must be sustained longest. The skeleton has three fixed zones: action band (top), main content (middle), reference footer (bottom). Content within each zone evolves weekly: orientation checklists become stay timelines become cumulative summaries. A 'what changed since last visit' indicator ensures every return visit offers discovery. This prevents the mid-lease boredom that the Shushwap village metaphor describes: 'the world became too predictable and the challenge began to go out of life.'

visual_spec.layout: Single-column page with three persistent zones: (1) Action band at top, max 3 items, collapses when empty. (2) Main content area with current-week focus + engagement prompt. (3) Reference footer with lease terms, House Manual, host contact. Max-width 680px centered.
visual_spec.background: var(--bg-light, #f9fafb) page background; var(--bg-white, #ffffff) for zone cards

interaction_spec.load_behavior: Page skeleton renders in under 200ms. Dynamic content (stay details, review prompts, action items) populates within 500ms. New-since-last-visit indicators pulse gently (opacity 1.0 to 0.6, 2s cycle) on sections with fresh content.
interaction_spec.hover: Timeline segments show tooltip with week details on hover. Checklist items show checkmark animation (scale 0 to 1.1 to 1.0, 300ms spring) on completion. Review prompt card expands on tap to reveal rating interface.
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: New-content pulse uses solid indicator dot instead of animation. Checklist uses instant state change. Timeline tooltip appears without delay.

copy_spec.orientation_intro: Welcome to your new space. Here is what to do this week.
copy_spec.reflection_intro: You have been here [N] weeks. Here is what you have built.
copy_spec.milestone_text: You have completed [N] of [Total] stay cycles
copy_spec.empty_visit: No new updates this week. Explore the neighborhood guide.
dont: Use the same headline on every visit
Lead with 'Payment due in 3 days' when there are more engaging items
Present review prompts as demands: 'You MUST submit a review'
Show empty state with just 'No updates'

elements.problem_it_solves: A static Stays Manager visited 13+ times guarantees Csikszentmihalyi's boredom zone by mid-lease: 'One cannot enjoy doing the same thing at the same level for long.' The complexity ratchet -- stable skeleton with evolving content across orientation, rhythm, and reflection phases -- prevents the guest from emotionally abandoning the platform while physically remaining in the lease, preserving the on-platform engagement that drives reviews, communication, and retention.

elements.name: Myth-First Discovery Hero Section
elements.description: A hero section for the discovery page that earns guest belief by showing evidence of the platform's collective fiction before requesting any participation. Real listings with photos and prices are immediately visible, flanked by a social proof aggregate that demonstrates other strangers already trust this platform. No signup prompts, no preference questionnaires, no AI prompts appear in the first viewport. The search bar is present but secondary -- the guest can browse passively before choosing to refine. This implements the Sapiens principle that collective fictions sustain themselves through demonstrated reality, not persuasion.

visual_spec.layout: Full-width section. Top: headline + social proof row. Below: 3-column listing card grid (2-column on tablet, 1-column on mobile). Search bar sits between headline and grid, styled as a soft input rather than a prominent CTA.

interaction_spec.load: Listing cards fade in with 50ms stagger, social proof count animates from 0 to actual value over 600ms
interaction_spec.scroll: Additional listing rows load progressively on scroll without page navigation
interaction_spec.search_bar: Focus triggers a subtle border color change to --secondary-purple; typing filters the grid inline

copy_spec.headline: Shared spaces in your city
copy_spec.voice: Understated and factual. No exclamation marks. No superlatives.

implements_principles: Value before the ask: real listings visible before any registration
Myth-first content hierarchy: social proof precedes functional UI
Progressive value reveal: content streams in without demanding input

elements.problem_it_solves: Guests bounce at discovery because the platform demands participation before demonstrating its reality. This hero section earns belief by showing an active, living marketplace immediately.

elements.name: Gossip-Layer Enriched Listing Card
elements.description: An enriched listing card with three-layer progressive gossip architecture. The glance layer (always visible) shows photo, price, neighborhood, and a verification badge. The scan layer (revealed on hover) slides in availability status, host response time, photo count, and a save action. The design implements Harari's gossip theory: each data point is a trust signal that enables the guest to assess a stranger without meeting them. The hover transition uses shadow elevation and background warmth shift to create a clear distinction between scanning and engaged states.

visual_spec.layout: Card with 60% photo area and 40% info area. Max-width 360px. Border-radius 12px.
visual_spec.photo_area: Aspect ratio 3:2, placeholder gradient, verification badge top-left, photo count bottom-right
visual_spec.info_area: Price in semibold, neighborhood as muted chip, gossip row slides in on hover
visual_spec.hover_state: Elevation shifts to shadow-md, background shifts to warm off-white, gossip row animates in from bottom

interaction_spec.hover_in: 200ms transition for elevation and background, 150ms delayed slide-in for gossip row
interaction_spec.mobile: Long-press 300ms triggers expanded state, tap outside dismisses
interaction_spec.click: Navigates to listing detail page

implements_principles: Gossip bandwidth: each hover data point is a trust signal for stranger-assessment
Three-layer progressive reveal: glance > scan > deep
Informed curiosity: enough differentiation to develop genuine preferences
Trust-first hierarchy: verification badge is the first visual signal
elements.problem_it_solves: Current listing cards provide insufficient social information for guests to assess stranger-trustworthiness at a glance, forcing costly click-throughs to listing detail for basic trust evaluation.

elements.name: Trust-First Listing Detail Header
elements.description: The top section of the listing detail page, structured with trust-first information architecture. The host identity block (photo, name, verification badge, response rate) sits on a warm accent background immediately below the photo gallery. Below that, a review summary line with star rating and most recent review quote provides peer trust evidence before any listing description. This implements the Sapiens cross-activation principle: a past guest's testimony activates a future guest's trust more effectively than any platform assertion. The 'Contact Host' and 'Create Proposal' CTAs are always visible as sticky actions.

visual_spec.layout: Full-width. Photo gallery placeholder at top. Host identity row on accent background. Review summary below. Two CTA buttons in a sticky bar.
visual_spec.host_row_bg: var(--bg-off-white) with left accent border in --secondary-purple

interaction_spec.review_expand: Click 'Read all' to expand full review list inline
interaction_spec.scroll: CTA bar becomes sticky when scrolled past the hero section

elements.problem_it_solves: Guests need to assess a specific stranger's trustworthiness before committing to a proposal. Without peer trust evidence prominently displayed, the platform bears the full trust-building burden alone.

elements.name: Contact Host Message Overlay
elements.description: A slide-up message overlay that enables the guest to gossip directly with the host before committing to a formal proposal. The overlay shows the host's name, photo, and response time, with a text input and send button. This implements the Sapiens gossip theory: humans evolved to assess potential cooperators through direct interpersonal communication. The messaging channel reduces the 'cooperation vacuum' where the guest has interest but no low-stakes way to act on it. The overlay preserves the listing detail context behind a dimmed backdrop.

visual_spec.layout: Bottom-sheet overlay, max-width 480px centered. Host identity mini-row at top, text area in middle, send button at bottom.
visual_spec.backdrop: rgba(0,0,0,0.4) over the listing detail page

interaction_spec.open: 250ms slide-up from bottom with backdrop fade-in
interaction_spec.close: 200ms slide-down, tap outside or X button
interaction_spec.auth: If unauthenticated, inline auth modal triggers first, then overlay opens automatically
interaction_spec.send: Minimum 10 characters required, send button disabled until threshold met

implements_principles: Gossip channel: direct stranger-assessment before formal cooperation
Low-commitment alternative: reduces proposal abandonment for unsure guests
Context preservation: listing detail remains visible behind overlay
Cross-activation: responsive host interaction increases trust velocity
elements.problem_it_solves: The guest wants to assess the host as a real person before committing to a formal proposal, but the current flow offers no low-stakes communication option between browsing and proposing.

elements.name: Ritual Proposal Summary with Live Price
elements.description: A pre-populated proposal summary card with a live price breakdown panel. The card pre-fills listing-derived terms (dates, schedule, price) so the guest confirms rather than constructs. The price panel updates in real-time as any field changes. The submit button uses the reserved gradient-purple treatment for binding actions, creating a ceremonial distinction from ordinary UI interactions. This implements Harari's incorporation ritual metaphor: the proposal is the moment dates and prices become an intersubjective reality shared between two strangers.

visual_spec.layout: Two-column on desktop (form left, price right), single column on mobile. Summary card on warm background with strong border frame. Submit button in gradient purple.
visual_spec.submit_button: gradient-purple-button treatment, reserved for binding actions

interaction_spec.pre_population: Fields populate with staggered 50ms fade-in on form open
interaction_spec.price_update: 150ms number-morph animation on any field change
interaction_spec.submit: Linear progress bar along button bottom edge during processing
interaction_spec.success: Full-viewport confirmation overlay with check animation and serif message

copy_spec.success_message: Your proposal has been sent to [Host Name]

implements_principles: Ritual clarity: proposal feels like signing a prepared document, not drafting from scratch
Price transparency: live breakdown visible at all times, no hidden fees
Committed momentum: pre-population reduces anxiety, ceremonial submit marks transition
Binding action gradient: submit button visually distinct from all other interactions
elements.problem_it_solves: The proposal form creates friction through redundant data entry, hidden costs, and authentication redirects. This pre-populated ritual form reduces the guest's cognitive burden and ensures the incorporation ceremony completes smoothly.

elements.name: Acceptance Confirmation Ceremony Overlay
elements.description: A full-viewport overlay that marks the moment the negotiable fiction becomes a binding agreement. After the guest clicks 'Yes, Proceed', the overlay appears with a ceremonial check animation, the host's name, the confirmed terms, and immediate next-steps orientation (House Manual access, move-in date). This implements Harari's insight that ritual moments require distinct treatment -- the acceptance confirmation must feel different from every other interaction in the product to mark the cooperation threshold. The spring-eased check animation is the only 'celebratory' motion in the entire guest journey.

visual_spec.layout: Full-viewport centered overlay on semi-transparent white backdrop. Check icon at top, terms summary in the middle, next-steps at bottom.
visual_spec.check_animation: Spring-eased entrance (only spring animation in the guest journey)
visual_spec.terms_summary: Compact card with confirmed dates, price, and host name

interaction_spec.duration: Visible for 3 seconds minimum, auto-transitions to dashboard
interaction_spec.manual_dismiss: Tap anywhere or 'Go to Dashboard' button

implements_principles: Ritual confirmation: spring-eased animation marks the cooperation threshold
Grounded reassurance: celebration immediately followed by practical orientation
Fiction-to-reality bridge: next steps prepare the guest for the physical transition
Ceremony without anxiety: the overlay celebrates without intimidating
elements.problem_it_solves: The acceptance moment needs to feel significant enough to mark the cooperation threshold but not so heavy that it creates last-moment anxiety. This overlay provides ceremonial weight with immediate forward momentum.

elements.name: House Manual Card System
elements.description: A structured, card-based House Manual that codifies the cooperation norms between guest and host for the fiction-to-reality transition at move-in. Four distinct section cards (Arrival, House Rules, Space Guide, Neighborhood) each use a warm surface background with a serif heading and section icon. Critical items (check-in code, emergency contact) use an info-blue highlight bar. This implements the Sapiens insight that cooperation beyond intimate acquaintance requires codified rules -- the House Manual is the lease's 'law book' that replaces personal knowledge with structured norms.

visual_spec.layout: Vertical stack of four section cards with generous spacing between them. Max-width 640px centered.
visual_spec.critical_item: Left border 3px solid --secondary-purple, background light purple tint

interaction_spec.default: Arrival section expanded by default on move-in day, others collapsed
interaction_spec.pre_move_in: All sections expanded for review, with a notification nudge 24 hours before check-in
interaction_spec.link_to_host: Each section includes a 'Message Sara about this' link

copy_spec.voice: Practical, warm, and orienting. Not legal, not casual -- collaborative.

implements_principles: Codified cooperation norms: structured law book for stranger cohabitation
Fiction-reality bridge: prepares the guest for the imagined-to-physical transition
Anchored confidence: critical items highlighted, messaging channel always available
Collaborative not authoritative: house rules framed as shared norms, not landlord dictates
elements.problem_it_solves: At move-in, the guest encounters the physical reality of a stranger's home with insufficient preparation. The House Manual codifies the cooperation norms that replace intimate acquaintance, reducing the fiction-reality gap that causes post-acceptance trust collapse.

elements.name: Listing Wizard Progress Card with Armor-Preservation Auto-Save
elements.description: A dashboard card that shows the host's listing creation progress with a visual step tracker, auto-save confirmation, and one-click resume or pause controls. Becker's insight that the host 'doesn't bite the world off in one piece but in small manageable pieces, as a beaver does' informs the step-by-step design: each completed step is a piece of character armor the host has safely shed, and the progress tracker makes this investment visible. The auto-save indicator ('Saved just now') is the platform whispering 'I have your work' -- delegated power that allows the host to disengage without losing character work. Pause is the first action in the menu, more prominent than any destructive option, channeling the retreat impulse into creative repression rather than listing destruction.

visual_spec.layout: Card, max-width 480px. Top row: listing name + auto-save indicator. Encouragement line below. Progress bar. Step checklist with status icons. Bottom: Resume CTA + Pause text link.

color_usage.current_step_badge: #c17a28 on #fef3e2 -- amber for the step needing attention

copy_spec.encourage: Two more steps to go live. Your progress is saved.
dont: Never say 'Your listing is only X% complete' -- frame progress positively
Never use aspirational step titles ('Share your story', 'Set your value') -- these pierce the vital lie by making the existential weight explicit
Never use questions as field labels ('What makes your space special?') -- questions invite self-reflection that activates fear of self-knowledge

elements.html_css_snippet:
2BR Williamsburg Walk-Up

Two more steps to go live. Your progress is saved.

  • Your space
  • Features & amenities
  • Lease style
  • Pricing

elements.problem_it_solves: Hosts abandon the listing wizard at the impasse-layer steps (photos, house rules) because the existential weight of self-exposure becomes conscious. This card fragments the exposure into beaver-sized pieces with visible, preserved progress, ensuring no character work is ever lost and the retreat to pause is always frictionless.

elements.name: Proposal Vetting Card with Stranger-Trust Signals
elements.description: A proposal review card that resolves the host's stranger-terror by placing guest trust signals (verification badge, review rating, completed stays, stated purpose) above proposal terms (dates, duration, price). Becker's insight that the stranger represents 'billions of individual organismic appetites' informs the trust-first architecture: the host's instinctual threat assessment must be resolved before rational term evaluation can begin. The verification badge is the platform-as-superego made visible -- communicating 'we have vetted this person; you are not forsaken.' The counter-offer button provides temporal control over vulnerability without rejecting the person. The three-button action bar uses graduated visual weight: Accept (filled purple, maximum prominence), Counter (outlined, medium), Decline (text-only, minimum) -- nudging toward the marketplace-sustaining action while preserving the host's sense of choice.

visual_spec.layout: Card, max-width 520px. Three zones: Trust Zone (top, tinted background with guest identity), Terms Zone (middle, white, structured grid), Action Zone (bottom, three graduated buttons).

copy_spec.message: Hi! I'm a product designer working a contract in Williamsburg. I keep a tidy space and work mostly from co-working spaces during the day. Looking forward to connecting.
dont: Never use excitement ('You have a new match!', 'Someone wants your space!') -- excitement amplifies anxiety
Never show a countdown timer on proposal response -- time pressure forces a decision before character defenses have processed the stranger
Never show 'Also applied to X other listings' -- this signals the stranger's appetites are diffuse and uncontrollable

elements.problem_it_solves: Hosts freeze or reflexively decline proposals when the stranger's credibility is not immediately visible. This card places the guest's verification badge, review rating, and stay history above the fold -- making trust the first thing the host processes and converting the terrifying stranger into a manageable, vetted person.

elements.name: Pricing Defaults Card with Delegated Confidence
elements.description: A pricing card that presents the platform's recommended price as a confident, pre-decided number -- not an open question. Becker's insight that people 'always rely on something that transcends us, some system of ideas and powers in which we are embedded' informs the visual hierarchy: the recommended price is a 36px hero number in DM Sans that dominates the card, communicating that the platform has already decided. The trust line ('Based on 12 similar rooms in Williamsburg') provides the host with an external authority to lean on. The guaranteed income projection in purple anchors the price to the host's primary anxiety buffer: predictable revenue. The 'Accept this price' button is full-width and prominent; the 'Adjust' link is below and subdued. The entire composition says: here is your price (certainty), here is what it means for you (security), you can change it if you must (agency).

visual_spec.layout: Card, max-width 440px, centered. Hero price at top. Trust line below. Guaranteed income in purple. Market range bar. Full-width Accept button. Subdued Adjust link.

copy_spec.label: We recommend
copy_spec.trust_line: Based on 12 similar rooms in Williamsburg
dont: Never present an empty price field -- an empty field is an existential void the host cannot fill without anxiety
Never say 'Set your own price' -- this forces autonomous self-determination that the host's character defenses are designed to avoid
Never show the platform's fee percentage before the host accepts the gross price -- fee revelation during self-valuation amplifies betrayal anxiety

elements.html_css_snippet:

elements.problem_it_solves: Setting a price forces the host to assign monetary value to something psychologically priceless -- their home. This card eliminates the existential void of an empty price field by presenting the platform's recommendation as a confident, pre-decided figure. The host accepts by embedding in the platform's authority, not by generating courage from their own center.

elements.name: Cleaning Photo Approval Ritual Card
elements.description: A dashboard card that surfaces cleaning photo verification as a ritual moment -- the host confirming their sanctuary survived stranger-contact and was restored. Becker's insight that 'self-preservation implies an effort against some force of disintegration' informs the card design: the photos are large (the host must see their space), the 'Approve: Space Restored' button uses the word 'Restored' (acknowledging something was at risk), and the confirmation state (purple checkmark overlay, 'Space verified' text) provides visual proof that can persist on the dashboard for 48 hours. The card moves from the urgency stack (amber border = needs attention) to a confirmed state (purple border = verified safe), enacting the psychological transition from vigilance to relief.

visual_spec.layout: Card, max-width 520px. Header: guest name + date. 2x2 photo grid. Action buttons below. Confirmed state overlay.

dont: Never add captions to individual photos -- the photos speak for themselves
Never auto-approve cleaning photos -- the host's explicit confirmation is the ritual seal
Never say 'Looks good!' -- casual language undermines the ritual significance

elements.html_css_snippet:
Cleaning verification from Jordan RiveraFeb 18, 2026
Kitchen
Bedroom
Bathroom

elements.problem_it_solves: During active lease, the host lives with chronic anxiety that their space may be damaged or disrespected by the stranger. The cleaning photo ritual provides a structured, conclusive outlet for this self-preservation instinct -- the host actively verifies their sanctuary is intact, and the confirmed state persists as visual proof that repression can re-engage.

elements.name: Host Dashboard Urgency Panel
elements.description: The top section of the host dashboard that surfaces action-required items as the host's externalized self-preservation instinct. Becker writes that 'such constant expenditure of psychological energy on the business of preserving life would be impossible if the fear of death were not as constant.' This panel converts the diffuse anxiety of stranger-in-home into discrete, actionable items. Each urgency card uses a left-border accent system: amber (#c17a28) for items needing attention, purple (rgb(109,49,194)) for informational items already handled. The panel heading 'Needs your attention' and the empty state 'All caught up' are the two poles of the host's dashboard experience -- threat-scanning and equanimity. The panel never rearranges between visits, providing the civilizational order that Becker identifies as a precondition for equanimity.

visual_spec.layout: Full-width panel, max-width 640px. Heading + vertical stack of up to 5 action cards. Each card: icon + description + deadline + action button.

copy_spec.heading: Needs your attention

example_items.desc: Review cleaning photos from Jordan Rivera
Date change request from Marcus Chen

copy_spec.empty_state: All caught up. Nothing needs your attention right now.
dont: Never place promotional banners above the urgency panel -- the host's vigilant state reads non-urgent content as the platform ignoring their needs
Never use red badges for routine attention items -- only for genuine sanctuary-threat events (overdue cleaning photos, missed payment)
Never rearrange the panel's position on the page between visits -- positional consistency is character armor

  • Date change request from Marcus Chen

    Awaiting your approval
elements.problem_it_solves: Without a centralized urgency panel, the host's self-preservation instinct has no structured outlet. Anxiety becomes diffuse -- manifesting as excessive messaging, micromanagement, or premature lease termination. This panel converts chronic background anxiety into discrete, resolvable items that the host can process and clear, restoring the vital lie that everything is under control.

elements.name: Hosting Legacy Summary Card
elements.description: A celebratory summary card presented at lease completion that reframes the hosting experience as an immortality project -- a contribution that transcends the individual transaction. Becker writes that 'the deepest need is to be free of the anxiety of death and annihilation; but it is life itself which awakens it, and so we must shrink from being fully alive.' This card provides the narcissistic supply needed to sustain the host's expanded hero system. The income hero number (36px DM Sans) declares the material value of the host's vulnerability. The three impact metrics (guests welcomed, months provided, average rating) provide evidence of meaningful contribution. Review snippets are voices of former strangers confirming the encounter was positive. The re-list CTA appears after validation -- the host decides from a position of affirmed strength, not unresolved anxiety. Pause is positioned as an equally dignified option: 'Take a break.'

visual_spec.layout: Card, max-width 520px. Purple-tinted canvas background. Hero income. Three-column metrics. Review snippet cards. Re-list CTA + Pause link.

copy_spec.label: Your hosting impact

reviews.name: Jordan R.
reviews.text: Spotless place, great location. Made my contract work so much easier.

reviews.name: Alex K.
reviews.text: Felt right at home from day one. Would book again.

dont: Never say 'Congratulations!' -- patronizing at a moment of genuine psychological significance
Never show itemized fee deductions -- this is a narrative of contribution, not a financial audit
Never say 'Start earning again' -- mercenary framing undermines the legacy narrative

elements.html_css_snippet:
Your hosting impact

3

Average rating

What they said about you

Jordan R.

Spotless place, great location. Made my contract work so much easier.

Alex K.

Felt right at home from day one. Would book again.
elements.problem_it_solves: At lease end, the host faces the existential question: was it worth it? Without a structured legacy narrative, the raw memory of hosting (anxiety, stranger-intrusion, control negotiations) overwhelms the positive outcomes. This card provides evidence that the vulnerability produced meaningful contribution -- income earned, guests served, positive validation -- giving the host the narcissistic supply needed to rebuild the vital lie around continued hosting.

elements.name: Pause / Resume Listing Toggle
elements.description: A listing card state toggle that allows the host to pause (retreat from exposure) or resume (re-engage) with a single tap and zero friction. Becker's insight that 'repression is not simply a negative force opposing life energies; it lives on life energies and uses them creatively' informs the design: pause IS creative repression -- channeling the retreat impulse into a productive holding state rather than destructive deletion. The paused state desaturates the listing card and shows a 'Paused' badge, making the retreat visible without making it punitive. Resume restores full color and live status. No confirmation modal on pause -- the host's boundary is respected without interrogation. No reason-collection form -- forcing the host to articulate their retreat breaks the repressive defense that makes pause psychologically viable. This card shows both the live and paused states side by side for comparison.

visual_spec.layout: Two cards side by side (live vs. paused) at max-width 260px each. Each card: listing photo placeholder, title, status badge, action menu.

dont: Never show an 'Are you sure?' modal on pause -- the host's boundary must be respected without interrogation
Never require the host to explain why they are pausing -- forced articulation breaks the repressive defense
Never send 'We miss you' re-engagement emails within the first 45 days -- respect the retreat

elements.problem_it_solves: Hosts who need temporary retreat from exposure face a binary: stay live (continued vulnerability) or delete (destroy everything built at existential cost). This toggle provides the Beckerian middle path -- pause channels the retreat impulse into a productive holding state where all character work is preserved, the host's identity as a host is maintained, and the door to return remains open.

elements.name: Move-In Welcome Peak Card
elements.description: A full-screen welcome card that appears as the guest's first interaction after check-in, engineering a positive peak through a cinematic four-frame reveal: hero photo, host welcome message, neighborhood essentials, and a first-impression sentiment capture. Kahneman's peak-end rule establishes that this moment will disproportionately define the guest's memory of the entire lease. The card commands the full viewport to direct the focusing illusion exclusively toward warmth and preparation. The host's personal message creates the human peak the remembering self stores; the neighborhood essentials answer 'now what?' before anxiety forms. Value before the ask: three frames of welcome precede the single gentle prompt.

visual_spec.layout: Full viewport takeover on first open after check-in. Hero photo fills 100% width, 60vh height. Content card overlays bottom 50% with 24px padding. After dismissal, persists as a standard 100%-width dashboard card for 48 hours.
visual_spec.background: Hero photo full-bleed; content overlay uses var(--bg-off-white, rgb(252,250,255)) with backdrop-filter blur(12px)
visual_spec.border: none on takeover; 1px solid var(--border-color, #e5e7eb) on dashboard card state
visual_spec.border_radius: 0 on takeover; 12px on dashboard card state

interaction_spec.load_behavior: Triggers on first app/dashboard open after check-in time. Hero photo fades in over 500ms ease-in. Content card slides up from bottom over 400ms ease-out, 300ms after photo starts. Essentials stagger in 100ms apart. Dismissable by scroll-past or 'Done' tap.
interaction_spec.hover: Sentiment options scale to 1.05 on hover with 100ms ease-out. Selected option fills with its color and shows a checkmark.
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: All elements appear simultaneously without animation. Card appears as standard dashboard card (no takeover).

copy_spec.host_message_example: Sarah left a note: 'The rooftop has the best sunset view in the building -- take the stairs at the end of the hall. Enjoy!'
dont: Lead with rules or house manual content
Use generic 'Welcome to Split Lease!' language
Show issue-reporting in the first 3 frames
Include administrative items (payment, lease terms)

elements.html_css:

The rooftop has the best sunset view in the building -- take the stairs at the end of the hall. The morning light in the living room is beautiful. Enjoy!

elements.problem_it_solves: Move-in is the single most consequential moment in the guest journey, yet it receives no deliberate design. The welcome peak card engineers a positive first impression that the remembering self stores as the lease's defining memory, using the focusing illusion to direct attention toward warmth (host message, neighborhood orientation) before any negative detail is noticed.

elements.name: Lease-End Farewell Ceremony Card
elements.description: A three-state evolving card that creates a graduated positive ending over the final 7 days of a lease. State 1 (Reflection) shows the lease summary and invites a memory prompt. State 2 (Farewell) adds the host's closing message and re-surfaces the neighborhood essentials from move-in as a narrative bookend. State 3 (Gratitude) presents the complete lease narrative with a rebooking prompt positioned at peak emotional warmth. Kahneman's cold-hand experiment showed that 80% of subjects chose to repeat experiences with gradually improving endings -- this card creates that gradient: neutral reflection to warm farewell to peak gratitude.

visual_spec.layout: Full-width dashboard card. Three evolving states share the same card shell (no page navigation). State 3 includes a hero photo element at top. Max-width 520px centered.

typography.phase_label: var(--font-inter), 11px, weight 600, var(--secondary-purple, rgb(109,49,194)), uppercase, letter-spacing 0.5px
typography.headline: var(--font-dm), 20px, weight 700, var(--primary-purple, #31135D)

interaction_spec.load_behavior: State 1 slides in on dashboard 7 days before final stay (300ms ease-out). State 2 evolves in place when host message arrives (message slides in 300ms ease-out). State 3 cross-fades from State 2 (400ms ease-in-out) 24 hours after final departure.
interaction_spec.hover: Rebook CTA shows subtle scale (0.97 to 1.0) on click. Memory prompt textarea has focus ring matching purple palette.
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: All state transitions are instant. No slide or cross-fade.

copy_spec.memory_prompt: What will you remember most about this space?
copy_spec.state2_host_message_example: It was wonderful having you -- the apartment felt alive when you were here. Come back anytime.
dont: Lead with administrative items (deposit, invoice)
Use urgency language for rebooking
Show the review prompt as the primary element
Frame the ending as a loss ('Access deactivated')

elements.problem_it_solves: The platform has no designed lease ending. The guest's final interaction is administrative (deposit, checkout), producing a flat memory that does not motivate rebooking. This card creates the gradually improving ending that Kahneman's research shows produces a preference for repetition: 80% of subjects chose to repeat experiences with gradually improving endings.

elements.name: Peak-Generating Listing Card
elements.description: A richly layered listing card that maximizes peak probability per impression by providing multiple visual peak opportunities. The photo carousel auto-advances on hover, the neighborhood identity pill creates an experiential memory anchor, and the availability alignment signal resolves the fundamental question without a page transition. Kahneman Ch 35: the search session will be prototyped by one card impression. Every enrichment layer multiplies the probability that this card's impression is vivid and positive. The focusing illusion is directed toward experiential qualities (neighborhood, transit) rather than transactional ones (price) to produce richer memories that support rebooking.

visual_spec.layout: Vertical card, 300px width on desktop grid. Hero photo area at full bleed top (aspect 3:2). Content area below with 12px padding. Hover reveals additional layers.

interaction_spec.load_behavior: Cards fade in from opacity 0 to 1 over 200ms ease-out as they enter viewport. Staggered 50ms per card. Photo carousel shows first image with dots and image counter badge.
interaction_spec.hover: Card lifts translateY(-2px) with shadow upgrade over 200ms ease-in-out. Carousel auto-advances 2.5s interval with 250ms crossfade on 800ms hover delay. Image counter updates. Neighborhood pill and availability signal become visible. Save heart appears top-right. Hover drawer slides up from bottom with transit info and Message Host button.
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: No transform, no auto-advance. Card gains 2px solid var(--secondary-purple) border on hover instead. All hover-reveal elements appear instantly.

dont: Make price the largest/first text element
Show full address on the card
Use 'View listing' as primary CTA
Add lease terms or long descriptions

elements.html_css:
1/5
Williamsburg
$175/night
Available your dates
3 min to L train
elements.problem_it_solves: The search session will be remembered by one prototypical listing card. A card with only a photo and price provides one peak opportunity. This card provides six: photo carousel, neighborhood identity, transit proximity, availability alignment, save action, and message action. Each enrichment multiplies the probability that the search memory is vivid and positive.

elements.name: Mid-Lease Narrative Milestone Card
elements.description: A lightweight narrative card that appears at strategic intervals during the active lease to combat duration neglect. Kahneman Ch 35: 'duration had no effect whatsoever on the ratings.' Without designed mid-lease peaks, weeks 2-15 of a 16-week lease are mnemonically invisible. This card creates temporal anchors that the remembering self can store: 'Halfway through. What has been the best part?' The milestone treatment uses controlled visual emphasis (DM Sans headline, off-white background, purple accent border) to distinguish it from routine stay cards while preserving the dashboard's operational order.

visual_spec.layout: Standard dashboard card width, 100% of content area. Slightly elevated visual treatment to distinguish from operational cards.
visual_spec.border: 1px solid var(--border-color, #e5e7eb); left border: 3px solid var(--secondary-purple, rgb(109,49,194))

interaction_spec.load_behavior: Card slides in on dashboard at lease midpoint (300ms ease-out). Persists for 72 hours, then dims to 60% opacity and moves to 'Past moments' section.
interaction_spec.hover: Quick-tap options darken background on hover. Selected option shows purple border and subtle fill. Text field expandable on focus.
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: Card appears instantly without slide. All transitions instant.

copy_spec.headline: Halfway through
copy_spec.prompt: What has been the best part so far?
copy_spec.acknowledgment: Glad to hear it. [X] stays to go.
dont: Use survey language ('Rate 1-5')
Create urgency or obligation
Upsell longer leases or other listings
Show more than one milestone card at a time

elements.html_css:
Halfway through

6 of 12 stays in Williamsburg

What has been the best part so far?
elements.problem_it_solves: Duration neglect makes the middle weeks of a lease mnemonically invisible. The remembering self discards weeks 2-15 of a 16-week lease because nothing stands out. This card creates temporal anchors -- moments of positive reflection that break the adaptation monotony and give the remembering self data points beyond just the peak and end.

elements.name: Counter-Offer Common-Ground Card
elements.description: A counter-proposal view that leads with the host's personal message and common ground before revealing changed terms, directly combating Kahneman's loss aversion. The staggered rendering order (host message at 200ms, common ground at 400ms, changes at 600ms) ensures the guest processes human warmth and agreement before encountering any parameter changes. No red, no strikethrough, no 'rejected' language. The action labels use the host's name and collaborative framing: 'Accept Sarah's suggestion' instead of 'Accept counter-proposal.' The remembering self stores the negotiation as defined by its peak moment -- this design ensures that peak is the host's warm message, not the shock of changed numbers.

visual_spec.layout: Full-width card. Host message section at top, common ground section with colored background, changes section in neutral, action bar at bottom. Max-width 520px.

interaction_spec.load_behavior: Host message fades in at 200ms. Common ground section slides in from left at 400ms ease-out. Changes section follows at 600ms. Action bar appears at 800ms. Staggered rendering creates a reading rhythm: warmth > agreement > detail > action.
interaction_spec.hover: Accept button shows scale pulse 0.97 on click. Adjust Terms button shows purple border highlight. Message link underlines on hover.
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: All sections appear simultaneously without animation.

dont: Use 'Counter-proposal received' language
Highlight changes in red or strikethrough
Create urgency ('Respond within 48 hours')
Omit the host's personal message

elements.problem_it_solves: Loss aversion turns counter-proposals into rejection experiences. The guest processes the loss (6 fewer weeks) more intensely than the gain (securing the stay). This card redirects the focusing illusion from loss to relationship by leading with human warmth and agreement, producing a 'we worked it out' memory instead of a 'they rejected me' memory.

elements.name: Lease Summary Memory Card
elements.description: A compact narrative artifact displayed on the active lease dashboard that shows the guest's lease story in progress -- stays completed, host name, neighborhood, and the guest's own milestone reflection. This card serves the remembering self by providing a visual summary that accumulates over the lease, combating duration neglect by making the passage of time visible and meaningful. At lease end, this card's data feeds into the Farewell Ceremony Card, creating narrative continuity from the middle to the ending. The card uses the precision register (Inter with tabular numbers) for factual data and the narrative register (DM Sans) for the headline, creating a visual artifact that feels like a personal record of the experience.

visual_spec.layout: Standard dashboard card width, compact height. Summary stats in a horizontal row, guest reflection below if available. Max-width 440px.

typography.headline: var(--font-dm), 15px, weight 700, var(--primary-purple, #31135D)
typography.reflection_text: var(--font-inter), 13px, weight 400, color: var(--text-description, #374151), font-style: italic

interaction_spec.load_behavior: Card appears on dashboard after the first completed stay. Stats update after each stay completion with a brief number roll animation (200ms). Progress bar fills incrementally.
interaction_spec.hover: Card does not have interactive hover states. It is a passive narrative artifact.
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: Number updates are instant. Progress bar fills without animation.

copy_spec.headline: Your stay in [neighborhood]
copy_spec.reflection_label: You said the best part was:
copy_spec.no_reflection: No reflection is shown if the guest has not yet completed the mid-lease check-in
dont: Show payment or financial data
Include issue history or complaints
Add gamified badges or achievement language
Use this card as a review prompt

elements.html_css:
Your stay in Williamsburg

8stays

Sarahyour host

"The neighborhood -- everything I need is a short walk away."
elements.problem_it_solves: During the active lease, the experiencing self adapts and the remembering self has nothing to store. The Lease Summary Memory Card makes the passage of time visible and meaningful by accumulating narrative data (stays, weeks, host name, reflection) that the remembering self can reference. At lease end, this accumulated narrative feeds into the farewell sequence, creating a through-line from middle to ending that combats duration neglect.

elements.name: Guest Stay Dashboard with Experiential Data
elements.description: The primary active-lease dashboard view that serves both the experiencing self (daily operations) and the remembering self (narrative peaks). The dashboard has two visual registers: an operational zone (upcoming stay, date tools, payment status) in clean, neutral styling, and a narrative zone (milestone card, lease summary, host connection prompt) in the warm purple-accented treatment. The experiencing self finds reliability; the remembering self finds memorable moments. Kahneman Ch 37: 'happiness is the experience of spending time with people you love' -- the platform should not try to be the source of happiness during the lease; it should remove obstacles to the guest's own happiness while strategically manufacturing peaks for the remembering self.

visual_spec.layout: Single-column dashboard, max-width 600px centered. Operational zone at top (hero card pattern), narrative zone below (when active). Lease Summary Memory Card embedded in the narrative zone.
visual_spec.background: var(--bg-light, #f9fafb) for page; var(--bg-white, #ffffff) for operational cards; var(--bg-off-white, rgb(252,250,255)) for narrative cards

interaction_spec.load_behavior: Operational zone loads first (hero stay card appears in 150ms). Narrative zone loads below if a narrative card is active (300ms ease-out slide-in). Baseline transitions between stay states are near-invisible (150ms).
interaction_spec.hover: Operational cards have minimal hover states (subtle border color shift). Narrative cards have warm hover states (shadow deepens slightly). Action buttons within cards follow standard purple button interaction (scale 0.97 on click).
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: All elements appear instantly. No slide-ins or transitions.

copy_spec.baseline_notification: Your next stay starts Tuesday, Mar 24.
dont: Over-notify for routine events
Mix narrative and operational elements in the same card
Use excitement language for routine operations
Show more than one narrative card at a time in the narrative zone

elements.problem_it_solves: The active lease dashboard currently serves only the experiencing self (operational data: stays, dates, cleaning). The remembering self finds nothing memorable in weekly operational cards. This dashboard adds a narrative zone that manufactures strategic peaks (milestones, host connections, reflections) within the stable operational structure -- serving both selves simultaneously and ensuring the lease middle produces memories, not just operations.

elements.name: Move-In Seven-Gate Orientation Card
elements.description: A notification card used exclusively for the seven-gate move-in orientation sequence. Each gate delivers one category of pre-arrival information -- neighborhood, access, house rules, arrival confirmation, House Manual, host check-in, morning debrief -- in a timed countdown sequence anchored to the move-in date. Campbell's Inanna is stripped of one ornament at each gate; the guest has one layer of uncertainty stripped at each gate. The card uses a distinct visual treatment (purple left border, gate number pill, serif title) to differentiate orientation messages from routine notifications. The gate sequence converts the Belly of the Whale from an unmediated crisis into a ritualized descent where vulnerability is expected and supported.

visual_spec.layout: Single card, max-width 520px. Left border accent strip (3px). Top-left: gate number pill. Below pill: serif title. Below title: body content (3-4 lines max). Bottom-right: optional action link.
visual_spec.border: 1px solid var(--border-color, #e5e7eb); border-left: 3px solid var(--secondary-purple, rgb(109, 49, 194))

color_usage.active_border: var(--secondary-purple, rgb(109, 49, 194)) -- 3px left border for current/upcoming gates
color_usage.completed_border: var(--accent-purple, rgb(140, 104, 238)) at 50% opacity -- left border for viewed gates

interaction_spec.load_behavior: Card fades in with 400ms ease-out and 2px upward drift. Slower than standard notifications (20-30% slower) to signal move-in gravity. Gate pill and title appear simultaneously; content fades in 100ms later.
interaction_spec.hover: Action link underlines on hover (200ms transition). Card itself has no hover state.
interaction_spec.completion: When guest views the gate content, left border transitions from secondary-purple to accent-purple at 50% opacity (400ms ease-in-out). Gate pill shows a small checkmark icon.
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: All animations disabled. Content appears in final position immediately.

copy_spec.gate_1_content: You are staying in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. The nearest subway is the L train at Bedford Ave, a 6-minute walk. There is a grocery store on the corner of N 7th and Bedford. Street parking is metered until 7pm.
copy_spec.gate_3_content: Three things to know before you arrive: quiet hours after 10pm, shoes off in common areas, trash goes out on Tuesday evenings. Full house manual available after check-in.
copy_spec.gate_6_content: First evenings in a new space can feel a bit unfamiliar. That is completely normal. Take your time settling in. If you need anything, you can message Sarah anytime.
copy_spec.gate_7_content: You made it through your first night. How are you feeling?
dont: Never use exclamation marks in move-in communication
Never say 'Welcome to your new home!' -- it over-promises
Never reference listing photos ('Just like in the pictures!')
Never dump all information in a single gate

elements.html_css:
Gate 3 of 7

Top House Rules

Three things to know before you arrive: quiet hours after 10pm, shoes off in common areas, trash goes out on Tuesday evenings. Full house manual available after check-in.

View full house manual
elements.problem_it_solves: Guests arrive at a stranger's home with all their expectations intact, producing a reality-shock crisis at move-in. The Seven-Gate Orientation Card strips one layer of uncertainty at each gate in a timed sequence (T-48h through T+9am), converting the Belly of the Whale from an unmediated crisis into a ritualized descent where each step is illuminated before it is taken.

elements.name: Stay Cycle Trial Timeline
elements.description: A horizontal timeline component showing every stay in the lease as a node, with visual treatment that differentiates completed stays (filled, purple), the current stay (larger, glowing), and future stays (outlined, gray). Milestone markers at stay 3, stay 6, and the final stay provide Campbell's 'momentary glimpses of the wonderful land.' The timeline sits at the top of the stay dashboard, providing instant orientation -- where the guest stands on the Road of Trials -- before any detail is consumed. Cumulative metrics (stays completed, average rating, total nights) display above the timeline as the hero's accumulated trophies.

visual_spec.layout: Card with 24px padding. Top row: cumulative metrics (3 items, horizontal). Below: horizontal timeline with nodes connected by lines. Below timeline: current stay label.

color_usage.current_node: var(--accent-purple, rgb(140, 104, 238)) -- filled circle, 16px diameter, with box-shadow glow
color_usage.completed_line: var(--secondary-purple, rgb(109, 49, 194)) at 40% opacity -- 2px solid connecting line
color_usage.milestone_dot: var(--primary-purple, #31135D) -- 4px inner dot on milestone nodes

interaction_spec.load_behavior: Timeline renders instantly. Completed nodes fill left-to-right with a staggered 50ms delay per node (max 500ms total). Current node pulses once with a box-shadow glow (400ms).
interaction_spec.hover: Hovering a completed node shows a tooltip with stay dates and review score. Hovering a future node shows scheduled dates.
interaction_spec.tap: Tapping a node expands a detail card below the timeline with that stay's dates, review exchanged, and any notable events.
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: All stagger and pulse animations disabled. Nodes appear in final state.

dont: Never show the timeline as a flat list
Never use the same visual weight for all nodes
Never hide cumulative metrics behind navigation

elements.problem_it_solves: The guest's stay dashboard presents stays as a flat list where stay 10 looks identical to stay 1. Campbell's Road of Trials demands visible progression. This timeline transforms the stay cycle from monotonous repetition into a visual arc where each filled node is a slain dragon, each milestone is a glimpse of the wonderful land, and the guest's position on the Road is always clear.

elements.name: Counter-Offer Person-First Card
elements.description: A counter-offer presentation card that leads with the host's identity and message (the goddess revealing herself) before showing changed terms (the terms as surface). Campbell's Fergus sees only the hag's ugliness and refuses; Niall sees the person and embraces. This card ensures the guest sees Niall's view: host photo, name, and note appear in a warm top zone before any term comparison. Three co-equal response buttons (Accept, Suggest Different Terms, Message Host) ensure the dialogue path is never subordinated to the binary accept/reject.

visual_spec.layout: Card with two zones. Top zone (host identity): warm background, host avatar + name + note. Bottom zone (term comparison): neutral background, side-by-side terms, response buttons.
visual_spec.background: Top zone: var(--bg-off-white, rgb(252, 250, 255)). Bottom zone: var(--bg-white, #ffffff)

color_usage.host_zone_bg: var(--bg-off-white, rgb(252, 250, 255)) -- warm purple tint for relational context
color_usage.changed_value: var(--secondary-purple, rgb(109, 49, 194)) -- not red, not loss-framed

interaction_spec.load_behavior: Card fades in over 400ms. Host identity zone renders 150ms before term comparison zone (staggered entrance: person first, numbers second).
interaction_spec.accept_path: Single tap. Optimistic UI: card transitions to confirmation state (host avatar + green checkmark + 'Terms accepted') in 200ms.
interaction_spec.counter_path: Tap 'Suggest Different Terms.' Inline editor slides down (300ms) below the term comparison, pre-populated with the host's proposed terms. Guest adjusts specific fields and submits.
interaction_spec.message_path: Tap 'Message Sarah.' Inline compose field slides down (200ms). Counter-offer summary remains visible above the compose field to anchor the conversation.
interaction_spec.undo: 5-second grace period after Accept. A small 'Undo' link appears below the confirmation. After 5 seconds, the acceptance is committed.
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: Stagger disabled. All content appears simultaneously.

copy_spec.host_note: I would love to have you! I usually start with a shorter period to make sure we are a good fit. How does 10 weeks sound?
copy_spec.term_1_context: Sarah suggests starting shorter to see how things go.
copy_spec.term_2_context: Shorter stays have a slightly higher nightly rate.
dont: Never frame changes as losses ('You will lose 6 weeks')
Never use passive voice ('The proposal has been modified')
Never subordinate the message button to accept/reject
Never use red for changed values
