elements.problem_it_solves: Counter-offers currently present as cold ledger updates (terms changed, new total). The guest sees Fergus's view: ugliness first, rejection follows. This card presents Niall's view: the host-as-person first (warm zone, photo, note, response time), terms second (neutral zone, contextual explanations), and three co-equal response paths that keep dialogue alive alongside decision.

elements.name: Transformation Mirror Reflection Card
elements.description: A reflection surface that appears at mid-lease and lease-end, presenting the guest's transformation narrative -- Campbell's Apotheosis made visible. At mid-lease: a journey-so-far summary with stays completed, reviews exchanged, and an optional 'share what is working' prompt. At lease-end: a fuller transformation narrative with composite review quote, credential visibility statement, and dual forward paths ('Continue with Host' / 'Explore new spaces'). The card uses the slowest entrance animation in the system (600ms) to signal 'this is a moment of significance.' The guest sees themselves in the mirror: not just a tenant who completed a lease, but a person who has been initiated.

visual_spec.layout: Card, max-width 480px. Top: serif headline. Middle: cumulative metrics in a horizontal row. Below: composite review quote in an inset block. Bottom: dual CTA buttons or single reflection prompt.

interaction_spec.load_behavior: Card fades in over 600ms with a subtle scale-up (0.97 to 1.0). This is 50% slower than any other dashboard card. Metrics appear with 200ms stagger delays. The pace communicates: 'this is different, this matters.'
interaction_spec.hover: CTA buttons shift to hover states. Card itself has no hover effect.
interaction_spec.dismissal: Card can be dismissed to a compressed badge ('Lease summary available'). Dismissal is a 300ms fade-out. The badge persists on the dashboard.
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: Card appears in final state. No scale or stagger animations.

copy_spec.subhead_midlease: You have completed 6 stays with Sarah across 42 nights. Here is what you have built together.
copy_spec.headline_endlease: Your Journey with Sarah Is Complete
copy_spec.subhead_endlease: 12 stays. 84 nights. 4 months of shared living.
copy_spec.review_quote: "Reliable, respectful, and easy to communicate with. I would host them again without hesitation."
copy_spec.credential_note: Your experience is now part of your Split Lease profile. Future hosts will see your 12 completed stays.
dont: Never use superlative flattery ('You are an amazing guest!')
Never frame the transformation as the platform's achievement
Never push re-engagement aggressively ('Book now!')
Never ignore negative experiences -- if the lease was difficult, emphasize completion over quality

elements.problem_it_solves: Guests complete leases feeling 'done' rather than 'transformed.' Without a mirror reflecting their growth, the Apotheosis cannot occur. This card presents the transformation narrative at mid-lease and lease-end: cumulative metrics, host review synthesis, credential visibility, and forward paths. The guest sees themselves as initiated -- not just a person who rented a room, but a person who knows how to live flexibly.

elements.name: Date Change Amulet Tool
elements.description: A calendar-first interface for adjusting stay dates during the active lease. Campbell's hero wields amulets as extensions of their will; the Date Change Tool must feel like the guest's own scheduling instrument, not a permission-request form. The entry point reads 'Adjust Your Schedule' (not 'Request Date Change'). The guest taps dates to toggle them, sees changes instantly in a pending state (lighter purple), and confirms with a single tap. Host approval is framed as 'confirmation' not 'approval.' The calendar responds in under 50ms to every interaction, creating the tactile responsiveness that makes an amulet feel like part of the hero.

visual_spec.layout: Calendar grid, 7 columns (Mon-Sun), with current month visible. Top: month/year header with navigation arrows. Below grid: change summary + confirm button.

color_usage.scheduled_bg: var(--secondary-purple, rgb(109, 49, 194)) -- fully confirmed stay dates
color_usage.pending_bg: rgba(109, 49, 194, 0.15) -- dates changed but not yet confirmed by host
color_usage.available_bg: transparent -- dates within lease period that are not scheduled
color_usage.unavailable_bg: var(--bg-light-gray, #f3f4f6) -- dates outside lease period, dimmed

interaction_spec.load_behavior: Calendar renders instantly from cached lease data. Scheduled dates are already filled.
interaction_spec.tap_to_toggle: Tapping an available date adds it (transitions to pending state in 150ms ease-out). Tapping a scheduled date removes it (transitions to pending-removal state, outlined in red-muted). All interactions are local -- no server calls until 'Confirm.'
interaction_spec.confirm: Tap 'Confirm Changes' to send. Optimistic UI: summary updates immediately. Status line appears: 'Sarah will confirm your schedule update.' Pending dates pulse once (200ms).
interaction_spec.host_confirmation: When confirmed, pending-bg transitions to scheduled-bg (400ms ease-in-out). Status updates to 'Schedule updated.'
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: All transitions are instant. No pulse or fade animations.

copy_spec.status_pending: Sarah will confirm your schedule update
copy_spec.first_use_hint: You can adjust your stay dates anytime. Sarah will confirm the changes.
dont: Never say 'Request Date Change' or 'Submit request'
Never use 'Waiting for host approval' -- say 'will confirm'
Never require a page navigation to reach the calendar
Never make the approval step the primary frame of the interaction

elements.html_css:
Adjust Your Schedule

MonTueWedThuFriSatSun

Adding: Tue Feb 24

Sarah will confirm your schedule update
elements.problem_it_solves: The Date Change Tool currently frames the guest as a petitioner ('Request Date Change'). The hero does not request permission to use their amulet. This calendar-first tool lets the guest manipulate dates directly with sub-50ms responsiveness, see changes instantly in a pending state, and confirm with one tap. Host approval is invisible in the interaction framing -- the guest schedules, the host confirms.

elements.name: Cleaning Photo Ritual Frame
elements.description: A visually elevated card for cleaning photo submission that transforms a compliance chore into a ritual act of honorable trial completion. Campbell's hero returns from each trial with evidence of victory -- the golden fleece, the sorted grains. The guest's cleaning photos are this evidence. The card uses guided placeholders ('Kitchen,' 'Bedroom,' 'Common area'), a serif ritual header ('Show Your Space Is Ready'), and a visible completion state (warm background shift, checkmark) to distinguish this ritual from a generic file upload. The timestamp anchors the ritual to a specific moment -- this trial was completed at this time.

visual_spec.layout: Card, max-width 440px. Header: serif title. Below: 3-slot photo grid with labeled placeholders. Below grid: completion indicator and timestamp.
visual_spec.background: var(--bg-white, #ffffff) before upload; var(--bg-off-white, rgb(252, 250, 255)) after all photos submitted

interaction_spec.load_behavior: Card renders with placeholder slots visible. No loading state.
interaction_spec.upload: Tap a placeholder to open camera or photo picker. Thumbnail appears immediately (optimistic). Background upload within 5 seconds.
interaction_spec.completion: When all 3 photos are uploaded, background transitions from white to off-white (300ms ease). Checkmark and 'Complete' label appear. Timestamp renders.
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: Background transition is instant. No fade effects.

copy_spec.subhead: Share photos of the space after your stay
dont: Never say 'Submit cleaning photos' or 'Upload required photos'
Never frame as surveillance ('Prove you cleaned')
Never use the word 'required' on the card

elements.html_css:
Show Your Space Is Ready

Share photos of the space after your stay

Kitchen
Bedroom
Common area
CompleteFeb 19, 2026 at 11:42 AM
elements.problem_it_solves: Cleaning photo submission currently looks and feels like a generic file upload -- indistinguishable from a tax return upload. This card elevates the act to a ritual: the serif header names the ritual ('Show Your Space Is Ready'), guided placeholders ensure structured evidence ('Kitchen,' 'Bedroom,' 'Common area'), the completion state (warm background, checkmark, timestamp) marks this trial as honorably concluded, and the framing converts compliance into contribution.

elements.name: Guest Initiation Credential (Bodhisattva Profile)
elements.description: A dual-facing profile credential that makes the guest's initiation journey visible both to themselves and to future hosts. Guest-facing: a 'Your Journey' section on the profile showing total stays, leases, nights, average rating, and a composite character description from reviews. Host-facing: a trust credential block embedded in proposal views showing verification status, completed stays, review score, and member tenure. Campbell's Bodhisattva 'permeated the whole texture of existence with the divine grace of his assisting presence' -- the experienced guest's history is this grace, making the marketplace safer for everyone. The credential collapses the distinction between self-knowledge and social proof: the same data powers both views.

visual_spec.layout: Card, max-width 400px. Top: guest avatar (large) + name + member since. Middle: four metric pills in a 2x2 grid. Below: composite character description. Bottom: credential statement.

interaction_spec.load_behavior: Card renders instantly from cached profile data. No loading state -- the credential is always available.
interaction_spec.hover: Metric pills show tooltip on hover with detailed breakdowns (e.g., hovering 'Stays' shows lease-by-lease breakdown).
interaction_spec.context: Guest-facing: appears on the guest's own profile dashboard. Host-facing: appears as the first block in a proposal view when the guest applies to a new listing.
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: No animations on this card. Static, dignified presentation.

copy_spec.character_desc: Hosts describe Alex as reliable, respectful, and easy to communicate with.
copy_spec.credential_text: Verified guest with 24 completed stays across 2 leases on Split Lease.
dont: Never use gamification language ('Level 3 Guest', 'Gold Member')
Never show comparative metrics ('Top 10% of guests')
Never surface negative history prominently
Never frame the credential as the platform's achievement

elements.html_css:

elements.problem_it_solves: The guest's transformation through shared living is invisible -- reviews live on individual listings, stay counts are stored in databases, trust scores are calculated behind the scenes. This credential card makes the initiation visible: to the guest themselves (a mirror of growth) and to future hosts (a trust signal that reduces anxiety). The guest who sees '24 completed stays across 2 leases' knows they are not a stranger -- they are an experienced participant in the shared-living marketplace. Campbell's Bodhisattva carries enlightenment forward; the experienced guest carries their credential forward.

elements.name: Solitude-Companionship Week Strip
elements.description: A 7-day horizontal rhythm visualization that shows the host at a glance when their space is shared and when it is theirs. Each day cell displays one of three states: guest-present (filled purple), guest-absent (open, warm white), or transition (gradient with directional arrow). Today is highlighted with a bottom border. Pending date changes pulse subtly on affected days. The strip sits at the top of the Stays Manager as the host's primary emotional anchor -- answering 'What does my week look like?' in under 3 seconds. Csikszentmihalyi's Dorothy structures her time with strict routines to prevent entropy; this strip structures the host's week with visual pattern recognition. The user stories demand urgency-first dashboards; the strip complements urgency by providing the temporal context beneath it.

visual_spec.layout: Full-width horizontal strip, 7 equal-width day cells in a row. Card container with 16px internal padding. Sits below the urgency action band, above the main content area.
visual_spec.background: var(--bg-white, #ffffff) for the card; var(--bg-off-white, rgb(252,250,255)) for guest-absent cells; rgba(49,19,93,0.08) for guest-present cells
visual_spec.border: 1px solid var(--border-color, #e5e7eb) for the card; 3px solid var(--primary-purple, #31135D) left border for guest-present cells; 1px dashed var(--border-gray-lighter, #ddd) left border for guest-absent cells
visual_spec.border_radius: var(--rounded-xl, 12px) for the card; var(--rounded-md, 6px) for individual day cells

interaction_spec.load_behavior: Strip loads with a left-to-right staggered fade-in, 30ms per cell, 150ms per cell duration. Today's cell appears last with a slightly longer 200ms fade and bottom-border draw-in animation.
interaction_spec.hover: Hovering a day cell reveals contextual detail in a tooltip below: 'Guest arrives 3pm' or 'Space is yours all day'. Tooltip fades in at 150ms ease-out.
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: All stagger and fade animations resolve instantly. Today's cell gains a 2px solid border instead of animated draw-in. Date change pulse becomes a static dashed outline.

copy_spec.heading: Your week
copy_spec.date_change_tooltip: Date change requested -- tap to review
dont: Use 'Occupied' or 'Vacancy'
Show countdown timers
Label absent days as 'empty' or 'unbooked'
Use clinical scheduling language

elements.html_css:
Your week

elements.problem_it_solves: The host experiences temporal uncertainty about when their space is shared versus private, producing the psychic entropy Csikszentmihalyi identifies as the default state of unstructured social expectation. The rhythm strip converts abstract schedule data into a felt pattern, providing the external structure that keeps the host's attention directed and their week predictable.

elements.name: Cohabitation Flow Dashboard
elements.description: A mid-lease dashboard section that maintains the three conditions for relational flow: common goals, reciprocal feedback, and escalating challenges. It shows a stay-cycle progress bar (13 segments filling with purple as stays complete), a recent feedback summary (the guest's last 2-3 micro-review ratings and notes), and a shared-goal reminder that connects the host's expectations to the guest's upcoming visit. Csikszentmihalyi warns that 'entropy is the basic condition of group life' -- this dashboard is the entropy prevention mechanism. The user stories' cross-activation principle applies: every review is both current-relationship feedback and future-marketplace trust.

visual_spec.layout: Vertical stack within the Stays Manager main content area. Three sections: progress bar at top, feedback summary in middle, shared goal at bottom. Full width within the Stays Manager card.
visual_spec.background: var(--bg-white, #ffffff) for the container; var(--bg-off-white, rgb(252,250,255)) for the feedback summary inset
visual_spec.border: 1px solid var(--border-color, #e5e7eb); left accent border 3px solid var(--secondary-purple) on the feedback section
visual_spec.border_radius: var(--rounded-xl, 12px) for the outer card; var(--rounded-lg, 8px) for inner sections

interaction_spec.load_behavior: Progress bar fills to the current stay count with a 400ms ease-out animation on page load. Feedback items fade in with a 200ms stagger. Shared goal appears last with a 200ms fade.
interaction_spec.hover: Tapping a completed progress segment reveals that stay cycle's review summary in a compact popover. The current segment pulses gently to indicate 'in progress'.
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: All animations resolve instantly. Progress bar shows filled state without animation. Current segment uses a static dashed outline instead of pulse.

copy_spec.progress_mid: More than halfway -- your hosting rhythm is solid
copy_spec.feedback_empty: Your guest has not reviewed this stay yet
copy_spec.goal_text: A clean, respectful stay that works for both of you
dont: Show payments as the primary content
Use countdown language
Frame reviews as obligations
Display the lease as a contract countdown

elements.html_css:
Stay progress

Stay 8 of 13 -- more than halfway. Your rhythm with Jessica is solid.

Recent feedback from Jessica

Everything was spotless. Loved the herb garden!

A clean, respectful stay that works for both of you. Jessica follows your quiet hours and kitchen schedule.
elements.problem_it_solves: Csikszentmihalyi warns that 'entropy is the basic condition of group life' and that without ongoing investment in the relationship, conflicts are inevitable. This dashboard maintains the three flow conditions (common goals, reciprocal feedback, escalating challenge) that prevent the cohabitation relationship from degrading into passive tolerance or active conflict.

elements.name: Listing Creation Self-Portrait Card
elements.description: A wizard step card that transforms listing creation from data entry into guided self-expression. Rather than 'Select house rules from the list,' it asks 'What does a good morning look like in your home?' The card shows a conversational prompt at the top, a response area styled as a personal note rather than a form field, and a differentiation calibration signal below ('Hosts who describe their mornings receive 15% more proposals'). A thin completion bar runs across the top. Csikszentmihalyi describes Dorothy personalizing her surroundings 'to an uncommon degree' -- this card helps the host express their own civilization. The user stories confirm that 'Completion percentage is a good host nudge' -- this card provides both completion feedback (bar) and quality feedback (calibration signal).

visual_spec.layout: Vertical card, full width within the wizard container. Conversational prompt at top, response area in center, calibration signal at bottom. Completion bar fixed at card top edge.
visual_spec.background: var(--bg-white, #ffffff) for the card; var(--bg-off-white, rgb(252,250,255)) for the calibration signal area

interaction_spec.load_behavior: Card slides in from the right as the previous step slides out to the left, 300ms ease-out. Completion bar fills smoothly to the current step percentage, 400ms ease-out.
interaction_spec.hover: Calibration signal has a 'Learn more' affordance that expands the full data point on tap. Dismiss X collapses the signal permanently for this step.
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: Card appears without slide animation. Completion bar shows filled state without animation.

copy_spec.prompt_example: What does a good morning look like in your home?
copy_spec.sub_prompt: Tell your guest what they will love about waking up here. This is what makes your space yours.
copy_spec.placeholder: A sunny kitchen, the smell of coffee, quiet until 9am...
copy_spec.calibration_text: Hosts who describe their mornings receive 15% more proposals
copy_spec.photo_prompt: Show the view your guest wakes up to -- that is what they will remember
dont: Use 'Configure your listing settings'
Say 'Select from standard rules'
Label photos as 'Bedroom 1 (required)'
Use 'property' instead of 'home' or 'space'

elements.html_css:
Step 5 of 6

What does a good morning look like in your home?

Tell your guest what they will love about waking up here. This is what makes your space yours.

Hosts who describe their mornings receive 15% more proposals in your area.
elements.problem_it_solves: Listing creation treats the host's intimate knowledge of their space as data-entry work. The host fills forms about bedrooms and parking but never expresses what makes their home alive. This card transforms the wizard from bureaucratic to creative, scaffolding the differentiation that Csikszentmihalyi identifies as the foundation for meaningful integration during active lease.

elements.name: Guest Compatibility Preview
elements.description: A dual-column proposal card that helps the host evaluate whether this specific guest will create flow or entropy in their household. The left column shows the guest's proposed terms (dates, duration, price). The right column shows who is proposing: photo, name, verification badge, previous stay count, and review excerpts from other hosts. A proposal quality indicator at the top provides instant triage ('Well-structured proposal' vs. 'Incomplete -- missing personal message'). The three action buttons (Welcome [Name], Suggest adjustments, Not this time) use hospitality language, not transactional language. Csikszentmihalyi warns that 'the same person can make the morning wonderful and the evening miserable' -- this card gives the host the social information to assess which outcome is more likely.

visual_spec.layout: Dual-column layout within a card. Quality indicator spans full width at top. Left column (55%) for terms, right column (45%) for social profile, separated by a 1px vertical border. Action buttons span full width at bottom.
visual_spec.background: var(--bg-white, #ffffff); var(--bg-off-white, rgb(252,250,255)) for personal message inset
visual_spec.border: 1px solid var(--border-color, #e5e7eb); 1px solid var(--border-color) for column separator

interaction_spec.load_behavior: Card opens with guest photo fading in first (200ms), then columns filling with a 100ms stagger. Action buttons appear last (300ms after photo).
interaction_spec.hover: Accept button darkens to var(--primary-purple-hover). Suggest button background intensifies. Decline text darkens slightly. Review excerpts can be tapped to expand full review text.
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: All elements appear simultaneously without stagger or fade.

copy_spec.header: Jessica would like to stay in your home
dont: Use 'Accept / Reject / Counter-offer'
Show 'Proposal #4291'
Display terms before the person
Add countdown pressure

elements.problem_it_solves: The host evaluating a proposal is making the highest-stakes social decision in their journey: inviting a stranger into their home. The current transactional proposal view shows terms but hides the person. This card surfaces both simultaneously, giving the host the social assessment information Csikszentmihalyi says is essential for determining whether a relationship will produce flow or entropy.

elements.name: Stay Cycle Arrival/Departure Ritual Card
elements.description: A compact ritual card that structures the two highest-anxiety micro-moments in the host's week: guest arrival and guest departure. When the guest sends an arrival notification, the host sees a warm card with the guest's message, arrival time, and a one-tap 'Got it -- welcome' acknowledgment. When the guest sends cleaning photos at departure, the host sees a gallery of thumbnail images and a 'Looks good' acknowledgment. Each tap transitions the corresponding day on the rhythm strip from transition to present (arrival) or present to absent (departure). Csikszentmihalyi describes Susan Butcher's routines demanding 'that her consciousness be focused on manageable tasks all of the time' -- these rituals are the host's manageable tasks that focus consciousness during the most entropy-prone transitions.

visual_spec.layout: Compact horizontal card that appears in the Stays Manager action band. Guest message/photos on the left, acknowledgment button on the right.
visual_spec.background: var(--bg-off-white, rgb(252,250,255)) with a 3px left border in var(--secondary-purple)

interaction_spec.load_behavior: Card fades in from opacity 0 to 1 over 200ms ease-out when the guest's notification arrives. Appears at the top of the action band.
interaction_spec.hover: Acknowledgment button darkens on hover. Photos expand to a larger preview on tap. After acknowledgment, the card content crossfades (200ms) to a confirmation message and collapses after 5 seconds (300ms height transition).
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: Card appears without fade. Confirmation replaces content without crossfade. Card hides without collapse animation.

dont: Use 'Acknowledge arrival'
Use 'Confirm departure'
Add mandatory steps
Show cleaning checklists

elements.html_css:
Jessica is arriving

Today at 3:00 PM

"On my way! Should be there by 3. Thanks for having me."

Guest arrived -- enjoy your week

Jessica has departed

Saturday at 11:00 AM

Space returned -- your week ahead
elements.problem_it_solves: Guest arrival and departure are the highest-anxiety recurring moments in the host's week. Without structured rituals, the host speculates ('Is the guest coming? Did they clean?'), generating the psychic entropy Csikszentmihalyi identifies as the cost of unstructured social transitions. These ritual cards convert each transition into a manageable, one-tap action that restores order.

elements.name: Autotelic Host Milestone Card
elements.description: A milestone card that surfaces the host's intrinsic growth at key moments during and after the lease. Rather than financial notifications ('You earned $850 this week'), it shows non-financial hosting achievements: 'Your 7th successful stay -- your hosting rhythm is solid,' 'Jessica rated this week 5 stars: Great host, everything was peaceful.' The card appears in the Stays Manager during Phase 2 (weeks 4-9) and Phase 3 (weeks 10-13) of the complexity ratchet. At lease end, milestone cards aggregate into the growth narrative. Csikszentmihalyi identifies the autotelic personality as someone who finds intrinsic reward in activity itself -- this card makes the host's developing autotelic capacity visible.

visual_spec.layout: Compact horizontal card in the Stays Manager main content area. Icon on the left, milestone text in the center, optional guest quote below.
visual_spec.background: var(--bg-white, #ffffff) with subtle left border gradient (purple to transparent)

interaction_spec.load_behavior: Card fades in with a 200ms ease-out when the Stays Manager loads on a milestone-eligible visit. No intrusive notification -- it appears naturally in the content flow.
interaction_spec.hover: Card has no explicit hover state. Guest quotes can be tapped to expand the full review.
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: Card appears without fade animation.

copy_spec.first_stay: Your first stay is complete -- you are a host
copy_spec.mid_lease: Stay [X] of [total] -- your hosting rhythm with [Guest Name] is solid
copy_spec.fast_response: Your response time averaged under [X] hours this week
copy_spec.date_change: You navigated a date change smoothly -- that is a real hosting skill
copy_spec.lease_end: 13 weeks with [Guest Name]. [Rating] average. [X] stays, [X] issues. You built something good.
dont: Use 'Achievement unlocked!'
Show leaderboards
Frame as gamification badges
Display income amounts as milestones

elements.html_css:
Your 7th successful stay -- your hosting rhythm is solid

4.8 average rating across 7 stays. No issues reported.

"Great host, everything was clean and peaceful. The herb garden is a lovely touch."

-- Jessica M., Stay 7
elements.problem_it_solves: Hosts receive financial notifications (payment received) but never see evidence of their growing hosting competence. The platform treats hosting as a transaction, reinforcing extrinsic motivation that Csikszentmihalyi warns cannot sustain long-term engagement. This card makes intrinsic growth visible -- the host sees skills developing, not just income accumulating.

elements.name: Lease-End Harvest Summary
elements.description: A full-page lease-end summary that reframes the hosting experience as a harvest of growth rather than an expiration of income. It opens with a stay-cycle timeline (13 segments filled in purple), followed by milestone achievements, guest feedback quotes in serif italic, a compact financial summary, and forward-looking challenge cards. The summary deliberately places the growth narrative before the financial data, inverting the typical platform pattern. Csikszentmihalyi says 'the ultimate test for the ability to control the quality of experience is what a person does in solitude' -- the host is returning to solitude, and this summary prepares them to carry internal structure from the experience. The Pause and Re-list buttons appear side by side, equally weighted, honoring both choices.

visual_spec.layout: Single-column page with four vertically stacked sections: timeline + milestones (primary), guest feedback (secondary), financial summary (tertiary, compact), forward-looking challenges (action). Full width within the Stays Manager container.
visual_spec.background: var(--bg-white, #ffffff) for the primary section; var(--bg-off-white, rgb(252,250,255)) for the financial section; rgba(109,49,194,0.06) for challenge cards
visual_spec.border_radius: var(--rounded-xl, 12px) for section cards; var(--rounded-lg, 8px) for challenge cards

interaction_spec.load_behavior: The Stays Manager crossfades from active-lease view to lease-end summary over 600ms. Timeline fills its final segment with a 500ms accent animation. Guest quotes fade in with a 300ms ease-out. Challenge cards slide up from below (400ms ease-out).
interaction_spec.hover: Challenge cards lift slightly on hover (translateY -2px) with shadow deepening. Pause and Re-list buttons have standard hover states. Financial summary has a 'See breakdown' link that expands detail.
interaction_spec.reduced_motion: All animations resolve instantly. Page appears in final state without transitions.

copy_spec.summary_line: 4.8 average rating. 13 stays, 0 issues. You built something good.
copy_spec.milestone_4: Response time in top 25% of hosts
copy_spec.challenge_1_desc: Update photos and descriptions based on what Jessica appreciated most
copy_spec.challenge_2_desc: Share your experience with a first-time host in your area
copy_spec.solitude_message: Your space is yours again. When you are ready, your listing is here.
dont: Say 'Your lease has expired'
Pressure re-listing with urgency
Show 'Delete listing' prominently
Frame financial data as the primary content

elements.problem_it_solves: When a lease ends, the platform shows a financial summary and an inactive listing -- framing the entire hosting experience as a completed transaction. The host's retrospective assessment defaults to 'Was the money worth the hassle?' This summary reframes lease end as a harvest: here is what you grew, here is what your guest said, here is what you could do next. It shifts the retention calculation from financial dependency to intrinsic meaning, which Csikszentmihalyi identifies as the only durable motivation for sustained engagement.
